column2: The Lodge-Gossett amendment to the Constitution, under which the electoral vote in Presidential elections would proportionately reflect the popular vote by states, has passed the Senate and is now awaiting action by the House.

Introduced in the showing of custom millinery yesterday at Milgrim's were such themes as tricolor combinaton of red, white and navy, the importance of red for spring, the popularity of flower hats and trims plus the appeal of sheer blacks for evening.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- American maritime labor unions strongly protested to a Senate Commerce subcommittee today the policy of letting American-owned vessels sail under foreign registry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- Strong signs were developing today that President Truman soon may ask Congress to abolish the present Maritime Commission and transfer its duties to the Department of Commerce.

LONDON, Feb. 27--One of the most troublesome domestic problems facing the re-elected Labor Government is the demand by about 4,000,000 workers for wage increases to compensate for the rise in the cost of living.

The National Orchestral Association presented an operatic program last night in the third concert of its Monday night subscription series at Carnegie Hall. It consisted of three overtures, an intermezzo, eight arias and a quartet.
Americans tend to over-value youth, to under-value the middle years and merely to tolerate old age, Dr. Margaret Mead, associate curator of the American Museum of Natural History, said yesterday.

If city hospitals are to be operated efficiently, more money must be allotted to pay doctors, nurses and other professional personnel, Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, Commissioner of Hospitals, asserted yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon of the Women,'s City Club in the New Weston Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The United States and Canada today signed a treaty providing for a vast increase in the power output of the Niagara River, but with safeguards to preserve the scenic beauty of the famous Falls.

BANFF, Alberta, Feb. 27--This Canadian Rocky Mountain community today gave a rousing sendoff to most of the brilliant collection of skiers from eleven countries who provided the greatest exhibition of skill in the Dominion's ski history during the North American Alpine events the past week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)--A representative of the motion-picture industry said Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder showed a "sympathetic view" today toward the industry's call for "relief" from the 20 per cent Federal tax on admission tickets.

Warmer weather was promised today for New Yorkers, who suffered yesterday through one of the severest days of the winter. Pedestrians were buffeted by biting 40mile-an-hour north winds, and Monday's wash sprouted icicles on backyard clotheslines.
MADRID, Feb. 27--The Basques of northern Spain are indignant over orders from Spanish authorities to remove inscriptions in the Basque language from tombstones and replace them with Castilian.

An easier trend in coffee futures prices marked trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Prices for the contract closed 17 to 36 points below Friday's levels, while the D contract dropped 20 to 35 points.

THE Yankees departed for their spring training base in Florida yesterday and their rookie crop holds not even a fraction of the rich promise it held just thirty years ago this month when a similar expedition reached Jacksonville.
The seventy-first international six-day bicycle race lost another star rider yesterday with the grind in its second day at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory, 168th Street and Broadway.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Feb. 27 (Reuters)--King George VI today sent a telegram of sympathy to Greta Lauder, niece of the Scottish comedian, Sir Harry Lauder, who died at his Lanarkshire home yesterday at the age of 79.

St. John's University of Brooklyn, Bradley University of Peoria, Ill., the nation's No. 1 quintet, and Duquesne of Pittsburgh yesterday became the first three schools to accept bids for the National invitation basketball tournament.

Three months have passed since the Presidential elections in Colombia were won by the Conservative Laureano Gomez. Whatever hopes were entertained at the time that the trend toward dictatorship would be reversed have been fading.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--A twoyear suspension of Otis Co., Cleveland investment banking firm, from the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., was announced today by its board of goveernors.

President Truman, Gen. George C. Marshall and Henry Fonda will participate in a nation-wide radio broadcast tonight at 10:30 o'clock which will mark the opening of the 1950 American Red Cross fund drive.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 27-- Prime Minister Liaqat Ali Khan said today that Pakistan had "no aggressive intentions toward India," but that "if India wants war she will find us fully prepared."

In spite of renewed appeals by city officials for water conservation and threats of new mandatory curtailments on water use, New Yorkers increased their average daily water consumption last week to 889,000,000 gallons, it was announced yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27 --The A.C. Gilbert Company, a toy concern, announced today development of a kit that will allow children to play with atomic energy at home.

Cornelius G. Kolff, retired president and founder of the Kolff Kaufmann, Inc., a real estate firm at 26 Bay Street, St. George, S.I., dean of realty brokers on Staten Island and a civic worker for more than forty years, died yesterday of...

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation increased its ingot productive capacity by 800,000 net tons last year and intends to "keep on growing," E.G. Grace, chairman, declared in annual reports issued yesterday to stockholders and employes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27-- In response to instructions from New York that economies must be instituted at the studio, Paramount laid off fourteen minor production executives and workers over the week-end, it was learned today.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman granted permission yesterday to the trustees of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation to apply to the Public Service Commission for a ten-cent fare on all its lines.

High Commissioner John J. McCloy made the headlines in the West German press yesterday by declaring that the unification of Germany is a major objective of United States policy and proposing free elections for the entire country, including the Eastern zone, which should be open to all parties and to full coverage of the press.

Completing the liquidation of its holdings in Brooklyn, the William M. Calder Company, builder, has sold twenty-one dwellings in the Sheepshead Bay section to Albert Levy of Levy Baird, real estate investors. The new owner plans to offer the houses for individual resale. Ernest M. Hollister and Samuel Kutay were the brokers.

Leading research institutions in the city, headed by the New York Academy of Medicine, are prepared to make a strong fight for a bill that would enable research groups to obtain animals for experimentation from the dog pound.
Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he had ordered an investigation of a report that an expense item of "upward of $20,000" carried on the books of a taxicab company was "for the cops."
Union College paid high tribute last night to its venerable treasurer and chief benefactor, 85-year-old Frank Bailey, at a ceremonial dinner to which Mr. Bailey had been lured by a ruse.

The data slips found in Judith Coplon's handbag and put in evidence yesterday at the spy trial in Federal Court contain excerpts from investigative reports of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that cover a wide variety of subjects.

The aftermath of the stranding of the U.S.S. Missouri on Thimble Shoal in Chesapeake Bay has now run its course. And the personal tragedy of Capt. William Drane Brown, the skipper of the battleship when she went aground, is nearing its fulfillment.
The seventy-first international six-day bicycle race continued on its dizzy way last night at Twentysecond Engineers Armory, with twelve teams. Fourteen duos started last Sunday night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, the Netherlands Foreign Minister who is in Washington as "political conciliator" of the European Marshall Plan Council, conferred with President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson today and said he was "optimistic" on prospects for European economic integration.

New issues of common stock of public utility enterprises serving areas in Kentucky, Texas and Louisiana will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings, which aggregate $9,618,163 in market value, are as follows:

The Government, which plans to rest its case today in the spy trial in Federal Court, placed in evidence yesterday typed and handwritten papers found in Judith Coplon's handbag when she was arrested last March 4 as she walked along Third Avenue with ...

Bold, vivid colors are contrasted with subtle, muted shades in a diversified collection of upholstery and drapery fabrics intorduced yesterday by Seymour Fabrics in its new decorator's showroom, 450 Fourth Avenue.
In his first step to combat juvenile gang war in the Bronx County Judge Samuel Joseph imposed the maximum sentence yesterday on a 17-year-old youth who pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter ...

Homemakers who have complained that there's not enough dining space in modern houses will find an improved situation in the Mid-Century House built by Walter G. Stackler and Leonard L. Frank at Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

Commissioner Bernard J. Gillroy of the Department of Housing and Buildings branded yesterday as "a vicious, unfair slur" the criticism of one of his deputies contained in a report by the Citizens Planning and Housing Council.

The question facing the United States as a result of the progress of the Marshall Plan up to now is whether we are to revise tariffs downward so the world can earn its own recovery, James Reston, diplomatic correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.
Elias Savada of 115 Central Park West, president of Savada Brothers, Inc., boys' wear manufacturers, 1115 Broadway, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after an illness of three months.

Strengthened by the return of two injured players, the New York Rangers tonight face the opportunity of gaining sole possession of third place in the National Hockey League race and matching a Blue Shirt team record for most ...

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 28--The acute shortage of elementary teachers is the "No. 1" educational problem facing the nation's schools today, Dr. Earl J. McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education, declared here today.

The American Tobacco Company last year increased its earnings to a new high record of $45,675,154 despite a somewhat lower volume of sales from 1948, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders today.
Aid to higher education for Negroes was recommended yesterday by John D. Rockefeller Jr. as "the sanest approach to problems which concern the Negro people."

ALBANY, Feb. 28--The executive budget making appropriations totaling $862,775,677 was approved today by the Republican-controlled Assembly. The Senate, also under Republican control, is scheduled add its approval tomorrow.

The ten-story store and office building at 10 East Forty-ninth Street has been purchased by an investor from the General American Transportation Corporation, builders and operators of specialized railroad freight cars, who leased the six upper floors where ...

Scientific strategy in the battle against cancer is now poised between the pressing demands for improved treatment for cancer patients and the certainty that only through long-range research can the disease be eliminated as a health problem, the American Cancer Society said yesterday.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that it had withdrawn its proposal to purchase the Long Island Lighting Company.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 28-- Hunger brought Oklahoma City's escaped leopard back to captivity today--and captivity brought it death.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 28 --A fourth witness testified at the "mercy killing" trial today that Dr. Hermann N. Sander admitted having killed Mrs. Abbie C. Borroto by giving her air injections.

In a setting of Easter lilies yesterday afternoon in her home at 50 East Seventy-seventh Street, Mrs. Helen Nicholson Macdonald Talley, widow of Truman H. Talley and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. D.W. Ross Macdonald of St. ...
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28-- Dr. John Matthai, India's Finance Minister, presenting his annual budget to Parliament, announced today that half of the nation's new budget would be spent on defense.

DETROIT, Feb. 28--Charles G. Nichols, president and general manager of the G.M. McKelvey Company of Youngstown, Ohio, today told the National Marketing Conference that cooperation between the retail merchant and the consumer will ultimately determine whether this country goes forward or sinks into a depression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--A registration statement covering 1,656,156 shares of $25-par value common stock has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, San Francisco.
Lady Abingdon is expected to arrive on the Queen Mary today from London, and will be at the Sherry-Netherland until she goes to Palm Beach, Fla.
The treaty just signed by the United States and Canada on the division of Niagara River waters lays a permanent groundwork for vast expansion of power facilities based on this great natural resource.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28--The Soviet Union increased the official value of the ruble tonight in terms of the dollar, and switched from the dollar to gold as its monetary yardstick.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28--All at Once, a 3-year-old that cost $2,700 as a yearling, added $2,600 to his earnings at Hialeah today when he beat four stakes-winners and one other colt in a six-furlong sprint. Four nominees for Friday's $50,000 Flamingo Stakes were in the line-up; they made a two, three, four, six finish.

Three educational motion pictures, produced at a cost of $90,000 by the Protestant Film Commission for use among forty denominations throughout the world, were exhibited for the first time yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Federal Judge Richmond B. Keech ruled today that the sole question before him in the Government's contempt-of-court case against the United Mine Workers of America was whether his two restraining orders had been obeyed.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 28--Despite an announcement by German authorities in Berlin last week, the West German steel embargo on deliveries to the Soviet zone has not been lifted nor does it appear that it will be lifted in the near future.
A strike of 4,600 maintenance and supply employes of American Airlines in thirty-four cities was expected early today to begin at 7:30 A.M. This was announced by a spokesman for the Transport ...

The rate of industrial buying of perishable tools and factory supplies moved up sharply yesterday throughout all industries in this district, industrial distributors revealed during a canvass of pur-- chasing trends. This movement followed a pattern of ordering for larger inventory requirements.

Parents cannot always do better just because they know better, a group of child experts agreed yesterday. Therefore, parent education courses--besides teaching the facts of child development and behavior--should help mothers and ...
The city's annual Red Cross appeal will start officially this morning with more than $1,000,000 in contributions already on the books.

A second degree murder indictment was dismissed yesterday against a 30-year-old mother on the ground that she had been insane on May 7, 1948, when she smothered her two infant daughters and then attempted suicide by slashing her throat and left wrist.

The 23,626-gross-ton liner Washington was back at her North River berth yesterday morning, having undergone an annual overhaul and the repair of some bow damage at the Brooklyn yard of the Todd Shipyards Corporation in the record time of 137 hours.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Feb. 28--The first 300,000,000 electron volt betatron, capable of producing X-rays and electron beams at high enough energy levels to open new domains in the study of the atom's nucleus, was publicly demonstrated at the University of Illinois today.

WHEN I got back to the White House I found that great progress had been made by the Combined Chiefs of Staff, and that it was mostly in harmony with my views. The President convened a meeting on January 12, when there was complete agreement upon the broad principles and targets of the war. The differences were confined to priorities and emphasis, and all was ruled by that ...

Nine and a half games ahead of the third-place Washington Capitols with only eleven left to play, the New York Knickerbockers engage the Baltimore Bullets in a National Basketball Association encounter at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Wednesday, March 1 (UP)--Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek resumed the Presidency of the hard-pressed Chinese Nationalist Government today, declaring that "at this critical moment I cannot shirk my responsibilities."

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28-- National League pennant production operations will begin in this elaborate baseball plant tomorrow morning under the camp direction of Fresco Lafayette Thompson, who has replaced Wid Matthews as the perambulating bookkeeper.
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 28--A proposal to investigate alleged slave labor practices in the Soviet Union was reluctantly shelved for another year today by the Economic and Social Council in the ...

News from Spain that the Franco Government is continuing to attack Basque nationalism would indicate that its efforts to date have not proved successful. It is hard for those who know the Basques to figure out how repression could succeed, except superficially.

Faced with a new reservoir storage loss of 60,000,000 gallons of water--marking the third day that the level of the Catskill and Croton reservoirs has dropped-- city water officials sought yesterday to speed up preliminary plans for possible rain making.

An order temporarily restraining Paul Robeson, the Civil Rights Congress and others from proceeding in their $2,000,000 damage suit against Westchester County officials was signed yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger.

ROME, Feb. 28--The Roman Catholic Church agreed in principle today to permit the Catholic clergy to discuss with representatives of non-Catholic Christian bodies means of pooling material resources and spiritual strength in what is hoped eventually will become a world-wide Christian antiCommunist front.

State coal conservation authorities fixed temperature limits last night for all state and municipal buildings. They called on owners of coal-heated office buildings, stores, theatres and other private buildings to adopt similar controls on a voluntary basis as a means of staving off heatless days and other "drastic" restrictions on fuel use.

ALBANY, Feb. 28--Exclusion of $500,000,000 for construction of the Second Avenue subway from New York City's debt limit was recommended today as part of a program for enabling cities and other local governments to finance urgently needed school construction and rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, in his annual report today recommended extension of old age and survivors insurance to many of the millions of persons not now covered.

Nearly a year ago the United Nations Economic and Social Council agreed to recommend a special investigation of one of the darkest blots on contemporary civilization--the spreading slave labor system in Soviet Russia and its satellites.

Consolidated net income of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation last year rose to a new high of $26,232,673 from the $17,071,475 earned in 1948, the annual report of Arthur O. Dietz, president, disclosed yesterday. The net for 1949 equaled $6.81 a common share, against $4.57 a share the year before.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The Cleveland investment firm of Otis Co. prepared today for a court fight against a two-year suspension order by the National Association of Security Dealers, Inc. (NASD).

Business which has placed itself on record against the welfare state has been "outsold" by the Government and unions, according to Herman W. Steinkraus, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The House Armed Services Committee voted twenty-three to eight today to approve a report charging that Admiral Louis E. Denfeld had been removed as Chief of Naval Operations by the Department of Defense in "reprisal" for his testimony before the committee. The report will be issued tomorrow.

Three Hooper radio and television rating services were sold yesterday for a reported $600,000 by C.E. Hooper, Inc., to its competitor, the A.C. Nielsen Company, according to a joint announcement. Thus Mr. Hooper relinquishes his national network radio, Pacific network radio and network television reporting services.

For three quarters of an hour yesterday legal activity was delayed in Children's Court while a delicate little woman described as "the nearest living thing to a saint and goodness to the core" was honored by fifty of her colleagues.

The $18,000,000,000 utility industry prepared yesterday to line up its defenses in anticipation of a swift move by public power proponents to capture the abundant electric power output from the waters of the Niagara River.
The Third Avenue Transit Corporation announced yesterday that it would go before the Public Service Commission "before the end of the week" to apply for a ten-cent fare on all its lines.

"The Heart of the Matter" has been deferred to next season, it was reported in Boston last night by Richard Rodgers, co-producer with Oscar Hammerstein 2d. The Graham Greene-Basil Dean dramatization of Mr. Greene's novel of the same name had been scheduled to open March 16 at the Imperial.
The board of governors of the Commodity Exchange took steps yesterday to prevent a threatened "squeeze" in March contracts in the hide futures market. At a special meeting at the close of the ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--State Department officials interpreted the increase in the price of the ruble today as a propaganda effort designed to impress the world with the soundness of the Soviet economy.

Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the twenty-two sessions of February was the smallest for any month since November, the volume of business was the largest for a corresponding month since 1946. Sales crossed the million-share mark in ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The House voted tentatively today to throw the strictest of security safeguards around the proposed National Science Foundation, an Administration-sponsored organization designed to spur advancement in American techniques for meeting scientific problems of peace or war and the training of promising scholars for the researches required.

George R. Marek, music editor of Good Housekeeping magazine, has been appointed assistant to the general manager of the RCA Victor record department. He will be responsible for coordination of Red Seal artist and repertoire activities with advertising, sales, merchandising and promotion functions.

Robert Casadesus gave his only Carnegie Hall recital of the season last night and 2,700 persons turned out to hear it. Being a master of the keyboard, he provided them with a program of brilliant and interesting piano playing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The Navy Department announced today it saw no threat to national defense if old-type American vessels were transferred to foreign registry. But Rear Admiral W.M. ...
WARSAW, Feb. 28--Archbishop Stefan Wyszinski, Poland's Roman Catholic primate, has protested to President Boleslaw Bierut that a "battle against the church" is fully under way in this country.

The $100,000 libel suit of William W. Remington, Department of Commerce official who was cleared of disloyalty charges, against Elizabeth T. Bentley, confessed Communist courier; the National Broadcasting Company and the General Foods Corporation ...

CHICAGO, Feb. 28--Tenders today of 142,000 bushels of cash wheat, 521,000 bushels of soybeans and 3,440,000 pounds of lard on March contracts resulted in scattered liquidation in futures on the Chicago Board of Trade today, ...

JERUSALEM, Feb. 28--The draft of a five-year nonaggression pact between Israel and Jordan was brought to the Cabinet here today by Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett. The treaty proposals are being studied at the same time by the Jordanian Government.
With a moderate business on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, closing prices for futures were irregular, 5 points lower to 11 points higher than on Monday.

February was the first month since last May that brought more than normal precipitation, the Weather Bureau announced yesterday. Despite the low temperatures of the last eight days, the month also was warmer than usual.

The Public Service Commission ordered yesterday a sweeping investigation of all track, signal and other operations on branch lines of the Long Island Rail Road to determine all measures necessary to assure the safety of the riding public.

In dividend actions taken yesterday, aside from regular declarations, favorable developments far outweighed the unfavorable moves. Of twenty-two reports of such activity, only three companies announced reduced payments to shareholders, extras were declared ...

Curtis E. Calder, chairman of the Electric Bond and Share Company, yesterday was elected a director of the United States Guarantee Company. He is also a director of the American Bank Note Company, Cathay Insurance Company, the Lehman Corporation, National City Bank, National Power and Light Company and other companies.

Reflecting the 7.6 per cent drop in sales last year of the B.F. Goodrich Company, its 1949 net income declined to $20,935,738 from the $23,740,705 shown the year before, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 28--Capt. W.D. Brown of the battleship Missouri today assumed full blame for the vessel's grounding last month in Chesapeake Bay. He reversed the defense case he had presented for almost four weeks before a Naval Court of Inquiry.
At an average of $153.86 each, delegates to 655 conventions spent a total of $150,000,000 in this city last year, the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau reported yesterday.
The $64 dollar question in bond investment circles continues to be: What price level for longer-term United States Government bonds will dry up offerings by the Federal Reserve System?

ALBANY, Feb. 28--The Senate Committee on the Affairs of New York City reported out favorably today a bill that would permit Vincent Impellitteri, president of the City Council of New York, to appoint a deputy to act for him on the Board of Estimate when he was in the city, but unable to attend board meetings.

Detailed plans for the constituting convention of a proposed National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. were outlined yesterday at an all-day meeting of nineteen top-ranking Protestant church leaders in the Gramercy Park Hotel.

Large flotations of state and municipal securities lifted the total of new bonds offered publicly here in February to $555,682,000, representing fifty issues, the largest amount for any February since ...
Joseph L. Ennis Co., Inc., have purchased the five-story 173-family corner apartment property at 1038-52 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx, from Louis I. Bregman, the builder.
The Society for Forgotten Music offered one of their most interesting programs of the season at Carl Fisher Hall last night. The soprano, Tatiana Pobers, was heard in a ...

Final oral arguments in the proposed Pan American World Airways-American Overseas Airlines merger will be heard today by the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington. The presentations made by representatives of all interested parties are expected to take three or four days and the participants hope for a decision before May 1.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28-- Paramount has acquired an option on "This Is Dynamite," a novel which Horace McCoy is writing, and the property has been earmarked for production by Robert ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Farm product prices increased nearly 1 per cent this month, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Saks Fifth Avenue showed an extensive array of bridal gowns yesterday. They were of varying degrees of formality. Gleaming heavy satin, frequently overlaid with rose point lace, with flowing train and floor length hem was favored for the cathedral ceremony, while crisp dainty organdies in the shorter length looked enchanting for more informal weddings.
LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP)--Following is the text of the Soviet announcement on revaluation of the ruble as distributed here by Tass, the official Soviet news agency:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Dean Acheson publicly affirmed today that he never had condoned the crime for which Alger Hiss was convicted and that never would he "knowingly tolerate"...

BILL CANE is an ageless and fabulous man who owns more horses than he can remember and has more dollars than he can count. He reminds one of the late Col. Matt Winn, another ageless and fabulous man. But where Colonel Matt had had only one gem in his tiara, the Kentucky Derby, Cane has a firm grip on the entire tiara. In harness racing circles the disarmingly youthful Bill is known as "Mr. Trotting."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28--A rebuttal witness called by the Government to testify against Harry R. Bridges at his perjuryconspiracy trial declared on the stand today that he himself had committed perjury before Congressional and legislative investigating committees.

BELMONT, Mass., Feb. 28--Dr. Percy Rogers Howe, director of the Forsyth Dental Infirmary for Children and a pioneer in research on the effect of diet on teeth, died here today in his home at the age of 85.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28--With the opening of spring training a matter of hours away, Casey Stengel already was confronted with a fresh problem tonight.
BOSTON, Feb. 28--Judge George C. Sweeney of the Federal Court allowed today a petition for reorganization of the Waltham (Mass.) Watch Company.

Thomasville Chair Company, one of the country's largest bedroom and dining room furniture manufacturers, again is accepting dealer orders and has increased prices on several items, Ernest Wall, president, said yesterday.

The stock market coasted to irregularly lower levels yesterday while awaiting developments in the coal Strike negotiations. Pressure was never heavy but support was lacking except in some special situations.
MONTREAL, Feb. 28 (UP)--Ted Lindsay, play-maker for the Detroit Red Wings, stayed on top of the National Hockey League scoring scramble today with 60 points.

PARIS, Feb. 28--A conference of the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France to frame a common policy for the Far East, such as they framed for Germany in Paris last November, is under consideration, it was said authoritatively here tonight.

As preparation of New York City's 1950-51 budget moves now from the stage of wishful thinking into hard reality it becomes appropriate to examine some of the elements in the fiscal problem, which involves as usual the transit fare.

Dramatizing the largest sales campaign ever planned for the plastics field, the Society of the Plastics Industry honored the W.T. Grant Company at a luncheon yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel. Beginning tomorrow and continuing through March 8, the chain ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Defense and Treasury Departments combined today in opposing the creation of an Accountant General to prescribe procedures and methods for all Executive departments.
Three of the first four seeded players in the men's singles in the Eastern indoor tennis championships at the Kingsbridge Armory saw action last night and all three won their matches.

BOSTON, Feb. 28--Princeton became assured of at least a tie for the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League title tonight by defeating Harvard, 65--48, at the Boston Garden before a crowd of less than 1,000.
Frederick Brown yesterday announced his resale for cash of the two-story building at 205 to 209 West Sixty-ninth Street, which is occupied as the Ansonia Station of ...

Despite the unsatisfactory hunting conditions which prevailed during a large part of the season, the result of abnormally mild weather, the Province of New Brunswick reports the largest take of whitetails since 1933.

LONDON, Feb. 28--Although British shipyards launched a bigger tonnage in 1948 than in the previous year, increasing competition cut down Britain's share of the world's launchings from 50.9 per cent to 40.5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The United States Chamber of Commerce accused the Truman Administration today of seeking "unsound, untimely, unnecessary, arbitrary, steam-rollered changes in existing tax laws."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The United States Maritime Commission has sent to President Truman a strong protest designed to head off a possible drastic revision of the agency. This was learned today following reports that the White House was considering plans to curtail the commission's operations, or to abolish it.

New York, at the end of the second year of its accident control program among municipal workers, ranks third among eight large cities with such plans, according to figures released yesterday by Alfred R. Lateiner, accident control consultant for the City College extension division.
Convention, New York State Society, National Society Daughters of the Union, New Yorker Hotel, 10 A.M.

PRAGUE, Czehoslovakia, Feb. 28--Titoists in Czechoslovakia have made attempts to put the nation into the "imperialist camp," President Klement Gottwald said in a speech last Saturday before the Communist party's Central Committee.

The Lehigh Valley and New York, Susquehanna Western Railroads reported yesterday that precautions against possible sabotage attempts had recently been put into effect. The former road said the action followed two serious derailments of freight trains.

HOIHOW, Hainan Island, China, Feb. 28--If China's Communists ever had a chance of seizing this island off the South China coast, it is gone, according to Gen. Hsueh Yueh, who commands for the Nationalists.
Officials of a greeting-card company whose eighteen employes have been conducting a sit-in strike since Friday took steps yesterday to turn the demonstration into a "boot-out" action.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 28 (AP)-- Public Service Coordinated Transport today reported its 1948 revenues at an all-time high, a statement which drew a demand from the Congress of Industrial Organizations for an immediate cut in bus fares.

Burglars, probably teen-agers, forced their way into the Columbia University Bookstore, at Broadway and 116th Street, sometime between 6 P.M. and 11 P.M. Sunday and escaped with goods valued at more than $1,000, it was reported yesterday by Alphonse Falise, security officer at the university.
Gristede Brothers, Inc., food stores, has leased through George D. Moriarty, broker, a store in the building which is being erected by Fitchberg Estates at 252 Third ...

About a month ago two incidents directed public attention to the fantastic size and nature of the problem that has been created under the Government's farm policies. One of these was an appeal by Secretary of Agriculture Brannan to Congress fob directions as to ...

LANGSON, Indo-China, Feb. 26 --The Communist movement of Ho Chi Minh and Mao Tze-tung are in regular contact across the steep, jungle-wrapped mountains and narrow valleys through which runs the border line between Viet Nam and China. Ho's Viet Minh forces are receiving Chinese support but the extent and significance of this aid is not yet clear.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The prospect of bitter and perhaps prolonged wrangling hung over the Senate today as it opened debate on a measure, long locked in the Judiciary Committee, to expand and liberalize the nation's displaced persons program.
PARIS, Feb. 28--The French National Assembly took the unprecedented course today of passing a bill aimed at a United States soft drink.
A young soprano with decided coloratura inclinations made her debut last night in Times Hall. Her name was Barbara Malotte, and she nonchalantly raced through such numbers as Mozart's ...

ON the dry and dusty thornveld of Northern Zululand, at the foot of the Lebombo Moun tains right on the edge of the native reserve, the two families lived. All around them were farms abandoned because their owners could not endure the droughts and the cattle pests and the isolation. But the Elliots stayed because the major was rich and because there was some ...

Henry Rosenfeld, dress manufacturer, has begun the production of women's suits for delivery before Easter, it was learned yesterday. They will be manufactured in out-of-town union coat and suit shops, he said, and the first shipment is scheduled for April 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Export license privileges of two New York concerns were suspended today by the Department of Commerce for violation of export control regulations.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 28--Leo Durocher was counting heads tonight preliminary to launching tomorrow the training grind which he hopes will lift the Giants out of the second division and near the top of the National League.
The State of California announced yesterday that it will put up for sale an issue of $50,000,000 of school bonds on May 3.
In his first address since he took leave of office, David Lilienthal has dealt with what he describes as "three false, mischievous and dangerous myths" about the atomic bomb and atomic energy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP)--Ohio State's Buckeyes, 1950 Big Ten basketball champions, today were selected to represent District 4 in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern play-offs at Madison Square Garden, New York, March 23 and 25.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Democratic leaders disclosed today plans for a gigantic rally, approaching in scope a mid-term national convention, to be held in Chicago on May 13, 14 and 15.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 28--Dr. and Mrs. George Renfrew Brighton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Waldo, to James Edgar Jones, son of Mrs. John Willey Jones of Greeley, Col., and the late Mr. Jones. The wedding will take place in the early summer.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 28--Judge Thomas Henry Morrow of the Common Pleas Court, a veteran of both World Wars and a United States prosecutor of Japanese criminals in Tokyo after the second World War, died here last night at the age of 65.
The men and women of the opera threw a party last night for Edward Johnson that he will remember long after his retirement on June 1.
Tomorrow is the day for couscous at Les Trois Moineaux, a tiny neighborhood bistro that is among the few restaurants in New York, if not the only one, to serve this North African specialty.

The need for greater coordination between public and private child welfare agencies, and for increased research in child development and behavior, were the chief points made yesterday by speakers at the closing session at the two-day Eastern regional conference of the Child Welfare League of America.

VIENNA, Feb. 28--Tomorrow's resumption of the Austrian treaty negotiations in London finds the Russians still not only refusing to negotiate with the Austrian Government regarding the repayment for post liberation food supplies but giving every indication that no treaty may be expected for the next two years, if ever.

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during January totaled 168,921,196 lines, an increase of 3 per cent over the like month of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: Automotive, up 36 per cent; financial, ...
LONDON, Feb. 28--Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee recast his Cabinet tonight to face the new Parliament in which Labor's lead over all other parties has shrunk from more than 140 to seven.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's statement on Alger Hiss:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--President Truman opened the American Red Cross drive for a $67,000,000 fund tonight with a broadcast appeal from the White House for all Americans to support "an agency that has become almost indispensable in our community life today."
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 28--A. Goodwin Cooke, European general counsel of the International Telephone and Telegraph ...

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 28--German unity on a democratic basis was advocated formally today by John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, in the first move of a political offensive aimed at establishing the Western powers and the Bonn Republic as the only genuine sponsors of a free and united nation.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 28-- Lieut. Gen. Ne Win, 40-year-old commander-in-chief of the Burmese armed forces whose troops are driving northward toward the Karen rebel stronghold at Toungoo, told this correspondent yesterday he expected victory over the insurgents to be completed by May.

In the tulip-decked Netherland Club, 10 Rockefeller Plaza, the Dutch custom of the "koffie praatje" was introduced yesterday to 100 unsuspecting New Yorkers. The gathering, it developed upon investigation, was an international hybrid that showed hardy strains of Nieuw--as well as old--Amsterdam.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Paramount, the attraction is "Captain China," a melodrama produced by William H. Pine and William C. Thomas and featuring John Payne, Gail Russell, Jeffrey Lynn and Lon Chaney. Lewis R.

MADRID, Feb. 28--Generalissimo Francisco Franco and his Cabinet attended a memorial service today at the monastery of El Escorial on the ninth anniversary of the death of King Alfonso XIII. The Spanish nobility held their own memorial service in Madrid, with numerous police in evidence outside, but there were no incidents.

Basketball scoring records fell left and right as Sherman White, Long Island University's elongated right forward, paced the Blackbirds to a 119-82 victory over John Marshall at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

Experimental animals receiving excessive doses of cortisone suffer profound changes in bodily chemistry and anatomy, it was reported last night at the first of two clinical research meetings sponsored by the New York Academy of Medicine.

The executive committee of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches voted yesterday to appeal the court decision, handed down ten days ago, barring the proposed merger with the Evangelical and Reformed Church.

Confusion developed last night over the application of staterequested temperature curbs to most of New York City's largest office buildings, department stores, motion picture theatres and railroad terminals.

SEOUL, Korea, March 1--President Syngman Rhee today told the Korean people that despite advice given by "friends from across the seas" not to attack the "foreign puppets." In North Korea, the cries of "our brothers in distress" in the north could not be ignored.

PARIS, March 1--Not content with having induced the National Assembly to deal a blow at CocaCola by devious means, the Communists are pressing a resolution to ask the Government to forbid by name its importation, manufacture and sale in France. This resolution will be discussed in a committee of the Assembly tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 1--Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, declared today the board was "trying to exercise authority it does not possess" when it modified its delegation of authority in two respects last week.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1--Although the Yankees, in marked contrast with their overwhelming crop of miseries last year, seem for the moment to be sound of wind and limb right down to the last man in camp, there still is no telling what that opening day lineup will be come April 18.

Railroad wrecks such as the recent crash on the Long Island Rail Road are virtually impossible on the city's transit system because of the skill required of its signal and towermen, spokesmen for these groups testified yesterday before the Mayor's transit fact-finding board as it resumed its hearings.

In an effort to help stem the rising tide of water consumption in New York, in the face of repeated official appeals for conservation, Water Commissioner Stephen J. Carney yesterday asked for the enactment of $50 fines and metering for water wasters.
PHILADELPHIA, March 1--Six nationally known champions of civil rights were honored tonight by the Philadelphia Fellowship Commission at a testimonial dinner attended by 1,000 persons.
THOMAS WOLFE, that vast Walt Whitman of Confederate prose, has had surprisingly few followers. The young novelists who have come after him usually live by stranger-- or more prosaic--gods.
The story of a sea disaster narrowly averted by smart seamanship was revealed here yesterday with the arrival of the transport George W. Goethals.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 1-- Ship planners of American President Lines are giving "serious consideration" to the possibility of using atomic energy to propel four round the world vessels that it expects to build, according to George Killion, the president. The blueprints for these ships, which would augment the three new "V-2000" type vessels under construction at Camden, N.J., have not been drawn.

The New York Knickerbockers clinched second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association by defeating, for the fifth straight time, the Baltimore Bullets, 82--76, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today held up a proposed further increase in railway express rates on a number of selected commodities, including daily newspapers.

The Beatrice Foods Company will show profits in the fiscal year ended on Feb. 28 as good or better than those of the previous year, C.H. Haskell, president, informed shareholders at the regional meeting held yesterday in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 1--A proposal to lay the foundations of German unity through the establishment of an economic coordination board has met only "stony silence" on the part of official circles in Eastern Germany, according to its author, Dr. Josef Mueller, Minister of Justice in Bavaria.
As the halfway mark of the seventy-first international six-day bicycle race at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory was reached last night, five teams asserted their class.

Strength in the steel section lent a measure of strength to the stock market yesterday. Gains in the heavy industrials did not range beyond major fractions, but financial circles interpreted the advance in the steels as an indication of hope for a decision this week in the coal impasse.

ALBANY, March 1--A bill that would bar convicted felons from running for public office was killed today by the Assembly Judiciary Committee. It had been sponsored by Assemblyman John R. Brook, Republican, of Manhattan.

LONDON, March 1--The Labor party laid its plans, as Parliament met today, for retaining power as long as possible. Both Prime Minister Attlee and Herbert Morrison, his deputy, made it clear at a meeting of their parliamentary supporters that they considered the outcome of the election a mandate for moderation.

A 19-year-old youth from Cambridge, Mass., who became a holdup man here, the police said, to finance an operation for his widowed mother, was arrested yesterday by three detectives on charges of assault, robbery and violating the Sullivan Law.

Charles G. Mortimer, vice president in charge of marketing for General Foods Corporation, will end three years of service as chairman of the Advertising Council on March 9, it was made known yesterday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, chairman of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, called yesterday for support by the American people of the record numbers of immigrants entering Israel as well as help for people throughout the world who are concerned with human rights and freedom.

BANFF, Alberta, March 1-- Another phase of the North American championships, the classic events of jumping, cross-country and combined, to be held in conjunction with the Dominion Alpine downhill, salom and combination, will make this Canadian hamlet the focal point of skiing for the next four days.
John J. Dillon, editor and publisher of the Rural New Yorker, an agricultural semi-monthly, for fifty-eight years, died yesterday of pneumonia in his apartment in the Plaza Hotel. His age was 93.

Women should not compete with men on the same footing in business and industry, Mrs. Anna W. M. Wolf of the family counseling service, Child Study Association of America, who is editor of the children's section of The Woman's Home Companion, declared yesterday.

The United States Lines has protested to French authorities the alleged mistreatment of a crewman on the liner Washington by customs officials while the vessel was laying over at Le Havre on Feb. 10 to embark passengers for New York, it became known yesterday.

Mrs. Cyril J. Redmond and Mrs. John A. FitzRandolph are cochairmen of the committee in charge of the plans of the annual spring fashion show and luncheon to be held under the auspices of the School Settlement Association on March 10 in the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the School Settlement in Brooklyn.
HONG KONG, March 1--Chiang Kai-shek's resumption of Nationalist China's Presidency will make little change in the Taipei administration.

An increase last week of 2,241,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, they were 133,888,000 barrels, a new peak, compared with 131,647,000 a week earlier and 124,382,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The House Education and Labor Committee adopted by a vote of 13 to 11 today a resolution not to report any bill for Federal aid to education until "the President of the United States submits a statement to said committee clarifying the authority and redefining the duties of the United States Commissioner of Education."

Faced with the prospect of early stoppage of loan insurance on many types of housing through the expiration last night of several sections of the National Housing Act, a committee representing the Long Island Home Builders Institute will go to Washington today to urge early reinstatement of these mortgage aids.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1--The probable regular infield of the Giants was revealed in their first workout under unfavorable conditions today and at the same time Manager Leo Durocher said he would use Sheldon Jones, righthander, almost solely as a starting pitcher in 1950.

The Detroit Red Wings enjoyed one big period in their National Hockey League game with the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night, and that period was more than enough to give them the triumph. Tallying four times in the middle session, the league-leading Wings had little trouble registering a 5-to-2 success over the local skaters.

MONTREAL, March 1 (Canadian Press)--Britain's action in directing the West Indies not to buy certain goods in Canada was criticized today by John A. Marsh, general manager of the Canadian Exporters Association.

The principle of a proposal that future residential construction provide for adequate garage or parking space was approved in executive session yesterday by the members of the City Planning Commission.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 1-- The secret negotiations between Jordan and Israel, which would amend the Rhodes armistice agreement and lay the foundation for a five-year nonaggression pact, include a proposal for granting Jordan a free port at Haifa, it was learned tonight from a reliable source.
A series of six documentary programs dealing with the work of the United Nations will start at 11:30 this evening over radio station WNBC.
When the liquid packed with canned vegetables is thrown away, as much as one-third of both the vitamin C or ascorbic acid and the vitamin B1 or thiamine is lost with it.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were easier yesterday and lost 15 to 27 points net on the day.

Premier Stalin may one day be the proud possessor of "certain articles of special rarity" pertaining to the Elizabethan era, under the will of Laird Shields Goldsborough, former foreign affairs editor of Time, filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 1-- Hurlbut Barnes Cutting, retired executive of the F.W. Woolworth Company, chain-store firm, died here today in Mountainside Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Cutting, who was 74 years old, lived in near-by Essex Fells.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 1--George Beatty, an automobile dealer here at 160 Huguenot Street, is defying the state's brownout regulation by turning on a large electric advertising sign outside his agency. The police said tonight they could do nothing more than report the case to Albany.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., March. 1 (AP)--Walter A. Bledsoe, coal operator with extensive mining interests in four states, died today in Miami Beach, Fla. He had gone to Miami Beach two weeks ago to recuperate from a heart attack at his home here. His age was 74.

TOKYO, March 1--Gen. Douglas MacArthur today was urged to take "positive action" on Japanese charges that war prisoners in the Soviet Union had been denied repatriation unless they pledged themselves to join the Communist party upon their return here.
WASHINGTON, March 1--The Robertson bill to bring labor unions under the anti-trust laws apparently has failed to rally strong support in Congress.

GENEVA, March 1--The French Government has signed an agreement with the International Refugee Organization, it was learned here today, under which it will take over All that organization's relief functions in France by next June 30.

John J. Downing, meet director for the Knights of Columbus games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, expects both a packed gathering in the stands and a heavy turnout of athletes on the board track as well. The relays find eighty-two teams on the program, not the least important being the nine quartets in the two-mile intercollegiate test.

SHARON, Conn., March 1 (AP)-- Alfred Habdank Korzybski, scientist and author, an early authority on general semantics, died early today at Sharon hospital at the age of 70. Death was due to a coronary thrombosis, with which he was stricken at his home in near-by Salisbury shortly after midnight.

CHICAGO, March 1--Grains showed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade today, and while final trades were under the high for the day, closing trades on soybeans, which led the advance, were up 2 to 4 cents, the March and May leading.

Only two contracts of March delivery of hides were liquidated on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, following the action of the Board of Governors regulating trade in that contract and limiting the advance on such contracts to 200 points above the June delivery contract price.

ALBANY, March 1--The Senate approved and sent to Governor Dewey today the state's budget for the fiscal year starting April 1. As revised by the Legislature it calls for total appropriations of $862,775,677. The Assembly approved the budget bills yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 --Issuance of orders by Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production at Warner Brothers, for 50 per cent cuts in personnel in all departments of the studio, was reported today by the trade paper Daily Variety.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 --Fordham's improving basketball team handed Yale its worst defeat of the season, triumphing by 72--53 tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 1--John Loomis Sherman, 54 years old, of Los Angeles was before the House Committee on Un-American Activities today, charged by Whittaker Chambers with having headed a pre-war Soviet underground apparatus in Tokyo and with having received help from American Communists, including himself.

PARIS, March 1--After three weeks of intensive negotiations, five agreements on French-Saar relations were initialed at the French Foreign Ministry tonight by the French and Saar chiefs of delegation.
Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey yesterday seized all facilities of the Bell Telephone Company within she state to forestall a strike by 12,000 operators and other workers.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 1--The summoning of a special top-level meeting of the United Nations Security Council in Europe is being discussed here by delegates and officials of the world organization as a possible method of ending the seven-week-old Soviet boycott.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 21, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

The city and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, locked in controversy over the latter's right to charge an 8-cent fare on its twenty-one Manhattan bus lines, took the dispute to the Appellate Division yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)-- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today the farm price-support program might collapse unless the Commodity Credit Corporation received adequate funds.

LONDON, March 1--South African gold-mining shares dominated the Stock Exchange here today. Their attraction as a refuge from the domestic political and economic uncertainties was supplemented by speculative buying. Although selling orders from Cape Town brought a reaction, there was a long list of net gains.

David E. Lilienthal, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, declared yesterday that recent statements by scientists and others predicting that a hydrogen bomb would bring about the "end of the world" served only to create a "growing sense of hopelessness and helplessness among our ...
March made a bright and almost balmy entry here yesterday, and except for gale-driven storms in the northern states most of the country fared about as well.

BONN, Germany, March 1--The Western Allied High Commissioners agreed today on the occupation costs to be charged to the Germans during the next fiscal year. Reliable sources estimated them to be between 3,500,000,000 and 4,000,000,000 Deutsche marks or nearly $1,000,000,000.

The Wear Ever Cooking Utensil Company has heavy back orders on many items in its line and will not be able to offer immediate delivery to dealers on all products until May 1, R.L. Becker, vice president in charge of sales, said yesterday. He made this statement at a luncheon in the Biltmore Hotel celebrating the company's fiftieth anniversary.
NASSAU, Bahamas, March 1-- Lawrence Grinnell, retired business man of New Bedford, Mass., died here last night at the age of 64.

ALBANY, March 1--A bill that in general would tighten the benefit provisions of the Unemployment Insurance Law was introduced in the Legislature today under the sponsorship of a joint legislative committee headed by Senator John H. Hughes of Syracuse.
MONROVIA, Liberia, Feb. 24-- President William V.S. Tubman today requested the United States to supply a military adviser to Liberia--at the expense of the Liberian Government--to train her army.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1--Battlefield, a chestnut colt bred in old Kentucky, and Liberty Rab, a gray colt foaled at the Christopher ranch five or six miles from Hialeah, today won the two divisions of the Hialeah Juvenile Stakes in identical time, but there was a big difference in the pay-offs. Battlefield, second choice in the first section, paid $6.80; Liberty Rab set up a $72.90 mutuel.

Those engaged in the uphill effort to "bring back" the Gordon setter are displaying laudable persistence, and a number of field trial enthusiasts undoubtedly will be on hand to cheer them on this Sunday when the Gordon Setter Club of America will hold a field trial at the Cowie Game Farm at Chester, N. J.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The report of the House Armed Services Committee on Unification and Strategy in the Armed Forces contained the following statement on the removal of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld from his post as Chief of Naval Operations and the following summary of the committee's views on unification:

Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien observed yesterday the first anniversary of his appointment to that post. In his office at Police Headquarters he reviewed changes in the department during his incumbency and spoke of strengthening relationships among members of the force and with the public.
License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey put into effect yesterday a series of stringent regulations designed to protect the patrons of legitimate theatres from overcharging.

ALBANY, March 1--Representative William L. Pfeiffer, the Republican state chairman, has blocked consummation of a bipartisan Brooklyn political arrangement involving creation of one new bench place and the exchange of Democratic and Republican endorsements for five judicial candidates.

The Philippine Cabinet has approved a recommendation to limit the disbursement of dollars for imports this year to actual receipts of dollars from exports, from payments and expenditures by the United States in the Philippines, and from other "inward remittances."

WASHINGTON, March 1--The contempt trial of the United Mine Workers was concluded today with heated arguments by Government and union attorneys. Federal Judge Richmond B. Keech reserved decision and may announce his ruling tomorrow.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 6.5 per cent in February, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, March 1--A Senate banking and currency subcommittee was told today that President Truman favored enactment of legislation to provide more effective control of bank holding companies but one of its members contended that "certain people" would like to block such action.
If there is a growing disposition to keep taxing and spending responsibility closer to the people, instead of yielding it to distant capitals, we believe ...
The police were investigating last night several puzzling features of the murder of a 60-yearold woman in the Bronx yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--A Government trade mission reported today that the Far East offers an outlet for wheat three times as large as average pre-war imports.

WASHINGTON, March 1--The House Armed Services Committee called today for basic changes in the planning and administration of national defense. It issued a report designed to insure stricter civilian control of the military and to carry forward more smoothly the unification of the armed services.
A woman was crushed to death yesterday morning in the Grand Central station of the I.R.T. subway as an elevator in which she had been a passenger suddenly slipped as she was stepping from it.
WASHINGTON, March 1--Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat, Liberal, of New York, said today that the present Displaced Persons Act was "basically cruel and deceptive," but declared that ...

WASHINGTON, March 1--A House of Representatives vote of 247--125 approved today the establishment of a National Science Foundation to overcome persistent post-war shortages of research skills essential to health, prosperity and national defense.

New issues of serial trust certificates totaling $18,180,000 were sold at competitive bidding yesterday to help finance the acquisition of new equipment for the Pennsylvania Railroad, the Chicago and North Western Railway, and the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis Omaha Railway. Awards were as follows:

ATLANTIC CITY, March 1-- With only two dissenting votes, the American Association of School Administrators adopted a resolution today opposing the use of public funds for the support of parochial schools.
New York City's interest in making rain in accordance with Dr. Irving Langmuir's principles has aroused some protest from neighboring communities.

WASHINGTON, March 1--A North Atlantic treaty conference to seek an all-Western plan for "a new approach to atomic peace" with the Soviet Union was urged today by Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut.

There's a lot to talk about in the Hattie Carnegie spring and summer collection that was shown yesterday afternoon. One always leaves the East Forty-ninth Street establishment with a feeling of stimulation, for Miss Carnegie puts thought into her fashion creations.

Reports from both Washington and London indicate that the Foreign Ministers of the twelve nations constituting the North Atlantic Security Alliance are planning to meet early this spring under the auspices of the Alliance's Council to coordinate their policies and make the Alliance itself a more positive factor in world affairs.

LONDON, March 1--As the excitement of election time dies down here the cold hard facts of economic life are beginning once more to plague the British Government and manufacturers. Chief among these as usual is the need to earn United States dollars.
Little hug-me-tight jackets and capes were the highlights of the Ritter Brothers' spring and summer fur collections presented, yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 1--A meeting this spring of the foreign secretaries of the United States, Great Britain and France appeared likely today as this Government decided that something considerably more than military preparation was needed to check communism in Western Europe.

DETROIT, March 1--Through a substitution of Government "palliatives" for venture capital, expansion of the American economy has been reduced to an "inching forward" movement, it was declared here today at the closing session of the National Marketing Conference, conducted by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
Mr. Attlee's reconstructed Cabinet looks enough like the old article to indicate what maybe expected of Britain's Labor Government in the new circumstances in which it resumes power.

Chiang Kai-shek, who has reassumed the Presidency of Nationalist China, which he dropped thirteen months ago, was denounced yesterday as a "dictator" and a would-be usurper, by Li Tsung-jen, Acting President of China. Mr. Li has been in this country for the past three months for medical treatment.

A comprehensive plan to eliminate serious accident or death from boxing bouts was put into effect yesterday by Eddie Eagan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission. Long in the process of preparation, the plan took on added significance coming to light, as it does, a week after it does, a week after the death of Lavern Roach.
MOSCOW, March 1 (AP)--Wide price cuts resulting from revaluation of the ruble sent crowds of Russians on an enthusiastic buying spree today in Moscow, stores and markets.

CHICAGO, March 1--Sewell L. Avery, chairman of United States Gypsum Company, told stockholders today that sales and earnings had increased in 1950, but warned that the company and the country must be prepared for a business slump.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1-- Pee Wee Reese, captain and key man of the Dodgers' infield, did his first serious exercising today since a Louisville surgeon worked him over last winter and felt "pretty good" when it was over.

The fleet of transports and coastwise vessels operated by the Army for the past fifty-two years was turned over to the Navy yesterday in formal ceremonies held simultaneously in New York, San Francisco and Seattle.
LONDON, March 1 (Reuters)-- Executives and workers in British shipyards, studying reports of record building achievements in 1949, are wondering whether they will ever see another year like it.

Thomas E. Stephens, the new secretary of the Republican State Committee, whom Representative William L. Pfeiffer, the chairman, has designated as coordinator of party activities in the five counties of New York City, disclaimed yesterday any intention of interfering with the prerogatives of the five county leaders.

ALBANY, March 1--Representatives of two large up-state conservation groups urged enactment today of the bill introduced in the Legislature by Assemblyman Jeremiah J. Ashcroft, Democrat, of Utica, that would give the state control over the cutting of merchantable timber in New York.
PHILADELPHIA, March 1-- Gian-Carlo Menotti's new musical drama, "The Consul," made a hit throughout the house tonight at its world premiere in the old Shubert Theatre on South Broad Street here.

Amendments to the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 are again under debate in the Senate. Last June the House passed H.R. 4567, which is, generally speaking, a satisfactory measure and should at least establish the principles for any new legislation.
MANCHESTER, N.H., March 1 --An autopsy of the body of Mrs. Abbie C. Borroto showed a needle puncture at the place where her nurse testified Dr. Hermann N. Sander injected air into her veins.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 1-- The University of California's loyalty oath controversy broke into an open verbal battle today between top faculty members and John Francis Neylan, a San Francisco attorney and a member of the Board of Regents.

The operations of American Airlines were seriously curtailed yesterday by a nation-wide strike of 4,000 maintenance and stores employes who began a work stoppage at 7:30 A.M. Personnel in thirty-four cities are affected.
WASHINGTON, March 1--Developments affecting Democratic primary election contests in three states were reported at the White House today.

La Salle College of Philadelphia yesterday became the fourth team to accept a bid to compete in the thirteenth annual national invitation college basketball tournament, which starts Saturday afternoon, March 11, at Madison Square Garden.
Fredric March and Florence Eldridge return to Broadway this evening as co-stars of "Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep," which will be presented at the Broadhurst Theatre at 8 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, March 1--Prof. Charles J. Pierson, retired head of the Zoology Department at Maryland University, died yesterday in near-by Laurel, Md., after a long illness. His age was 83.

The purchase by an investor of the fifteen-story apartment house for 102 families at 390 Riverside Drive from the Trawley Realty Corporation was announced yesterday by Joseph H. Lopin Co., the brokers in the deal. The property is assessed for $775,000.

Plans for a six-story, elevator apartment building to house ninety-six families were announced yesterday in connection with the sale by David S. Meister, New York operator, of a plot of land on the west side of Westchester Avenue, at Broad Parkway, White Plains, in Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, March 1--Yugoslavia received a second $20,000,000 line of credit by the United States Export-Import Bank today, the proceeds to be used to buy a wide variety of American products and to meet dollar commitments incident to the reorientation of Yugoslavia's trade from East to West.

WASHINGTON, March 1--Western Europe is determined to integrate its now divided economic structure as rapidly as humanly possible, and this new unity will not be without a substantial contribution from Great Britain, Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, Netherlands Foreign Minister, told a cross-section of Washington officialdom tonight.

Fuld Co., Inc., greeting card manufacturers of 352 Fourth Avenue, where seventeen employes have staged a sit-in strike since last Friday, was unable yesterday to move its property to Catskill, N.Y. Union moving men refused to cross a mass picket line.

Combined motives of propaganda, economic self-interest, and financial realism have led the Soviet Union to define the ruble for international purposes in terms of gold rather than dollars, according to the Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy.

Dividend actions of a favorable nature dominated the announcement yesterday by a representative list of corporations. Two corporations, however, took no action on declarations usually made at this time of the year.
The American Cyanamide Company, chemical and allied products manufacturer, in 1949 achieved the largest sales and earnings in its history.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 1--The Communist Information Bureau blockade against Yugoslavia has by now had a serious cumulative effect upon this country's already threadbare economy.

Higher rental apartments in Manhattan now are in ample supply and should be freed from rent control, John F. Hamlin, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co., and chairman of the De Luxe Apartment Committee of New York, declared yesterday at a conference in the Elliman office.

The Appellate Division, Second Department, granted yesterday the application of eight Bishops and 1,123 other clergymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church for permission to participate as a "friend of the court" in the defense of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, ...

The United Corporation, which is in transition from the status of a utility holding company to that of an investment concern, announced yesterday in its report for 1949 that by 1955, "if not sooner," it would not own as much as 5 per cent of the voting securities of any public utility or holding company.

In a sharp exchange of contradictory statements, the chairman and the president of the $165,000,000 Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company last night presaged a stormy meeting of the ten-man board at the road's offices, 30 Church Street, today.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 1-- The United Nations will invite concerns throughout the world to bid on the supplying of $2,000,000 worth of furniture and equipment for its thirty-nine-story skyscraper on the East River, it was announced today.

Scattered over the metropolitan area are 231,000 members of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York for whom sickness and accident no longer hold their former fears. North Carolina announced yesterday that it would receive bids March 22 on $75,000,000 of secondary road bonds.
