A schoolboy basketball team set a record in Madison Square Garden yesterday as Bryant High, in a preliminary round of the P.S.A.L. championship play-offs, passed the century scoring mark to best De Witt Clinton, 102 to 83, before 5,000 excited fans.
A request that any industrial water restrictions be applied "equably across the board" instead of against entire industries was made to Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas ...

ALBANY, March 2--The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that the right to freedom of speech did not include the right to block traffic on public sidewalks and streets and to incite a crowd to riot.

Federal District Judge Richmond B. Keech has absolved the United Mine Workers of legal responsibility for the walkout of its 370,000 members and the resulting cessation of soft coal production since early February.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 2--The 1950 Congressional elections will be the major test of the American Farm Bureau Federation's views on farm policy as opposed to Administration proposals for farm legislation, Allan B. Kline, Farm Bureau president, said today.

Although Easter Sunday, which falls on April 9 this year, is still more than a month off, retailers giving prominent display to greeting cards for the occasion are already experiencing good sales activity, trade sources observed yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., March 2--Admiral William M. Fechteler, Commander in Chief of the Atlantic Fleet, sailed from here today aboard his flagship, the General H.W. Butner, a naval transport, to direct "Operation Portrex" in the Caribbean.

A two-page holograph letter of George Washington and two Bibles he used were displayed last night at a special meeting to commemorate the 150th anniversary of Washington Lodge No. 21, Free and Accepted Masons, at the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twentythird Street.
WASHINGTON, March 2--Dr. Helen B. Chapin, internationally known student of Far Eastern Art and Iconography, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. She was 55 years old.

Apart from the effects of the coal shortage, the business news has been favorable and the outlook through the Spring is almost everywhere considered good, the National City Bank of New York reports in its Monthly Letter, published today.

Cutting winds with gusts up to forty-five miles an hour roared across the city and below-freezing temperatures chilled its citizenry yesterday as a cold snap closed in over the Eastern section of the country.

March 1 has come and gone, rainfall in the New York City watershed exceeded normal in January and February by a total of two inches, and our reservoirs are still only 47 per cent full. Whatever the results of yesterday's "dry-day" savings, it is apparent that ...

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and its subsidiaries reported yesterday net earnings of $102,668,228 for 1949, equal to $6.72 a share, compared with $140,079,286, or $9.16 a share, the year before.
A dozen 4-year-old children of young doctors at the Memorial Cancer Center sat yesterday in a circle in their nursery school at 316 East Sixty-third Street reciting "The House that Jack Built."

A suspended three-month workhouse term was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Mrs. Alice R.P. Satterthwaite, former social service worker who had pleaded guilty Feb. 17 to placing a newborn child in adoption without being an authorized agent.

SEOUL, Korea, March 2--The United Nations Commission on Korea decided today to ask Secretary General Trygve Lie to appoint "trained observers" to watch over military developments in Korea. A message to that effect has been sent to Lake Success.

A stocky, balding tax consultant, whose many clients include several corporations, was arrested yesterday in the State Attorney General's offices on charges of defrauding New York State on his own income tax return.

LONDON, Friday, March 3 (AP) --The Soviet Union has agreed to a United States request that five persons be allowed to leave its territory for the United States. It has turned down a request that thirty-three others be allowed to go.

The first major development in the investigation by District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County into organized gambling in the borough occurred yesterday with the arraignment of three men as material witnesses.

The "streamlined" operations of American Airlines continued yesterday during the second day of the strike of 4,600 of its maintenance and stores workers employed at thirty-four cities across the country.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 2--Defense counsel told the "mercy killing" jury today that Dr. Hermann N. Sander would take the stand, would admit giving air injections to Mrs. Abbie C. Borroto, but deny they killed her or that he intended them to.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 2--Three Soviet satellites were accused before the International Court of Justice today of having wilfully refused to implement their peace treaty obligations to arbitrate United States and British charges that they had deprived their people of human rights.
Continuing their downward trend for the fourth successive week, business loans made by banks in this area declined $13,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, March 2 (AP)--Britain's Labor Government angrily denied tonight that its newly named War Minister, John Strachey, was or ever had been a Communist.

BOSTON, March 2 (AP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today it had filed action in United States District Court to compel the Atlas Tack Corporation to file annual and quarterly financial reports and to correct deficiencies in some reports filed.

Two designers provided the themes for Bergdorf Goodman's spring and summer showing of custom-made fashions, which was previewed yesterday afternoon. Leslie Morris set the pace for the younger fashions; Mary Gleason, ...

WASHINGTON, March 2--President Truman pledged his wholehearted support today to any move toward world peace, but he added with unmistakable finality that he would not lead a mission to Moscow while he was President.

GENEVA, March 2--Russian and German steel production in 1949 increased by more than that of all the rest of Europe combined over the 1948 output, according to figures released here today by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

TRENTON, March 3--Legislation to revive New Jersey's standby rent-control law and to extend a utility anti-strike measure was agreed upon today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and Republican leaders of the Legislature for early passage. The Legislature will return Monday, ending a three-week recess.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 3--Arrested last night and early this morning in raids on pool rooms, bars, restaurants and rooming houses in Westchester County, twelve men were booked today on charges of illegally peddling narcotics. All were remanded to the county jail at Eastview pending grand jury action.

BANFF, Alberta, March 3--Andre Bertrand, 17-year-old FrenchCanadian from Laval University, Quebec City, today turned in the biggest surprise of the ski season by scoring a close victory over Austria's Egon Schopf in the men's Canadian downhill championship over precipitous Mount Norquay's one-mile-and-a-half course.
Leading medical and scientific organizations mapped yesterday a campaign to push through the Legislature a bill that would make available for research stray dogs that are now killed in the pound.

Bob Zawoluk, St. John's 6--6 center, went on a scoring rampage last night as the Redmen crushed St. Peter's quintet, 105--61, at DeGray Gymnasium, Zawoluk collected twenty-five field goals and fifteen fouls for 65 points, individual high this season.

The 10,000-ton Serbia, biggest steamship in the Yugoslav fleet since the Partisanka was burned last year, left the port of New York the same day that Marshal Tito made the second of two campaign speeches asserting that he would not make political concessions in return for foreign aid from any quarter and implying that his country might have to get along without further outside assistance.
FRANKFORT, Germany, March 3--Reports that United States officials had recommended turning over several Liberty ships to the Germans were quashed here today.

NEWARK, March 3--Every dog is entitled to one bite, as the commonly accepted view of the law has it, but two dogs in this state have apparently been entitled to five bites--and a good try for a sixth--under traditionally severe Jersey justice conditions.

ALBANY, March 3--The Court of Appeals has handed down a ruling which, in effect, holds a Mexican "mail-order" divorce to be "a decree of disinheritance." The court previously had held such a divorce worthless in New York State.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., March 3--The marriage of Miss Ann Lindley Wurtele, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine Wurtele of Minneapolis, to Carteret Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Lawrence of 417 Park Avenue, New York, and Terryall, Smithtown Branch, took place this afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church.

It will be extremely difficult to get the British to understand the American philosophy of competitive selling, according to Arthur H. Motley, co-chairman of the American delegation of sales executives who sailed for Great Britain last night aboard the Queen Mary.

Ljuba Welitch sang her first Aids of the season at the Metropolitan Opera last night, infusing the well-worn opera with new life. It was the second performance of the Verdi work in one day, a special performance for students having been presented by a separate cast in the afternoon.

In his message to Congress yesterday the President expressed the hope that a last-minute agreement between the coal miners and the operators would make unnecessary the enactment of the "seizure" legislation which he sent to Capitol Hill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 --"The Human Interest Story," a newspaper film, will be Billy Wilder's next production at Paramount, the studio announced today. Lesser Samuels and Walter Newman are collaborating with Wilder on the scenario, and the producer hopes to get the picture before the cameras sometime in May.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 3--A farmer organization spokesman warned today that the American farmer "can go broke easier than he could after World War I" because he was at the mercy of the cost and price structure determined by labor-management policies.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 3 --Dr. Albert F. Snay told the "mercy killing" jury today that he had found Mrs. Abbie C. Borroto to be dead and had so informed Dr. Hermann N. Sander before Dr. Sander injected air into her veins.

A new issue of $21,000,000 of city-guaranteed tax-exempt bonds of the New York City Housing Authority is under consideration of the city's housing officials, according to reports received in underwriting circles yesterday. March 21 is the date reported for receiving bids for the issue. The Housing Authority is to meet next week to take formal action on the borrowing.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 3--Johannes A. Louwers, Dutch business man who pleaded, partly guilty yesterday to charges of military and economic espionage, ilegal foreign exchange dealings and helping Czech capitalists to flee the country, listened silently in Pankrac prison courtroom today...

A new contract agreement was reached last night by John L. Lewis in behalf of the striking coal miners and by the Northern, Western and "captive" mine operators several hours after a demand by President Truman for Congressional authority to seize the closed mines.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 3--Dr. Alexei Cepicka, Minister of Justice and head of the state's Office for Church Affairs, today issued "a last warning" to the Roman Catholic Bishops to turn against the Vatican.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 3 (AP) --A Minneapolis investment firm made $3,479.12 more than it considered would be the fee in the recent much-disputed Minnesota purchase of $5,208,000 Arkansas bonds, the Minnesota Public Examiner reported today.
The goal the cyclists in the sixday race have been working toward on the banked masonite track at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory at 168th Street and Broadway began coming into sight last night.

ATHENS, March 3--Premier John Theotokis reported to King Paul today that "satisfactory conditions" prevailed throughout the country for the national elections Sunday. The Premier announced his intention and that of the caretaker Government he heads to resign soon as the results were published.

VIENNA, March 3--Seldom has an American play been received in Vienna with more universal critical acclaim than the German version of Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman," which had its premiere this week in the Josefstaedter Theatre, with Ernst Lothar as producer and his wife, Adriene Gessner, in one of two leading roles.

The results of the British election have again brought to the fore a perennial question which is fundamental for the effective functioning of any democracy. This is the question of the electoral method which best assures both fair representation and a stable and workable government.
For the third time since January the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered new cuts yesterday in railroad passenger and freight services requiring the use of coal.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)-- The Government's investment in farm surpluses under its price support program has climbed to the $4,000,000,000 mark.

Sylvia Muehling, the pianist who made her debut last night in Town Hall, devoted the entire first half of her program to the music of Bach, playing a pair of choral preludes arranged by Busoni, the B flat Partita, the Prelude and Fugue in D sharp minor from the "WellTempered Clavier," and the Toccata in E minor.

A supervising railroad equipment inspector of the Public Service Commission told Commissioner George A. Arkwright at a public hearing yesterday that the Long Island Rail Road was now using rolling stock of 1908 vintage.

The heavy over-cutting of New York State's privately owned woodlands has aroused well-justified alarm. Preservation and proper management of this invaluable natural resource is a matter of direct concern to all citizens of this state, not merely to the property owners on whose land the trees happen to grow.

In addition to revising the Statutes governing the treatment of women offenders, Massachuset's needs to take a look at some of the reasons for which women are sentenced to its reformatory at Framingham, it is suggested by authorities in the field of penology.
The news that the coal strike negotiators must reach a quick settlement or face Government seizure of the bituminous mines inspired fresh buying yesterday on the stock market.

WASHINGTON, March 3--Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, a hero of the First World War and a strategist of the Second, told Congress today that the United States must continue Marshall Plan aid to Europe "to secure our flank in the west while we take the initiative in Asia" to head off its subjugation by Soviet Russia.

"Cry of the Peacock," the Jean Anouilh play which James Colligan and Don Medford are producing, will make its Broadway debut at the Mansfield Theatre on Thursday evening, April 6. Booking contracts were signed yesterday.

Antin Properties, Inc., bought for investment from the Rialto Management Corporation the sevenstory business building at 134-36 West Forty-fourth Street, near Broadway, which about ten years ago was converted from a clubhouse.
BERLIN, March 3 (AP)--Poland's expulsion of the last 125,000 Germans in the western territories she occupied after the war got under way today.

Biting cold nipped bare fingers and ears here yesterday after the mercury dipped to 9.3 degrees at 6:20 A.M. to set a new low mark for the date and failed later to climb above the freezing point. Elsewhere along the Atlantic seaboard there were arctic air masses or deep snow.

The only one missing yesterday at the Vanderbilt Hotel's party for employes with twenty-five years or more of service was "Bill" O'dwyer. So a parish priest told forty-three men and women who received scrolls for their long service.
The high-flying Holy Cross basketball team nipped the New York A.C. 58 to 56, at the city clubhouse last night before a packed gathering to stretch its winning streak to twenty-six this season.

WASHINGTON, March 3--The United States charged Hungary to day with violating a treaty with this country by not making adequate compensation to United States citizens whose property had been seized under the Hungarian nationalization law.
Coffee futures were steady in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Contract S closed 17 to 32 points above Thursday's levels. Contract D closed 10 to 25 points up.

ALBANY, March 3--Charging that the Federal Government had diverted into its general funds $150,000,000 collected from New York State employers for the administration of the unemployment insurance law, Governor Dewey appealed today for revision of the Federal law that would earmark the tax for unemployment insurance purposes. The sum siphoned from all states had been $1,000,000,000, he declared.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 3-- Branch Rickey, Dodger boss, apparently has ceased to be worried about the weight of his ace second baseman, Jackie Robinson.

Today's lone film newcomer is "Borderline," s melodrama from Universal-International, which is opening at the Criterion. Co-starred in this story about the adventures of a feminine narcotics agent in Los Angeles and Mexico are Fred MacMurray and Claire Trevor.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- Claims of prospective Democratic victories across the nation's bread basket in November were made today by William M. Boyle Jr., Democratic National Chairman.

Edwin H. Morris Co., one of the country's largest independent publishers of popular music, filed in Federal court yesterday a civil anti-trust suit for $1,710,000 against five motion picture companies and fourteen music publishing concerns.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 3--German nationalism is not now a "major or serious" factor in German politics but has a potential for danger in the future that is enhanced by the "deeply rooted" authoritarian practice of governmental procedures, according to a United States report on nationalism.

WASHINGTON, March 3--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Kansas City Power and Light Company, Kansas City, Mo., had filed a registration statement covering 1,904,003 shares of its no par value common stock.

PARIS, Saturday, March 4-- Bent on preventing the voting of measures to break up their campaign of blockading United States shipments of arms to France, Communist party Deputies by violence and obstruction held up legislation in the National Assembly all night.

Warnings that Americans have "the jitters" and are inviting mediocrity into their schools, businesses and Government by putting a "premium on conformity" were given yesterday by speakers at the Columbia College Forum on Democracy in its second day on the campus.

Pert little navy wool coats with white trim and soft pastel dresses for the young Easter promenader were highlights of Gimbels spring collection of children's fashions previewed by the press yesterday. They are to be presented to the public at a showing at 11 o'clock this morning in their new sixth floor auditorium.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)-- The town of Hempstead, L.I., through Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, and Representative Leonard W. Hall, is pressing its case for funds to improve the navigation facilities of Jones Inlet.
LONDON, March 3 (AP)--Following is the text of War Secretary John Strachey's statement denying that he retains Communist sympathies:

Bruno-New York, Inc., distributor of television and radio products of the Radio Corporation of America in the metropolitan area, will declare an immediate thirty-day "moratorium" on all local cooperative advertising of R.C.A. Victor television receivers.

PARIS, March 3--A lease on the operation of the Saar coal mines that would be extended over fifty years, provided that it was approved by the treaty of peace, was granted to France in the chief of a series of agreements signed today by France and the Saar at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (AP)-- In a roundabout way, the National Football League admitted today that it didn't merge with the AllAmerica Conference. Instead, it merely gobbled up the A.A.C.

WASHINGTON, March 3--John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and representatives of the Northern, Western and "captive" coal mine operators tonight agreed on a new contract to end their nine-month struggle.

Time Inc., headed by Henry Luce, has given up its plans to erect a thirty-nine-story office building on the black occupied by the Marguery Hotel and apartments at 270 Park Avenue, it became known last night.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey named yesterday the three public members of the five-man arbitration board that, starting Monday, will seek to settle the dispute between the Communications Workers of America, C.I.O., and the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- Alexander E. Squadrilli, European coordinator of the Displaced Persons Commission, told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that prospective emigrants to the United States were screened by five United States agencies before they land at a port in this country.

BONN, Germany, March 3-- Sources close to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that the West German Government would make no move in the foreseeable future to join the Council of Europe as a consequence of the French-Saar treaty that was signed in Paris today and was greeted here with violent opposition.

Congress is fully aware of the vital relation between the transportation industry and national defense and is devoting much time to legislation that will stimulate air, water and land transports, according to Representative Louis B. Heller, Democrat, of Brooklyn.
The United States is not immune from atomic-bomb attacks despite the high level of its defense establishment, Defense Secretary Louis Johnson declared last night.
TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES: I wish to report to the Congress on the emergency confronting the nation as a result of a shortage of coal, and to recommend legislative action.

WASHINGTON, March 3--The United States refused entry visas today to the twelve-member "World Congress of Partisan of Peace" on the ground that the delegates were "known Communists and fellowtravelers" and subject to exclusion under the immigration laws.

The Container Corporation of America and its subsidiaries had a net profit last year of $8,777,328, after taxes and all charges, equal to $8.46 a share of common stock, the 1949 annual report revealed yesterday. Net profit for 1948 amounted to $10,424,593, or $10.12 a common share.

CHICAGO, March 3 (AP)--Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe issued today a temporary order restraining offices of a Tucker corporation subsidiary from writing checks on $23,976 on deposit in a New York bank.
E. Don Pam has been appointed New York district manager of the Plax Corporation division of Hartford-Empire Company, Hartford, Conn., maker of plastic products.
When that doughty mentor of Scottish Covenanters, John Knox, was having his troubles with Mary of Lorraine, acting...

WESTPORT, Conn., March 3--In Christ and Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Mrs. B. Eleanor Herbert Finnegan, widow of Lieut. Thomas R. Finnegan, A.A.F., and daughter of Mrs. Haswell Herbert and the late Captain Herbert, A.A.F., was married to Dr. Neil F. Lebhar, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Norman J. Lebhar of New York. The Rev. Frederic L.C. Lorentzen performed the ceremony.

People are beginning to talk. Another Shaw play has been added to the two that are already upsetting the town. "Saint Joan" has been produced by the Equity Library players at the Clinton Community Center, at Mosholu Parkway and Paul Avenue, the Bronx, where it opened last evening.

The last five families in the condemned tenements on East Seventy-ninth Street between First and York Avenues were moved out yesterday. Meanwhile, the New York Housing Authority acted to find apartments for at least three of the families that were evicted on Thursday.
The Rev. David V. McCauley, rector since 1947 of Our Lady of Martyrs Tertianship, Aurlesville, N.Y., died Thursday in Miami, Fla., at the age of 55, according to word received here yesterday.

ABOARD THE TRANSPORT GENERAL BUTNER, EN ROUTE TO VIEQUES, March 3--A sprawling sea-air "war" raged over wide latitudes of the Atlantic today from the vicinity of Norfolk, Va., and Bermuda to Puerto Rico as Operation Portrex, the nation's largest peacetime amphibious maneuver, approached its climax.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3-- Yesterday dawned here for six New York food writers with cafe au lait in the old quarter and breakfast on a chartered plane that took them 150 miles west to New Iberia. After a short drive to Avery Island, they toured the Tabasco sauce factory and descended into the oldest salt mine in North America.

The six-story building at 704-706 East 182d Street, the Bronx, containing six stores and forty-six apartments, has been sold by the Graymoor Management Corporation to the Randolph Trading Corporation. Mintz, Brown Parker, Inc., and Louis Aronson were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 3--The Senate was geared tonight to start debate on a coal mine seizure bill in extraordinary session tomorrow, but a wage agreement between the United Mine Workers and the Northern, Western and "captive" mine operators appeared to solve the immediate problem. The House leadership put off the seizure issue until Monday.

A Jewish Scroll of the Law, or Sefer Torah, embracing the five books of Moses in the Bible, was accepted yesterday afternoon by Capt. James L. Gregory, Irish master of the new steamship Henrietta Szold, in a Purim ceremony on board the vessel at Pier 84 of the American Export Line, North River.

The "excellent results" of this week's Dry Thursday, in which New Yorkers used only 858,000,000 gallons of water, put off for at least one week the threatened mandatory restrictions on industrial use of water.

Long Island University, which clinched its berth by sweeping to a 68-to-52 triumph over Hamline at Madison Square Garden Thursday night, became the sixth team to accept a bid for the National Invitation basketball tournament, it was announced yesterday. Already entered in the event, which will have a dozen starters, are St. John's, Duquesne, Bradley, La Salle and Syracuse.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 (AP)--Jack Burke, the young man with a great golf game went out in front by two strokes as the St. Petersburg open reached the halfway point today.
Disheveled and hungry, fifteen men and women ended a week-long sit-down strike at Fuld Co., a greeting card concern, 352 Fourth Avenue, yesterday under the threat of a court injunction.

Keep a child out of shoes until he has started to walk by himself, parents were advised yesterday at the opening of the fifty-fourth annual convention of the New York State Podiatry Society in the New Yorker Hotel.

HANOI, Indo-China, Marcn 1-- Announcements by the French militart headquarters here in the last few days claim virtual completion of the campaign to sweep Viet Minh from the rich Red River delta region of Tongking. The large-scale delta operation began in December and the French predict it will be concluded soon.
DES MOINES, March 3--Frank McDonough, editor of Better Homes and Gardens Magazine since 1938, died of a heart ailment at Mercy Hospital today. He was 44 years old.
A haven for transient and convalescent priests of the Columban Foreign Missionary Society, which has its administrative headquarters in Navan, Ireland, has been established in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Administration said today that none of the recent accidents involving persons being sucked or blown out of planes in flight reflected faults in structural design.

The Isbrandtsen cargo liner Flying Arrow, the subject of much international controversy in Janu ary, will arrive at Pier 3, Hoboken, about 10 o'clock this morning, still bearing the scars of gunfire by naval craft of the Chinese Nationalist Government.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 3--The United Nations sent to the Soviet Union today a complete and formal denial of Russian charges that United Nations officials were being used as informants by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The first income surplus since 1944 was announced yesterday by R. Gregory Page, president of the Provident Loan Society of New York in a report on the organization's 1949 operations. The income surplus amounted to $133,000.

The National Mediation Board requested yesterday that the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., on strike against American Airlines, "restore status quo" by returning to service, "following which the board members are prepared to meet" representatives of both parties in Washington on Monday.

After nearly a quarter of a century in leased buildings on West Fiftieth Street in Manhattan, Bickford's, Inc., restaurant chain, soon will move its headquarters to Long Island City, Queens, executives of the company announced yesterday.

A group of flying sportsmen from Pennsylvania have hit upon a novel but adequate method of winter game feeding, and tomorrow 105 light aircraft piloted by members of the Aero Game-Feeding Club will leave Phillipsburg Airport with 2,400 bushels of corn to be dropped on Allegheny County forests.

CHICAGO, March 3--Failure of expected rains to develop in the West and Southwest and removal of hedges against export sales of wheat and of flour to the domestic trade combined to bring about a rapid advance in the deferred deliveries of wheat on the Board of Trade today with the close at gains of 1 1/8 to 1 cents.

WASHINGTON, March 3--Development of a lightweight alloy that will improve the rate of climb, range, payload and maneuverability of jet aircraft was announced today by the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics. The Navy said the alloy was as strong as highstrength steel and only half as heavy.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 3--The United Nations Economic and Social Council voted unanimously today to grant top consultative status to the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, an anti-Communist alliance representing unions in fifty-three countries.
The Navy transport Gen. A.W. Greely arrived here yesterday from Bremerhaven, Germany, with 1,301 displaced persons.

OTTAWA, March 3--There is no reason for panic or alarm, External Affairs Minister Lester B. Pearson told the House of Commons today in a review of the foreign situation. But there is good reason, he said, for care, firmness, and unity of purpose and method among the free peoples.
LAKE SUCCESS, March 3-- Contributions in any amount will now be accepted from anybody anywhere who wants to help complete and furnish the permanent world capital designated as United Nations, N.Y.

To its unbroken record of successful premieres, New York City Ballet Company at the City Center last night added still another, its fifth of the season. It is a little piece by George Balanchine for Janet Reed and Herbert Bliss called "Pas de Deux Romantique," set to Weber's "Concertino for Clarinet,' and though it will not make anybody rich or famous it is an undoubted success.
RENSSELAER, N.Y., March 3 (AP)--Mrs. Helen Overlander returned today to a joyous reunion at her home with the husband and three children whom she had left "forever."
Special Sessions Justice Frank Oliver criticized policemen and district attorneys throughout the state yesterday for failure to obtain warrants before entering and searching the homes of suspects.
LONDON, March 3--John Strachey, Secretary of State for War in the new Labor Cabinet, issued a statement tonight dismissing his early espousal of Communist philosophy as the follies of youth.

Released after a four-year confinement from what he called "that neutron-infested cage in Washington," meaning, of course, the Atomic Energy Commission, David Lilienthal spoke his mind in New York on the "oracles of annihilation" who have been telling us of late that the explosion of a hydrogen bomb would set the atmosphere on fire or at least scatter over the earth particles which would remain fatally radioactive for 5,000 years.

For the forty-fourth consecutive year the Greenwich House Music School, located in the heart of Greenwich Village, at 46 Barrow Street, will present its annual concert tonight at the Town Hall for the benefit of its student scholarship fund.

With the season's top performers matched in a series of "naturals," the thirty-first annual games of the New York Chapter Knights of Columbus will bring the 1950 indoor track season at Madison Square Garden to a smashing close tonight.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., March 3--A last-ditch effort by a citizens' committee to reopen the plant of the Continental Paper Company failed yesterday when the union that struck the mill rejected a proposal that had been accepted by the company.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 3--By a vote of 12 to 2 the International Court of Justice ruled today against Argentina's attempt to restrict the use of the veto on the admission of new members to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.)-- An attorney for Pan American World Airways said today that Hitler tactics are being used by opponents of his company's plan to buy American Overseas Airlines.

WASHINGTON, March 3--Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican, of Washington, demanded today that a Senate Banking and Currency Subcommittee call officials of the Transamerica Corporation, San Francisco bank holding company, to testify on a bill designed to tighten Government control of such companies.
WASHINGTON, March 3--The House Ways and Means Committee concluded hearings on President Truman's tax program today, exactly a month after these had opened.

FUENTERRABIA, Spain, Feb. 18--The fishermen of this little Basque village, facing France across the Bidassoa River, scorn modern labor unions and the Falange system of social insurance. They have their own guild nearly 600 years old, and it handles its own insurance.

LONDON, March 1--A chill wind blew down St. James Street the other day and on into stately Pall Mall. Old gentlemen in their high club windows seemed to become violently agitated, as if the Labor Government were trying to force their sacred strongholds of tradition with some of its "social democracy."
WASHINGTON, March 3--Mrs. Harry S. Truman today breezed into the All States Fair at the Congressional Club, unaccompanied even by Secret Service, and picked up two shopping bags full of bargains.

WASHINGTON, March 3--Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, writer and specialist in Latin-American affairs, received the Order of the Aztec Eagle at the Mexican Embassy today. The presentation was made by Ambassador Rafael de la Colina, acting on behalf of President Miguel Aleman.

Wide variety in contemporary painting is found in four New York exhibitions. The tie that binds the Spiral Group, nine artists who are now showing recent work at the New School, is difficult to determine. Except that they paint the whole gamut from complete abstraction to comparative realism and that they are good at what they individually do, they have little in common.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3--Take it from any of the 28,204 who saw the running of the $63,400 Flamingo Stakes on Hialeah's closing program today: Tom Gray's Oil Capitol is a top-ranking contender for Kentucky Derby honors.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP)--A Federal court refused today to dismiss a suit brought by the trustees of a bankrupt radio and television company against its former president.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 3--A group of non-tenure faculty members of the University of California, without representation in the Academic Senate, voted today, 300 to 1, to quit in a body if any member of the group is dismissed for failure to sign the disputed loyalty oath imposed by the Board of Regents.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady 17 to 34 points net higher than on Thursday.

JERSEY CITY, March 3--Mayor John V. Kenny, Democratic leader of Hudson County, announced today his support of Alfred Sieminski, a Jersey City laundry executive, as Democratic candidate for Representative from the Thirteenth New Jersey Congressional District, to succeed Mrs. Mary T. Norton.

Many retail trade observers said yesterday that this week might be the first of the season in which department store sales here would exceed those in the corresponding week of last year. Estimates placed the average gain at 1 to 2 per cent.

ONE of the lingering American illusions is the theory that the Navy is the silent serv ice. It was pretty well shattered, of course, when everyone in the Navy started shouting at once about unification last year during the heaviest fighting in the Pentagonian Wars.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3--Casey Stengel, who has never been one to neglect preparations for the future, did a bit of crystal ball gazing today and came up with a remarkable announcement. No, he didn't name his pitcher for the opening game of the 1950 season. But he did announce the flinger who will go to the mound for the Yankees when they engage the Cardinals in their first exhibition game on March 11.
Mayor O'Dwyer made a dramatic, unheralded appearance at the biweekly meeting of the Traffic Commission yesterday and bluntly ordered it to "fish or I'll cut your bait."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3-- Testimony that the "post-war line of the Communist party" included the organization of a third party was given to the jury today in the perjury-conspiracy trial of Harry Bridges by Mervin Rathborne, a Government rebuttal witness.

The art of salvaging brokendown Victorian and later furniture creations from their inevitable fate on some rubbish heap, will be demonstrated on Monday at the National Antiques Show at Madison Square Garden by a young New York artisan to whom nothing that has been made is expendable.

Mayor O'Dwyer's Committee on Unity, in an interim report on the operations of the Department of Housing and Buildings, recommended yesterday closer coordination among city departments having responsibility for the cleanliness, safety and sanitary conditions of dwellings.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3--The first step in converting cannonarmed Jack Lohrke from a thirdbaseman into a pitcher was taken on the Giants' third day in training today.
MANILA, March 3--The Philippine Government is becoming increasingly concerned over the infiltration of immigrants from Communist China, both legally and illegally.

Only in the last fifty years has ready-to-wear fashion been within easy reach of every woman. Its development and growth were determined largely by the vast styling and somewhat magical achieve ments of the fabric mills.

ALBANY, March 3--The State Banking Department announced today that the liquidation of the affairs of the Banco di Napoli Trust Company of New York has been completed by the Superintendent of Banks, the corporation dissolved and the corporate existence terminated.

A large-scale inter-group education program aimed at preventing occurrences similar to last summer's Peekskill disorder is now under way in twenty-three communities in Westchester County, it was learned yesterday.

CAIRO, March 3--King Abdullah's appointment of Samir Pasha Rifai to form a new Jordanian Cabinet after the sudden resignation yesterday of Premier Tewfik Pasha Abul Huda was taken as the long awaited signal that Abdullah was prepared to conclude a definite agreement with Israel that would be in effect a peace settlement.
MT. CARMEL, Ill., March 3 (U.P.) --A fugitive plane from Texas landed here late today and police said they seized the pilot, who gave his name as Robert Pryor, 27 years old, of Tulsa.

Lloyd's Register of Shipping has just issued a revised edition of its rules for the construction of tankers. The new rules embrace all the advances in tanker building since the last list was published twentyfive years ago.
LONDON, March 3--Prices sagged and business dwindled to meager dimensions here today as cautious and hesitant stock markets awaited the Government's declaration of policy on Monday.
ROME, March 3--Francis Cardinal Spellman was received by the Pope today in a private audience that lasted forty minutes.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 (AP) --Land distribution, the lure with which the Chinese Communists attracted the peasantry, was shoved into the future by the Peiping Communist regime today.

WASHINGTON, March 3--The House approved by a 186-146 vote today the thirty-three-year-old bid of Alaska to become the forty-ninth state of the Union. It then began consideration of the fifteenth appeal (the first was in 1920) of Hawaii for statehood, but no decision had been reached when adjournment was taken until tomorrow. It was expected generally, however, that the House would approve Hawaii as the fiftieth state.

Serious labor shortages in British foundries are forcing such plants to consider using new American methods for handling production materials, it was stated here yesterday by fifteen members of a British gray iron founders team which has just ended a six-weeks' tour through sixteen Americans plants.

DETROIT, March 3--The United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., opened its 1950 contract campaign today by demanding that the General Motors Corporation grant a pension plan that would provide $125 a month as part of over-all increases representing a wage rise of 31 cents an hour.

The chief and four deputies in the income tax fraud squad for the Third Collection District of the Internal Revenue office here were indicted yesterday by a special Federal grand jury on charges of accepting and extorting bribes from taxpayers.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 3-- Dr. Alan E. O'Donnell, assistant chief of the neurological staffs of the Charles V. Chapin and Rhode Island Hospitals here, died this morning at the age of 45.

Mao Tze-tung, chieftain of the Chinese Communists, is now back in his native land after his extended pilgrimage to Moscow. Because of the fact that he went there to negotiate a treaty most of the emphasis upon his return has been placed, so far, on the question: What did he come back with? It is equally pertinent to ask: What did he come back to?

BOSTON, March 3--Rallying spiritedly from the disappointments of last Saturday's intercollegiates, Yale's track and field squad tonight ended Army's twoyear domination of the indoor Heptagonal championships.

The still-current case of the "war bride" who was denied admission to this country without a hearing may yet serve a notable purpose. It may yet result in bringing about a change in one remarkably un-American aspect of our immigration procedures.

WASHINGTON, March 3--Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ending on last Tuesday, Feb. 28, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index stood at 152.6 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.9 per cent above the level of four weeks ago and 3.8 per cent below the comparable week of 1949.
Jersey Joe Walcott spotted Omelio Agramonte of Cuba eleven years in their scheduled ten-round star bout at Madison Square Garden last night, but didn't let the handicap bother him too much.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 3-- Miss Alice C. Lloyd, Dean of Women at the University of Michigan since 1930, died this morning at her home after an illness of more than two years. Her age was 56.

A suggestion that the State of Israel renounce its claims on Jews throughout the world and that American Jews cease to interfere in the political life of the new state was made here last night by Alfred M. Lilienthal, Washington lawyer and writer.
The over-all outlook for natural rubber is now better than at any time since the end of the war, Edward Jago, deputy chairman of the British Rubber Development Board of London, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3--The names of "Hiss" and "Sayre," of the State Department, were mentioned today by George Racey Jordan, a former Air Force major, as he told the House Committee on Un-American Activities that he found American military secrets in "diplomatic" air shipments to Moscow in 1943.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP)-- The State Department has accused the Soviet Union of holding some United States citizens in forced labor camps and sending others to Siberia, it was revealed tonight.

The Graham-Paige Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it is offering to holders of its outstanding preferred stocks the right to exchange their shares for common stock, $1 par, from March 7 through March 27. The number of common shares to be offered in exchange will depend upon the closing price of the common on the New York Stock Exchange on next Monday, March 6.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 3--Contributions totaling $4,500, including a "substantial donation" from a New York socialite, were reported today by George Woodbury, chairman of the Dr. Hermann N. Sander Fund.

The barrier created by the soft coal strike was finally crossed last week by the stock market. Indications near the week-end, which became a reality on Friday night, that a resumption of bituminous mining was a certainty inspired sufficient buying of equities to pull the share list out of the neutral corner in which it had crawled to await Washington developments on the coal crisis.

Part of the late Baron Max von Goldschmidt-Rothschild's collection of French furniture, Renaissance jewels, gold and enamel boxes, old porcelains and other works of art and decorative objects will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

New products especially designed for the American market now are coming off the secret lists of United Kingdom manufacturers, it was disclosed here yesterday by the British Information Services. The products are expected to be sold here in 1950 to help bring Anglo-American trade nearer balance.

WASHINGTON, March 4--Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat-Liberal, of New York, defended before the Senate today the screening procedures employed before displaced persons in Europe are allowed to enugrate to the United States. The Senate is considering a bill to raise the number of displaced persons to be admitted by June 30, 1951, to 320,000.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 4--Taxpayers of Union Free School District No. 4 in the largest vote ever cast in Port Washington have approved a $3,750,000 school building program proposed by the Board of Education. The margin for approval was 61 ballots of the 3,239 votes cast.

WASHINGTON, March 4--Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, who is up for re-election this year, said today that socialism, spending and Administration "softness" toward communism would be three of the principal issues of the 1950 campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4--Depending mostly on outside shots in the first half. Cornell broke through Pennsylvania's zone defense to defeat the Red and Blue at the Palestra tonight, 60--53, before 6,000 spectators.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 4-- Dr. Horace W. Gillett, a former associate of the Late Thomas A. Edison and recognized as one of the world's foremost metallurgists, died of a heart attack yesterday in Nicholasville, Ky., while returning to his home here from a hunting trip in Georgia and Florida. He was 66 years old.

ALBANY, March 4--A special committee appointed by Governor Dewey last month to consider methods for financing the New York-Buffalo thruway declared in a unanimous report today that the road could be made selfliquidating by the licensing of vehicles using it.

CAIRO, March 4--The Saudi Arabian Government has issued a communique stating that any nonMoslem found inside the sacred areas of Mecca and Medina is subject to a prison sentence of up to five years and a fine of 5,000 Saudi Arabian rials (about $1,300). Leftwich of Lambertville, and Douglas Campbell of Cos Cob, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Edwin O. Kennedy performed the ceremony.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 4 --Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pope have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Leavitt, to Henry James Carey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Carey of Floral Park, L.I. The wedding has been planned for the summer.

LONDON (By Wireless). THESE are times of great uncertainty in Britain. The nation stands at the crossroads of socialism and free enterprise. Internally prosperous, it is plagued by a shortage of dollars. Longing for peace and security above all else, its people see a world divided and under the shadow of new and more destructive wars to come.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4-- Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's 6-yearold Yankee Hill, who in the last couple of weeks apparently has moved into his second colthood, hustled around the Gulfstream Park oval today to win the $7,500 Inaugural Handicap and crack the track record for six furlongs.

UTICA, N. Y., March 4 (AP)-- United States curling rinks today won the Gordon international medal, taking fifteen of twentyeight matches from Canadians in a two-day bonspiel at the Utica Curling Club. United States curlers rolled up 332 points to the Canadians' 299.
WELLESLEY, Mass., March 4 --Wellesley College will formally install Dr. Margaret Clapp as its eighth president March 17, the Rev. Dr. Palfrey Perkins, chairman of the trustees, said today.

ALBANY, March 4--George S. WASHINGTON, March 5--A new and determined drive by the House Indian Affairs Subcommittee to get the Indians out of wardship by a long-range education, rehabilitation, and restriction-lifting program will have to cut through many old deadlocks if it is to succeed.

ST. LOUIS, March 5--Six hundred members of the Young Democratic Club of Missouri who attended their annual two-day convention here were returning home today after hearing W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, declare that he was proud of being a member of "the socalled Missouri gang."

Net income of the $868,000,000 Commonwealth Edison Company last year amounted to $29,301,334, equal to $2.13 on each of the 13,732,000 shares outstanding at the close of 1949. This was $5,082,071 above the $24,219,263 reported for 1948 when share earnings were $1.76.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5--The Kid has not the slightest intention of quitting at the end of this season. No, siree. There almost was a defiant gleam in his pale blue eyes when he made the statement. "I hope to manage the Athletics next year and for many years to come," said Connie Mack, a trim, sprightly and agile-minded 87-year-old. "Attaboy, Connie!" exclaimed his listener and then stopped abruptly, appalled by such irreverence.

The Federal Reserve System's feeding of longer-term Treasury bonds into the market at declining prices shows no signs of abating.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6-- Some idea of Jack Kramer's po-- tential value to the 1950 Giants is expected to be forthcoming Wednesday.

Methods used by the Long Island Rail Road to check the qualifications of its engine men were disclosed yesterday by Horace B. Stetson, superintendent, after he had submitted a report on the subject to the Public Service Commission.

The Traffic Commission quietly has reversed itself and invited representatives of the Greyhound Bus System to appear at an executive sesion on Friday to discuss its proposal to expand and reconstruct its West Thirty-fourth Street terminal, it became known yesterday.

The Citizens Budget Commission and other civic groups that on Sunday had criticized proposed city and state laws to change the police and fire pension systems were accused yesterday of "deliberately misleading the people of New York with false figures on the cost of pension reform."

The possibility of settlement by "consent decree" of the Government's civil anti-trust suit against the Shuberts charging them with monopolistic practices in the legitimate-theatre business was indicated yesterday afternoon.
The annual report of the CocaCola Company and its consolidated subsidiaries, issued to stockholders yesterday, shows 1949 net profit of $35,990,927 after taxes, Class A dividends and all charges.

Fourteen to fifteen inches from the floor was the prevailing length for day dresses in the spring collection of custom order designs presented yesterday by Sally Milgrim. Slim and full-skirted silhouettes were shown, the slender line taking over the suit and daytime picture, fabric being used generously in full-skirted gowns for evening.

CHICAGO, March 6--Wheat developed independent strength as the result of aggressive buying of the May contract attributed to a professional trader and exporters, and that delivery, as well as the March and December, sold at a new seasonal high on the Board of Trade today, closing trades being 1 to 2 cents a bushel higher.

Charles H. Studin, an attorney, died Sunday evening in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. His age was 73.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Patricia Ann Williams, daughter of Mrs. Whitenack Williams of Larchmont, N. Y., and Harold Williams of New York, to Dr. Guido A. De Blasio, Son of Mr. and Mrs. Carmine De Blasio of Mount Vernon, N. Y.

Asserting that "it's about time that we stopped clip joints in our town from beating up customers," Magistrate Hyman Bushel yesterday freed a defendant brought into Mid-Manhattan Court by a midtown dance hall.

American Gas and Electric Corporation has elected three new directors, the company has announced. They are E.D. Dougherty, manager of the Portsmouth division of the Ohio Power Company; J.P. Gills, manager of the Bluefield division of the Appalachian Electric Power Company;...

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 6--New York's new expressways will soon bring so much additional traffic into Westchester that the county will be atop a "triple crater volcano," the Board of Supervisors was told this afternoon at an unprecedented meeting addressed by planning, engineering and parkway officials.

MONTREAL, March 6 (Canadian Press)--John Joe Barry of Ireland and Villanova College tonight won the Canadian Legion Mile in the slow time of 4:19.1. Horace Ashenfelter of Penn State was second and Bob Weaver of Syracuse third. F. Schoeffler of Tufts College was last in the fourman field.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 6 (AP) --Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in a forty-five-minute speech today called on his Chinese Nationalists to win the civil war or perish.

TOKYO, March 1--The Japanese shipping industry is seeking permission to send a technical mission to the United States to study methods of reducing shipbuilding costs. The action is based on the Japanese hope of capturing a larger share of the international shipbuilding market into which Japan has re-entered with some success since the surrender.
Duane F. Kuntz has been named Eastern regional manager of the motor truck division of International Harvester. He formerly was district manager of the motor truck district in Minneapolis.
Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., has instituted coast-tocoast daytime air coach service. The one-way fare is $110, plus tax of $16.50.

Dealers in produce refuse to accept potatoes from the Government as a gift. Potatoes are being dyed to prevent their utilization for any purpose but that of fertilizing the soil or of feeding livestock; yet Canadian potatoes are unloaded at Southern ports at prices less than those charged for our own product.

Stockholders of Colt's Manufacturing Company, at a special meeting on March 29 at Hartford, Conn., will vote on a proposal to authorize directors to buy or otherwise acquire outstanding shares of the capital stock of the company, and to hold, sell, exchange, transfer or retire these shares at the directors' discretion.

A new color television system, designed by DuMont for industrial and scientific use only on "closed circuits" such as wires or cables, and not for broadcasting to homes, was demonstrated yesterday at the annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- Martin A. Hutchinson, a lawyer of Richmond, Va., was nominated by President Truman today for membership in the Federal Trade Commission to fill the unexpired term of the late Ewin Lamar Davis, who died last fall.

Important new acquisitions of rare books, manuscripts and watercolors by the Pierpont Morgan Library, 33 East Thirty-sixth Street, were announced last night at the first annual meeting of the library's fellows.
BUENOS AIRES, March 6-- President Juan Peron and Senora Peron are electioneering these days as industriously as if they themselves were candidates.
The furore aroused at the University of California over a requirement that all of its employes take a special loyalty oath reflects the dilemma imposed by the Communist problem in a free society.
ABOARD TRANSPORT GENERAL BUTNER, San Juan, P.R., March 6--Operation Portrex, the largest amphibious exercise ever held by our armed forces in peace

Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service, Inc., has been elected president of the Technical Valuation Society, Inc., a national organization of enbineers and appraisers. Arthur Eckstein was elected vice president.
LONDON, March 6--The state opening of Parliament, with all its ancient splendor, provided the British people today with one of those ceremonials they like so much.

In what was described as a precedent-setting legal action, three Special Sessions justices yesterday unanimously convicted Max Stark, 45-year-old gambler, and another man of conspiring in this state to violate the New Jersey gambling laws.

The home cannot do all that is necessary in sex education of children, Dr. Lester F. Beck of the Department of Psychology, University of Oregon, said yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 --Yogi Berra, the Yankees' doughty catcher, who flew in from St. Louis in the hope of settling his salary differences with General Manager George M. Weiss, may have made the trip in vain.

Looking to a reversal of the upward trend of its debt ratio, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that more than half of its $394,372,900 convertible debenture offering of last May--the largest corporate financing in history--had been converted into stock in the six months since the conversion privilege began on Sept. 1.

Most Army and Navy men stationed in or near New York wear civilian clothes while off duty to guard against annoyances in the city's streets, it was learned yesterday. One estimate was that 95 per cent of all service men here did not wear their uniforms in public while off duty.
WASHINGTON, March 6--Offerings of stock and bonds registered by business concerns with the Securities and Exchange Commission during the year ended last June 30 totaled $5,333,362,000.

WASHINGTON, March 6--The Democratic leadership of the Senate, caught flatfooted by an unexpected midafternoon motion for an overnight recess, charged today that a filibuster was under way to block liberalization of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948.

In a purchase for investment, Irving Maidman has acquired the twenty-five story Candler Building at 220-224 West Forty-second Street, the Harris Theatre at 223229 West Forty-first Street, extending through to 226 West Forty-second Street, and the adjoining five-story building at 218 West Forty-second Street.

Numerous Belgian manufacturers are showing interest in plans for making American products in Belgium under licensing arrangements with United States...
A talented young pianist made her debut in Town Hall last night. She was Sonia Vargas, who was born in Peru and, according to the program notes, first appeared in public at the age of 6.

The city school system is "concerned" over the effects of television on school children and believes the situation is "serious," Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday.

Final plans to raise $10,000 for Casa Verdi, a home for aged musicians founded in Milan by the composer Giuseppe Verdi, were completed yesterday in the home of Mrs. Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, chairman of a committee for the charity.

WASHINGTON, March 6--The Cook Coffee Company, Cleveland, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 101,250 shares of no-par value common stock to be sold by a group of stockholders.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 6--A return visit to the wondrous Dodger baseball factory here is very much like seeing a giraffe for the second time. It no longer seems as preposterous or as implausible as it did on the first occasion.

CHICAGO, March 6--Hopes that the great Lincoln collection made by Oliver R. Barrett, who died Sunday, would be sold intact to the Library of Congress were expressed today by leading Lincoln authorities of Chicago.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular yesterday, and closed 9 points higher to 9 points lower.
The appearance of Blanche Thebom as Marfa in the third performance of Mussorgsky's "Khovanchina" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House was of distinct benefit to the opera and to the cast.

ATHENS, Wednesday, March 8 --The Populist party maintained and at times increased its lead in the national election during another day of toil and turmoil in votecounting establishments yesterday.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, March 7 (Reuters)--This year's ninetyfirst Shakespeare festival at Stratford-on-Avon, opening Thursday, not only will be the longest of the series, but it will be remembered for the first visit to the new Memorial Theatre by a king and queen of England. The theatre was opened by the Prince of Wales in 1932.
The New York division of the United Jewish Appeal began its 1950 campaign yesterday with gifts totaling $5,925,000 from 600 business and community leaders at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 7-- The principal phases of the sub marine and anti-submarine operations ended today as more than 150 ships of the invasion fleet passed through Mona Passage and concentrated off the beaches of Vieques.

Mayor O'Dwyer reiterated yesterday a statement of city policy he and other members of the Board of Estimate endorsed in 1947 to the effect that no bus terminal construction or reconstruction would be approved in the area between Eighth and Lexington Avenues, Twenty-second and Fifty-ninth Streets.
The Benjamin Franklin and James Monroe High School basketball teams were victors yesterday in the first round of the P.S.A.L. championship play-off series at Madison Square Garden.

Senator Tydings has introduced a resolution in the Senate requesting the United Nations to call a world conference to be devoted exclusively to the question of general disarmament. Mr. Tydings must hope that a special effort of this kind would succeed where the ordinary machinery of the U.N. has ...

A year--almost to the day--after they were arrested on a New York street, Judith Coplon and Valentin Gubitchev have been found by a jury to be guilty of attempted espionage. Thus the second chapter of the Coplon case ends as unhappily for both defendants as did the first for Miss Cop- ...
Dr. Frederick A. Goetze, treasurer of Columbia University for thirty-two years before he retired in 1948, died yesterday morning in Venice, Fla. His age was 79.

Announcement from New Haven that Yale would meet Southern California and Michigan State in a triangular meet at Los Angeles on April 29 supplemented miscellaneous information on the waning indoor season disseminated at the final winter luncheon of the Track Writers Association at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

LONDON, March 7 (AP)--Dick Button of Englewood, N.J., calmly parked his chewing gum at the judges stand tonight, then turned and twisted his way to his third straight men's world figure skating championship.

One of the principal Republican supporters of President Truman's Point Four program told prospective recipient countries last night that it was not a "give-away" scheme and that its success depended on how recipients acted to attract private capital.
