Daniel Frisch, president of the Zionist Organization of America, the most influential body in the General Zionist movement, died early yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, where he had undergone an operation on Monday. He was 52 years old. His home was at 300 Central Park West.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)--Following is the 261-110 vote by which the House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill to make Hawaii a state:

LAKE SUCCESS, March 7--A spokesman for Trygve Lie. Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that "Mr. Gubitchev's position in the Secretariat will now be considered in the light of the results of the trial."

The Museum of Modern Art will open to the public today a retrospective exhibition of the work of Charles Demuth (1883-1935)--a selection of 137 water-colors, eleven oils and as many temperas and several drawings. It is sufficient tribute to both the artist and the museum to record at once there isn't a dull spot in the show.

Bradley (27-3), Kentucky (254), Duquesne (22-3) and St. John's (22-4) were seeded in that order yesterday and the draw was made for the thirteenth annual national invitation college basketball tournament, which gets under way at Madison Square Garden Saturday afternoon.

BERLIN, March 7 (Reuters)-- Plans to grant dismantling concessions to the Germans have been scrapped by Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British High Commissioner, because of yesterday's anti-dismantling riots in Watenstedt-Salzgitter.

Prices of coffee futures declined sharply yesterday in active trading. With producing interests and commission houses engaging in strong selling, opening prices on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange were 54 to 156 points under Monday's final levels.
How sharply oil and natural gas have been cutting into the market for coal in recent months was indicated by a study yesterday.

BERLIN, March 7--Describing the Berlin economic situation as unsatisfactory, Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British High Commissioner, proclaimed today it was long past time for other countries as well as Western Germany to realize that the support of West Berlin was also their responsibility.

Joseph P. Kennedy, United States Ambassador to Britain during the surrender of Belgium in 1940, and James M. Landis, former dean of Harvard Law School, have written an article, digested below, reporting an investigation of the surrender. On March 12 the Belgians will vote on the return of Leopold III to the throne.

From that part of the countryside which, at long last, finally had it, the snow again is disappearing. Up in the Catskills, it is trickling off to give shaving water to bearded, although insufficiently worried, New Yorkers.

WASHINGTON, March 7--John L. Lewis mailed back to Philip Murray today a $500,000 gift check with thanks and a proposal that their two unions, and possibly others, enter a "mutal aid pact for common defense."

A 34-year-old Baptist minister, who less than a year ago was paralyzed from the neck down as the result of a swimming accident, will preach his first "full dress" sermon on Sunday at the Creston Avenue Baptist Church, 114 East 188th Street, the Bronx.

George Gillette, 39-year-old brother-in-law of Joe Adonis, Brooklyn gambler was sentenced yesterday to twenty years imprisonment and was fined $20,000 for his part in a travelers' check counterfeiting ring.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 7--Peewee Reese is the Grand Old Man of the Dodgers and he is about to begin his eleventh season with the Brooks. But he's the only one who outranks in seniority two chaps who are about to start their seventh campaign in Flatbush uniforms, Eddie Miksis and Tommy Brown. Miksis now is an ancient 23 years of age and Brown an even more decrepit 22.
John David Provoo, 33-year-old former United States Army sergeant, attempted yesterday to plead guilty to charges of dealing treasonably with the Japanese in time of war.

WASHINGTON, March 7--The Province of Alberta, Canada, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering $61,000,000 of debentures due March 1, 1968, through 1973.
Mayor O'Dwyer described himself yesterday as a city manager-- and a good one--and said that he intended to remain just that for the rest of his term.

ROME, March 7--Relations between Italy and Yugoslavia became tenser today when news reached Rome that a young Italian shipowner had been killed on board his own fishing vessel by an officer of the Yugoslav Coast Guard well outside Yugoslav territorial waters.
New issues by public utility companies of mortgage bonds and preferred stock valued at $45,000,000 will be offered to investors here today by underwriting syndicates. The offerings are:

Wide-eyed youngsters in the kindergarten of the Children's Aid Society's Jones Memorial Center, 405 East Seventy-third Street, received valuable pointers in art yesterday in a demonstra tion by their "elders" who had been distinguished by the center as its "painters of the year."
Private homes were among properties on the East Side that passed to new control in sales reported yesterday.
Eighty-thousand New Jersey commuters are affected by the new fares announced yesterday.

Whisky Consumption Shown A new presentation showing state-by-state variations in bonded whisky consumption on a per-capita basis was announced yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

CHICAGO, March 7--President Truman today hailed the achievement in farm electrification of the Rural Electrification Administration program as "an ideal demonstration" of cooperation between government and the people "in solving pressing economic problems."

A new blood test to improve the diagnosis and treatment of tuberculosis was described for the first time last night at a scientific session of the annual conference of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association. The session was held at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

Jackson Vitrified China Company yesterday introduced a new line made with the acid incrustation method of chinaware manufacture, which it contends is priced 50 to 75 per cent below comparable merchandise at retail. The line was shown at a press and dealer preview in the Park Lane Hotel.

Yesterday was moving day for John Grimaldi, a 24-year-old Navy veteran, his wife and their four children, who exchanged a room in a basement for a modern fiveroom apartment in the new Lester W. Patterson Houses, first lowrent development constructed in the Bronx since the war.

ALBANY, March 7--The Senate unanimously approved today a bill introduced by Senator MacNeil Mitchell, Republican of Manhattan, to implement the Constitutional amendment on veterans preference in civil service. The amendment was approved by the voters last November.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)-- Repeal of all Federal taxes on oleomargarine, which date back sixtyfour years, was voted finally by the House today, 262 to 106. Quick Senate approval is expected to send the measure to the White House.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 7-- Nine hundred members of the Academic Senate of the University of California refused by unanimous vote tonight to accept a special non-Communist oath which the Board of Regents had demanded they sign by April 30 or face dismissal.

WASHINGTON, March 7--The charge that Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat-Liberal of New York, resorted to "deliberate untruth" in answering attacks on the Displaced Persons program was heard in the Senate today as hope disappeared for an early vote on liberalizing the program.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7-- Princeton concluded its home season tonight with an impressive 63-49 victory over Georgetown before 2,500 fans in Dillon Gymnasium. It was the ninth-straight triumph for the Tigers, who have already clinched the Eastern League championship.

WASHINGTON, March 7--The Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report split along party lines today as a majority approved findings that last December's steel price increase was unwarranted and proposed that the industry be required to give thirtyday public notice of future rises.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7--Dr. Emory R. Johnson, Emeritus Professor of Transportation at the University of Pennsylvania, where he was dean of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce for fourteen years, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness. His age was 85.

Lewis Wolfe, a convicted murderer with a polished courtroom manner, spent an hour and a half in Kings County Court yesterday cross-examining two psychiatrists. He was attempting to prove that he was not insane but legally eligible for a first-degree murder sentence that would almost certainly send him to the electric chair.

Madison Square Garden, where C.C.N.Y. and N.Y.U. clashed last night for the thirty-sixth time since 1914, was no place for weak hearts, high blood pressures or nervous stomachs. As figured, City College conquered the Violets, 64--61, evening the traditional court rivalry at eighteen games each.

ALBANY, March 7--Administration-sponsored bills providing state aid for libraries were approved today by the Senate Finance and Assembly Ways and Means Committees with an amendment reducing the first year's appropriation from $3,000,000 to $1,000,000.

Theatregoers will receive another opportunity to see "A Streetcar Named Desire"--at bargain prices, this time, at the City Center from May 23 through June 4. For the occasion, a special troupe is being organized by Irene Selznick, sponsor of the dual winner of the Pulitzer and Critics Circle prizes.

Individuals who are interested in custom-made furnishings but do not trust themselves to judge final results from the usual sketches or renderings may now see some completed luxurious furnishings of this type.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7--With Dan Topping in town and hovering in the background and Casey Stengel twice acting as intermediary, the Yankees today slashed their holdout ranks in half by signing what probably will be their opening-day battery.

Legislation to preserve New York's centers of historic, artistic or cultural interest was proposed last night before the Greenwich Village Association by Francis Keally, president of the Municipal Art Society. At the meeting in Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, he pointed to such laws in Charleston, S.C., Alexandria, Va., and New Orleans.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 7--Dr. Eberhard Rotberg, a spokesman for the Ministry of Justice in Bonn, outlined today a proposed law that would make warmongering punishable and would protect conscientious objectors against recruitment in any army.

Universal-International will produce thirty-six feature films during the coming year and Warner Brothers has twenty scripts in various stages for production within the next four months, it was announced yesterday by the companies.

As if a handsomely decorated new abode, located at 410 Park Avenue, at Fifty-fifth Street, were not enough to open for one afternoon. Mme. Aranka, milliner, also announced yesterday that she had just become the sole New York agent for Mme. Suzy of Paris.

CHICAGO, March 7--A fivepoint program aimed at mobilizing United States public opinion behind a movement to persuade the Government to mint a 2 cent and a 7 cent coin was endorsed unanimously today by 350 delegates attending the first national convention of the Music Operators of America.

Plans have been completed by Miss Harriet W. Chapman, daughter of Gilbert W. Chapman of Cedarhurst, L.I., and the late Mrs. Chapman, for her marriage on April 15 to Henry Worthington Kalt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Kalt of Pelham Manor, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- George V. Robbins, coffee buyer for the General Foods Corporation, today told a Senate investigating committee that there was a shortage in the world's coffee supply and the shortage would continue until September, 1951.

Joseph Magalhaes, operator of a bar and grill in the three-store dwelling on lot 20 by 90 feet at 75 Seventh Avenue, between Fourteenth and Fifteenth Streets, bought the property from the John Hassett Hayes Estate in a deal reported yesterday by the Kempner Realty Corporation, broker.

The state visit of the President of the French Republic to London is the occasion for one of those displays of royal pageantry which the British do so well and enjoy so thoroughly. The King's speech at the opening of Parliament was in keeping with the gray mood of the deadlocked assembly, but ...

The Ballet Theatre will celebrate its tenth anniversary by returning to the Center Theatre in Rockefeller Center for a three-week season beginning April 23. It was in this theatre, currently occupied by "Howdy, Mr. Ice," that it made its first appearance on Jan. 11, 1940.

Firm prices, with reports of increases on some types of leathers, marked the opening yesterday of the fall and winter leather show sponsored by the Tanners Council of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 7--Rear Admiral Joel T. Boone, senior medical man in the Office of the Secretary of Defense, who today told the House Armed Services Committee that he had criticized Secretary Louis Johnson's cutback of the military hospital program, has been transferred from his post.

Two hundred and fifty priests from parishes in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York met yesterday morning at Cathedral Girls High School, Lexington Avenue, to plan for the annual drive of Catholic Charities, which starts April 23.

TOKYO, March 7--Japanese trade unions today launched their long-threatened "labor offensive" for a new round of wage increases in opposition to the Government's policy of disinflation, which was demanded by the Occupation.

ROME, March 7--Italy and France this evening signed several agreements to facilitate the interchange of goods and services. The agreements are regarded as steps toward a customs union that eventually will integrate the economies of the two countries.

New defense procurement services here enable New York plants to get more orders at lower cost. Two branches of the Armed Services said yesterday that prospective contractors can get complete information here about sales opportunities throughout the country in both arsenals and Air Force procurement. Information staffs are expanded, Data sheets are improved. Bidders can compile proposals at large savings of expenses formerly required for travel.

One of the best demonstrations of the benefits bestowed upon European countries by the Marshall Plan has been provided in Italy. Thanks in large part to American aid under that Plan, Italy has long since recovered from the chaos that followed the wartime collapse.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 7 (AP)--Joe Culmone, a 19-year-old apprentice, stole the riding show today at Gulfstream Park by winning with four of his eigtht mounts.

Two new films will open in firstrun, theatres this morning. At Loew's State, the attraction is "The Outriders," a Metro-GoldwynMayer Western in Technicolor, starring Joel McCrea. Arlene Dahl, Barry Sullivan, James Whitmore, Claude Jarman Jr. and Ramon Novarro are among the principals in the offering, which was directed by Roy Rowland and produced by Richard Goldstone from a story and screen play by Irving Ravetch.

In the absence of Cardinal Spellman, Msgr. John S. Middleton, New York Archdiocesan Secretary for Education, denounced yesterday the attack made Monday on Cardinal Spellman and the Roman Catholic Church. He said that the position of the Catholic hierarchy and the Cardinal had been misrepresented.

WASHINGTON, March 7--A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the Marine Cooks and Stewards, C.I.O., violated the TaftHartley Act by instructing members to refuse to sail on any ship employing a certain seaman who had been expelled by the union.

The campaign for the next British general election has already started with the Conservative challenge to the weakened Labor Government on the issues of the nationalization of steel and housing. This is not so much a move to overthrow the Government as one designed to make it less popular.

The State of Tennessee sold yesterday an issue of $1l,150,000 of bonds maturing March 15 from 1955 to 1960 to a banking syndicate headed by National City Bank at an interest cost of 1.4098 per cent. The winning bid designated interest coupons of 3 per cent, 1 per cent and 1 per cent.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 7--Fearful that the projected $400,000,000 New York-Buffalo Thruway for mixed traffic would be an objectionable neighbor, the Greenville Community Council of Greenburgh Township asked Westchester County officials today to prevent the superhighway from utilizing Central Avenue in Greenville.

ATHENS, March 7--A definite liberalization of Greece's internal policy with possible repercussions in the field of foreign affairs appeared likely tonight if, as is widely expected, a center coalition government is formed.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 7--Offices of the United States Embassy in Prague were this morning the only ones in Czechoslovakia closed in honor of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, first president of the Czechoslovak Republic.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 7-- Rex Barney, the Dodgers' problem pitcher, was unveiled in the final two innings of a 4-2 loss to the Fort Worth farm club today.

Plans to erect in the Philippines an eight-and-a-half foot copy of the Statue of Liberty were announced yesterday at a ceremony in the office of Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, chief of the Philippine Mission to the United Nations, in the Empire State Building.

WASHINGTON, March 7--Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations has intervened with the United States, Soviet Russia, Britain, France and several other nations in an effort to break the United Nations deadlock over China.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 7--The Cabinet of the Western German Federal Republic considered today the presentation of a formal protest against the FrenchSaar economic pact to the Western Allied High Commission at its meeting Thursday.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)-- A high Government official told a House committee today the Administration is opposed to a high tariff on oil imports.

GENEVA, March 7--There is serious danger that the movement toward the liberalization of trade in Europe may be reversed before it has gone any farther toward the ideal of economic integration to which the United States attaches so much importance.

Economic life in the United States is returning to its normal ways. The railroad trains are getting back on schedule. The steel industry is recalling its furloughed workers. And the lights on Broadway have been turned up again.

Two new marvels of the world of electronics--a super-power vacuum tube capable of generating more than a half-million watts of radio power for transoceanic operation and a miniature, but highly effective eight-pound television pick-up camera for industrial uses--were officially unveiled yesterday at the 1950 annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

WASHINGTON, March 7--Former President Herbert Hoover went before a Senate committee today to voice a personal plea for "vast and energetic reform" of the Government's accounting set-up, as recommended by his Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch.

WASHINGTON, March 7-- Powerful efforts to put a military man on the presently all-civilian Atomic Energy Commission, the controlling agency over all weapons in the atomic-hydrogen field, were opened today in Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7--Dr. Eldridge Lyon Eliason, emeritus professor of surgery at the medical school of the University of Pennsylvania, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital, after a brief illness, at the age of 70.

LONDON, March 7--Tass, official Soviet news agency, said tonight that Dr. Klaus Fuchs, British scientist sentenced in London last Wednesday to fourteen years' imprisonment, had lied in saying he betrayed atomic secrets to the Soviet Union.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 7--The Czechoslovak Government this afternoon expelled three of the four diplomats on the staff of the Netherlands Legation. It ordered them to leave "within the shortest possible time--at most within eight days."
PARIS, Wednesday, March 8-- The French National Assembly early today passed the Government's anti-sabotage bill after a wild fist-swinging brawl provoked by Communist taunts.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 7 (AP)--Various fishermen and newspapers today demanded naval escorts to protect Swedish fishing boats from seizure by Soviet authorities.

DETROIT, March 7--A $200-amonth pension within ten years is the goal of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., striking Chrysler Corporation employes were told today by Walter P. Reuther, the international president of their union.

The Rev. Dr. Burton Scott Easton, professor emeritus of the literature and interpretation of the New Testament at the General Theological Seminary for the last two years, died early yesterday in St. Barnabas Hospital of a cardiac ailment after a long illness. His age was 72.

Plans for establishment by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation of the first passenger automobile assembly plant in Israel were disclosed here yesterday by Arthur Lourie, Consul General of Israel, and Edgar F. Kaiser, president of the American automotive company.

Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder told American business men last night that Governmentrecommended changes in the tax structure "should be a major factor" in swelling the present trickle of American private capital abroad under President Truman's Point Four program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 --Twentieth Century-Fox today announced the engagement of Bette Davis to star in "All About Eve," a photoplay dealing with the career of a famous Broadway actress, which Joseph Mankiewicz has written from a radio play by Mary Orr. Mankiewicz will direct the film, and Darryl F. Zanuck, Fox production chief, will produce the picture personally. The cast also will include Anne Baxter and George Sanders.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 7 --Dr. Richard Ford, acting head of the Department of Legal Medicine at Harvard Medical School, testified as a defense expert in the "mercy killing trial" today that in his opinion air injections did not cause the death of Mrs. Abbie C. Borroto.
WASHINGTON, March 7--President Truman asked Congress today to set up as soon as possible a commission to recommend solutions for the basic problems of the coal industry.

Of the 1,000 wildfowlers who replied to the annual questionnaire submitted by Ducks Unlimited, 70 per cent reported having seen more geese last season than during the previous season, and 58 per cent reported seeing more ducks.

Reports from abroad about the construction of new passenger tonnage for the Swedish American Line and the Holland-America Line gained further credence yesterday with the sudden departure by plane for Sweden of G. Hilmer Lundbeck Jr., managing director of the Swedish company.

WASHINGTON, March 7--Representative Mary T. Norton, Democrat of New Jersey, a member of the House for twenty-five years, announced today she would not seek re-election.

LONDON, March 7--Before an almost evenly divided House of Commons today Winston Churchill, Conservative party leader, laid down the terms on which his followers could live together with an ideologically opposed Government until the nation's business was carried out.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7-- Whether the Giants have a pennant winner, or even a flag contender, only the future will decide. There are teams like the Cardinals, Dodgers and perhaps the hitherto lowly Phillies that may have some influence on this point, but Manager Leo Durocher is satisfied with the transition a few changes have wrought.

LONDON, March 7 (UP)--The Sofia trial of five Bulgarians accused of spying for the United States turned today into an attempt by the prosecution and the trial judge to refute charges that Communist police torture prisoners.

LONDON, March 7--Within two hours after his arrival in London today with President Vincent Auriol of France, Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, was engaged in a conference with Ernest Bevin, British Foreign Secretary, discussing questions of Germany and security in the Far East. The meeting was the first of a series that the two Ministers will have during the French President's state visit to Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 7--The Administration asked Congress today to authorize another $100,000,000 of aid for the Republic of Korea and warned that without it there was no hope of its survival as a symbol of liberty in an area threatened by aggressive communism.

JERUSALEM, March 7--The Israeli Government will offer to extend the British-registered concession of Palestine Potash, Ltd., for exploitation of Dead Sea mineral resources on condition that the company is reorganized and converted virtually into an Israeli enterprise.

Spring apparel which has been lagging far behind home furnishings in store sales here during recent weeks is beginning to "show signs of life" a check of local stores disclosed yesterday. Main credit for the sales increases was given to slightly milder weather and the approach of Easter, although it was also recognized that other factors have made their influences felt.
WASHINGTON, March 7--The Interstate Commerce Commission today permitted six railroads and a ferry serving the New YorkNew Jersey commutation area to increase fares.

The composure exhibited by the stock market during the last stages of the soft-coal strike was completely shattered yesterday. Complacency over the after-effects of the fuel shortage gave way to the usual realistic appraisals, and the market indicated its wariness over the near-term outlook. The reaction centered in the heavy industrial issues--those closely attuned to the coal industry--and produced the second widest drop of the year in prices.
A bilingual ceremony that fostered a literal monument to Franco-American friendship was held yesterday in the cultural division of the French Embassy at 934 Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, March 7--In a surprise move, Republican-controlled fiscal committees of the Senate and Assembly approved a plan for cutting the special New York City, Nassau and Saratoga County taxes on horse race betting pools by 80 per cent over a period of five years.

The huge radio-electronics program in the country's armed forces laboratories was emphasized yesterday with demonstrations at Grand Central Palace and the Commodore Hotel as the 1950 convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers ended. PARIS, March 9--Housewives in Paris and most other French cities had a difficult time preparing meals today because of a drop in the gas pressure, and many streets were thrown into darkness as the strike in the national gas industry called at midnight last night took its effect.

The Florida pink shrimp, mentioned in this column last Friday, continue to arrive. A shipment of 50,000 pounds reached here yesterday, according to the Fishery Council, which lists them as one of the most plentiful varieties now in the stores. They're about 85 cents a pound.

The stock market was subjected to new pressure yesterday, but the selling never became insistent and slackened after the opening rush. An attempt to recoup the initial losses also lacked force and final prices were midway between the lows and highs, with the composite rate down 0.21 on the day.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Administration said today it was buying $4,210,750 worth of radar-type equipment to inform pilots continuously of their distance from a radio range.

PARIS, March 10 (AP)--Garry Davis, who renounced his United States citizenship to become "world citizen number one," today received permission to enter his homeland as an immigrant. If he remains in the United States he can become a citizen after required residence like any other immigrant.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP)-- Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, called on the State Department today to ask Great Britain to halt shipments of arms to the Arab nations. He told the Senate that Britain had resumed arms shipments to the Arabs since the United Nations Security Council had lifted its arms embargo to the Near East.

WASHINGTON, March 10--The Administration's middle-income housing program went before the Senate today and immediately ran into opposition of sufficient strength to force a close test when voting begins.

Francis I. Curtis has set back until next fall his production of "We Sing of Lydia Pinkham," formerly called "Lydia Pinkham Is Her Name." The necessity for script revisions was given as the reason for the delay.

COUNT the week lost that sees no new books about Shakespeare and the Elizabethan days. PETERSBURG, Ill., March 10 (UP)--Edgar Lee Masters, the poet, was buried today in the Oakland Cemetery that inspired his bestloved work, "Spoon River Anthology." Earlier a funeral service was held for the onetime partner of the noted criminal lawyer, Clarence Darrow.
LONDON, March 10--Business was meager on the stock exchange here today. Prices were not adequately tested and moved narrowly and irregularly, with a tendency to drift lower.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Union, C. I. O., requested President Truman yesterday to seize and operate American Airlines whose 4,600 maintenance and stores employes have been on strike for ten days.

HONG KONG, Saturday, March 11 (UP)--The Chinese Communist radio charged early today that French planes from Indo-China had violated Chinese territory, killing one person and injuring, another in strafing attacks, on three villages in Kwangsi Province.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)-- Representative Mary Norton, Democrat of New Jersey is "getting along very well" after a re cent attack of influenza, her office reported today. She has recovered enough to sit up for a short time each day. Mrs. Norton is at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center.
Plans to sponsor a research study dealing with important phases of the apparel habits of boys have been completed by the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10-- President Truman is taking virtually his whole "kitchen cabinet" on his trip to Key West, Fla., on Sunday.

The snake found wrapped around a riser pipe near a radiator Thursday night in the home of Eugene Lever at 54 Barrow Street in Greenwich Village was identified yesterday in the Manhattan Shelter of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals as an Eastern Milk Snake.

Rocky Graziano, former middleweight champion of the world, signed yesterday to meet Tony Janiro of Youngstown, Ohio, at Madison Square Garden on March 31. The battle is scheduled for ten rounds.
SINGAPORE, March 10 (Reuters) --Malaya's "anti-bandit month," which began on Feb. 26, is proving "an extraordinary success," it was officially reported today.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 10 (AP)-- Fred Cockrell, president of the Atlanta (Ga.) Cotton Excange, suffered a stroke in the lobby of the Shamrock Hotel about 3 P.M. (C.S.T.) today. Dr. C.A. Dwyer, physician at McCarthy Center, said Mr. Cockrell's condition was serious, Mr. Cockrell was in Houston to attend the Texas Cotton Association convention.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 10 (AP)--Eddie Waitkus banged three hits, one of them a double, to lead Dusty Cooke's side to a 10-8 victory over Benny Bengough's team in the Phillies intrasquad game today.

GENEVA, March 10--Europeans sometimes despair of ever being able to earn their dollars honestly by selling a good product at a good price in the United States market.

President Auriol went beyond the polite conventions of a social visit in his address before a joint session of the British Parliament. Ordinarily the President of France does not discuss live political issues in public.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture said today the winter wheat crop has escaped serious damage so far from recent soil blowing and dust storms in the Great Plains.

Sean O'Faolain, most versatile and prolific of contemporary Irish authors, will have a new book published by Devin-Adair on April 18. "A Summer in Italy" is based upon Mr. O'Faolain's travels there in the summer of 1948 and is about other matters than Italy.

The world's largest producer of motor vehicles reported yesterday that its earnings last year amounted to $656,434,232, an increase of 49 per cent over its 1948 total, the previous peak.
Carl Fisher Hall was filled to capacity last night for the third of a series of four "Programs of Contemporary Music" offered by the League of Composers in cooperation with various music publishers.
Several carpet mills that have not yet put a third round of price increases into effect will do so soon, company representatives reported yesterday.

The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to bring outdoor movies under its jurisdiction. The commissioners held this step was needed to avert serious traffic congestion and to protect the health and general welfare of the people of the city.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 13-- The Red Sox may still be guilty of a deal of lefthanded thinking and base running, but there was no denying the power in Ted Williams' mighty bat today.

Medals were awarded yesterday in the office of Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle to two firemen who last Aug. 4 dived into the Harlem River and rescued a would-be suicide in spite of his efforts to assault them. Two other firemen also received life saving medals.

A scheduled appearance by Paul Robeson on Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's television program has been "indefinitely postponed" and probably will be canceled, the National Broadcasting Company said last night.

And not time-taking creations either, but desserts that may be done with dispatch; and that are delicious, too.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15 (AP)--Alice Stone Blackwell, internationally known women's suffrage leader, died tonight at her home after a week's illness. Her age was 92.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)-- John McCarthy, chairman of the Michigan Public Service Commission, asserted today that the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company was trying to "skim off the cream" in his state's natural gas markets.

WASHINGTON, March 15--Ugo Carusi, chairman of the Displaced persons Commission, told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that immigrants reaching the United States under the commission's auspices were screened more carefully than those reaching the country under the ordinary immigration law.

NEW DELHI, India, March 15 --India has declined an invitation by Philippine President Elpidio Quirino to a conference of South and Southeast Asian countries on measures to meet the Communist menace to a free Asia.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 1,076,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 135,284,000 barrels, a new peak, compared with 134,208,000 a week earlier and 126,188,000 a year ago.

DALAT, Indo-China, March 13-- Former Emperor Bao Dai, Chief of State of Viet Nam, discounted possibilities of Titoist tendencies on the part of Viet Minh leader Ho Chi Minh in an interview with this correspondent at his mountain resort headquarters here.

Consolidated net income of the $429,000,000 North American Company, a major utility that is nearing completion of a twelve-year divestment program, amounted to $15,076,825, equal to $1.76 a share, compared with $15,814,519, or $1.84 a share in 1948.

A syndicate owning the blockfront on the east side of Madison Avenue between Eighty-first and Eighty-second Streets yesterday announced the awarding of a contract to the Paul Tishman Company, general contractors, of New York, for construction work on a luxury apartment house to accommodate 317 families and to cost about $6,500,000.

Frank W. Chambers, New York attorney and an alumni trustee of Columbia University, died of a heart attack yesterday in St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach, Fla., where he had been on a vacation, according to word received here. His age was 65.

HILLSDALE, Mich., March 15-- Fifteen major Protestant denominations have had an average membership gain of 36 per cent in the last twenty-five years, it has been announced here by the United Stewardship Council.

While obligated to grant tax concessions on certain housing projects where commitments have been made, the city in future should allow such benefits only where slum clearance is involved and the incomes of prospective residents do not exceed $4,200 annually, Borough President Maurice A. FitzGerald of Queens declared yesterday.

JERUSALEM, March 15--The issue of education of religious children in immigrant camps, which has been the cause of a Cabinet crisis, has been resolved by a compromise providing for religious schooling in the camps under Government supervision.

ROME, March 15--Ten provinces with about 12 per cent of the total Italian population were paralyzed today by a general strike that the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor called as a protest against the wounding of five workers in a fight with the police at Porto Marghera near Venice yesterday.
GENEVA, March 15--The trade liberalization program in Europe is beginning to yield a strong odor of fish.

The world's largest utility, the billion-dollar Consolidated Edison Company, moved yesterday toward securing the title when the Public Service Commission approved an application to acquire control of the Staten Island Edison Company for $10,720,000.
Valentin A. Gubitchev cleared the way yesterday for his return to the Soviet Union by surrendering his right to appeal from his conviction of conspiracy and attempted espionage.

ALBANY, March 15--Adjournment of the 1950 session of the Legislature next Wednesday was decided upon by legislative leaders today as both houses drove through heavy calendars and disposed of scores of bills.

WASHINGTON, March 15--The Navy cracked down hard tonight on Capt. John G. Crommelin Jr., the Navy officer who, despite a reprimand and several warnings, has kept up a running attack on defense policies. Francis P. Matthews, Secretary of the Navy, ordered Captain Crommelin furloughed ...

LAKE SUCCESS, March 15-- The deadlock in the United Nations over the China question, and the accompanying Soviet walkout, will continue until the United States, Britain and France give smaller countries a definite indication of the policy they intend to follow, a leading delegate predicted today.

The Commercial Credit Company's move to effectuate conversion of its $15,884,500 of outstanding 3.60 per cent preferred stock into common stock will make use both of underwriting and dealermanaged solicitations of conversion during a period ending April 14, it was announced yesterday.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., March 15--The combination of a warm sun and a brisk March breeze sent a shower of ice crashing down today on homes and streets to the leeward of the 760-foot tower of Station WOR-TV, here. Residents were frightened and policemen had to wear air-raid helmets to patrol the area.

LONDON, March 15 (AP)--The United States advanced to the final rounds of the world amateur hockey championship tonight by swamping a polite but defenseless Netherlands team, 17--1, before a crowd of 8,000 at Harringay Arena.

Women are wasting too much energy appraising themselves by others' standards of external success, Mrs. Helen M. Lynd, Professor of Philosophy at Sarah Lawrence College, declared yesterday at the New School, 66 West Twelfth Street.

RED BANK, N.J., March 15-- Six hours of seeing the seamy side of country life--disease, distance, wind and weather--failed to change the minds of five senior nursing students from Presbyterian Hospital in New York about their future careers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 --A deal for George Cukor to di rect the screen version of "Born Yesterday" at Columbia has been completed, and contracts with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Cukor's home studio, have been drawn up to cover the loan-out, it was learned today.

TRENTON, March 15--A utility anti-strike bill, endorsed by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, to maintain state arbitration as a last resort in utility labor-management disputes, passed the New Jersey Senate tonight.
ON THE U.S.S. WILLIAM C. LAWE, March 15--Bright sunshine and smooth blue water made life more carefree today aboard the yacht Williamsburg, taking President Truman to a vacation at Key West, Fla.

ALBANY, March 15--A bill backed by up-state manufacturers that is expected to curtail New York City's income from the gross business tax by more than $1,000,000 was passed in the Senate today and sent to the Assembly. The vote was 32 to 24.
LONDON, March 15 (UP)--A British chef said today that Americans did not know how to cook an omelet and said the French style was the only one fit to eat.

WASHINGTON, March 15--The Senate tonight voted $2,500,000,000 in further incentives for the conistruction of middle income housing, but only after stripping the Administration program of broad assistance sought for housing cooperatives.

WASHINGTON, March 15--John Stewart Service, a career diplomat accused by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of "Communist affiliations," was recalled from India today by the State Department to appear personally in a review of his loyalty record.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 15-- Secretary of State Dean Acheson today warned the Chinese people, on the basis of old friendship, against allowing "their new rulers" to lead them into "aggressive or subversive adventures" beyond China's borders.

William C. MacLaren, an oldtime cracksman whose skill has been the subject of police and safe company testimonials, was arrested last night while picking the lock on the door of the Charles Kellner Real Estate Company office at 55 West Eighty-sixth Street.

The complete alignment of the Eastern United States ski team that is to meet Eastern Canada in their annual international rivalry this week-end at Mount Baldy, Ste. Marguerite, Que., was announced last night by Mrs. Janet Macomber, manager of the American squad.

With Christian Dior, Pierre Balmain and Lucien Lelong among the guests of honor, the Fashion Group, meeting at the Astor Hotel yesterday, heard a report on the recent Paris collections by Jessica Daves, editor of Vogue.
Curt G. Pfeiffer, senior counselor, former president and a founder of the National Council of American Importers, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 79.
Henry E. Perry, president of the Commercial Solvents Corporation, fell to death at 8:20 A.M. yesterday from his fourteenth floor office at 17 East Forty-second Street.
LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 15 --"Put this on the air--over and over and over again."

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)-- Doubt was expressed today by spokesmen for the Maritime Commission whether certain wartime vessels could be moved into the Great Lakes to revive package freight service there.
TAMPA, Fla., March 15 (AP)-- The Reds again used their newly found power hitting to beat the Braves, 7 to 6, today.

Plans for the immediate erection of a one-story taxpayer building were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by the Venture Realty Corporation, Y. Ben-Zeev, president, of a vacant plot at the northeast corner of Boston Post Road and Fenton Avenue, the Bronx.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 15--While observers still debated the meaning of Dr. Vladimir Clementis' resignation, signs multiplied today that a purge announced by Ladislav Kopriva, a member of the Communist Central Committee three weeks ago was gathering momentum in Communist party ministries and economic institutions of all kinds.

WASHINGTON, March 15--By a vote of 368 to 2, the House of Representatives approved today a widespread and drastic toughening up of laws dealing with espionage in this country. The dissenters were Representatives Vito Marcantonio, American Labor party, and Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat, both of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)-- Eighteen cotton-producing states stand to increase their total 1950 cotton acreage allotments by an estimated 1,250,000 acres under the bill approved by a House-Senate conference committee.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15-- Ralph Greenleaf, world's pocket billiards champion seventeen times and one of the game's all-time greats, died this afternoon in a waiting room at Hahnemann Hospital. He was 50 years old.
The cotton futures market yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange moved within a narrow range. Final prices were 3 to 9 points net higher than on Tuesday.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 15-- Jasper McLevy, Socialist mayor of Bridgeport for the last seventeen years, announced today in an interview that he would be a candidate again for Governor on the Socialist ticket this fall. It will be his thirteenth campaign for the governorship.

Charitable and welfare organizations received $16,100,000 from seventy-nine of the 100 largest manufacturing corporations in the United States in 1948, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. In 1947, the board said, the same amount was contributed by seventy-one of the corporations.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 15 (UP)--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said here today she felt many persons "misunderstood" the nature of her television program on which Paul Robeson was to have taken part in a discussion group.

Jerome A. Newman was elected president of the Atlantic Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines and Charles H.C. Pearsall was elected president of the New York, and Cuba Mail Steamship Company at board meetings yesterday.

New leases were announced yesterday in the R.C.A. Building, Rockefeiler Center, involving a rearrangement of floor space and some structural changes to accommodate tenants in the large exhibition hall previously occupied by the Museum of Science and Industry.

Will the national invitation basketball tournament have an allmetropolitan final for the first time in its thirteen-year history? Tonight's semi-finals at Madison Square Garden will supply the answer to this question, which has local court fans in a dither.

A police call to investigate a disturbance at 3 A.M. yesterday in the basement of a building housing a bar and grill resulted in the recovery of the first wire trash basket since a city-wide investigation got under way six weeks ago to track down the disappearance of hundreds of receptacles.

HONG KONG, March 15--The mainland of China is in the grip of the severest famine in seventy-two years. The Communist regime frankly acknowledges that the situation is bad. Peiping radio reports range from 4,000,000 starving in Hopeh Province alone to 16,000,000 starving in North China.

CAIRO, March 15 (AP)--I do not know what tennis clothes I am going to wear at Wimbledon. I am a tennis player. I am going to wear clothes. I can play tennis in--the best tennis I can because I want to win the Wimbledon title more than anything else.
CHICAGO, March 15 (AP)-- Friends of destitute Battling Nelson 67-year-old former world lightweight boxing champion, opened their fight today to obtain a Spanish-American War pension for him.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 15 --Joe DiMaggio, recovered from his blistered heel, joined in the carnage that blistered the Phillies to a crisp brown today.

From Shanghai to Warsaw the noise of slamming doors fills the circumambient air. Spurred by a timetable calling for a beginning of initial rainmaking operations by the end of next week, city water officials moved yesterday to arrange for the selection of meteorological field headquarters in the Catskills and for providing needed equipment.

TOKYO, March 15--Japanese and Chinese Communists have opened a sharp attack on Gen. Douglas MacArthur's policy of paroling top-flight Japanese war criminals. Under this policy, the men held responsible for the Pacific war will be released from imprisonment at Allied discretion after proving good jail behavior.

Creation of 1,000,000 new shares of $100 par value preferred stock by Celanese Corporation of America will be passed upon by stockholders at the company's annual meeting April 12, it was announced yesterday.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15--Wright Field was the wrong field for the Dodgers here today, just as it was last spring, as they collected only four hits in dropping their 1950 opener with Connie Mack's Athletics, 4--1.
Two new pictures will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the attraction is "A Woman of Distinction," a Columbia comedy starring Ray Milland and Rosalind Russell.

A new type of wood panel, which can be produced from waste chips and shavings for 25 to 40 per cent less than the cost of the cheapest fir plywood panel, will be placed on the market by the United States Plywood Corporation this year, Lawrence Ottinger, president, said yesterday.

PARIS, March 15--The National Employers Association through its president, Georges Villier, declared today that satisfying French labor's present wage demands would endanger France's foreign trade. The second of several $1,000 railroad bonds, missing since 1944 and reportedly the property of Mrs. Harriet Feldman when she died the year before under suspicious circumstances, has been offered for redemption, Assistant District Attorney Julius A. Helfand of Kings County said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15--A registration statement covering 100,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company of Houston, Tex.

ALBANY, March 15--The fate of the state administration's residential rent-control bill was placed in doubt today by a threatened revolt of Westchester Republicans. Net income of the Armco Steel Corporation in 1949 amounted to $30,918,202, equal to $7.68 a common share, compared with $32030,712, or $8 a share, in 1948, the company reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders. Net sales last year were $341,350147, against $382,563,811 in 1948.

WASHINGTON, March 15--The difficulties Senator McCarthy is meeting in establishing his charges, even as repeatedly modified, that Communists and fellow-travelers have widely infiltrated the Department of State arise principally from the weakness of much of his evidence.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 15--Miss Helen George Kingsley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman W. Kingsley, was married tonight to Richard Mason Goddard Jr., son of Mr. Goddard and the late Mrs. Goddard, also of Upper Montclair.

Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard said yesterday that steps to be taken by the city to modify the formula on which relief allowances are based would ameliorate to some extent the effects of the cuts imposed earlier this year. But he added that the city was not planning to cancel the cuts.

It took a five-minute overtime period for the New York Knickerbockers to defeat the Boston Celtics, 88 to 84, last night in the local professional quintet's final home appearance of the regular National Basketball Association campaign at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

Meaney.

Blind persons and others handicapped by visual defects will be able to hear readings from important and provocative magazine articles in a weekly series entitled "The Talking Magazine," to be started by WNEW next Monday, from 10 to 10:30 P.M. Stars of Broadway shows will serve as readers.

An all-out drive by the Port of Boston Authority to increase foreign commerce through that port was described here yesterday by John Bresnahan, acting director of the agency.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 19-- Ground will be broken here at Post and Olmstead Roads this week for a new $275,000 public library building financed by private and public funds after years of negotiation.
Edward J. Clark, chief engineer of the Department of Water, Gas and Electricity, yesterday urged conservation of "proper memories" along with water.

TIBERIAS, Israel, March 19-- Israel wants to negotiate a formal peace with all her Arab neighbors as quickly as possible and on a basis of this young nation's present de facto frontiers. She harbors no present or future intention of expanding into adjoining territory.

Frank C. Mawby, formerly sales manager of finished products, has been named department head of bedspreads at Bates Fabrics, Inc., succeeding Paul G. Crommelin, who has retired. Edgar B. Mooney Jr., promotional manager, also will be sales manager.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., March 19--Three hundred residents of this veterans' housing project met today to find out when the first wrecking crews would start tearing down some of their barracks-type homes.

MIAMI, Fla., March 19--Joe McCarthy's battering Bosox were still banging the ball in lively fashion today and with their pitching a trifle more effective than it was yesterday, the Red Sox walloped the Yankees, 10 to 7, before a crowd of 11,782. That put the Sox
LEWISTON, Me., March 19 (AP) --Mrs. Frances Hayes, only daughter and last surviving child of Rutherford B. Hayes, nineteenth President of the United States, died here tonight at the age of 82.
FRESNO, Calif., March 19 (UP)-- A 14-year-old girl shot and killed her identical twin sister with a .22 caliber rifle today soon after they returned home from baby-sitting authorities said.

NEWARK, March 19--Nathan L. Goldstein, Manhattan lawyer and condemnation expert, is scheduled to receive $277,000 from Newark, the result of a verdict in the Port Newark-Navy condemnation case in Federal District Court here Friday.

Municipal issues scheduled for sale this week aggregate $155,766,249, including $25,650,000 temporary loan notes, and compares with $52,463,050 which included $5,385,000 short-term notes for last week, according to yesterday's report of the Daily Bond Buyer of New York.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 19--Moshe Piyade of the Yugoslav Communist Politburo broadened today the attacks on Soviet imperialism that have been a keynote in the current election campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 19--Since the end of World War II this country has experienced a record growth in higher education. During the last two years, for example, more than 150 colleges and universities have been added to the list of recognized institutions of higher learning in the United States Office of Education directory--more than in any comparable period in American history.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., March 19--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ellsworth R. Littler of the engagement of their daughter, Patricia, to William H. Dresser, son of Mrs. Elizabeth J. Dresser of Hartford, Conn., and Dr. Richard Dresser of Boston.

The Texas Company last year had a net consolidated income of $132,745,159 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $9.62 each on the 13,797,624 capital shares outstanding, according to the annual report for 1949, released for publication today.

PATUXENT, Md., March 19-- Navy electronics and air navigation experts said here today that they were convinced, on the basis of experiments now under way, that an all-weather flying system could be evolved for aircraft carriers.
A good demand for small apartment buildings in the East and West Side areas of Manhattan was indicated in sales reported over the week-end.
PARIS, March 19--For the second time the Cabinet tonight postponed a decision upon wage concessions at a moment when the wave of French strikes appeared to be receding.
Five new pictures, including an importation from Italy, are scheduled to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

The steering committee of the Citizens Zoning Committee has adopted a resolution urging Mayor O'Dwyer to approve a budget for the Department of City Planning for 1950-51 sufficient to provide a capable and adequate staff with which to carry out its functions as outlined in the City Charter.

A mother and father in Woodside, Queens, were remanded yesterday to Kings County Hospital for observation after it was charged in Queens Felony Court that they had failed since Feb. 23 to provide proper medical care for a seriously burned 5-year-old daughter.

William Warfield, the baritone who was heard earlier this season in Marc Blitzstein's musical drama "Regina," showed yesterday afternoon in his first New York recital at Town Hall that he is also a highly gifted concert singer. It was an auspicious debut.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP)-- The Government will get an idea tomorrow how far farmers plan to go this year in applying the brakes to an overproductive agricultural machine.

RANGOON, Burma, March 6-- A marriage of convenience between the White Flag Communists and the Karens, who are generally considered the "Right Wing" among the eight groups fighting the Government, is alleged by Burmese leaders here.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 19 (AP)-- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias won the women's titleholders golf tourney with a record-breaking 298 strokes today.

Retailers are prepared for the expected surge for Easter apparel and accessories, with ample inventories, excellent values and enticing promotions, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
The Philadelphia Transportation Company reported yesterday in its annual statement for 1949, net loss of $1,545,164 in contrast to $361,578 earned in 1948.
An end to what it called this city's "import excise tariff" on merchandise from out of town was asked yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) --A House Appropriations subcommittee today criticized Federal aviation agencies for everything from employe drinking of too much coffee in working hours to allegedly confused accident investigations and outmoded business methods.

The year-end statements of the corporations comprising the General Reinsurance Group disclosed today, total assets of $53,557,094 for General Reinsurance Corporation, a gain of $2,561,497 over the 1948 year-end, and total assets of $21,566,894 for the North Star Reinsurance Corporation, a gain of $3,208,485.
AMSTERDAM, March 19--Recent Indonesian monetary measures have resulted in losses in Indonesian shares on the Adsterdam stock market of up to 10 points.

WASHINGTON, March 19-- Pledges of $350,000 to the Henry Monsky Foundation were announced last night at the convention of B'nai B'rith. The gifts were from various groups and individuals of the organization.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 20--The trial of fourteen persons, including a Roman Catholic priest-- charged with murdering a policeman, spying and subversive activity in the service of the United ...
WASHINGTON, March 20--The House cleared the Administration's controversial middle-income housing program for full debate today after preliminary skirmishing indicative of a bitter floor fight.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad is planning to dispose of property it owns adjacent to suburban stations along its entire right-of-way to raise badly needed revenue and to reduce taxes, it was learned yesterday.

National Boys Club Week was opened here yesterday with a ceremony in the Boys Clubs of America, 381 Fourth Avenue, in which 15-year-old David Russo, a member of the Columbia Park Boys Club of San Francisco, was selected the "outstanding boy of the year."

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 20 --The hunt for a 22-year-old West Point cadet missing since Jan. 14 was pushed here today as Army troops began searching the rugged countryside of the academy's reservation.

Eddie Cantor returns to the local stage this evening at Carnegie Hall, for a single performance, in a one-man show entitled "My Forty Years in Show Business." The famous comedian of stage, screen and radio has not been seen hereabout since "Banjo Eyes" was produced nine years ago.

Although Easter business has fallen short of expectations, specialty stores in the New York area are going ahead with late spring and summer buying, it was learned yesterday at the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart showing in the New Yorker Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 20--Attorney General J. Howard McGrath today ordered a thorough Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry into charges that John L. Lewis had used "secret signals" to direct continuation of the recent coal strike while he publicly ordered the 370,000 strikers to return to work under a court injunction.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 20 --Acting Premier Gaston Eyskens failed today in his first efforts to form a new Belgian coalition government to replace the administration that fell Saturday on the question of King Leopold's return to the throne.

The man who fired the shot that killed 29-year-old William Hupe in Queens last Wednesday was identified yesterday as John J. King, 21 years old, of 48-24 Forty-eight Street, Sunnyside, Queens, according to the police.

WASHINGTON, March 20-- Another delay was encountered today in speeding the cotton acreage bill which carries a provision that the 1951 potato crop shall be put under strict marketing quotas to end the piling up of costly surpluses.

WASHINGTON, March 20--Ambassador at Large Philip C. Jessup accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today of making "false and irresponsible" charges that harmed this country's foreign relations and showed a "shocking disregard" for its national interest.
A two-weeks drive to recruit 4,000 daytime women volunteers for the New York City Cancer Committee's crusade beginning on April 3 opened yesterday in basement headquarters at 535 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)-- James Boyd, director of the Bureau of Mines, said today the United States has a long way to go before its stockpiling program is a success.

WASHINGTON, March 20--The House Committee on Foreign Affairs voted today to cut $1,000, 000,000 of cash from the proposed $3,100,000,000 fund for carrying the Marshall Plan through its third year, but to provide an equivalent value in American agricultural surpluses for European recovery.
ALBANY, March 20--By a vote of 60 in favor to 75 against, the Assembly defeated tonight a bill that would have required taxicab operators to increase their liability insurance coverage.

Substantial liberalization of the volume of import licenses to be granted by Brazil is expected for the second half of this year, Maurice M. Abrahams, vice president of the Unity Export Corporation, said yesterday in a report that will be sent to members of the American Brazilian Trade Council.
FULLERTON, Calif., March 20 (AP)--Catcher Ray Murray belted two home runs, a triple and a single in a perfect day at bat today for the Indians, who defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 7--5.
WASHINGTON, March 20--The Federal Trade Commission today challenged advertising claims for two anti-histamine preparations as "false and misleading" and issued complaints against the producers.

New York's Rangers will make their first start in the Stanley Cup play-offs at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night, March 29, it was revealed yesterday as the opening round schedule of the play-offs was drawn by the National Hockey League's Board of Governors at the Hotel Commodore.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 20--A recent attempt by Britain to break the deadlock over the admission of Communist China to the United Nations Security Council has failed to produce any result, it was disclosed today.
A few dozen priests donned white aprons yesterday and served a special lunch to 700 elderly men and women.
Net income of the Ohio Edison Company last year amounted to $11,708,764, equal to $2.95 a share, compared with $11,176,281, or $2.82, in 1948.
The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad last year spent $14,692,242 for additions and betterments, according to the road's ninety-eighth annual report, issued yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 20--Traffic on the Westchester parkways increased 15 per cent in 1949 and will continue to rise at least 10 per cent a year until 1955, the County Park Commission said today in an annual report to the Board of Supervisors.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh made known yesterday that for two weeks he had been scrutinizing the activities of lawyers and bail bondsmen in Women's and Gamblers Courts.
An attempt by the stock market yesterday to work itself back to the high rates of last week met with resistance.

TOKYO, March 20--Japanese and foreign observers today read with more than usual interest dispatches from Moscow detailing conditions under which the Soviet Union would consider a peace treaty with Japan as stated in Pravda by Yakob Victoroy. A certain amount of skepticism was expressed, however, if apparent concessions to the Western viewpoint which the Soviet Union now is hinting advanced the actual negotiations much further.

GENEVA March 20--The United States bluntly told members of the General Council of the International Refugee Organization today that there would be no more American money for the international care of refugees after March, 1951.
GENEVA, March 20--Delegates from eighteen countries in Eastern and Western Europe met here today to examine the possibilities of better utilization of Europe's agricultural resources.
The two-story three-family at 711 Avenue U, Brooklyn, also containing two stores, has been sold by Prodromos P. Eftimiou to Louis De Candia.

CHICAGO, March 20--Trucking companies cannot replace but can ruin railroads financially unless the truckers are compelled to pay operating fees to offset the damage they do to public highways, Andrew H. Phelps, vice president of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, told the Western Railroad Club today.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)-- Seven seafaring unions of the C.I.O., the A.F.L, and of independent status signed a mutual aid pact today to fight for retention of their union hiring halls.

WARSAW, March 20--The Polish Sejm followed today the lead of other Eastern European countries by unanimously adopting a Government bill that established provincial and municipal administrations cut to the Soviet pattern.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., March 20--In a knock-down and drag out battle highlighted by five home runs, for 1,941 onlookers, the Giants emerged from a threegame losing streak today as they upset the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9 to 8.

WASHINGTON, March 20-- Four American B-29 Superfortresses, their long fuselages bearing freshly painted Royal Air Force insignia, lifted into the air from Andrews Air Force Base near Washington this afternoon and headed out to sea for England.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20-- Christian R. Lindback, president of Abbotts Dairies, Inc., for the last thirty-six years, died today of a heart attack at Miami Beach, Fla., where he was taken ill a few days ago. His age was 72.
James H. England of 45 Prospect Place, executive director of the New York City Housing. Authority, died on Sunday in Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 56 years old.

MONTREAL, March 20--Robert Villemain, French contender for the world middleweight championship, tonight outpointed Kid Gavilan, Cuban welterweight, in the ten-round main bout at the Montreal Forum before a crowd of 11,745.
Another sign of spring, this one connected with the circus, is due to appear today with the arrival of twelve bears from Germany aboard the United States Lines freighter American Banker.

Harry B. Carter, president of the Bee Line, Inc., testified yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing that the bus company, serving 36,000 persons daily in Queens and Nassau, would be forced to suspend operations at the end of this month unless a twocent fare increase was granted.

WASHINGTON, March 20-- House economy forces today deferred their major fight for substantial budget slashes as the House Appropriations Committee tentatively approved without change all except one chapter of a ten-chapter omnibus appropriations bill.
The Nurre Company, Inc., a leading mirror manufacturer, has increased prices of decorative mirrors to retailers 2 to 10 per cent, effective immediately, Henry Bell sales manager, said yesterday.

ALBANY, March 20--Republican legislative leaders appeared tonight to have given the green light to a bill placing upon the New York City administration full responsibility for fixing fares on privately operated bus lines in the city.

TRENTON, March 20--The New Jersey Assembly passed a measure tonight to increase fees on heavy trucks while the Senate's Republican majority, in caucus, appeared nearer agreement on state rent control.

ALBANY, March 20--A bill that will New York City's income from the gross-receipts tax by $1,000,000 a year, according to city computations, received final legislative approval in the Assembly tonight and was sent to Governor Dewey.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20 (AP)--Woolford Farm's Delegate, inactive since last November, staged a successful comeback to the turf wars as he charged to victory in the featured sixth race at Gulfstream Park today.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation that finances installment sales of automobiles and other G.M. products, announced yesterday plans to increase outstanding debt and capital stock as much as $225,000,000.
WASHINGTON, March 20--The State Department commended a five-nation investigation committee today on the thoroughness of its study of disturbances in Caribbean countries.
Dr. Herbert M. Kaufmann, chairman of the board of directors of the Mutual Chemical Company of America, died yesterday at his home at 970 Park Avenue after a brief-illness. He was 79 years old.

Operations last year of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries resulted in consolidated net earnings of $8,733,254 after taxes and all charges, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

After joining Dr. Wallace E. Howell, consultant meteorologist, on an inspection of police planes and equipment at Floyd Bennett Airport yesterday, Mayor O'Dwyer said he was satisfied that all would be in readiness by the end of the week to take advantage of the first favorable opportunity for a preliminary rain-making experiment.
LONDON, March 20--A better deal for United States film producers will be sought with Britain's Board of Trade within the next month or so.

A TOURIST will occasionally bring North with him more than just memories and impressions from Florida's spring training. Some times he also brings back some material he never did have a chance to use.

HONG KONG, March 20--The Chinese Nationalist Defense Ministry in Taipei, Formosa, announced today that Nationalist planes on the last raid over Communist-held Shanghai had encountered fighters "unlike any American or Canadian planes the Nationalist government ever had."

Although a majority of leaders in the American shipping Industry consider increased maritime subsidies an unlikely prospect in the current atmosphere in Congress, organized tramping cornpanies are planning to seek action for their segment.

ALBANY, March 20--Governor Dewey's, $450,000,000 New York-toBuffalo Thruway was approved tonight in the Senate by a strictly party vote of 31 to 25. Concurrent Assembly action is scheduled as the first order of business tomorrow.

The Bohack Realty Corporation sold the taxpayer building at North Park Avenue and College Place, Rockville Centre, L.I., to Stanley Kempner and Morton Wormser, operators, who sold the contract to Hyde Associates, Inc., represented by Harry H. Wachtel, attorney.

WASHINGTON, March 20--The State Department said today that the evacuation of some 2,000 foreigners, including 310 Americans, from Shanghai was being held up because the Chinese Communist authorities would not let two shallow-draft ferrying boats enter the city.

LONDON, March 20--John Strachey, recently appointed Secretary for War, told the House of Commons today that Britain intended to reduce her total strength in the Middle East during the coming year so the "striking" force in the United Kingdom, could be increased.

The presence of a precipitation specialist on a Catskill mountainside ready to take immediate advantage of any opportunity offered by that condition known familiarly as the "synoptic situation," seems to be giving trout fisherman something to think about other than the first day of fishing.

CHICAGO, March 20--All deliveries of soybeans except November and all deliveries of corn as well as March and May oats sold at new seasonal peak prices on the Board of Trade today, and while the best figures were not maintained, soybeans closed 2 to 4 cents higher.

In one of those acts of impromptu "statesmanship" that occasionally crop up in Congress, the House Foreign Affairs Committee voted yesterday to slash cash funds for the third Marshall Plan year by a round billion dollars and to substitute an equivalent amount in American farm surplus commodities.

Three paintings and nine drawings by Boardman Robinson have been presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by a group of 134 artiste, it was announced yesterday at a trustees' meeting by Roland Redmond, the president.

HAVANA, March 20--Windigo, the 71-foot yawl sailed by W.S. Gubehnann of New York was today declared the Class A winner in the seventeenth annual St. Petersburg to Havana yacht race.

Having suffered five straight setbacks, the New York Rangers, with nine victories over the Chicago Black Hawks to date, seek to make it an even ten tonight when the clubs meet for the last time at Madison Square Garden. Tonight's battle, the only Tuesday booking of the campaign here, will not be telecast.

There will be the double pleasure of familiarity and surprise for visitors to the exhibition of ToulouseLautrec's lithographs, which opens with a gala premiere at M. Knoedley Co. this evening for the benefit of the Museum of Albi, France.

The 3,800 employer of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation will be asked tonight by officials of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., to call a strike against the company for 4 A.M. on April 2, Michael Quill, union international president, announced yesterday.

Their elements of drama are mere repetitions of familiar stereotypes. That is why one of the satisfactions of fiction is to find novelists imposing form on experience.

Mayor O'Dwyer is planning a series of semi-monthly television broadcasts in which he will discuss with members of his staff and administration "current situations and problems of interest to the people," it was learned yesterday.

Although beer production costs have continued to rise during the last year, retail prices will definitely not be increased, Sam Bernstein, counsel for the New York State Beer Wholesalers Association, declared yesterday at an industry management seminar in the New Yorker Hotel.
Prices of coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange rose sharply in early trading yesterday, but lack of demand in late dealings forfeited much of the advance.

Lewis Wolfe, 42-year-old selfproclaimed "Messiah" convicted of murdering his wife, was sentenced to the electric chair yesterday after ranting dramatically for an hour and a half in King's County Court.
GENEVA, March 20--Prolongation of the international tariff truce until at least Jan. 1, 1954, was approved today by the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 20 --Walter S. Crandell, a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1909, died here today at his home, 23 Ridge Road, after a sixmonth illness. Mr. Crandell, who was 70 years old, retired last year from his brokerage business at 25 Broad Street, New York.
