The bidding today for $21,275,000 of new bonds of the New York Housing Authority marks the fourth requisition to be made on the bond market since November, 1948, in fulfillment of Mayor O'Dwyer's program of city-guaranteed, no-cash-subsidy housing.

Budge Patty of Los Angeles, second only to William Talbert among the top contenders for the National indoor tennis championship, had a narrow escape from defeat last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Dr. Milton Steinberg, rabbi of the Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East Eighty-seventh Street, since 1933, died yesterday, after a brief illness, its his home at 145 East Ninety-second Street. He was 46 years old.

Peace in the garment trades, as A.H. Raskin reminded readers of this newspaper yesterday, is nearing the end of its first uninterrupted quarter century. Employers in a once chaotic and disorganized industry have come to realize the value of unions; unions have moved ...

Reporting on operations last year of Combustion Engineering-Superheater, Inc., Samuel G. Allen, chairman, and Joseph V. Santry, president, informed stockholders in their annual statement issued today that the net income amounted to $6,686,772 after taxes and all charges.

In behalf of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association, Mrs. Cleveland F. Bacon, chairman of the group, will give a reception on Monday afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club for members of the committee. During the afternoon, Miss Claudia Pinza of the Metropolitan Opera Company will sing. There also will be a showing of garden slides.

The Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company had a net income in 1949 of $11,075,729 after taxes and all charges, or $5.33 a common share, compared with $7,557,000, or $3.56, in 1948, E.H. Little, president, revealed yesterday in the annual report.

The Collyer brothers are all but forgotten in the Harlem neighborhood, where once they were a legend. But tales of their bizarre life and death will be revived on Friday when proceedings on their estate come up in Surrogate's Court.

Auction-goers should have a field day Wednesday at 2 P.M. at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. For these a vast and varied collection of furniture and decorative accessories donated by members and friends of the American Institute of Decorators will go to the highest bidder.

WASHINGTON, March 20--Figures released today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation revealed 1,763,290 serious offenses during 1949. This meant a crime every eighteen seconds of the year, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the F.B.I., said.

Enthusiasm over the victory of City College in the national invitation basketball tournament continued unabated yesterday as members of the Lavender's fourteen-man squad were congratulated in ceremonies held both at City Hall and on the C.C.N.Y. campus.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)-- Official figures on the omnibus appropriations bill will not be made public until the entire measure is acted upon.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 20 (AP)--Cary Middlecoff, the national open champion, used his "black widow" putter to win the $2,000 first prize in the Jacksonville open golf tourney with a 72hole score of 279 today.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange in cotton futures was active yesterday, but prices were irregular and on the close ...

CAIRO, March 20--Certain member states of the Arab League are considering a proposal to expel Jordan because of her alleged contacts with Israel during and after the Palestine war, according to the Wafdist party organ, Sout Al Oma.
PITTSBURGH, March 20 (UP)-- Chief Justice George W. Maxey of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court died in court chambers today after delivering a eulogy on a deceased colleague.

WASHINGTON, March 20-- President Truman has decided to call for a larger United States import program, and is now in the process of organizing a high level interdepartmental committee to deal with it.
The 105th annual report of the New York Life Insrance Company, to be issued to policyholders today, shows $9,970,371,347 of life insurance in force under 3,864,338 policies on Dec. 31, 1949.

LONDON, March 20 (AP)--John McIntyre of Medford, Mass., whipped home a loose puck with a minute and 45 seconds left to play tonight to give the United States a 3-2 victory over Great Britain in a world amateur hockey tournament game marked by fistcuffs and an assault on the referee.

ALBANY, March 20--Twelve objections to legislation requested by Mayor O'Dwyer to set up a New York City Parking Authority were listed today by Frank C. Moore, State Controller, in a memorandum filed with Senator Walter J. Mahoney, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 20-- President Truman demolished today rumors that he planned to supplant Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, with Chief Justice Fred Vinson. Furthermore, he said that Mr. Acheson was doing his work "admirably."

Thirty-three contract bridge teams started play for the Curt H. Reisinger team-of-four championship at the Park Sheraton Ho tel last night. The Reisinger Cup event is the first major contest to be decided in the annual Eastern States contract bridge tournament, which got under way Saturday afternoon and will continue through Sunday.

Utilization of scientific management principles should be applied to office work as well as shop effort, it was stressed last night by Carl E. Lindquist, chief development accountant of the Western Electric Company.

WASHINGTON, March 20--A revival of proposed universal military training to prepare the United States against the impact of atomic or disease bomb attack was urged today before the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy at the Capitol.
BERLIN, March 20--John J. McCloy today tacitly invited residents of the Soviet zone to demonstrate to the Western powers their sentiments in favor of free elections throughout Germany.
WASHINTON, March 20--The Army announced today that it was restoring part of the drill pay cut ordered last December for units of the Organized Reserve Corps.

ALBANY, March 20--The Assembly approved tonight an Administration bill setting up a system of state aid for public libraries and appropriating $1,000,000 for the first year of its operation. When it gets into full operation the annual cost will be $3,653,000.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 20 (UP)--Dr. Hermann N. Sander, acquitted mercy murder trial defendant, has been banned from two Roman Catholic hospitals, and a charge has been made against him by a member of the Hillsboro County Medical Society, medical officials announced tonight.

WESTFIELD, N.J., March 20-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Basil L. Emery of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Louise, to Richard Beeson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Beeson of Muncie, Ind. The wedding has been planned for the autumn.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 2 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 3 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20-- Harry R. Bridges was described today as a "rock-ribbed figure of honesty and integrity" by his attorney, Vincent Hallinan. The lawyer, in final arguments, told a Federal jury here that the Government had spent $2,000,000 to $3,000,000 in a fifteen-year "wild animal chase," as he called the "persecution" of the West Coast longshore leader.

CINCINNATI, March 20--A draft "code of practice" for Reform Judaism began to take shape here today when more than sixty rabbinical scholars and educators opened a three-day Institute on Reform Jewish Theology at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 20-- Some indication that to the average woman the problem of making her home attractive is as important as running it efficiently might be seen in the "standing-room only" conditions that prevailed ...

Corning Glass Works and its consolidated subsidiaries last year attained the highest sales and earnings in its ninety-eight-year history, according to the annual reports issued yesterday by Amory Houghton, chairman, and William C. Decker, president.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 20-- Net income of $2,517,989 for last year, after taxes and provision for subsidy recapture, was reported today by American President Lines.

The Musicians Guild concluded its series of chamber music concerts in Town Hall last night with performances that had the audience cheering. The heaviest applause went to Lillian Fuchs for her rendition of Bach's unaccompanied 'cello Suite No. 4 in E flat, which she played on the viola.

WASHINGTON, March 20--The Blue Ridge Investment Corporation of New York, applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for an exemption order permitting the purchase from it by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., of 30,000 shares of common stock of Cramp Shipbuilding Company at a price of $28.52 a share.

Jesse Stuart, author of "Taps for Private Tussie" and "Beyond Dark Hills," has a novel on Whittlesey House's list for May 1. "Hie to the Hunters" deals with the people of the Kentucky hills. Mr. Stuart's recent work, "The Thread That Runs So True," was an account of his experiences teaching school in the hills of Kentucky.
Delayed arrivals apparently are an inconvenience that the kitchen staff of the Italian liner Conte Biancamano takes in stride.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) --An official estimate that farmers would plant another big crop this year destroyed any hope today that the Government would be able to start tapering off its multi-billion dollar farm price support program.

A determined company of New York Marine Corps reservists battled its way Sunday through equally determined toll collectors, traffic policemen and Sunday drivers to recapture a strategic piece of New Jersey from an imaginary enemy.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 20-- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett called upon the seven-member nations of the Arab League today to make peace with Israel by direct negotiations. He said that this small land wished only to consolidate its present position, and added: "There will be no further war if the Arab world does not will it."
American Airlines will begin transcontinental air coach service in seventy-passenger DC-6 airliners on April 9, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, March 20--The legislative leadlock that threatens to block action at this session on the Dewey Administration's residential rent control bill appeared unbroken tonight after a series of conferences involving both Democrats and Republicans.

Madison Square Garden and WPIX have reached an agreement whereby the station will televise 118 sporting events during the Garden's fall and winter season if a sponsor can be obtained for the $500,000-package deal.

Domestic oil companies cannot compete with the prices at which foreign oil can be sold here, W. Alton Jones, president of the $946,000,000 Cities Service Company, asserted yesterday in the fortieth annual report to stockholders.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 20-- The somewhat travel-worn Yankees invaded the lair of the Tigers today and scarcely were prepared for what they encountered.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 --Larry Parks and Barbara Hale were named today by Columbia to play the leading roles in a comedy, temporarily titled "The Doctor's Husband," which Eddie Buzzell will direct, starting next Monday.

A small injection of A.C.T.H., hormone from the pituitary gland, can be used as a test to foretell how a patient will undergo the shock of a major surgical operation, according to a report published yesterday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

The six-story and penthouse Building at 3750 Broadway, southeast corner of 156th Street, containing seven stores and thirtyseven apartments, has been sold by the Sillam Realty Corporation to an investing client of Abe Hertz, attorney.

Record sales and earnings in 1949 marked the forty-eighth annual report of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, which produces a diversified line including Scotch and other tapes, coated abrasives and chemicals.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)-- The Government acted today to cancel its 1941 sale of the former Post Office and Court House site in Newark, N.J.
Active buying is absorbing available New York industrial stocks of surplus iron and steel products, purchasing agents reported here yesterday.

There is no such thing as single blessedness for earrings. An earring without its mate is about as useful as one hand on a clock. Yet from nearly every woman's jewel box, at least one such stranded bauble--living alone and hating it --shines up at her reproachfully.

The garden year in perspective was spread out over four floors of Grand Central Palace when the thirty-fourth International Flower Show opened at noon yesterday. Throughout the week, gardens and front yard plantings typical of both spring and summer, as well as flower arrangements for any season, will be displayed for gardeners from city, suburb and country.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 20 --The Dodgers will look a bit more like themselves when they take the field at Miami Wednesday against the Athletics, for their iron man first baseman will be back on the job.

HAVANA, March 21--The seventeenth annual St. Petersburg to Havana yacht race, which started at noon last Saturday, ended today as the last of twenty-four finishers reached Havana Harbor.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,296 against 1,805 last week and 1,477 in the similar week of last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There Were 587 arrivals yesterday compared with 896 last Tuesday.

ALBANY, March 21--The Assembly approved today, without dissent, a bill that would cut minimum premiums on group life insurance policies issued in New York. The measure had previously been approved by the Senate and now goes to Governor Dewey for his consideration.

A large loan exhibition of paintings by Renoir will open with a gala premiere tonight at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixtyfourth Street. The show, consisting primarily of paintings which are being shown in New York for the first time (including several from private collections in Paris), is being held for the benefit of the New York Infirmary.

The taxpayer building at 39-02 to 39-10 Sixty-fourth Street, Woodside, Queens, containing seven stores, has been sold by Norman D. Dellerson to Morris Schindelheim. The property, on a plot 40 by 100 feet, is assessed at $23,000.

ALBANY, March 21--Governor Dewey this afternoon affixed his signature to an Administration bill that sets up a State Authority to construct and operate the proposed $500,000,000 Thruway from New York City to Buffalo.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 21 --In a caustic open letter to exiled King Leopold, Socialist leader PaulHenri Spaak tonight urged the monarch "to make a gesture of greatness and wisdom" by abdicating in favor of his son, Prince Baudouin. M. Spaak told the King this was the only way to save Belgium's "unity and prosperity."

Early last month, 8-year-old Billy Anderson of Summerland, Miss., was admitted to Bellevue Hospital. He was suffering from acute leukemia. His body had wasted. His eyes were dull. He cried continually.

Morris Warschauer quit work at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon-- the earliest ever, he said, since he became an employe of the Board of Education in 1907, But, even though it was a relatively "short" day for Mr. Warschauer, it was also a momentous one.

Designs of Paris, couturiers and duplications at modest prices were shown yesterday by Ohrbach's at Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South. French models were exhibited side by side with the store's copies.

Directors of the Childs Company elected N.C. Earl Jr. as president of the restaurant chain, according to the announcement of Everett Frank, chairman, following the meeting yesterday.

ALBANY, March 21--Governor Dewey recommended to the Legislature today the passage of Democratic legislation that would give New York City sole jurisdiction over the fares charged by private bus companies, which serve 61.2 per cent of the city's population.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (U.P.) --The nation's economic activity increased "moderately" in January and February despite the coal strike, the Department of Commerce reported tonight.

ALBANY, March 21--The Senate formally killed the Judicial Council proposals for modernizing New York City's courts, rejecting five measures by a vote of 21 ayes to 26 nays.

Yesterday afternoon at Bonwit Teller, Emily Wilkens, who was one of the first to put style into teen-age clothes about six years ago, offered her newest collection. This time she returned with a brand new array of fashions for young sophisticates sized from 7 to 15.

Nightmares are composed of a good many things other than Welsh rabbit, or the thoughtless combination of sauerkraut, chocolate malted and warm beer. Those nightmares are only dreams, and are over as soon as the body twitches suddenly into wakefulness.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt refused yesterday to reschedule a television program with Paul Robeson that was canceled because of hundreds of protests. She spoke sharply to representatives of leftwing groups who questioned her at a meeting at the Park-Sheraton Hotel.

The Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, the first new crossing between Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn in forty-one years, will open on May 25, ten years after President Roosevelt broke, ground for the $80,000,000 project.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will participate in tableaux to be features of the spring supper dance tonight in the Sect Room of the Waldorf-Astoria after the preview of the Renoir loan exhibition at the Wildenstein Gallery for the Benefit of the New York Infirmary maintenance fund.

A program of "talking books" that was started five years ago to supply blinded war veterans with up-to-date text and reference material for their studies has been expanded by the New York Public Library to include all sightless readers.

City College's basketball players, walking around with their heads in the clouds following their sensational triumph in the national invitation tournament, will buckle down tp work today for the Eastern regionals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, announced yesterday that the City Council, would hold a special session at 11 A.M. today to consider a concurrent resolution asking the Legislature to pass an amended version of the bill to create a New York City Parking Authority.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Approved by a voice vote in the Senate, a deficiency appropriations bill containing funds sufficient to continue the enforcement of rent control at present levels at least until mid-May went today to the White House for signature by the President.

LONDON, March 21--The Lord Mayor of London, Sir Frederick Rowland, announced today opening of a 2,000,000 ($5,600,000) National Thanksgiving Fund to commemorate gifts of food sent to Britain since l940 by commonwealth nations and the United States.

ALBANY, March 21 (AP)--Bee Line, Inc., which operates bus service in parts of Queens and Nassau Counties, was authorized today, by the Public Service Commission to raise some fares 1 cent until June 30.

ATHENS, March 21--Concluding his talks With all the political leaders, King Paul tonight decided to abide by a factored constitutional custom and offer a mandate to Constantin Tsaldaris, whose Populist party received more seats in the new Chamber of Deputies than any other single party in the March 5 elections.
FRANKFORT, Germany, March 21--Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, repeated today a suggestion for a FrenchGerman union as a solid front against the threat of communism.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance by Private Capital, said yesterday that he would move soon to acquire $16,000,000 in Federal housing funds to make a start on new projects here.

Spring elections were held yesterday in many incorporated villages is Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk and Rockland Counties. Local officials were chosen after contests in thirty villages, while in sixty-three others they were selected without contests.

Eight principal sessions of the twentieth annual convention of the New York Safely Council will be broadcast by WNYC during a fourday period beginning Tuesday. The programs, originating from the Statler and Governor Clinton Hotels, will be heard twice daily from 10:30 A.M. to 12 noon and from 2:30 to 4 P.M., except on Friday morning, March 31, when the pickup will begin at 10:45 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Representative Ralph E. Church, Republican of Illinois, died today while testifying before a Congressional committee on behalf of a resolution he had written in opposition to President Truman's plan for abolishing the office of General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board and transferring its functions to the board's chairman. He was 66 years old.

Small business men in Great Britain are showing a strong inclination to export goods to the United States, according to Arthur H. Motley, publisher of Parade Magazine. Their individual efforts, he said yesterday in an interview at the Canadian Club, will close the dollar gap in trade between the two countries.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21--The Braves, who, after a deal of midwinter face lifting, are believed to be going places again this year, scarcely were able to get off their goal line today as the Yankees trampled them under foot, 4 to 2.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor here have united on a project, backed by Mayor O'Dwyer, to raise subnormal economic and social conditions among New York's 50,000 or more Puerto Rican workers, it was learned yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, March 23-- The Government campaign against La Prensa and La Nacion has taken a new form this week.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Failure to provide for appeals to an impartial review board gave rise to controversy today over a House of Representatives bill setting up machinery for on-the-spot suspension of persons in key Government agencies suspected of being poor security risks.

Fada Radio and Electric Company, Inc., yesterday entered the mass market for television receivers by introducing a new line of sets to retail from $199.95 to $359.95 at a dealer showing in the Park-Sheraton Hotel.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 23--Manager Leo Durocher, due to rejoin his Giants tomorrow in Oakland, may find that his quest of one important cog in the 1950 Giant machine has ended.

Fifty years ago today, ground was broken for the first stretch of New York's subway system. The event was hailed in the newspapers, and in speeches at the ceremony, as the greatest in the history of the city since the opening of the Erie Canal, seventy-five years before.

A working plan for the development of S. Parkes Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn, north of Tillary Street, as "an integral part" of the Brooklyn Civic Center was submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses. The development would cost $921,120.

With increased activity, metal futures on the Commodity Exchange showed underlying price strength yesterday. Higher prices were posted for copper, tin and zinc.

What amounts to the most complete revision of the racing rules in the one-hundred and six years of the New York Yacht Club was put before its members yesterday afternoon in the clubhouse at 37 West Forty-fourth street.

The first adjustment in a radio station's rates because of competition offered by television was announced yesterday by Station WFIL in Philadelphia. On behalf of Columbia University, I thank Mr. Leo Silver for the generous gift that will make the Gabriel Silver Lecture on Peace a recurring feature of the University calendar.

Plans are being completed for the performance of "Great to be Alive", the new musical, on Monday evening at the Winter Garden, which has been taken over for the benefit of the Institute for the crippled and Disabled.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 23-- In a special state-wide radio broadcast Gov. Chester Bowles tonight assailed what he called "a small and selfish group of men, who, with utter ruthlessness, are seeking to destroy" an opportunity to reorganize the state government.

WASHINGTON, March 23--An article by Dr. Frederick Seitz, research professor of physics at the University of Illinois, published in the current issue of The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, has already made a great impression on the Government and the impression is growing.

PARIS, March 23 (UP)--France called on military personnel today to unload American fighter planes from the aircraft carrier Dixmude as Communist-controlled dock workers in Tunisia refused to handle the United States equipment.

WASHINGTON, March 23--A voice vote of the House of Representatives approved by a wide margin today a $2,000,000,000 increase (from $4,750,000,000 to $6,750,000,000) in the borrowing power of the Commodity Credit Corporation to assure its ability to meet rising costs of agricultural price supports.

HONG KONG, March 23--Reports that the Nationalists are preparing to invade the Chinese mainland within six months are growing more insistent and certain troop dispositions by the Communists indicate they, at least, are not inclined to take them lightly.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 23 (AP)--Don Scurlock was the riding star of the card at Gulfstream Park today as he booted home three winners, including Roman Road, paying $129.80, $27.80 and $10.80 for $2 across the board, in the featured sixth race, named for the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

Private and commercial growers yesterday brought many choice and colorful flowers to add to those which have been on display at the International Flower Show in Grand Central Palace.

A city-wide school survey to determine whether television has made inroads in the children's study, eating, recreation or sleeping habits has been started under the auspices of the United Parents Associations, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23--A Iong-range estimate issued today by the Office of Education indicated that in the school year 1959-60 there would be 10,500,000 more children in elementary and high schools than in the year 1946-47.
WASHINGTON, March 23--A farm bill to liberalize previous cuts in this year's planting of cotton and peanuts and to restrict potato production failed to obtain final passage by the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, March 23--A Senate Labor subcommittee's hearing on maritime hiring practices turned into an audience-participation show today when a Great Lakes ship operator complained that he was forced to take on "bums" or see his ships tied up.

ROME, March 23--The Army was called in today to help the police in quelling a strike with marked insurrectional characteristics that broke out in San Severo, a town of 45,000 inhabitants, in the province of Foggia.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23--Casey Stengel today was still testing the depth of his "bench," which may or may not encounter another year of heavy toil, and what the Yankee skipper found was again wholly gratifying.

ATHENS, March 15--The United States Economic Cooperation Administration has transmitted to the Greek Goverment the report of a New York engineering firm blueprinting an integrated electric power program for Greece.
Unity on American foreign pol-- icy is essential to avert another war, Frederick H. Osborn, former deputy United States representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, said last night.

CHICAGO, March 23--Closing out of March grain and lard contracts resulted in nervous markets on the Board of Trade today. March wheat closed 1/8 to 1 cents lower, March corn 1/8 to 1 cent higher, oats 7/8 to 1 cent lower and soybeans 1 to 3 cents lower.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., March 23--The second annual plenary meeting of the Conference of U.S.A. Member Churches of the World Council of Churches issued today an urgent appeal for an additional $591,000 in 1950 to prevent collapse of interchurch aid and service to refugees in Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 23-- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charge that "the top Russian espionage agent" in this country had a present or very recent "connection" with the State Department was attacked and denied by the department today.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad is disposing of parcels of land that are not required for railroad purposes, when possible to secure reasonable prices, according to the road's report for 1949. Taxes covering several thousand parcels of land, some of which have been held for over forty years, cost the company over $200,000 a year.
A 66-year-old retired boiler maker from New Jersey will sail today on the liner Washington for Hamburg, Germany, to pay a surprise visit to a sister he has not seen in fifty years.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)-- Dick Button, the world champion, was not up to par today but he piled up a substantial lead at the mid-way mark in the men's national figure skating championships.

WASHINGTON, March 23--By a vote of 347 to 12, the House of Representatives approved today $150,000 more for its Committee on Un-American Activities. This brought the total for the committee to $350,000 for the current Congress.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 23-- While the North Atlantic Pact is essential to European defense against possible aggression a Mediterranean alliance is necessary to complete the strategic picture of mutual protection, Nejmeddin Sadak, Turkey's Foreign Minister, said today.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., March 23--An eleventh-hour agreement, including drastic shifts in the local union set-up, brought a settlement today of a nine-anda-half-month strike against the multi-million dollar Continental Paper Company, located on Industrial Road here.

Roland La Starza, Bronx heavyweight who has yet to meet defeat as a professional, will encounter a rival who also boasts a record free of defeat when he meets Rocky Marciano of Brockton, Mass., in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 23 (AP)-- Twelve men were killed this morning in the flaming crash of a B-50 Air Force bomber in a remote desert area near Hyder, Ariz. Two men parachuted to safety.

MUNICH, Germany, March 25--The pilot of one of three Czechoslovak transports that landed at near-by Erding military airfield yesterday said today that he had been forced to do so at the point of a gun.

But in the process of tracking down these persons, dossiers containing the most personal and defamatory information on the lives of some 11,000 others have been accumulated.

HYDE PARK THE papers of Thomas Jefferson --his draft of the Declaration of Independence and those wonder ful drawings of plowshares and axe helves with which he occupied his universal mind--lie scattered in such varied places as Washington and Mis souri, Pennsylvania and Virginia, Bos ton and New Haven.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 25 (AP)--United States Senator Brien McMahon asserted tonight that "unprecedented American prosperity" had forced Communists "to revise their prophecy that the capitalistic system would quickly dig its own grave."

ONIONS are easy to grow. If the right varieties are planted, a year's supply can be produced even in a small vegetable plot. Onion sets give quick results, but they do not store as well as those sown from seed.

SAN SALVADOR, March 25-- The people of this smallest American republic will vote tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday for a President and fifty-two members of the constitutional Congress in what is expected to be the first free and fair election to be held here in many years.
AINTREE, England, March 25-- Freebooter, a half brother of an Irish plow horse, won the Grand National Steeplechase today, smashing a twenty-three-year jinx on favorites.

AFTER the hard riding over Western plains which the past literary season has put us to, it is a pleasant change to return to the New England hills and catch up on the latest news of Toby Clark and his pony, Windy Foot. These Windy Foot stories are as much concerned with family doings as with horses and therein lies much of their enduring interest.

During the next few weeks trout seasons will be opening all over the place, and with rods, reels, flies, waders and the assorted miscellany of equipment in readiness the angler will find some of the new angling books an interesting and soothing means of curbing his impatience.

THE major surprise in Post master General Jesse M. Donaldson's recent announcement of his stampissuing program for the rest of 1950 lay in his disclosure that one of the specials would be the commemorative "Gateway to the West --Midwest Centenary."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25--Acting in defiance of a military precept which decrees that it is exceedingly hazardous to wage a war on two fronts, the Yankees today mustered a "B" team to batHe the Tigers while the main detachment engaged the Dodgers in Miami. The St. Pete contingent held up its end nicely enough, tripping the Bengals, 7 to 5.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 25-- Racial segregation offers a "fruitful field" for Communists, machina politicians and white-supremacy demogagues because all three groups essentially are enemies of democracy and seek to promote antagonisms and fears.

A series of eleven African cruises on liners of the Holland-Africa Line, beginning next Thursday, was announced here yesterday by the Holland-America Line, United States agents for the company. Six of the cruises will be for seventyeight days and five will be seventyday trips. They will start at Antwerp and Southampton.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 25 --The Belgian political crisis took a sudden, startling turn tonight. The Liberal leader, Albert Deveze, agreed to try to form a new government. It was M. Deveze' party that brought down the coalition Cabinet of Premier Gaston Eyskens last Saturday by opposing the return of the exiled King Leopold III to the throne. M. Deveze was Deputy Premier and Defense Minister in the Eyskens Cabinet.
The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Bench, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Bench of Englewood, N.J., to Donald Morgan Nielsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Nielsen of Ridgewood.

Another championship trophy for the City College showcase was annexed by Nat Holman's Beavers last night at Madison Square Garden. Right down to the wire went the Eastern regional final in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tourney and when the quintets crossed the finish line it was C.C.N.Y. by five, 78--73, over hard-driving, resourceful North Carolina Mate, which, with a halfminute to go, trailed by only two points.

CHICAGO, March 25--The Chicago Mercantile Exchange was the scene of a marketing drama this week, with Fred H. Vahlsing of New York City in the leadmg role as winning speculator in onions. This humble perishable commodity is ruled out of their operations by Federal price supporters.

Diggs, the company's vice president in charge of passenger traffic and one of the top passenger promotion officials in the travel industry, it was announced yesterday by George Killion, the president.

Start of construction work on a group of ranch-style dwellings in Livingston, and the sale of an industrial property in Newark were among the developments in New Jersey real estate reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25--Once more the Bureau of the Census has its great adding mills primed and ready to go. In one week, the enumerators will be out gathering the raw statistics for the hopper, and from all indications, neither rain, nor snow, nor charges of improper questions shall keep them from their appointed rounds.

THIS is the account of a journey that the late Dr. Alexis Carrel made to Lourdes in 1903 and of what he saw there and its influence upon him. At the time, Dr. Carrel had abandoned his Catholicism and become a follower of Kant and what he calls' a "tolerant skeptic."
BERKELEY, Calif., March 25-- Mrs. Carrie Lucretia Hoyt, Berkeley's only woman Mayor and a veteran civic leader, died in her home today at the age of 83.
GREENSBORO, N. C., March 25 --Par golf was good enough for Sam Snead to boost his Greensboro open golf tournament lead to three strokes at the halfway mark today.
LAKE SUCCESS, March 25-- Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo called today for the. convocation of a world conference of scientists to work out a new approach to international control of atomic energy.

An appeal to the "conscience" of Iron Curtain countries for the return of thousands of Greek children abducted by Communist guerrillas was made here last night by Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator.

Declaring that "life expectancy is about three years" if the present trend in world affairs continued, Norman Cousins, editor of The Saturday Review of Literature, urged yesterday that this country exert a "moral leadership" for peace. He spoke to 500 alumni and faculty members of the School of Education of New York University at their annual spring conference.

ALBANY, March 25--The 1950 session of the Legislature came to an end this week with Governor Dewey's future political intentions the subject of conflicting interpretations and the Democrats badly divided on the selection of a candidate to head their ticket.

BERLIN, March 25--Western German policemen dispersed within ten minutes today a group of 200 Communist demonstrators after they had gathered in a square in the strongly Communist section of Charlottenburg. The police arrested several of the leaders of the demonstration before it had been dispersed.

ATHENS, March 25--Gen. Nicholas Plastiras and Georges Papandreou, leaders of the Center political groups, issued a joint statement tonight countering Pre-- mier Sophocles Venizelos' long declaration of policy, published earlier in the day.

The battered legions of Chiang Kai-shek demonstrated a somewhat surprising resilience last week-end when a raiding party from Formosa landed on the mainland, captured a town 200 miles south of Shanghai and held it briefly.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25-- A proposal that President Truman summon Republican and Democratic leaders into a conference to lay the basis for a "consistent, realistic foreign policy" was made here tonight by Representative Richard M. Nixon, California Republican.

PARIS, March 25--The plan for a European payments union, under discussion here, is rapidly becoming a dominant political and economic issue for Europe and the United States, in the opinion of high European and American officials who are in a position to measure its implications, and the sharp diversity of views it has provoked. THE era of flying saucers is bringing unrest to Captain Video. As a self-appointed protector of all things good and noble, he is itching to throw off his earthly yoke and take up missionary work on the planets beyond, if his writer holds out.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 24--The first of 3,000 Jews whom Hungary will allow to emigrate under an agreement concluded with the Israeli Government three months ago will leave Hungary for Israel April 10, it was reliably learned today.

MOSCOW, March 25--Moshe Sharrett, Israel's Foreign Minister, was called today a "malicious babbler" and "liar" and Israel's ruling circles were said to be "hitching Israel to the chariot of American imperialism," in a sharp commentary published by the Literary Gazette.

STONY BROOK, L.I., March 25--The Stony Brook Board of Education, planning to build the first campus-type elementary school in New York State, will submit a $225,000 proposition to the voters next Friday.

A brilliant backhand shot by Ray Harrington from 25 yards out gave the Brooklyn Polo Club an 11-10 "sudden death" victory over the New York A. C. at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night as the National Senior Championship tourney began.
The price decline in certain Government bonds which the Federal Reserve System has been a party to by sales from its open-market investment portfolio continues to perplex the financial district.
GENEVA, March 25--The Soviet Union has repulsed the latest efforts of Western governments and the United Nations to find a practical basis for expanding EastWest trade.

ALBANY, March 25--Plans for financing and constructing the self-liquidating $450,000,000 New York-to-Buffalo Thruway will be ready by next fall, Superintendent of Public Works Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the State Thruway Authority, said today. Albany sources estimated the Thruway would be completed within four years.

One hundred twenty-six pairs began play yesterday in the Eastern States contract bridge tournament at the Park Sheraton Hotel, competing for the open pair championship and the Julian Goldman trophy.

Willie (The Actor) Sutton, whose crimes are as numerous as his disguises, was paid by the city for two years to play the role of porter at a farm colony while the police sought him over the country for a variety of offenses.

A CONTINUOUS supply of tomatoes from July until November is the result of my growing forty to sixty plants from seed each year. Seed is started at various times from January through March. If started in the house where there is little sun, compared to greenhouse conditions, seed is sown early.

With March ending, we yearn for green, the green that soothes the eye and warms the heart. Not the thick green of the pine, or the dull green of the cedar, but the new fresh green of grass and of maple leaves no bigger than a squirrel's ear and of tulip swords and daffodil lances. The green of a violet's leaf and calyx. The green that mists the hills and livens all the valleys.

Repeated predictions of a drop in American college enrollment are not borne out in the latest directory of the United States Office of Education which was made public last week. The directory indicates that such enrollments will continue to increase for at least another ten years.

WASHINGTON, March 25--For thousands of students who will finish school and start looking for work this year, the hardest job of all will be finding a job, according to the Labor Department's Bureau of Employment Security. Miller of Columbus, Ohio, took place here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Hugh C. Tucker, who was assisted by the Rev. Ernest C. Potter.

A plea to Governor Dewey to sign the Democratic residential rent control bill was made yesterday by the Liberal party in a letter signed by Ben Davidson, executive director, and James J. Donnelly, legislative representative.
