It was in the eleventh annual competition of the kennel club of northern New Jersey and the winner was Mrs. Charles Fleishman's Champion Cartlane Once from North Hollywood, Calif.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- Owen Lattimore, who has served as a State Department adviser on the Far East, was identified tonight as the man described by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin as being Russia's top espionage agent in the United States.

E.G. Ewell, vice president of Mack-International Motor Truck Corporation, has been named general sales manager of the company's Eastern, Atlantic and Southern sales divisions. He will be in charge of Mack truck, bus and fire apparatus sales activities in the eastern half of the United States.

The marriage of Miss Adeline Oppenheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Oppenheimer of 277 West End Avenue, to Henry Elihu Baron, son of Mrs. Saul J. Baron of 1095 Park Avenue, and the late Mr. Baron, took place last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman.

In its first annual report, issued for publication today, the $207,000,000 Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation shows a net income of $737,752 for 1949. However, these earnings represented only the difference between interest from investments in securities, $1,005,965, and income deductions of $268,213.
VIENNA, March 26--Russian economic penetration of Austria is beginning to worry United States authorities here.

CAIRO, March 26--The question whether Jordan has reached the parting of the ways with the Arab League and the majority of the league's states is now the dominant issue at the meeting of the league's council, which started yesterday with an imposing list of Arab Premiers and other Cabinet Ministers in attendance.

With the appearance of roving Ambassador Jessup before Congressional committees this week after his extensive Asiatic trip, we should have some concrete suggestions as to how our help can be effectively given to the threatened areas of Southeast Asia.

One of the most important jobs assigned to the 1949 Legislature by Governor Dewey was to bring some order and uniformity out of differing, obsolete local building codes in the state. The purpose was modernization, to encourage use of new techniques and new materials.

A new singer was introduced to the New York City Opera Company in Saturday night's "La Boheme." He was Cesare Bardelli, previously of the San Carlo company, and he sang the role of Marcello in a manner to suggest that when he overcomes his initial nervous flutters and hesitancies he will be a valuable addition to the company.

All branches of the home furnishings industry have pledged support for Home Fashions Time, which will be held in stores over the country from Sept. 21 to 30, W.E.S. Griswold Jr., chairman of the Home Furnishings Industry Committee, reported last week.
One hundred and sixty thousand New Yorkers have drawn all the state unemployment insurance checks they are eligible to receive in the present "benefit year."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 26--The general strategic concept of defense of the twelve North Atlantic Pact nations, accepted by the Foreign Ministers Council in Paris last December, has been translated in the four months since then into a definite plan to counter aggression against any one of the pact's signatories.
Sales of vacant land in Long Island areas formed the bulk of realty deals reported over the week-end.

Tactics of the Federal Government in new parity regulations on broadleaf tobacco surpluses were assailed yesterday as "penny-wise and pound-foolish" by the Cigar Manufacturers Association of America, Inc.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 26 (AP)--Dr. Melvin Amos Brannon, retired educator and author, died here today at the age of 84. He had been ill for several days.
ROME, March 26--The police acted promptly yesterday and today to nip in the bud scattered land seizures attempted by peasants here and there in Southern Italy and Sicily.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 26--Gov. Francis K. Newcomer has announced four appointments under the Panama Canal reorganization plan which becomes effective July 1. Col. Richardson Selee was named public affairs director, Henry L. Donovan ...

The city's water storage in the Catskill and Croton reservoirs increased by 1,106,000,000 gallons in the twenty-four hours ended at 8 A.M. yesterday. Edward J. Clark, chief engineer of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, announced the reservoirs held 140,247,000,000 gallons, as compared with 139,141,000,000 gallons at 8 A.M. on Saturday.

This newspaper is always glad to publish a communication from Henry L. Stimson, not because Mr. Stimson was twice Secretary of War and once Secretary of State and has otherwise distinguished himself, but because he is one of the wisest and bravest men we know.

The local wholesale markets were relatively quiet last week with few visiting buyers in town, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. In the ready-to-wear field, lastminute orders were received requesting immediate delivery on ...

New York bridge players dominated the twenty-fourth annual Eastern States bridge championships at the Park Sheraton Hotel last night when Dr. William T. Lipton of New York and Victor Mitchell of Brooklyn won the open pairs championship and received the Julian Goldman trophy.
Twenty-seven hundred adolescents in New York were helped with the problems of growing up last year by the family service staff of the Community Service Society, it was made known yesterday.

Figures purporting to show that from 1914 to 1948 wages rose twice as much as prices and living standards improved in "almost every area of family expenditure" were released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The Metropolitan Opera Company, having completed its regular season on Saturday, will leave today on the first part of its postseason tour. The company will depart at 10 A.M. from Grand Central Station to give nine performances during its week in Boston.

While the 1950 outlook for domestic business appears to be generally favorable, the domestic nonferrous metal industry is faced with the threat of large importations of metal and concentrates. This is due to low costs of foreign producers obtained by recent currency devaluation, low wages and ...

PITTSBURGH, March 26--Details of an agreement that settles a dispute over the advisability of merging the Pittsburgh Community Chest and the Health and Welfare Federation were made public today by Howard C. Scharfe, the federation's acting president.

Dave H. Morris Jr. of 455 East Fifty-seventh Street and Mrs. Alice Agnew Morris of 103 East Seventy-fifth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marian, to R. Bruce Baldwin, son of Mrs. Francis Elmore Baldwin of Highland Park, Ill., and the late Judge Baldwin.

WASHINGTON, March 26--Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's plea for an unpartisan study of the course the United States should pursue when the European Recovery Program ends won wide acclaim today in Congress, as well as within Administration circles.
A new plan under which the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States would buy new freight cars and lease them to the railroads was announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 23--An Australian observer, P.G. Law, who accompanied the joint BritishScandinavian Antarctic Expedition to its base, has now returned aboard the expedition's ship Norsel and described the difficulties of reaching Queen Maud Land through the barrier ice 60 to 100 feet high that shuts in the area.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 26-- The impending minimum wage scale for hotel and restaurant workers drew gastronomic as well as economic protests from owners and operators today.

Bob Manson figured in all three goals as the New York Rovers brought their home season to a close by battling the Milwaukee Clarks to a 3-3 tie in the initial clash of the final round Eastern Hockey League play-offs at Madison Square Garden before 6,482 yesterday afternoon.

A lower East Side property that had been in the Astor family ownership for 147 years passed to new control in a deal reported over the week-end when Nathan Wilson operator, bought 110-12 Avenue A, 134-38 East Seventh Street and 537 East Sixth Street, facing Tompkins Square, from the trustees of the Astor Estate.
WASHINGTON, March 26--The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important votes during the period March 18 to 24 are given in the appended tabulation:

GARCHES, France, March 26-- Scientists of Pasteur Institute said here today that after five years of research they had established beyond doubt the presence of antibodies, or agents combating bacteria, in the milk of mothers who had been immunized against disease in the last months of pregnancy.
In yesterday's Carnegie Hall Twilight Series the honors fell to Barbara Denenholz, who gave a piano recital that maintained the high standards this series has offered. Miss Denenholz played ...

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 26--A Communist campaign of "direct action and incitement to violence," as it is described in one official report, is gathering momentum throughout Western Germany, according to authoritative sources.
FREEPORT, L.I., March 26-- Lieut. Comdr. Jack Sperling gripped the forward rail of the bridge with one hand and peered intently through his binoculars.
Snow--wet and mixed with rain, but still snow in the records of the Weather Bureau here--fell in the metropolitan area last night as a soggy finale to a pleasant spring Sunday.

Let us look again at a very important matter. On April 1, Mayor O'Dwyer's executive budget must be presented to the Board of Estimate and the City Council. We are aware that many pressures are upon him in the making of this budget. Many of the hundred agencies and departments represented by lines in this budget will have to be disappointed, at least in part. The money isn't there.

LOS ANGELES, March 26-- Horse racing with pari-mutuel betting is illegal in California under a decision just handed down by the State District Court of Appeals here, holding the horse-racing act unconstitutional.
Jack Jordan, 45-year-old United States citizen sentenced Wednesday in Hamilton, Bermuda, to a month in jail for reufsing to tell what he did with 6,000 he had on deposit in a Hamilton bank, said ...
For the first time in the twentyfive-year history of the New York Community Trust, it reported yesterday that grants in a year had exceeded the million-dollar mark.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 26--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Benneyan of White Plains and Willow, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Jean Louise, to Andrew Peter Kordalewski, son of Mrs. Vaclaw Kordalewski of Springfield, Mass., and the late Mr. Kordalewski. The wedding will take place in June.

Moura Lympany was the piano soloist on Saturday evening with the Philharmonic-Symphony conducted by Victor De Sabata. She played Beethoven's G major Concerto. The revised program also contained Ravels "Mother Goose" Suite. Held over from the previous Thursday evening-Friday afternoon pair of concerts were Verdi's "Sicilian Vespers" Overture and Dvorak's "New World" Symphony.
All was ready at Hapsburg House, an eating place with OldWorld atmosphere on Fifty-fifth Street off Second Avenue, at 2 P.M. yesterday for the Gourmet Society dinner.

Three thousand members of the Police Department from Manhattan, Richmond and the Bronx overflowed the grand ballroom of the Astor Hotel yesterday for the thirty-second annual communion breakfast of the Police Department Holy Name Society.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 26-- Chris Mohn, Norwegian athlete studying at Middlebury College, made a brilliant comeback with two jumps of 199 feet to turn back his compatriot, Art Tokle of Brooklyn's Norway S.C., for the Class A Vermont Open ski-jumping championship today.

IN the first post-war baseball season of 1946 the fans excitedly exclaimed, "The pros are backs!" They were delighted to see the old stars in action once more. Perhaps the majority of the sideline observers never noticed it in the next few campaigns, but there was a disturbing ....
ZURICH, Switzerland, March 26 --Swiss experts have analyzed the gold price drop in France.
MADRID, March 26--A new and vigorous campaign, ostensibly against Freemasonry but with Britain apparently the real target, is developing here.

In a pastoral letter read yesterday in all churches of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. Cardinal Spellman begged the faithful to join with Pope Pius XII in Passion Sunday prayers that leaders of nations "may realize that war is the bitter fruit of blindness and hatred, while peace is the golden harvest of wisdom and peace."

The battleship should be stripped of her big guns and converted into a launcher of missiles, guided and otherwise, and should also be used for anti-aircraft defense at sea, asserts Vice Admiral Gerald F. Bogan.

The grand slam of basketball-- victory in both the national invitation and the National Collegiate A.A. tournaments--is only one step removed from City College's amazing band of hoopsters. This proximity to the much sought after double was made possible by the Lavender's sensational 78-73 success over North Carolina State in the N.C.A.A. Eastern final at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

The return to God of our "selfsatisfied and intellectually cocky" generation is not at all impossible, the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, pastor of the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, Broadway and 174th Street, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 26--A new Congressional investigation of the steel industry, with subpoena powers to force the submission of requested data, was proposed today as a Senate House study committee submitted its findings.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 26-- Anglo-Israeli financial negotiations on problems dating from the mandate days will be concluded in London tomorrow with the signing of an agreement satisfactory to both sides, according to reliable sources.

CHICAGO, March 26--Grain markets extended their advance on the Board of Trade last week, marking two weeks of almost daily upturns. All deliveries of wheat and corn, May oats, and May, July and January soybeans were carried to new seasonal peak levels.
TOKYO, March 26 (AP)--Shanghai, the "city built on mud," is being strangled by the ooze from which it arose.

Museum directors who attempt to improve on the beauty of a work of art by an over-ambitious exhibition of it were sharply criticized yesterday by Rene d'Harnoncourt, director of the Museum of Modern Art.
BATTAMBANG, Indo-China, March 26--Activities in their behalf carried on within Thailand have been of vital importance for revolutionary groups in Indo-China since the Japanese war.

JAMESTOWN, R.I., March 26-- Comdr. Owen Bartlett, U.S.N., retired, who won the Navy Cross and the Order of the British Empire for action aboard destroyers in Europe in the first World War, died at his home here today. He was in his sixty-sixth year.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved irregularly last week. Spot cotton and the nearer future deliveries showed net losses, while the more distant months were relatively unchanged to slightly higher. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 20 to up 16 points for the week.

Eight super-tankers and a giant hopper dredge were completed last year by the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Chester, Pa., but no new contracts for ship construction were received and orders for four super-tankers were canceled, according to the annual report of the parent Sun Oil Company.

Spring and summer fashions for 7-to-14-year-olds were modeled Saturday morning in the Special Events Center at Abraham Straus. Starting with spring coats and suits, the show progressed to warmer weather styles of picolay and organdy.

Early appearance of icebergs in the Atlantic eastward of Newfoundland has resulted in an advisory message from the Navy Hydrographic Office to all ships recommending that they drop farther south to steamer track B immediately, the Third Coast Guard District reported yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, March 26--The steel ingot output rate rose 5 points last week to 95.5 per cent of rated capacity. This figure represents a considerable amount of steel, because there have been new capacity figures since the start of the year. It was believed here that last week's increase will be bettered this week.

The real reason for the existence of the church is the preparation of conditions in which it will not be necessary, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Gill declared in a sermon yesterday at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue ands 105th Street.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 26 --For the first time in the sailing dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Bob Bavier Jr. led in the scoring today. Over eight races in his boat Cricket he made 214 points, two more than Arthur Knapp accumulated with his Agony.

By cutting red tape and designating Commissioner Francis J. Bloustein to expedite applications, the City Planning Commission, is inducing private operators to construct garages in congested residential areas, Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the agency, announced yesterday.

THORNWOOD, N.Y., March 26--For the delicate task of correcting the thinking of wayward boys before quirks lead to crime, Westchester County is developing on a farm near West Lake Drive an unusual "reflection center" that has no woodshed and few restraints.

WASHINGTON, March 26--Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, announced today that the infant mortality rate in the United States had dropped to an all-time low in 1948, when only thirty-two out of every 1,000 babies died during their first year.

The League of Composers gave its fourth and last regular concert of the season last night in the Museum of Modern Art, presenting two pieces of chamber music new to this city and two first performances. One of the latter, Leon Kirchner's String Quartet (1949), was an impressive work of art.

Secretary General Trygve Lie's proposal for a special meeting of the United Nations Security Council as part of a twenty-year peace program was backed last night by Carlos P. Romulo, president of the U.N. General Assembly, when he spoke at Carnegie Hall at the fifth annual George Gershwin memorial concert of B'nai B'rith Victory Lodge No. 1481.
Four men were arrested early yesterday morning and charged with committing three crimes within twenty minutes in the Yorkville section. Two patrolmen fired seven shots to halt the fugitives.

Physically handicapped radio operators, including many who sailed on ships throughout World War II, have been reassured of thier eligibility to go to sea by a new order that in its original wording had threatened to put many of them ashore, it was reported yesterday by the American Radio AssociaC.I.O.

Carpet manufacturers who recently granted pension benefits to employer are studying additional manufacturing costs involved to determine whether a price increase is called for, mill representatives revealed last week. They ruled out immediate price advances.

LONDON, March 26--In the last week the stock markets have not been provided with any fresh developments to stir them out of the state of listlessness into which they have drifted since the general election.

ROME, March 26--Political strikes and social hatred fostered by atheistic and anti-clerical forces, the breakdown of moral values, licentiousness, the will to destroy what are the bases of civilized Christian life--these factors are responsible for the evils besetting present-day society, Pope Pius XII said today.

Arthur Godfrey, accompanied by his ukulele, will begin a series of twice-weekly television programs over the Columbia Broadcasting System, beginning April 4. The entertainer will present songs and ukulele lessons on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 7:45 to 8 P.M.

WASHINGTON, March 26--A lavishly furnished suite of rooms with blue, yellow and chartreuse walls was finished two years and four months ago at the Army Medical Center and is yet to be occupied. It has remained empty because of President Truman's excellent state of health.

The thoroughness with which Willie (The Actor) Sutton had prepared for the $64,000 robbery of the Sunnyside, Queens, branch bank of the Manufacturers Trust Company, was disclosed yesterday by the police when they made public papers left by the missing bandit. The documents showed he had planned the robbery for a month before its execution on March 9.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 26-- Although 6 points ahead with only a minute and fifteen seconds to play, the New York Knickerbockers could not hold this apparently insurmountable lead over the Syracuse Nationals tonight. Joe Lapchick's lads did gain a 77-77 regulation-time draw, only to collapse in the five-minute overtime, the Nats pulling away for a 91-83 triumph.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 26-- The Administration has settled on the position it will maintain on the issue of releasing loyalty files and it will be presented tomorrow in Washington by Attorney General J. Howard McGrath with President Truman's approval.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26-- Erwin Mason Simpson, for thirtyfive years president of William A. Simpson Son, one of this city's oldest insurance brokerage firms, died last night at his home in the Mayfair House, Germantown, after a long illness. His age was 84.

The spicy scent of Italian cooking filled THE TIMES' test kitchen the other day; it was cooking by a master. On the stove were heating a tomato meat sauce for spaghetti, stuffed mushrooms and some manicotti.

LONDON, March 26--Renewal of negotiations for a new British military treaty with Egypt, which is a keystone of the Middle East defensive system, has lately been under consideration in London and Cairo after a lapse of three years in treaty talks.

The New York Americans gained their second consecutive victory in the Lewis Cup competition of the American Soccer League by defeating the Philadelphia Americans, 1--0, yesterday at Sterling Oval, the Bronx. The first half was scoreless.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 26 (AP)--Sammy Snead put the chill on his challengers with a morning 66, then came back with a closing 67 to win the $10,000 Greensboro open golf tournament today by ten strokes with a record 269 total.

Net income of the Alleghany Corporation in 1949 decreased to $1,869,557 from $3,925,952 in 1948 due largely to the fact that the 1948 account included $1,456,897 of nonrecurring accumulated interest on bonds of certain railways in reorganization, the corporation reported yesterday.

Feminine counterparts of the eccentric Collyer brothers of Harlem were found yesterday in a junkfilled cold-water flat at 1410 Amsterdam Avenue, near 130th Street. One sister was dead, the other incoherent.
CHICAGO, March 26--Corn has been the surprise of the grain trade in advancing in the face of record-breaking supplies back in the country. But, as is the case with wheat, so much grain is in ...

A colorful parade was staged yesterday on upper Fifth Avenue to mark the 129th anniversary of Greek independence. A sidewalk throng, estimated by the police at 100,000, applauded the matchers. Civic, veteran, church and school groups representing Greek organizations of the metropolitan area strode up the Avenue from Sixtieth Street to Seventieth behind banners proclaiming Greek-American friendship and demanding release of 28,000 Greek children being held by Communist neighbor States.

HENRY MORTON ROBINSON is about as versatile a jack of all literary trades as you can find among modern writers. At various times he has written poetry, short stories gnd magazine articles. In collaboration with Joseph Campbell he labored five years and brought forth a triumph of scholarly ingenuity and misspent energy, "A Skeleton Key to Finnegans Wake."

Despite a drastic reduction in the numerical strength of Great Britain's armed forces, her military budget for the fiscal year 1950-51 will equal 25 per cent of the nation's entire national budget, according to Lieut. Gen. Frank E. W. Simpson, head of the West Command of the British Isles.

The Westchester County Park Commission has come up with some sobering thoughts in its annual report to the county's Board of Supervisors. The Commission found that traffic on Westchester parkways increased 15 per cent in 1949 and could be expected to rise at least 10 per cent a year until 1955.

One of the pleasant rewards for an off-Broadway prowler was unfolded last night by that recently formed group calling itself Theatre Classics. In the Walt Whitman School's tiny hall this band of competent players put on a thoroughly enjoyable revival of Moliere's amusing escapade, "The Miser," adapted from "L'Avare." This is Theatre Classics' second production of the season and it would seem that the band has gotten off on the right track.

The winter is, of course, the season for dining out, or for dining in while surrounded by those friends whose turn it is to dine out. Once or twice a week it is possible to inspect the operation of other homes, privately deploring the behavior of children and speculating

Newbold Morris, former president of the City Council, and Arthur Garfield Hays, attorney, received last night the Louis D. Brandeis medals for 1950 for their consistent efforts in the promotion of good-will between Christians and Jews.

The New York Rangers conquered the Toronto Maple Leafs in the final game of the regular National Hockey League race at Madison Square Garden last night. Flashing a persistent and aggressive type of play, the Blue Shirts sent the visiting sextet down to a 5-to-3 defeat.
PARIS, March 26--West Germany's entry into the Council of Europe is an essential condition for a French-German understanding Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, declared today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 26 --There are strong indications that Anglo-United States policy toward the Soviet puppet state of Albania has temporarily altered during the last few months, and that for the moment, instead of desiring the overthrow of the satellite Government of Enver Hoxha, it is content ...

Net income of the United Aircraft Corporation in 1949 amounted to $10,093,182, equal to $3.31 a common share, compared with $9,423,718, or $3.05 a share, in 1948, the company reported to stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON. March 26--Efforts to create an air-cargo fleet, or air merchant marine, useful alike in peace or war, are at a standstill in Congress pending Administration efforts to agree on a program President Truman can support.

WASHINGTON, March 26--Publication of a 109-page pamphlet, Parents Responsibility in Character Development, was announced today by Mrs. J.L. Blair Buck, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

DETROIT, March 26--Hopes for an early settlement of the 62-dayold strike against the Chrysler Corporation by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., were raised today when negotiators met in an unusual Sunday session for an hour and adjourned until tomorrow ...

The dual bill of Christopher Fry's "A Phoenix Too Frequent" and Kenneth White's "Freight" is being steered into the Fulton, where the joint offering is slated to open April 29, it became known yesterday.

Sales of cooperative apartments were reported by Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., as follows: in 10 Mitchell Place to Charles B. Gilbert; in 1220 Park Avenue to Mrs. William J. Banigan, and in 19 East Seventy-second Street to Mrs. Elmer D. Coulter.

Raising the voice of statesmanship above the partisan wrangles that threaten to engulf our foreign policy, Senator Vandenberg has issued a new appeal for domestic unity and an unpartisan approach to the vast problems confronting us as leaders of the free world that is faced with Soviet Russia's "sinister plan for world domination." As one of the principal Republican architects of our bipartisan foreign policy, which he ...

CHICAGO, March 26--The title of best in show in the recordsmashing event of the International Kennel Club went as expected to Mrs. John G. Winant's imported Scottish terrier, Ch. Walsing Winning Trick of Edgerstoune tonight.
PARIS, March 26--Discussions over attempts to bar the sale of Coca-Cola in this country have drawn French attention to the subject of the export of French wines to the United States.

MIAMI, Fla., March 26--The Dodgers had another gala afternoon playing host to their cousins from the Bronx, better known as the world champion Yankees, beating them today for the third straight time in the spring exhibition series, 11-8.

GENEVA, March 26--The breakdown last week of the latest and possibly final effort to get the Soviet bloc to talk seriously about means of increasing East-West trade has forced Western economic officials to start a complete re-examination of the world trade pattern.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 26-Government reports from all parts of the country have indicated that a record vote was cast in today's general election for 620 Deputies to... the two houses of Parliament.
American teachers were urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken, minister of the Riverside Church, to stimulate free inquiry in their classrooms as a matter of conscience.
ALBANY, March 26--Representative Vito Marcantonio, state chairman of the American Labor party, indicated today that the party would nominate its own candidate for Governor this year.

Although groups that have requested hearings on the Senate postal increase bill have failed to obtain clear-cut information on whether any will be scheduled, precedent and differences between the measures and that approved by the House virtually assure calling of hearings, it was learned last week.
A new series of counterfeit bills in the $10 and $20 denominations is being "mass produced" and circulated here in growing volume, it was announced yesterday.

A new development in the mental health field is under way in New York. Two settlement houses --Henry Street on the lower East Side and Hudson Guild in the West Side Chelsea area--are pioneering in aiding their members with emotional troubles in an effort to help...

Expressing confidence that British exports to the United States would show a substantial increase this year over 1949, Cyril Kleinwort, managing director of Kleinwort Sons Co., merchant bank of London, said yesterday that the Drake America Corporation for the...
LAUREL, Md., March 27 (AP)-- Manchac outgamed John E. Hughes' Vital Sun in the final eighth mile to score a head victory in the featured Monument purse, a sprint at six furlongs at Laurel Park today.
An evening of new chamber music was presented by the Contemporary Music School, whose director is Stefan Wolpe, in Times Hall last night.

The Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York, which reduced its net operating loss last year, could cut it still further in the future if the city's payments for the care of indigent patients were increased, Charles P. Cooper, president of the hospital, declared yesterday in its eighty-first annual report.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 27-- Existing theories that persons choose their life work by "accident" or by "impulse" are false, Dr. Eli Ginzberg, Associate Professor of Economics at Columbia University, said tonight.

The principles of the motionpicture production code have been adopted by WOR-TV to apply to its television shows, it was announced yesterday by Theodore C. Streibert, president. The action of the video outlet comes after Wayne Coy, chairman of the Federal Communication...

Meeting for the second session of its four-day convention at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday, the National Association of Basketball Coaches nominated four men for Metropolitan Basketball Association's "outstanding man of the year award" for 1950.

WASHINGTON, March 27--It was learned tonight on good authority that the resignation of Col. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney as Under Secretary of Commerce was on the President's desk but had not yet been accepted.

Emerson Foote, president and founding partner of Foote, Cone Belding, has been given a one-year leave of absence, it was learned yesterday. Don Belding, who has been chairman of the executive committee and head of the Los Angeles office, has become president.
Spot-checking New York's daily imports of 3,300,000 quarts of milk is an around-the-clock detective job performed by twenty-one Health Department inspectors.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 27--Five acres on the northern rim of the Westchester County Airport in Purchase were leased to the Government today by the Board of Supervisors as a site for a $500,000 administration building for the Fifty-second Fighter Wing of the Air National Guard.

The City of New York awarded yesterday $40,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes to a group of twentysix banks and trust companies. The notes, dated today, will mature on May 4. They bear an interest rate of 1 1/8 per cent.

Consumer resistance to lesserknown Scotch whiskies of standard quality must be overcome by cooperative promotions, Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., declared yesterday in his annual industry review.

EL CENTRO, Calif., March 27-- The illegal immigration of 10,000 Mexicans monthly across the California border--in addition to some 20,000 elsewhere along the 2,000mile frontier--is causing extensive disruptions in the American labor picture.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- Charging that Administration key men were trying to gag him, Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire took the Senate floor tonight to open what was viewed widely at the Capitol as a frontal Republican move to "get" Dean Acheson, Secretary of State.
A city-wide stoppage on the municipally owned subway, elevated and bus lines was threatened yesterday by Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O.
CHICAGO, March 27--Centralized purchasing systems are in use in forty-two of the forty-eight states, a report by the Council of State Governments noted here.
SAIGON, Indo-China, March 27 --The chief issue in the IndoChina state of Viet Nam as far as the majority of the people are concerned is the simple undiluted one of national independence.

State-supervised banks of the United States and Hawaii registered a gain in assets of $1,500,000,000 in 1949, almost four times the increase in 1948, Maurice C. Sparling, president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks and California Superintendent of Banks, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that an employer must furnish a labor union with full information regarding merit ratings of employes and pay rises based on the ratings, regardless of...
ANKARA, Turkey, March 25-- Turkey has only one fundamental problem in foreign affairs and that is proximity to dynamic Russia. Czar and commissar have been edging down this way for generations.

A vacant plot, 100 by 205 feet, at the southwest corner of Albemarle Road and Gravesend Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Andros Holdings, Inc., to Henrietta Kanter. The property is assessed at $25,000.

DETROIT, March 27--Prospects for an early settlement of the strike against the Chrysler Corporation by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., struck a snag today when the union accused the company of hedging on its offer to set up a $30,000,000 fund for pensions.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)-- A Navy expert said today he had reason to believe that a development was just ahead that would enable the United States "to drive submarines off the seas."

The Knights of the Wine Cup in America celebrated their tenth anniversary by dining with their guests at the Pierre Hotel last evening. Manuel Orta, the chef supervising the complex preparations for the 108 men and women who attended, muttered:

Britain's wage-freeze is melting fast. Sir Stafford Cripps met the Economic Committee of the Trades Union Congress last night in the opening skirmish of what is going, to be a hard-fought and crucial battle for increased wages.

The Truman Administration is putting the final touches on Congressional recommendations intended to permit the Federal Government to come to the rescue of state unemployment insurance funds when their reserves fall too low.

GENEVA, March 27--The European coal surplus, which has been growing steadily but almost unnoticed outside coal circles, has blossomed this spring, like a skunk cabbage, into an embarrassing economic problem.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 --"Lights Out," a 1945 novel by Baynard Kendrick which Universal bought for the screen three years ago and subsequently shelved, has been revived for production by Robert Buckner, it was learned today.

HONG KONG, March 27--Communist China's first serious attempt to invade the Nationalist stronghold of Hainan Island was completely smashed in a nine-hour battle yesterday, it was reported from Hainan today.

CHICAGO, March 27--The tobacco industry needs a comprehensive public relations program and more efficient and economical distribution methods, O. Parker McComas, president of Philip Morris Co., said today.
LONDON, March 27--Despite several factors that made for caution on the part of investors, most sections of the stock markets here were quietly steady today.

Prices of identical qualities of men's suits and topcoats for next fall will show advances of approximately 40 cents to 75 cents over the opening quotations for spring, Jerome I. Udell, president of Max Udell Sons Co., Inc., manufacturer of Gramercy Park Clothes, estimated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The British Government has proposed that the foreign secretaries of Britain, the United States and France should review all aspects of their relations with the Soviet Union in their meeting beginning in London during the first two weeks in May.

Pending trial of a suit to determine whether the American Bowling Congress should be barred permanently from sponsoring tournaments in New York State, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein applied yesterday in Supreme Court for a temporary injunction against the international organization. This motion for an immediate restraining order will be argued on April 6.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The Supreme Court today sustained the contempt-of-Congress conviction of Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States. It rejected his argument that a Communist official could not have a fair trial before a jury that included Federal employes.
The constitutionality of the Feinberg Law was upheld yesterday in a unanimous opinion by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 27--The chiefs of staff of the North Atlantic Treaty countries will meet here tomorrow to approve a detailed defense plan that lays down the first estimates of requirements from each of the twelve countries over a five-year period.
Dr. John Frederic Erdmann, "the grand old man of New York medicine," marked his eighty-sixth birthday yesterday with a round of activities that would have exhausted many a younger man.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The highest legal and investigative authorities of the Truman Administration refused today to turn over to the Senate all or any part of the Federal Bureau of Investigation loyalty files on accused State Department personnel.
CHICAGO, March 27 (UP)--A cyclonic spring storm whirled eastward tonight, generating high winds, blizzards, hail and thunderstorms that took a mounting toll of lives.
Despite the slow pace in fullfashioned hosiery buying, brand name manufacturers will resist pressure for lower prices, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)-- Counsel for the State of Louisiana today asked the Supreme Court to review its so-called California decision on which the Federal Government bases a claim to oil-rich lands adjoining Louisiana and Texas in the Gulf of Mexico.

The rise of mammoth unions in the mass production industries has taken the spotlight away from such long-established organizations as the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union.
WASHINGTON, March 27--The United States has told Russia that her plans to double the price of rubles for American diplomatic personnel in Moscow are "completely unjustified."

BERLIN, March 17--Two bored Russian soldiers guarding a bridge along one of the main arteries for traffic into Berlin from the Soviet zone proved susceptible last weekend to the lure of a bottle of "schnapps" discreetly proffered by a passing Germany, and retired into nearby woods for a brief respite.
The city's first attempt at making rain artificially by seeding clouds with dry ice particles is scheduled for this morning.

Surrogate George Frankenthaler ruled late yesterday that Russian War Relief, Inc., "was not functioning" when William Nelson Cromwell died on July 19, 1948, and was not qualified to receive a legacy of nearly $450,000 that he bequeathed to it.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 27 --The Bollingen Prize for Poetry, whose award last year to Ezra Pound stirred a storm of protest, was won today by Wallace Stevens, 70-year-old Hartford, Conn., insurance executive. The prize is $1,000.

CHICAGO, March 27--Private bankers today attacked the Federal Government's expansion of its banking activities, then warned against low down-payments on long-maturity installment loans by banks. They spoke at the first day's session of the American Bankers Association's annual credit conference.

Revisions in the City Code pertaining to construction of buildings that might give Broadway five new legitimate theatres within the next year will be brought before the City Council for approval next month.

DETROIT, March 27 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings, haunted by one of pro hockey's most persistent play-off jinxes, were trying to sleep off the specter of Toronto today as they rested up for another shot at the old hex.

FOR many years one of the most distinguished citizens of the town where I live was a blue-eyed Yankee with Vermont ties who lived with his wife and five daughters in an old New England house not far from the railroad station. He was shy and modest and a little deaf.
The almost universal acceptance of the transparent dress has presented to designers of underclothes a major problem similar to that of the short, tight skirt and the strapless dress.
CAIRO, March 27--King Abdullah, in a note to the Arab League Council delivered today, announced that Jordan was boycotting this meeting of the Council.

Investigation into the Long Island Rail Road wreck at Rockville Centre, L.I., on Feb. 17, in which thirty-two persons were killed, developed yesterday into a dispute on the proper interpretation of statistics.

Amid all the confusion and uncertainty that seem to surround the future of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System one central fact seems clear to us. This is, that the employes of that company must receive the $1,500,000 in back pay that is due them.
Mayor O'Dwyer has told the principal Democratic leaders in the state that he would not support for election this fall any statewide Democratic candidate who is also the nominee of the Liberal party.

BURBANK, Calif., March 27-- The T-men on the Giant squad took over today when the indications were that all else would fail and broke the spell of the Browns with a victory that was measured by 5 to 3.

GABERONES, Bechuanaland, March 27 (UP)--Hhe British were reported today to have ordered papers served on Seretse Khama, excluding him from Serowe, capital of the Bamangwato reserve, and a tribal spokesman warned again that there might be violence among the 100,000 tribesmen.

LONDON, March 27--There was a lean and hungry look about many of the questions on the House of Commons order paper today. Several wistful members wanted to know what the prospects were for more and tastier food.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27-- United States Ambassador Loy W. Henderson declared in a speech tonight that "it is the sincere desire of the United States that the countries of Asia shall maintain their political independence and territorial integrity."
A last-hour assault on prices caused a sharp recession yesterday on the stock market and even eliminated a good portion of strength exhibited earlier by the television issues.
The grand jury in Brooklyn investigating organized gambling struck yesterday at betting syndicates operating among college students in the borough.
GENEVA, March 27--The Trusteeship Council completed substantive work today on the statute for an internationalized Jerusalem.
PARIS, March 27--The Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor ordered a twentyfour-hour dock strike today in all French ports and, except for Cherbourg, the order was generally effective.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 27 --Mrs. Starr Blasingame Carithers of Winder, Ga., widow of Hugh A. Carithers, was married here today to Bishop Ivan Lee Holt of St. Louis, chairman of the Methodist Council of Bishops and president of the Methodist World Federation,...

Although hotel occupancy rates declined somewhat last year, the Hilton Hotels Corporation increased its earnings over 1948 partly through its success in applying industrial methods to hotel operations, Conrad N. Hilton, president, revealed in the annual report issued to stockholders today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27-- A "calculated risk" in America's "national strategy" during the cold war calls for keeping industry capable of "immediate and explosive expansion," Karl R. Bendetsen, assistant secretary of the Army, asserted here today.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- Mrs. Esther Caukin Brunauer, a State Department official accused by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of "Communist-front activities," swore today that she was not and never had been a Communist or Communist sympathizer.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 27 (AP) --The off-again-on-again National Boxing Association heavyweight title fight between Ezzard Charles and Challenger Freddie Beshore finally hit the rocks for keeps tonight.

The third Saturday in April marks the opening of the trout season in several nearby states, including Connecticut, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and Maryland, and the fact that the 15th falls on Saturday will give the truant officer a chance to do some fishing.

Safety aspects of the shipbuilding, ship operating and stevedoring industries are scheduled for discussion at the two-day session of the marine section of the National Safety Council, tomorrow and Thursday in the Statler Hotel.

CHICAGO, March 27--All deliveries of wheat, corn, soybeans and lard sold at new seasonal highs today with May and June soybeans up the daily permissible limit of 10c a bushel at one time.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27--"Bases on Balls," that parody from the New York Baseball Writers' show last winter, was Manager Burt Shotton's theme song tonight, but he wasn't warbling it joyfully, after watching Carl Erskine and Pat McGlothin walk six straight men to blow a game to the Athletics in the eighth inning.

NEW DELHI, India, Tuesday, March 28--The general secretary of the All-India Hindu Mahasabha (Great Society), an extremist organization claiming 600,000 members and many more partisans, called for war against Pakistan yesterday.

The two executive offices of the National Room Service, Inc., of 55 West Forty-second Street, and the corporation were convicted yesterday in Special Sessions of fortyone counts of petit larceny in connection with a $76,000 fraud upon apartment seekers.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 27--The dickering and bickering with which the West German Government has surrounded its presumptive entry into the Council of Europe has succeeded in arousing the anger of the three Western occupation powers.
Prices of coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange were sharply higher in active trading yesterday, with distant deliveries rising the daily permissible limit of 200 points.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 27-- New processes and techniques for improving production and reducing costs of petroleum products were described here today before the 117th meeting of the American Chemical Society. About 2,500 chemists and chemical engineers from over the nation are attending.
It is none too soon to begin making careful plans for April 1. Since a fair share of the world, and not all of it the juvenile part...
Women active in behalf of the West Side Day Nursery have taken over the mezzanine of the Radio City Music Hall on Friday from 10 A.M. until 3 P.M. for the special Easter program.
WASHINGTON, March 27--At the end of what might be compared to the seventh inning in baseball the Administration's score against Senator McCarthy of Wisconsin is nine to nothing.

The Public Service Commission held yesterday what many persons hoped would be the last hearing on a case that opened nearly four years ago to determine whether the Consolidated Edison Company should reduce permanently the rates of 2,500,000 electricity consumers in the city.

TRENTON, March 27--The New Jersey Assembly approved tonight an extension of the utility antistrike law, now operating in the wage dispute of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company and its 12,000 operators.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 27--President Truman announced with pleasure today that Dr. Philip C. Jessup, the most prominent person accused by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in his charges of Communist and spy penetration of the State Department, would continue indefinitely in his position as United States Ambassador at Large.

WASHINGTON, March 27--For the second time this year, the Supreme Court refused today to interfere with a lower court ruling that hiring halls for seamen as now conducted were illegal under the Taft-Hartley Act. The tribunal rejected a plea for reconsideration of its action of Feb. 13.

ALBANY, March 27--Governor Dewey signed into law today a bill divesting the Public Service Commission of jurisdiction over fares on private bus lines in New York City and placing full responsibility for all bus fares in New York upon the city administration.

A milliner who does not believe in any one "look" for a season, but rather in creating a variety of silhouettes designed to flatter the many different types of faces, is Keneth Hopkins of Beverly Hills, who arrived with a collection of 144 hats for a showing yesterday at Russeks.

The Equitable Gas Company will offer today 2,000,000 shares of its common stock to the public at $24.25 a share. The stock is being sold for the account of the Philadelphia Company in compliance with a divestment order of the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
PARIS, March 27 (AP)--Control of the world's trade in tin may be placed under United Nations supervision as a result of a meeting being held here, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) --A professor told a special House committee investigating lobbying today that members of Congress were as much to blame as anyone if they got "pushed around" by "pressure" groups.

A bookstore in New York is about to take to the road with a traveling salesman at its wheel. Libraries on wheels are nothing new--many outlying communities that have no branch libraries are served by them--but as a commercial venture, this is the first of its kind.
The first really spring-like weather of a season that so far has been largely spring in name only was promised yesterday by the Weather Bureau for today.
WASHINGTON, March 27--Republicans in the House of Representatives agreed as a matter of policy today to seek a substantial cut in the Administration's $3,372,450,000 foreign aid requests.

Max Perlow, who publicly resigned from the Communist party last June to retain his position as international secretary-treasurer of the United Furniture Workers of America, C.I.O., has been decisively defeated for two posts in his own union, Local 76-B, it was announced yesterday by the union's "rank and file" committee.

Ample evidence of the growth and usefulness of The New York Community Trust is contained in its current report on the twenty-fifth year of its operation. Beginning in 1924 with an inconsequential grant of $20, the Trust reports that its 1949 grants for philanthropic purposes aggregated $1,065,065.

Four men were scalded to death yesterday when steam and boiling water under high pressure roared from a broken pipe in a five-story boiler at the New York Steam Corporation, 417 East Thirty-fifth Street.

Contract negotiations between the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A.F.L., and Atlantic and Gulf coast shipping companies were resumed yesterday for the first time since Dec. 15. The present contract expired on Sept. 30, but was extended four times and now is due to expire April 15.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The State Department announced a major shift of top-level officials this afternoon, after President Truman had announced in Key West that Dr. Philip C. Jessup would remain Ambassador at Large.
A four-alarm fire that spread to three tenements in Harlem routed 120 families early yesterday, two occupants and a fireman being slightly injured.
Dr. Spaulding took office less than four years ago as State Commissioner of Education. His death at the age of 53 deprives the state and the nation of an able and useful leader.

Transparency is the fashion in hats as well as in dresses this year. Milgrim's array of spring and summer millinery seen yesterday during luncheon in the Persian Room of the Hotel Plaza included openwork lacy straw and sheer horsehair, together with a special group of French imports by Jacques Fath.
ERDING, Germany, March 27-- Two of the Czech pilots who flew three transport planes to the airfield here last Friday said that a major reason for their doing so was religious.

TOKYO, March 27--The Japanese Government with approval of Allied headquarters today placed a curb on labor's "March offensive" for a new round of wage increases by ordering compulsory arbitration of a coal miners' strike, which was held to be endangering the national economy.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 27--The United States has the biggest and strongest navy in the world but it is "not completely adequate to meet all the requirements of war," Admiral Forrest P. Sherman said today.

SAN SALVADOR, March 27-- William W. Renwick, an American fiscal representative, who had lived here since 1923 and had aided this and other Latin-American countries in financial matters, died today after a long illness. His age was 60.
WASHINGTON, March 27--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it has approved a plan for the reorganization of the Pittsburgh Railways Company.

On the threshold of the greatest achievement in City College sports history, Nat Holman's Beavers yesterday were installed two-point favorites to defeat Bradley tonight before 18,000 persons at Madison Square Garden and wrap up the National Collegiate A.A. basketball championship.

Thousands of devices for the protection of man against most of the hazards of modern living were set up yesterday in the Statler Hotel for New York's twentieth annual Safety Convention and Exposition, which will open today and continue through Friday.

Three museums whose interests center on modern art issued yesterday a joint statement affirming their belief in the necessity of expression in the arts, and defining their function as objective surveyors presenting an impartial review of the contemporary scene.

"Strange Convoy," a magazine story by Tom Blackburn about San Francisco a century ago, which R.K.O. bought last May and subsequently shelved, has been revived for production by Warren Duff. Oliver H.P. Garrett has been engaged to work on the scenario.

F.B.I. Director Hoover and Attorney General McGrath refused yesterday to turn over secret loyalty files to a Senate committee and said they would continue to withhold them until specifically ordered by the President to release them.
Fiber rugs, styled so that they are as suitable indoors as on the porch all the year 'round, now are being introduced in most New York stores.

LONDON, March 27--Approaching the critical period of budget debate, the Labor Government had its over-all majority in the House of Commons reduced to three today when another Labor member of the House died.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The Immigration Service revealed today that it was preparing a full report on the case of Mrs. Ellen Knauff, a German war bride whom the Attorney General seeks to deport as a security risk.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27--The Yankees are still traveling in reverse. Today even the Cardinals, their one soft touch thus far this spring, got out of hand.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 27 (AP)--The Boston Braves' rookie first sacker, Hank Ertman, clubbed a bases-loaded double in the last of the eighth today, scoring the runs necessary for an 18-16 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

The Staff Officer Association of America, which recently won the right to represent pursers on four major steamship lines operating from New York in elections sponsored by the National Labor Relations Board, has opened negotiations with the operators for a contract, it became known yesterday.

Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., operator of a chain of retail apparel stores from coast to coast, established in 1949 its eleventh consecutive annual increase in sales and earned the second largest profit on record, Hyman P. Kuchai, president, informed stockholders in the annual report, released for today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27--Premier Marshal Tito was elected to Parliament in four of the Republics of the Yugoslav Federation by majorities ranging from 99 to 99.8 per cent.

The National Aniline DivisionAllied Chemical and Dye Corporation, in an expansion move, has leased the entire twelfth floor of the Crystal Building at 47 West Street. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., were the brokers.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 2 points lower to 15 points higher, with new-crop months showing the most strength.

Two thugs who are believed to have been armed with toy pistols escaped yesterday with a $6,000 payroll after forcing twelve persons to leave an elevator on the twenty-second floor of 498 Seventh Avenue, at Thirty-sixth Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 28--Mrs. Natalie Bayard Dresser Brown, mother of former Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, John Nicholas Brown, who herself was long active in civic and political life here, died at her home, Harbor Court, last night after a long illness, in her eighty-first year.

For the second time in ten weeks the Ambrose Lightship was rammed yesterday at her anchorago nine miles east of Sandy Hook. The accident was due to a heavy fog that delayed shipping, including the largest liner in the world, the Queen Elizabeth, as long as twenty-two hours.
TOKYO, March 28 (AP)--Gen. Douglas MacArthur commuted today the death sentences of six Japanese war criminals convicted of having murdered three United States Navy fliers in 1945.

CHICAGO, March 28--Both sales and earnings of Oliver Corporation in the quarter ending April 30 will be higher than in the preceding quarter, but will remain below the level a year ago, Alva W. Phelps, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting today.

ALBANY, March 28--With bond money appropriated in the supplemental budget now awaiting Governor Dewey's approval and Federal aid, the State Public Works Department is planning a $104,500,000 road-construction program in the fiscal year starting Saturday that will emphasize arterial highway construction in cities and other urban areas.

First steps toward the eviction of fifty-nine tenants living in or near the former Rhinelander properties in Washington Square were taken yesterday before the City Rent Commission. The move met spirited protests from the tenants fighting plans to erect an elevenstory apartment house on the site.

Too many young persons take school or college courses with the sole idea that they will help them get better jobs, Miss Dorothea F. Sullivan of the Catholic University of America in Washington declared here yesterday.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 (AP)--Eddie Miller, once rated the fanciest-fielding shortstop in baseball, received his unconditional release today from the Phillies.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday and closing prices were irregular, 9 points higher to 8 points lower than on Monday.

LONDON, March 28 (Reuters) --Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, has just lost one of his jobs--Deputy to the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. Of the more than fifty members of the Soviet Council of Ministers [Cabinet], only a handful have retained seats as Deputies.

Wallin, Chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents, voiced objections tonight to the "widespread belief" that the Government should provide an opportunity for higher education for all who desire it. He spoke at a dinner given here for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 28 (AP) --Chiang Kai-shek today appealed for world aid for the millions starving in Communist China.
CHICAGO, March 28 (AP)--The Chicago Great Western Railway today was ordered to set aside part of its March dividend for possible use as lawyers' fees in a stockholders' suit.

MOSCOW, March 28--Pravda declared today that Soviet Government "with consistency and firmness" had given repeated demonstrations of full preparedness to undertake the task of regularization of Soviet-American relations.

WASHINGTON, March 28--A Senate commerce subcommittee decided late today to invite C.V. Whitney, Acting Secretary of Commerce, to appear Thursday to tell what he knows about the case of Michael Lee, chief of the Department's Far Eastern branch, now the subject of a reopened loyalty investigation.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 28-- The chairman of Korea's National Assembly predicted here today that the Nationalist Government would return to power on China's mainland.
GENEVA, March 28--The World Health Organization issued a warning today against unrestricted use of streptomycin in the treatment of tuberculosis.

Prison sentences of up to five years were handed down yesterday to nine persons who admitted participation in a three-cent stamp counterfeiting ring. Seven others, also pleading guilty, received suspended sentences from Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman.

The Appellate Division, Second Department, reserved decision yesterday on an appeal from a lower court's ruling that sustained the removal last year of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish as rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Wednesday, March 29 (AP)--The Chinese Communists have cleared the approach route to Tibet by crumpling Nationalist resistance in Sikang Province, official dispatches said today.

WASHINGTON, March 28--Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder today announced that Liberty Bells of the same size, shape and tone as the original before it was cracked, will ring in all fortyeight states and the national Capital for the 1950 United States Savings Bond campaign, May 15 to July 4. With two spirited drills under their belts, the New York Rangers are "up" for the opener of their best four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup series with the Montreal Canadiens tonight at Madison Square Garden. Neither tonight's battle nor the only other play-off here on Sunday night will be televised.

Net earnings of the Standard Oil Company of California last year amounted to $137,856,477 or 15 per cent below the record $161,491,932 earned in 1948, the annual report informed its 94,691 stockholders yesterday.

The New York unemployment insurance law is the center of a "cold war" that may erupt as one of the pivotal issues in the state election campaign this fall.

Instead of lunging at the pitch, however, the Boston slugger let it go past him and thereby accepted a relatively harmless base on balls.

With the first pussy willows and clear sunny weather, conscientious homemakers begin thinking of spring cleaning. Simplified methods and new products have changed this task from its once dreaded nature.

Colonial Airlines has leased space on two floors in the New York Central Building at 230 Park Avenue, in which the airline will consolidate its general offices. Downtown and Radio City offices will be moved to their new quarters about May 1. Cross Brown Company, brokers, negoiated the lease.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 28 (AP)--Don McNeill of Bellerose, L.I., today advanced to the quarterfinals of the Bermuda invitation tennis. New York's rainmakers took to the skies yesterday on what was to have been their initial cloudseeding attempt, but the combination of a late start and blue skies over the Catskill watershed turned the expedition into a dry run.

The situation in India is again (or perhaps one should say, still) alarming. The Hindu extremists have now actually called for war against Pakistan. Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled, 1,126, compared with 1,296 last week and 1,337 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 497 arrivals yesterday against 587 last Tuesday.

PARIS, March 28--Disciplinary action against Lieut. Gen. George Revers, former French Chief of Staff, and Gen. CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 (AP)--The Phillies pounded out fourteen hits, including two home runs, and received fifteen bases on balls as they whipped the Cardinals, 21--6, in an exhibition game today.

OTTAWA, March 28--Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt was killed this morning in a plane crash that also took the lives of three United States Air Force officers and the 20-year-old son of the United States minister here.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 28--New automatic computing machinery will enable the Census Bureau to compile necessary information at least 400 times, faster than is being done through present methods, it was disclosed here today.

Muttering quietly to himself, John Himberger looked over the big chunks of red meat before him. He would pick one, set it down in his metal cart and say "the tiglon," or "the leopard." Each steak was suited to the personality of one of his charges in the lion house at the Central Park Zoo.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29-- A new attempt to evacuate 1,600 foreigners, including about 400 Americans, from Communist Shanghai is to be made by the American President Lines, it was disclosed here today by George L. Killion, president of the company.

A new type of deep-water telephone cable, equipped with automatic repeater devices that will magnify the sound of the voice at intervals as the electric signals speed along the ocean floor, is being installed between Key West, Fla., and Havana, it was announced yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Four three-story apartment biuldings in the Bronx to cost a total of $1,400,000 were among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Watson Gardens, Inc., of 371 East 149th Street, the Bronx, is the owner. Sidney Goldhammer is the architect.

The Lexington School for the Deaf, said to be the oldest institution of its kind in the country, has begun using television as an aid in the teaching of 255 deafened youngsters from 2 to 19 years old.
