WASHINGTON, March 29--A committee report to the House favoring abolition of the office of General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board said today the present structure had led to internal disruption and public confusion.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The programs formulated by free democratic labor in its worldwide fight on Communist sabotage of arms shipments under the North Atlantic Treaty and on Communist efforts to seize the budding trade union movement in Southeast Asia and Africa, were described to United States labor leaders here today.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 29 --The Dodgers today closed their spring series with the Athletics by losing a 10-inning, two-hour-fiftyminute marathon, 9--8, giving Connie Mack's men the rubber game of the seven played.

General Eisenhower told a Senate subcommittee yesterday he still believed in an over-all $15,000,000,000 ceiling for defense, but felt that $500,000,000 at the most added to President Truman's $14,114,460,000 overall budget would strike a fair balance between economy and security needs.

ROANOKE, Va., March 29--Earl J. McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education, called today on the expanding junior college movement in this country to slough off traditional patterns and philosophies of four-year colleges and large universities.

Postmaster Albert Goldman and Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, were appointed yesterday as commerce and industry section chairmen of the New York City Cancer Committee's 1950 Cancer Crusade.
Rufus Edgar Turpin, former assistant Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died Tuesday in Louisville, Ky., it was learned yesterday. He was 82 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29-- F. Joseph Donohue, special prosecutor in the Harry Bridges perjury-conspiracy trial, opened his final address to the jury today with a bitter denunciation of defense counsel.
ALBANY, March 29--Following Is the text of the new state emergency rent law that Governor Dewey signed today:

NEW DELHI, India, March 29-- President Rajendra Prasad in his first broadcast to the nation tonight called for restraint on the part of the people toward the communal rioiting in East and West Bengal.

As the city rain-makers marked time yesterday, natural accretions to the water supply increased storage in the Catskill and Croton reservoirs by 7,303,000,000 gallons in the twenty-four hours ending at 8 A.M. Supplies now total 151,062,000,000 gallons, or 59.7 per cent of capacity.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 29--If it's true what they're saying about Phil Cavarretta in the valley of the sun, he did a marvelous job of salesmanship today as the Cubs defeated the Giants, 5 to 3.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 29--After nine months of gradual development at top business and governmental levels, the proposed constitution and by-laws of a new organization to help guide the growth of Westchester were submitted today to 200 manufacturers, publishers, utility executives, bankers and county officials.

The five-story buildings at 48 to 56 Old Broadway, northwest corner of West 130th Street, which were modernized into eighty-two apartments in 1947, have been sold by the Manhattanville Veterans Apartment Corporation to the Westchester Mortgage Company,...

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 29--At a meeting with west Germany's trade union leaders, the Allied High Commissioners denied today that the contemplated revision of the trust-busting law for Ruhr steel and coal industries would be "detrimental" to workers.
John J. King, the fugitive accused of the killing of William Hupe near his Flushing home, surrendered in Chicago yesterday and a Queens prosecutor left here last night to question him.

WASHINGTON, March 29--An impartial appraisal of Government functions and sources of taxation at Federal, state and local levels to prevent a "deterioration into economic and political disaster" was proposed in a resolution introduced in the House today.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 29-- Mrs. Virginia Wigglesworth, 42 years old, president of Division 55, Communications Workers of America, was killed last night when her station wagon ran off a highway and burst into flames.
ALBANY, March 29--Spencer E. Bates, president of the State Tax Commission, announced today the opening of a drive to bring to book persons who have been delinqent in filing State income tax returns.

BUENOS AIRES, March 29-- Pan American Airways, which has been unable to send to the United States any fares collected in dollars since 1948, has now received assurance from the Argentine regime that remittances will be permitted to start in the near future, probably in April.

WASHINGTON, March 29--A priest of the Episcopal Church, the Rev. Clarence Parker of Chicago, told the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities today that the Nixon subversive activities control bill, if enacted, would create "a new crime, punishable without the commission of an overt act."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 29--United States Defense Secretary Louis Johnson said here today that there was "nothing controversial" for the North Atlantic Treaty defense ministers to discuss when they meet Saturday "because our chiefs of staff have understood one another so completely."

An off-duty patrolman was killed yesterday, two persons seriously injured and three shaken up after a car jumped the four-foot high center island on the Belt Parkway near the Bay Parkway exit, Brooklyn, and rammed into two cars in the opposite lane.
Battling to stay in the race for the National Basketball Association title, the New York Knickerbockers will oppose the Syracuse Nationals tonight at Madison Square Garden.
Decorating suggestions to save homemakers hours of tedious housework were outlined yesterday by Miss Elizabeth Kaufer, home furnishings consultant.

Speaking at ceremonies yesterday morning as construction was begun on the second of four bulkheads to help support the Harlem River Drive, Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. indicated that completion of the $20,000,000 improvement would be a major aim of his administration.

WASHINGTON, March 29--A bill to set up a new United Medical Administration that would combine all Government medical facilities under one agency was opposed in testimony today by Dr. Charles W. Mayo, Dr. Leonard G. Rowntree, chief medical adviser of the American Legion, and other witnesses.

OTTAWA, March 29--Nothing has yet been discovered to explain why the C-47 courier plane in which Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Canada, and four others lost their lives yesterday morning, had caught fire and exploded.

Two three-story store and apartment buildings occupying a plot 42 by 114 feet at 122-24 West Fordham Road, the Bronx, were purchased by a syndicate headed by John Boettjer through Armstrong Bros., brokers, who also arranged a lease with Peter Reeves Markets, Inc., which plans a supermarket in the building.

CHICAGO, March 29--O.R. Norberg of Cincinnati, head of the refrigeration and appliance department of Avco Manufacturing Company's Crosley Division, said today that "the public trust and confidence in plastics articles is now higher than it has ever been before."

Frederick W. Bruchhauser of 148-24 Eighty-seventh Road, Jamaica, Queens, a senior vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, in charge of all Brooklyn and Queens offices, died yesterday in Brooklyn Hospital, after an illness of several months. His age was 65.
It was "Allagaroo" through the canyons, the side streets, on Times Square, Fifth Avenue, and all over the borough of Manhattan through the night and late into the afternoon yesterday.

Return to a forty-minute application of the rules on fouls and important revisions with regard to timing and substituting were recommended yesterday by the National Association of Basketball Coaches at the final session of that organization's three-day convention...
BOSTON, March 29--Mrs. Benjamin P. Cheney, known professionally as Julia Arthur to theatre audiences of a generation ago, died last night at her home. Her age was 81.
Dishes rattled and windows trembled at 9:43:06 A.M. yesterday as a slight earthquake excited numerous persons in Fairfield County, Conn., and on Long Island's North Shore.
LONDON, March 29--Washington lobbyists with their suites of offices and fat expense accounts would have died laughing if they could have seen a report made today on some of their British brethren.

PARIS, March 29--Anticipating a discussion of Germany at the Western Foreign Ministers Conference in London in May, the Foreign Affairs Committee of the French Assembly today "condemned tendencies in Germany and in certain Allied circles" toward raising the level of German production of crude steel, fixed at 11,l00,000 tons a year.
Copper, zinc and lead futures displayed continued price firmness on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, while tin futures recorded further declines.
Home work desks these days can be anything from portable offices to inexpensive made-at-home models.

Inadequate depreciation charges allowed under current tax laws "will eventually cause industry to postpone replacements for as long as possible," Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the National Steel Corporation, declared in the annual report sent yesterday to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, Newark, N.J., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for registration of $26,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, series due May 1, 1980.

Irked by charges that fraud was a major factor in last year's 93 per cent increase in state unemployment insurance payments, the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Labor Department has analyzed its records to discover where the extra $172,000,000 went.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 29 --Advertising must do a much greater part of the selling job-- and with less "foggy double-talk" --if business is to meet its present heavy responsibilities, it was declared here today at opening of the forty-first annual spring meet-...

LONDON, March 29--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of the West German Republic is being informed by the Western Allied High Commission in Bonn that the Western occupying powers cannot accept all his conditions for Western Germany's adherence to the Council of Europe, authoritative quarters said today.
ALBANY, March 29--Governor Dewey signed into law today the so-called Republican bill transferring residential rents from Federal to state control as of May 1.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP)--An agreement between Argentina and Swift International--a holding company incorporated in Buenos Aires --providing for the transfer of the meat and food processing company from Argentina to the United States, was announced today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 29--Vicente Lombardo Toledano insisted today that the LatinAmerican Labor Confederation (C.T.A.L.) had a broader grip on organized labor south of the Rio Grande than the new InterAmerican Labor Confederation (C.I.T.) with which the American Federation of Labor is associated.

WARSAW, March 29--In announcing today the details of Poland's 1949 international trade, the Foreign Trade Ministry indicated that henceforth the Warsaw Government would list all its achievements in terms of rubles rather than dollars, which had been used as the measure of economic progress.
Generalissimo Franco's rebuke to the monarchists is an interesting example of how and why he is still in power eleven years after the civil war.

The ultimate decision on the Coast Guard Board of Inquiry, which opened a hearing yesterday into the cause of the collision, between the Grace liner Santa Monica and the Ambrose Lightship, may hinge on how long a dense fog can continue when confronted by winds of gale force.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 29-- Scores of the Air Force's finest fighter pilots met here today to fly in the armed services first publicly viewed aerial gunnery meet.

In an interview here yesterday as the first Irish Ambassador to the United States. John J. Hearne branded as "criminal" the action of the British Parliament in continuing the separation of northern and southern Ireland.

Final steps toward the creation of an "integrated defense plan" for the North Atlantic community are now being taken at The Hague, where the top military leaders and defense ministers of the North Atlantic Pact nations are meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 29--Vice President Alben W. Barkley today urged continued buying of savings bonds as a means of keeping this country "so strong no one can impose ruthless, godless ideologies on us."

The six-story store and apartment building at 68-04 Burns Street in Forest Hills Queens, has been sold by Ben and Sam Schatten to Bernard Rothchild for cash above mortgages of $85,000. Key Realty was the broker.

Unless the death march of accidents on the state highways is curbed, "tougher weapons" will be used to deal with those who refuse to conform with road regulations, Commissioner Clifford J. Fletcher of the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles warned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Tiny Midway Island, 1,300 miles west of Hawaii in the central Pacific, will be abandoned by United States military and civil aviation personnel in the next few months.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 29--The Czechoslovak Government expelled today Nathan Polowetzky, the last Associated Press correspondent here, thus bringing to five the number of Western correspondents expelled this year.

Showing a recklessness that was rarely a part of their makeup in the regular National Hockey League race, the New York Rangers outskated the Canadiens of Montreal in the first game of their Stanley Cup eliminations at Madison Square Garden last night.
Next Wednesday has been proclaimed by Mayor O'Dwyer as "Brand Names Day," it was announced yesterday.

The utility industry was assayed by Donald C. Cook, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, yesterday and found in good condition.
MANILA, March 29--Communist-led Hukbalahaps struck in four separate raids today in three provinces surrounding Manila, killing fourteen people, wounding a score of more and kidnapping a mayor.

Two Negroes, one formerly a member of the Fair Employment Practices Committee, filed separate actions in Federal Court yesterday for $10,000 damages each against American Airlines, Inc., and Sky Chefs, Inc.

MADISON, N.J., March 29-- Arthur Herrington, former secretary and manager of the International Flower Show and one of the nation's leading horticulturists, died yesterday at his home 1 Fairwoods Avenue, after a long illness. He was 84 years old.
America must train for and venture into foreign fields as a long-range program to combat the world Communist threat, according to Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York.
Progressive legislation furthering the merchant marine will be pressed by the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries, its new chairman pledged yesterday.
Ninety-four members of the uniformed force of the Fire Department were promoted yesterday to next higher grades by Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle in ceremonies at the Municipal Building.

Supplies of fresh water fish for Passover are so scarce that prices have risen as much as 25 cents a pound since last Friday. Wholesalers at the Fulton Fish Market said yesterday that they could make use of stocks 500 per cent larger than those on hand.

CHICAGO, March 29--May and July soybeans broke the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel at one time on the Board of Trade today, reversing the action of Monday, when they advanced a like amount.

JERUSALEM, March 29--A legislative act providing special privileges for private investors in Israel was adopted by the Knesset (Parliament) today.
Plans for a "massive shipment" of food to Western Berlin were announced yesterday by the International Rescue Committee of 103 Park Avenue.
LONDON, March 29--The new three-week account started quiet and steady on the stock market here today. Although business remained at a low level, one or two sections were able to make a good showing.

ROME, March 29--Rome was founded, about the year 575 B.C., or approximately 175 years later than had hitherto been supposed, according to a Swedish savant, who bases his conclusions on an excavation he recently finished in the Roman Forum.

NORFOLK, Va., March 29--The first non-union seaman to sign aboard any deep-water vessel previously manned through hiring halls will precipitate a nation-wide strike by seven sea unions, it was indicated today by Roland Carvalho, Norfolk port agent for the National Maritime Union, C.I.O.
New issues of public utility securities totaling $18,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates.

LONDON, March 29--Britain's Labor Government, which has an over-all majority of only three seats in the House of Commons, was taken by surprise tonight and defeated for the first time in the present Parliament.
LAKE SUCCESS, March 29-- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil came out strongly today for the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

Senorita Minerva Bernardino of the Dominican Republic, who was one of the four women signers of the United Nations Charter, is a plump, attractive redhead who does not hesitate to identify herself as a militant feminist.
The State of South Carolina borrowed yesterday $5,000,000 on highway bonds maturing serially from April 1, 1956, to April 1, 1960, at an interest cost of 1.29 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 29--If the Senate pursues its demand for the secret executive files in the loyaltysecurity cases after the President's order to the heads of the State and Justice Departments and the chairman of the Civil Service Commission to ignore the Senate's subpoenas, its next step could be to summon these executive officers to the bar of the Senate in contempt.

The celebrated case of the "war bride," Mrs. Ellen Knauff, has now taken another turn. Mrs. Knauff, wife of an American citizen, was denied admission to the United States without a hearing, for security reasons.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)-- The Maritime Commission and labor unions today urged a $25,000,000 ship-repair program to prevent "demoralization" of American shipyards.
A boyish escapade resulted yesterday in the death of 9-year-old Charles Hauptman of 357 South Third Street, Brooklyn, Who plunged five floors from the roof of the building next door.
Emory Roth Sons, architects, are moving on Friday to new and larger quarters at 488 Madison Avenue.

News that the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs will hold its seventeenth session (the first since the war) next summer will be welcomed by those who remember the stimulating round-tables conducted there in the inter-bellum years. The 1950 program will be organized under the theme, "The United States and the Post-War World."

Elmer Rice has completed the first draft of a new play, "Love Among the Ruins," and it is on the schedule of the Playwrights' Company for next season. Set in the modern-day Near East, the drama is in two acts and has fourteen characters, with important roles for one woman and two men.

RICHMOND, Va., March 29 (AP) --A two-day meeting of stockhold-- ers of the Standard Cap and Seal, Corporation ended here today and a spokesman for the management said a complete tabulation of votes showed the company's slate of directors was elected by "a substantial majority."

LONDON, March 29--For an hour and a half today Lord Vansittart, former permanent head of the Foreign Office, held the rapt attention of the House of Lords as he named many whom he charged with aiding the Communist cause.

The Atomic Energy Commission has set such strict standards against radioactive contamination that ordinary kitchen waste can't be flushed into sewers at some of its nuclear energy plants, Merril Eisenbud, health and safety director for the New York Operations Office, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29--Secretary of State Dean Acheson and Ambassador Philip C. Jessup sought bi-partisan support in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today for increasing United States economic, information and small-arms programs in the Far East and Southeast Asia.

Under record gross revenue, Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., operated at a profit last year for the first time since 1945, the airline informed stockholders in the annual report, issued yesterday.

"The Celebrated Case of Fitz John Porter: An American Dreyfus Affair," a new book about the Civil War by Otto Eisenschiml, is scheduled for May publication by Bobbs-Merrill.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 29-- The White House said today that President Truman would ignore Congressional subpoenas demanding the surrender of confidential loyalty files.

Characterized as members of an East Side gang of muggers that "roved the streets like a pack of mad dog's," three men were held in $40,000 bail each yesterday in Felony Court on charges of robbery and felonious assault.

STRASBOURG, France, March 29--The foreign ministers of twelve European countries were arriving here tonight for the meeting tomorrow of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe, which is expected to be decisive for the future of that organization.

An opinion poll taken by the Council on Foreign Relations among 720 "intelligent, well-informed Americans" shows that they "are confused and disturbed about the policy of their Government in China," the council reported yesterday.

The semi-annual unaudited report of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., to be distributed to stockholders today reveals an increase of $6,421,204 in sales for the six months ended on Jan. 28 over the previous year's period, but a decline of $1,952,935 in earnings.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 29 (AP)--The body of a New York scientist, Dr. Oskar Baudisch, 68, was found on a beach here today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 30--In two notes to the United States Embassy, the Czechoslovak Government tonight demanded the extradition "as common criminals" of eight Czech airmen who plotted the flight of three mixed planeloads of anti-Communists and Communists to Munich last Friday.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 30 (AP)--Boston's Braves won their first game in three tries from the St. Louis Cardinals today, edging the Redbirds, 1--0, as Johnny Sain and Vern Bickford combined for the five-hit shut-out.

SOMEWHERE in Connecticut in a university town quite like New Haven, only smaller, there is a street known as Evergreen Ave nue. KEY WEST, Fla., March 30-- President Truman today categorically denied, as Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has contended, that certain phases of this country's defenses have been reduced below the safety limit.

WASHINGTON, March 30--Dr. Percy N. Annand, chief of the Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine since 1941, died yesterday of a heart ailment after an illness of several months. His age was 51.

PARIS, March 30--Deeming the present British proposal for a European Payments Union unacceptable in anything like its present form, the Economic Cooperation Administration has begun the discussion of possible compromises. However, it has made no formal proposals of its own.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 30-- While it won't bring them any world series cut, the Dodgers definitely are champions of their farm system. They beat St. Paul today for the second time, 5--4, and now have dropped only one decision in eight games with their farm hands, Fort Worth having taken the opening game.

WASHINGTON, March 3--During the week ended March 29 member bank reserve balances decreased $187,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ALBANY, March 30--Governor Dewey signed today a bill providing state aid for libraries, up to an ultimate maximum of $3,653,000 a year, contingent upon changes in the organization of libraries that will make their facilities available to greater numbers of readers.

Perley B. Merry will join the Phillips-Jones Corporation, manufacturer of Van Heusen shirts, on May 1 in an executive merchandising capacity. He is now executive vice president in charge of merchandising and sales at the B.V.D. Corporation.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 30-- American high schools fail to give 80 per cent of the students the kind of education they need in presentday society, representative students of private, parochial and public schools declared here today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30--A jet-powered helicopter that has about double the efficiency of conventional helicopters over shorthaul routes was described here today at the opening of the annual forum of the American Helicopter Society.

TOKYO, March 30--The "labor offensive" of Japanese trade unions for a new round of wage increases in opposition to the anti-inflation policy of the Government and occupation authorities virtually collapsed today.

Rocky Graziano, East Side puncher who once held the middleweight championship of the world, will make his first Madison Square Garden appearance in four years when he trades wallops with Tony Janiro of Youngstown, Ohio, tonight. The fight is scheduled for ten rounds, and interest is such that a crowd of 15,000 is expected.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) --The Veterans Administration was warned today that its plan to wipe out about 4,700 medical jobs by April 10 would seriously hamper the care and treatment of veterans, particularly nervous and mental cases.
WASHINGTON, March 30--The Navy "twisted the dials" today to tune the public in on a television program it is sponsoring under water and several miles in the air.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 30--By 11 to 3, the International Court of Justice ruled today in favor of the United States and Britain in their efforts to have Rumania, Hungary and Bulgaria live up to the human rights provisions of their peace treaties.
Registering the largest weekly decline since the beginning of this year, business loans made by banks in this area declined $55,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 (AP) --The State Supreme Court today reprimanded Pittsburgh's Common Pleas Judge Michael A. Musmanno for barring a woman from grand jury duty on the ground she was a Communist.

Early American designs adapted from old documents found in New England cellars, attics and trunks were outstanding in two collections of wallpaper introduced yesterday. Richard E. Thibaut presented the Waterhouse collection with matching fabrics, and William J. Galligan showed a small group of wallpapers only.
Failure of traffic-light signals to protect the lives of children at school-street intersections here was emphasized yesterday by T.T. Wiley, director of the city's Department of Traffic Engineering.

The National Biscuit Company, tenant in the one-story garage building on plot 175 by 92 feet at 415 to 425 West Sixteenth Street, has purchased the property from Frederick Brown, the latter reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- Eben M. Whitcomb, director of investigation and chairman of the Planning and Reviewing Committee of United States Tariff Commission, will retire tomorrow, on his own request, after more than thirty years' service with the agency.

Fears for the future of transAtlantic sea transport are groundless and American ships will not only continue to hold their own in the passenger business but will get a large share of an expected 50 per cent increase in overseas travel, John E. Slater, president of American Export Lines, asserted yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30--A spanking breeze that carried plenty of bite from the North cracked down on this city of friendly warmth and eternal sunshine today and that made the afternoon's visit of Luke Sewell's Reds most inopportune.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 30--Official figures published here today show that the average wage of a West German worker is $58 a month. Previous estimates by labor and political groups have been much lower.

Edward C. Carter, provost of the New School for Social Research and former secretary-general of the Institute of Pacific Relations, declared last night that he had visited the Soviet Union in 1936, but explained that the visit had been in connection with institute matters.

Mayor O'Dwyer sent yesterday to the Board of Estimate an executive budget of $1,243,451,794 for the fiscal year beginning July 1. It was the largest in the city's history and the fourth, in a row to pass the billion dollar mark.
BANGKOK, Thailand, March 30 --The profound public response to the return here of King Phumiphon Aduldet and to the ceremonies in ...

LONDON, March 30--The Amercan motion-picture industry's fight to break further into the British film market was helped indirectly here tonight when the House of Commons approved without a vote a new Government order cutting the quota for British-made feature films from 40 to 30 per cent. The quota fox supporting pictures was kept at 25 per cent, with both measures to take effect on Oct. 1.

With fare rise applications from ten of the city's eleven private bus companies before it, a special three-man committee was created by the Board of Estimate yesterday to weigh such petitions. It indicated that it would complete its job by May 15.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 30--Gordon Gray, retiring Secretary of the Army, was appointed today by President Truman as a special Presidential assistant to coordinate Administration ef forts to close the dollar gap between this country and the democracies that we are trying to rehabilitate.

Emil Schwarzhaupt, who had donated anonymously to the Central Park Zoo in the past ten years $30,000 for the purchase of animals, died yesterday morning in his apartment at the Hotel Pierre after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

The building at 404 East Fourteenth Street, running through to 405 East Thirteenth Street and adjacent to the southeast corner of First Avenue, has been sold by the Fuldner Realty Corporation to Charles Walzer, operator, who said yesterday that a deal was pending for the leasing of the entire premises to a chain-store organization.
Trading in futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, and prices at the finish wera 6 points lower to 9 points higher.

Indications point to substantially larger early orders for men's clothing for fall than a year ago, according to Sol R. Feldman, vice president in charge of sales of Joseph H. Cohen Sons, one of the largest men's clothing manufacturers in the country. He has just returned from an intermediary sales trip to key cities in several areas of the country to observe significant early fall trends.

Relations between the United States and Israel could be endangered because of the actions of "Zionist zealots" in this country, Rear Admiral Ellis M. Zacharias, retired, former Deputy Chief of the Office of Naval Intelligence, declared yesterday.
Edward J. Grant, registrar of Columbia University since 1920, died yesterday in Tucson, Ariz., at the age of 64.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- Senator Matthew M. Neely, Democrat of West Virginia, today charged on the Senate floor that there was a "mesh of restrictions, priorities and favored categories" in the McCarran Displaced Persons Bill "to satisfy a demand for sheepherders in the West."

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 30 (AP)--George Fazio, veteran Washington professional, put together nine-hole score of 34, 33 for a 5under-par 67 today to lead the first round of the $10,000 Wilmington Azalea open golf tournament by one stroke.

A committee of police officials, which had held hearings last September on an application for revision of taxicab regulations to permit use of smaller stock cars as cabs, made known yesterday its disapproval of the request.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)-- Farm product prices remained unchanged during the month ended March 15, but prices paid by farmers increased nearly 1 per cent, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

New to us was using cornmeal in a dough somewhere between pastry and biscuit batter. New, too, was cutting such a dough to give the braided effect shown in today's pictures. The two ideas in combination--a cornmeal pastry braid--came to us from Mrs. Reidun K. Sweeney of the Quaker Oats Company. Part of Mrs. Sweeney's work is to create unusual uses for the cornmeal that her company packages.

WASHINGTON, March 30--Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, told the Senate today that lack of restraint on the part of Democrats as well as Republicans was putting in jeopardy the bipartisan approach to the nation's foreign policy problems.

Continued support of the United Jewish Appeal campaign is imperative or the immigration program in Israel will collapse and the "situation will be disastrous," Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the American Section for the Jewish Ageney for Palestine, said yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 30--Rate regulation "by law" and not "by emotion" was called for today by Martin W. Clement, chairman of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
The economic and human cost of industrial accidents was described yesterday as appalling, and the off-the-job accident record of workers was shown to be even worse.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)-- The Government's commitment to support hog prices, in case of a sharp decline, will end tomorrow at midnight unless eleventh-hour action is taken to extend it.

CHICAGO, March 30 (AP)--Pullman, Inc., said today freight car production "practically came to a halt" in the fourth quarter last year. Deliveries of passenger train cars reached a new post-war high during the year, it was added.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)-- Representative Albert J. Engel, Republican of Michigan, said today that Great Lakes shipping should have equal treatment with ocean shipping in obtaining surplus Government-owned vessels.

President Truman solved several appointment problems yesterday by generally satisfactory choices. Frank Pace Jr., the Budget Director who broke with tradition by producing a budget summary the public could understand, ...
WASHINGTON, March 30--The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the merger of the Ohio Public Service Company, of Cleveland, into the Ohio Edison Company of Akron.
PARIS, March 30--Leon Blum, former Premier of France and veteran Socialist leader, died today of a heart attack. He would have been 78 on April 9.
Doorbells in every borough will be rung today by a census-taker carrying a big black portfolio.
CLEVELAND, March 30 (AP)--Oliver T. Burnham, Lake Carriers Association secretary, said today navigation in the upper Great Lakes probably would start some time between April 10 and 16.

WASHINGTON, March 30--Secretary of State Dean Acheson urged the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today to hasten in authorizing $45,000,000 requested by the Administration for international development along the lines of President Truman's Point Four program.

DETROIT, March 30 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings smashed their way back into the thick of the Stanley Cup hockey play-offs tonight as they beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3--1, in a bruising battle marked by two free-for-all player fights.

Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed executive budget for the fiscal year 1950-51, beginning Juty 1, is $1,243,451,794. The 3.49 per cent increase amounts to $41,896,430, and it will strain the limits of present taxation. A rise of twenty points in the real estate tax rate is highly possible but no new taxes are mentioned.

The much-discussed "two-minute rule" went into the discard yesterday when the National Basketball Committee of the United States and Canada, law making body for the sport, decided on the regulations for the 1950-51 season.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Southern farm leaders in both houses of Congress today met rumors of an imminent veto on the cotton acreage bill with a flurry of telegrams to President Truman at Key West.
The wide gamut of contemporary American painting is seen in six one-man shows and a group exhibition now on view in New York galleries.

Virtually all of the issues of Treasury bonds of intermediate and long term moved down again in the dealer's market yesterday, with special pressure still felt on the Victory 2 per cent issue of 1972-1967. Nine issues touched ...

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 30-- Refinements in styling and improvements in power plants were emphasized among the outstanding features of the new line of cars and trucks shown to dealers here today by Willys-Overland Motors, Inc. Price cuts of $40 to $120 were announced by the organization.

CHICAGO, March 30--The National Association of Tobacco Dealers ended a convention and merchandise fair of record proportions here today by adopting resolutions calling for more effective assistance to small business, taxation of cooperatives and other "mutual" organizations, and clarification of federal rules governing trade practices. "Exorbitant" taxes on tobacco products also were attacked.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 30-- Trade negotiations between the Giants and Cubs blossomed openly today just when the Giants decided to hit Frankie Frisch's troupe with everything they had. The trade business was unproductive. The ball game was something else again. The Giants plastered three of Frank Frisch's pitchers with a variety of sixteen hits that brought a lop-sided victory, 10 to 5.
Final installation work on a new radar unit, expected to be in operation late in April, was near completion yesterday at La Guardia Airport

ALBANY, March 30--Many additional tributaries of the Finger Lakes were opened to rainbow trout fishing starting Saturday under the provisions of a Conservation Department bill signed into law today by Governor Dewey.

A plea for technological assistance from "all the countries of the world" to help the United States of Indonesia was made here last night by Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo, first Indonesian Ambassador to the United States.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., March 30 --Historic Sandy Hook Lighthouse, built with the aid of a lottery authorized by the Colonial New York Assembly, will observe its one hundred eighty-sixth anniversary next June.

WASHINGTON, March 30--Development of the St. Lawrence River seaway project by the Fed eral Government or as a joint undertaking of the State of New York and the Canadian province of Ontario, was urged in a resolution adopted here today at the closing session of the American Public Power Association.

CHICAGO, March 30--The grain markets closed higher on the Board of Trade today after fluctuating in an extremely nervous manner. There was no pressure at the opening and both wheat and soybeans were up around 4 cents before there was any selling of consequence.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 30-- Sweden submitted today to the Security Council a statement holding that the Government of Israel did not take adequate measures to prevent the murder of Count Folke Bernadotte, United Nations Mediator for Palestine, or to apprehend those responsible.
Paul Reynaud, president of the Economic Commission of the Consultative European Assembly, urged last night the creation of a common general staff for all Atlantic nations.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 30--A major political crisis is taking shape in Western Germany as a result of the decision of the Committee of Ministers to admit the Western Germany Federal Republic and the Saar territory to the Council of Europe on the basis of equality as associate members.
The City of Baltimore, Md., announced yesterday that it will receive bids April 11 on $19,500,000 of water serial bonds due Sept. 1 and Dec. 1, 1952 to 1979.

A daring pickpocket wrested free of his captors on a crowded IND Queens-bound train last night, leaped onto the tracks after the train reached the station and fled through the tunnel toward Manhattan despite several shots that were fired at him.
Large industrial organizations were urged yesterday to participate in the financial support of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology through a program for industrial-university cooperation.

New York University will support other tenants on Washington Square in opposing the demolition of the Rhinelander properties, Dr. Leroy E. Kimball, vice chancellor and controller of N.Y.U. announced yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 30-- Job prospects for June's college graduates are worse than at any time since the end of the war, the nation's top labor statistician said today.

CHICAGO, March 30--Donald R. McLennan Jr., insurance executive, was missing from the nominees for the board of directors of Montgomery Ward Co. in the proxy statement mailed today to stockholders. Two new directors were proposed for election at the annual meeting, April 28.

Garry Davis, 29-year-old actor and former bomber pilot who renounced his United States citizenship two years ago to become a "world citizen," returned to this country yesterday as an immigrant and was not admitted.

LONDON, March 30 (AP)--Northern Ireland's Prime Minister, ready to leave for a tour of the United States, took a look today at recent American happenings and commented: "If my hosts don't like the look of me they can send me back."

HONG KONG, Friday, March 31 --In what is obviously an inspired editorial, a Peiping newspaper has revealed the official Communist line toward proposals that Western nations send food for China's starving millions. Kwangming, the daily...

WASHINGTON, March 30-- Spokesmen for two top policy agencies of the executive and legislative branches today said in effect at the House investigation into lobbying that while the Government itself as well as private lobbyists applied great pressures to influence Congress, it was a tough if not impossible job to check on the Government's activities.

TOMORROW marks the beginning of National Laugh Week. It also is April Fool's Day. It also signals the opening of the local horse racing season at Jamaica. Any connection between any of these items is accidental, invidious and an insult to the hardiest breed of man ever foaled, the hoss player.

The concert given by Leopold Stokowski and the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall opened with the "Sinfonia" of Bach, his 174th cantata, which is none other than the first movement of the Brandenburg Concerto in G major of an earlier day. It is delightful, brisk music.

A short but intense wave of selling struck the stock market yesterday afternoon for the severest jolt this month. Standing fairly firmly again against the trend, however, were the radio-television issues which emerged with gains in some cases of more than a point, while the rest of the list surrendered 1 to 3 points. There was a drop of 1.42 points in the composite rate.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30-- The overemphasis in parent education in the last twenty years on praise, no discipline and the need to protect children from failure has filled high schools and colleges with young people who cannot stand up to difficulty, Dr. Elizabeth Lee Vincent, dean of the College of Home Economics, Cornell University, declared today.

The City Club is to go on. The 64-year-old organization, which some months ago was about to disband because of the lack of fighting young blood elected yesterday new officers and directors, formuulated a new program and announced in its room at 45 Park Avenue that it expected to be as effective as it was in the days of the Lexow investigating committee.

Teen-age justice, aided and abetted by adult guidance, prevailed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court. The occasion was a morning visit by sixty-eight pupils of the seventh and ninth grades from Junior High School 29, Brooklyn, in connection with their social study course.

MOSCOW, March 30--The foreign affairs journal New Times today published a significant analysis characterizing the victory of Mao Tze-tung in China as essentially an "agrarian revolution that has the basis and content of burgeois democratic revolution."
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 30 (AP)--Three Western news correspondents received today a threemonth renewal of their permits to work in Czechoslovakia.

Mementoes of five of the most outstanding achievements and competitors in Columbia University's athletic history were preserved for future generations yesterday at a ceremony on the site of the Columbia Fieldhouse, now under construction at Baker Field.

NEWARK, March 30--Construction on a $20,000,000 brewery for Anheuser-Busch, Inc., was formally inaugurated today with a groundbreaking ceremony on the fiftyene-acre site on Route 25, adjacent to the airport here, which the St. Louis company acquired several years ago.

HONG KONG, Friday, March 31 --The Peiping radio has confirmed that an agreement establishing two Sino-Soviet companies for the exploitation of oil and nonferrous metal resources of Sinkiang province was signed in Moscow on Monday.

TRENTON, March 30--Employment Security Director Harold G. Hoffman today ruled that a New Jersey employer in interstate commerce must engage in collective bargaining with employes before asking them to ballot on approving a private plan of temporary disability insurance.

WASHINGTON, March 30--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy asserted today that he had a witness who was ready to swear that Owen Lattimore had been for years a member of the Communist party and that this witness had been "high up" in its circles.

Robert N. Denham, General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, last night took the words of the late Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis for his own in maintaining that the present divided authority of his office and the board helped "save the people from autocracy."

LAKE SUCCESS, March 30-- Secretary General Trygve Lie has drawn up a six-point list of top United Nations problems, including the hydrogen bomb, and suggested that they be put on the agenda of a special Security Council meeting for threshing out by high-level delegates.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30-- The Navy today sent a destroyer to an area off the northern California coast to join patrol planes in a search for a submarine, reported sighted yesterday afternoon and again early this morning.

A medal struck in honor of Herbert Hoover in recognition of his attainments as a scholar, humanitarian and statesman, was presented to the former President yesterday at ceremonies in the American Museum of Natural History marking the golden anniversary of its monthly publication.

The marriage of Miss Florence Eve Dubin, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Dubin of 888 Park Avenue, and the late Mr. Dubin, to Warren J. Sinsheimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome W. Sinsheimer of New Rochelle, N.Y,, took place last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. The Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Nathan G. Meltzoff.

LONDON, March 30--A problem that once was considered to be the most complicated and troublesome one outstanding between Britain and the young State of Israel was resolved by the two Governments today.

Engendering comedy--from belly laughs to grins--for nearly five decades has taught Bobby Clark all the nuances of directing. Timing is a director's greatest asset and Mr. Clark feels he should make use of that knowledge.

HONG KONG, March 30 (UP)-- The Chinese Communists are sending wave after wave of "nuisance" sorties against Hainan Island in an effort to wear down Nationalist resistance before a major assault, it was reported today.

Fifteen thousand milk drivers and dairy employes in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut metropolitan area will receive protection under the first industry-wide welfare fund in the milk industry, effective at midnight tonight.
LONDON, March 30--The stock markets were undecided today. While most markets were basically steady, a little surface dullness developed in places.
TWIN FALLS, Idaho, March 30 (UP)--The Republican National Chairman, Guy G. Gabrielson, called on his party tonight to review its position in the bipartisan foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, March 30--Plans to increase next year's defense budget by $647,000,000 in order to build up all phases of the country's air power were put forward today by the House Armed Services Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 30--As noted in these dispatches under date of March 29, the constitutional power of Congress to enforce its subpoena on the Executive has several times been asserted but never directly tested in the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)-- The Eastern railroads today moved to make major freight rate cuts in bulk iron and steel shipments effective May 1. The cuts, roughly averaging 25 per cent, are intended to meet highway truck competition. They will apply only to large quantity business handled in carload lots with a minimum weight of 80,000 pounds.

NORFOLK, Va., March 30--The four-stripe naval officer whose orders to the helm ran the battleship Missouri hard aground in Chesapeake Bay last January faced a general court-martial today and accepted full blame for the mishap.
ALBANY, March 30 (AP)--The State Department of Commerce today reported the following conditions at New York ski centers:

WASHINGTON, March 30--Determined to prevent a recurrence of yesterday's rout, Administration leaders in the House of Representatives ran roughshod today over a series of crippling amendments to the pending Marshall Plan authorization measure and then dug in for a more crucial test tomorrow.
Citing economic reasons, Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind announced yesterday his intention to resign from the judicial office he has held since June, 1941.

WASHINGTON, March 30--Dr. Herbert Feis, once the State Department's chief economic adviser, has been recalled by Secretary of State Dean Acheson to be a member of his policy planning staff and to undertake as his first assignment a thorough new study of the economic troubles of Europe.

The defense of this country, General Eisenhower has told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee, rests upon moral and spiritual strength as well as a healthy economy and these are essential, since "arms are merely the cutting edge." In his quiet and statesmanlike testimony, of which this is an example, General Eisenhower put the emphasis in the defense problem where it belongs, on quality and not merely quantity.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- Rarely has any Senator, and especially one in his first term, become so desperately engaged on so harsh an issue as has Joseph R. McCarthy in his campaign against alleged Communists in the State Department.

WASHINGTON, March 30--John J. Hearne, the new Irish Ambassador, said today that he would welcome discussions with the United States Government of his country's membership in the North Atlantic alliance, but made it clear that Ireland would not join as long as her six northern counties were separated.
An open battle in the "cold war" that has been continuing between Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard and the United Public Workers of America, Local 1, developed yesterday.

The New York Knickerbockers are still alive in the National Basketball Association play-offs. To remain so they had to stave off a determined closing bid by the Syracuse Nationals last night at Madison Square Garden, staggering to an 80-76 victory before 10,000 persons. The triumph squared the Eastern Division series at 1-all and paved the way for a rubber game at the Syracuse Coliseum Sunday night.

The Artbee Realty Corporation has sold the five-story building at 1907 Loring Place, the Bronx, containing six stores and sixty-two apartments, to Walter L. Rothschild. Louis Aaronson was the broker. Albert W. Fribourg was attorney for the buyer.
WASHINGTON, March 30--Another attempt to achieve labor unity may be undertaken by the two major labor organizations in the next few weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Truman has expressed the hope that on Easter Day "all nations and all peoples will turn away from divisions and disunion to seek unity in the love of God and the love of man."
HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 30-- Advertising management was urged today to help the retailer by training store personnel through the emotional appeals of advertising.
MIAMI, Fla., March 30-- Former Gov. James M. Cox, Democratic nominee for President thirty years ago, will be 80 years old tomorrow, but there will be no interviews--not even in his own newspapers.

WASHINGTON, March 30--The Senate was told today that Charles Sawyer, Secretary of Commerce, twice decided that no security restrictions need be placed upon the chief of his department's Far Eastern branch, then undergoing a second loyalty investigation.

Morris W. Haft Bros., Inc., the country's largest manufacturer of women's and misses' coats and suits, will split into two companies for the fall, 1950, season, it was announced yesterday by Morris W. Haft, retiring president. Two new corporations have been set up to take over the business, he said, with one taking the Swansdown trade-mark and the other the Jaunty Junior trademark.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 30-- A social Nassau County grand jury investigating the Long Island Rail Road wreck at Rockville Centre on Feb. 17 today found there had been failure by the railroad to give adequate consideration to safeguarding the public in its planning and operation.

Charming young evening fashions supplied much of the excitement in a showing yesterday at Oppenheim Collins to celebrate the eighteenth anniversary of the opening of its junior shop. Snowy white and delicately embroidered organdies were short and fullskirted. White lace, worn over a yellow taffeta slip, looked particularly chic with its low scooped neck and a pleated organdy ruffle edging the swaying skirt.

Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, announced last night that he had approved preliminary plans for a new Pier 57 at Fifteenth Street, and had instructed the engineering concern of Madigan-Hyland to proceed with final plans for the structure.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- American business this year will spend about 11 per cent less on new plant and equipment than in 1949, according to the latest survey of capital outlays made public jointly today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Commerce. Capital outlays are expected to total $16,100,000,000 this year as compared with $18,100,000,000 last year and $19,200,000,000 in the peak year of 1948.

MADISON, Wis., March 30-- After a period of watchful waiting, Wisconsin Republicans are moving to divorce themselves from responsibility for the personal conduct of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in the investigation of his charges of Communist infiltration in the State Department.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30--A war-wounded mental patient at the Belle Vista Sanatorium confessed today, the State Police said, that he set the fire which killed nine other male inmates of the institution last night, touching a match to a towel on a rack near the laundry chute.
The first ship carrying American military equipment to strengthen the armies of Western Europe sailed from New York Harbor last night for Italy.
If chill winds blow on Easter Sunday, the fashion parade will bring forth an exciting display of styles from the many attractive coats now in the stores.
The Jewish Passover festival will begin at sundown tonight and be celebrated by Orthodox and Conservative Jews for eight days, and by Reform congregations until sundown next Saturday.
HOUSTON, Tex., March 31 (AP) --A $100,000,000 expansion program to start in April has been announced by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.

Ted Cott, program manager of Station WNEW for the last six years, has been named general manager of the National Broadcasting Company's local radio and television outlets in New York, it was disclosed last night. He will be in charge of the operations of WNBC and WNBC-FM, the standard and frequency, modulation radio stations, and WNBT, the video station.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 --Business men and farmers must unite forces if they are to prevent the enactment of new Government programs which would cost the taxpayers an additional $25,000,000,000 annually, William Rhea Blake, executive vice-president of the National Cotton Council, told the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute in session here today.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 31-- Although great undeveloped mineral wealth exists in wide areas of Iran, this country will extend no further concessions to foreign countries or concerns for exploration or exploitation of oil or other raw materials, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi said today in an interview with this correspondent.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 (AP)--The Detroit Tigers downed the St. Louis Cards, 2 to 1, in eleven innings today. It was the Red Birds' fourth straight loss.
WASHINGTON, March 31--Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that the Soviet Union was moving "on a grand scale" to detach Sinkiang Province from China.

A laundress was injured early yesterday morning in a spectacular four-alarm fire on Wards Island that destroyed an employes' residence building at Manhattan State Hospital for the Mentally Ill with a loss estimated at $100,000.

Outstanding decreases in aviation accidents in the last decade were described here yesterday at the closing sessions of the four-day twentieth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council.

LONDON, March 31--The national financial year ended tonight with a true budget surplus of 62,000,000 ($173,000,000), a surplus that is 48,000,000 ($134,400,000) more than Sir Stafford Cripps budgeted for last year.

Law enforcement representatives agreed yesterday that when the average motorist is good he is very, very good, but when he is bad he's a menace. This finding was based upon data presented at the closing sessions of the annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Statler.

A frail-looking blond boy fastened his leather windbreaker, pulled down the earmuffs on his plaid cap and, clutching an overseas airlines zipper bag, walked out of Babies Hospital yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 31-- After saying in a pre-game interview that he had "a better club than last year," Manager Barney Shotton today watched the Dodgers drop their final game here to their Montreal farm, 6-5.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 --Charlton Heston, a recruit from Broadway and East Coast television, will take over the role previously announced for Burt Lancaster in "Dark City," which is scheduled to go before the cameras at Paramount on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)-- Two nutritionists said today that American livestock was fed better than many human beings.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 31-- The marriage of Miss Ann Young Evans to William Robertson Coe 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Rogers Coe of Glen Cove, L. I., took place here this afternoon in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roger F. Evans.

Chief Petty Officer Alfred Collins, who was in charge of the Ambrose Lightship when it was in collision last Tuesday with the Grace liner Santa Monica, testified yesterday that he thought the liner would clear his ship and that he did not give an alarm until she was within 150 yards of the lightship.

Beginning today many an American seamen on the country's 2,000 active merchant ships will be scratching his head and chewing on a pen while filling out a special yellow form designed by the Bureau of the Census.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 31 (AP)--Dave Bauer, the veteran Midland, Tex., pro, is not ready to say whether his famous golfing daughters, Marlene and Alice, will enter the 1950 women's national amateur championship.

WASHINGTON, March 31--The House passed and sent to the Senate today an omnibus foreign-aid authorization of $3,102,450,000, including $2,850,000,000 for European Recovery in the fiscal year 1951. The vote was 287 to 86.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 31 -Col: John J.Dooley, U.S.M. C.R., retired, a leading expert on military rifles and machine guns and for many years an official at the National Rifle Matches at Camp Perry, Ohio, died here yesterday in his home, 10 Bayard Street, at the age of 80.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 31 (AP)--Michigan State moved to the front in the National Collegiate A.A. boxing tournament tonight as Louisiana State's hopes of retaining the team title vanished in the semi-final round.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., March 31--Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer tonight urged business to inform the American people of its vital contributions to their daily lives with actions and facts, rather than general statements lauding the American way of life. Such a course, he said, will serve to regain for business its lost political and public influence.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., March 31 --In the Scarsdale Congregational Church Miss Julia Ray, Gibson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd C. Gibson, was married tonight to John Philip Axtell, son of Mrs. John Harold Axtell and the late Mr. Axtell. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward C. Boynton. A reception was held in the Gibson home.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month expanded slightly over February and was the heaviest for March since 1937.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 31-- Bouncing up with three runs in the eighth inning, the final pair riding home on the wings of a single by Willard Marshall, one-time favorite at the Polo Grounds; the Braves today toppled the Yankees, 7 to 6. That gave Billy Southworth's refurbished club the spring exhibition series over the world champions by a margin of two games to one.
LONDON, March 31--The year ending March 31, 1949, was Britain's best year in terms of good health, the Ministry of Health reported today.
FRANKFORT, Germany, March 31--Representatives of the East and West German governments have resumed negotiations for the lifting of the embargo on steel shipments from the Ruhr to the Soviet zone.
TOKYO, March 31, (UP)--Japan'S merchant fleet, long subsidized and run by the Government, will go back into private operation tomorrow for the first time in eight years.

The Whitney Museum's annual exhibition of sculpture, watercolors and drawings will open to the public today and will run until May 28. More than seventy pieces of sculpture, as many watercolors and about thirty drawings are included.

ALBANY, March 31--Joseph D. McGoldrick, a Democrat who served as Controller of New York City in the late Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia's administration, was appointed today by Governor Dewey as State Rent Administrator at $15,000 a year.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31-- Naval aircraft and the Destroyer Colahan continued a search today for an unidentified submarine reported seen forty miles off Cape Mendocino, on the northern California coast, on Wednesday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31-- The helicopter, long a dream but in the last few years a flying reality, is in the "acceptability phase" of its development, two hundred designers, engineers and operators of such planes were told here today by Harry S. Pack, vice president of the Piasecki Helicopter Corporation, Morton, Pa.
PARIS, March 31 (UP)--Former Premier Leon Blum will--be buried Sunday afternoon at Montmartre Cemetery, Socialist party headquarters announced today.

Performances will be given today at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. by the Sue Hastings' Marionettes of "The Adventures of Raggedy Ann and Andy," at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue. (Admission prices are 70 and 90 cents, tickets available at the box office.).

Successful outcome for the standby underwriting of the new issue of $37,727,000 of the Southern Pacific Company's convertible debentures was assured yesterday by reports that less than 10 per cent of the issue remained unsubscribed when the two-week subscription period ended yesterday afternoon.

DILLON, Col., March 31 (AP)-- Zipping through a snowstorm, Colin Stewart of Dartmouth covered a 2,970-yard course down Norway Mountain in 2 minutes 9.5 seconds to win the downhill race that opened the college ski tournament today.
LAWRENCE, L. I., March 31-- The high school athlete's father had suffered a slight heart attack and would have to remain in bed for a few days. Money earned by his mother was needed more than ever.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 31-- Grapplers from two Iowa institutions of learning, Iowa State Teachers College of Cedar Falls and Cornell College easily captured the spotlight as the opening session of the sixtieth annual National A.A.U. two-day wrestling championships was completed at Hofstra College's Calkins Gymnasium tonight.

CHICAGO, March 31--Reports that the Commodity Credit Corporation had bought 1,000,000 bushels of soybeans in the Southwest and wanted 100,000 bushels more started a buying movement in that commodity in the late trading on the Board of Trade today and sent the May position up 4 cents a bushel from the early low, with the close at net gains of to 3 cents.

ATHENS, March 31--In a stern letter to Premier Sophocles Venizelos, the United States Ambassador, Dr. Henry F. Grady, warned Greece's Government and Parliament today that effective measures for economic rehabilitation must be taken quickly if Greece wished to continue receiving full Marshall Plan aid.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 31-- The creation of a small international armed force capable of putting down local "breaches of the peace" has been suggested to members of the United Nations Security Council by Secretary General Trygve Lie.

Plans for the construction of a store and office building in Hempstead, L. I., were announced in connection wish the purchase of the leasehold of the property at the northeast corner of Main and Front Streets from the eight heirs of the Kreischer estate.

The city's churches will have their annual Palm Sunday devotion tomorrow, with music retelling the story of the opening of Holy Week as celebrated through the centuries by Christians.
If the weather stays fair, there'll probably be between 45,000 and 50,000 winner-seekers at Jamaica today for the opening show of New York's 196-day racing season.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31--A spokesman for the Yugoslav Government announced today that the problem of thousands of Greek child refugees in Yugoslavia would be dealt with according to the principles of the United Nations resolution of last November urging the return of the children to their homes.

WASHINGTON, March 31--The Munitions Board of the Department of Defense listed 200 plants in the National Industrial Reserve as of Feb. 28 in a report submitted today to Congress. This compares to 236 in the reserve status a year ago.
New York's rain-making project became a big-league operation yesterday.
The fact that the Senate is nearing a showdown on amendments to the Displaced Persons Act of 1948 is cause for encouragement.

Two men suspected of robbing the homes of several families in Newton, Mass., of $75,000 in jewelry in the last few months were arrested yesterday after a scuffle in a midtown hotel lobby. Stolen jewelry worth $25,000 was recovered from the pair, according to the police of the West Sixtyeighth Street Station.

BERLIN, March 31--Lord Mayor Ernst Reuter disclosed tonight that a great athletic meet would be staged in the Olympic Stadium in the British sector coincident with the Communist youth demonstration in the city on Whitsunday, May 28.

Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared tonight that the Truman Administration had drawn the nation to "disaster" in foreign policy, and was headed the same way fiscally.

Stormy public hearings before the Board of Estimate on Mayor O'Dwyer's record-breaking 1950-51 executive budget of $1,243,451,794 were forecast yesterday when the Mayor and his colleagues on the board were bitterly assailed on two fronts.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 31--The United States plans to seek British and French approval at the Western Big Three Foreign Ministers Conference in London in May for acquisition of air bases in Spain.

Small-town newspapers hold the front line in the battle for the maintenance of America's free press, Robert U. Brown, editor of the magazine Editor and Publisher, told a meeting of the National Editorial Association yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- President Truman, in a message to the national convention of Americans for Democratic Action, declared today that the 1950 elections "may well be one of the most crucial tests of liberalism in this century."

WASHINGTON, March 31--Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, announced his intention today of pressing for a try-out of the food allotment plan that he had introduced in Congress each year since 1943.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 31--Coinciding with the return of Seretse Khama to Bechuanaland from London where he had unsuccessfully pressed his claim to be installed as chief of the Bamangwato tribe, Sir Evelyn Baring, the British High Commissioner here, announced the appointment today of W. Forbes Mackenzie of the Colonial Service as virtual ruler of the tribe.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP)--The Professional Golfers Association of America disclosed tonight that most of its headline tournament stars are planning to bolt the organization and form their own group.

Fall lingerie lines opening June 15 will present a larger percentage of silk fabrics and laces than in any season since the war, according to Herbert Miskend, president of Yolande Corporation. Couture lingerie, lines shown in Paris, he said, have emphasized the use of silk sheers, crepe de chines and other novelty fabrics.

TEANECK, N. J., March 31-- United States Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, declared here tonight that the ideological front, not the military or economic fronts, was the real scene of the struggle between the United States and Communist Russia.

Prices of rubber futures advanced sharply on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, reflecting the steadily rising London and Singapore markets. Gains of 20 to 35 points in the near-by deliveries established new high prices for the life of the contracts.
Frank M. Folsom, president of the Radio Corporation of America, last night called on industry to take the leadership in providing equal employment opportunity for Negroes and other minority groups.
PORTLAND, Me., March 31-- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, tonight called President Truman's denunciation of three Republican Senators "bitter and prejudiced."

Twenty American and Canadian youths made their first plane trip yesterday on a special goodwill exchange flight of the Trans-Canada Air Lines to mark the start today of operation of a new airline route between New York and Montreal.

Six hundred persons attended a funeral service for Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Canada, yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. Mr. Steinhardt died on Tuesday near Ottawa in a plane crash that also took the lives of four others.

Latest additions to the collection of brilliant heavy crystal accessories at Steuben Glass, 718 Fifth Avenue, range from a shallow ashtray seven inches in diameter to a deep wide bowl with clawlike base.

Directors of the Zenith Radio Corporation have declared a $2 dividend, payable April 29 to holders of record on April 14.

MOSCOW, April 2 (AP)--A Russian-Chinese civil airline has been established in a ten-year agreement to operate flights between Peiping and cities in the Soviet Union, it was announced today.

The Passover message of freedom, with its age-old emphasis on the dignity of man, was stressed by rabbis yesterday in sermons marking the first day of the festive season.

Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, pontificated at the solemn blessing of palms in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. Then he presided at the solemn mass of Palm Sunday. There was a congregation of 4,500.

None of the lightness usually associated with contemporary Scandinavian furniture is to be found in the new collection by Pers Persson at Swedish Modern, 675 Fifth Avenue. The pieces are noticeably heavy and are distinguished by matched crotch veneers.

CHICAGO, April 2--A bull market was on in grains on the board of trade last week, all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats and soybeans, except September oats, selling at new high prices for the crop year to date with May soybeans in new ground since May, 1948, while May corn went to a new high since last July.

Fairfield Osborn, president of the Conservation Foundation, had some wise things to say recently regarding what he calls a "forgotten cause" of today's world-wide political and social tensions: the lack of balance between available natural resources and the demands of a growing population.

PITTSBURGH, April 2--The steel rate advanced again last week with the operating schedule up one point to 96.5 per cent of rated capacity. There was further evidence late last week that the rate this week would be equal to or better than last week's.

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP)--The Professional Golfers Association of America tonight announced that George Schneiter had been dismissed as P.G.A. tournament bureau manager.

Smythe, president, declared yesterday, in the annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 3--Senator Herbert H. Lehman, DemocratLiberal of New York, charged in the Senate today that changes in the displaced persons law proposed by the Judiciary Committee would "pervert and destroy" the present program to find homes in this country for war refugees.
As a result of increasing demand for accommodations from the Midwest and West the French Line is planning a so-called "southern route" service from New Orleans to Europe, it was announced yesterday.
The National Basketball Association had a who-dun-it case on its hands today titled "who sent the phony telegram to referee Arnold Heft?"

Ten men aboard the forty-foot fishing boat Claire were rescued from the Long Island Sound off Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon after a collision between the vessel and the 1,139-ton oil tanker Mystic Sun.

TRENTON, April 3--A standby rent-control bill was passed by the New Jersey Senate tonight, 19 to 1, but it was far different from the administration measure proposed by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

Landers, Frary Clark, manufacturer of "Universal" home appliances, will move in Supreme Court today for temporary injunctions against twelve dealers allegedly underselling fair traded merchandise, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 3--The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today the nomination of Irving R. Kaufman for a new Federal judgeship in the Southern District of New York.

Joshua Logan said here yesterday that he contemplated writing a new play and would like to have someone else, possibly Elia Kazan, handle the direction.

WASHINGTON, April 3--President Truman's reorganization plan to transfer certain functions to the Secretary of Labor was approved today by the House Committee on Expenditures in Executive Departments after it heard testimony by Maurice J. Tobin supporting it.

Fourteen hundred decorators from all over the country registered at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday for the opening of the nineteenth annual conference of the American Institute of Decorators. The three-day convention...

WASHINGTON, April 3--Individuals in the United States last year saved $4,300,000,000 in liquid form, such as currency and bank deposits, equity in savings and loan associations, insurance and pension reserves, securities and reduction of mortgage debt, the Security and Exchange Commission reported.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 3 --A suit brought by stockholders of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation and affiliates for repayment of losses suffered through alleged mismanagement in the late Nineteen Thirties came to trial here today before Supreme Court Referee Frederick P. Close.
CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., April 3-- A truck of The Reader's Digest was waylaid by four armed robbers at 3 P.M. today as it was leaving the magazine plant, four miles from Pleasantville.

WASHINGTON, April 3--Earl J. McGrath, Commissioner of Education, told a House education subcommittee today that the school construction bill could be no substitute for the general aid to education bill.
LONDON, April 3--A brisk turnover was recorded in two new issues on the London stock market today. In general, however, are approaching budget and the Easter holiday kept business on a low level.

A message in which President Truman promised to "continue to press for legislation to provide more adequately for the housing of middle-income families" was a highlight of the nineteenth annual meeting of the National Housing Conference yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel.
The money market continued tight yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 17/16 per cent, with conditions little changed from those prevailing on Friday.
Easter vacation time is almost here again, and all over the land millions of students, from the youngest kindergartners to college seniors, are awaiting it with impatience they disdain to conceal.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)-- The Supreme Court announced today that it would not review a refusal by two lower courts to approve a reorganization plan for the Florida East Coast Railway Company.
Retail food prices probably will continue their slight but steady decline during the second quarter, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, declared yesterday.

Radio station WINS was charged with a "lockout" yesterday by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians after the station declined to renew its union contract and dispensed with its entire staff of eight musicians.

PARIS, Tuesday, April 4--Two new coordinating bodies, at the highest level of the French military establishment were brought into existence this morning with publication of a governmental decree in the official journal of the French Republic.

Garry Davis, 28-year-old selfstyled "citizen of the world," was released from Ellis Island yesterday evening and admitted to the country of his birth as an immigrant.
WASHINGTON, April 3--President Truman urged Congress today to overhaul fundamentally the whole farm program.

The net income of the Aluminum Company of America in 1949 was $24,218,404, equal to $4.45 a common share, compared with adjusted earnings of $39,969,145, or $7.67 a share, in 1948, the company announced in the annual report to stockholders issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)-- United States News and World Report says there is competent evidence that flying saucers are real aircraft of revolutionary design, developed in the United States.

TRENTON, April 3--A $30,000,000 damage suit was filed in United States District Court today, charging conspiracy by three large airlines and two aviation associations.

ROME, April 3--An antiquated system of taxation and governmental red tape today were labelled by James D. Zellerbach, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission to Italy, as the two outstanding obstacles to Italy's continued economic propress.
