LONDON, April 3--The British preoccupation with food was reflected in the House of Commons today when one member of Parliament after another pressed Government spokesmen for informaion about easing the restrictions that have helped to keep the nation's diet dreary and monotonous.

Blame for the Long Island Rail Road wreck that took thirty-two lives at Rockville Centre on Feb. 17 was laid yesterday upon the railroad, the State Public Service Commission and the State Department of Public Works by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.

ATHENS, April 3--United States officials cracked down tonight on Premier Sophocles Venizelos' failure to form a stable government by authorizing the first "indefinite delay" in United States aid projects to Greece.

EL PASO, Texas, April 3--The Giants launched their homeward trek series against the Cleveland Indians today in something less than an auspicious manner. They ran into weather which complicat-, ed matters somewhat. But the real difficulty was found in the good right arm of Early Wynn, who baffled Leo Durocher's clubbers and laid the groundwork for a Cleveland victory, by 5--3.

WASHINGTON, April 3--Representative Clarence Cannon, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, opened debate today on the largest peacetime money bill in history with a warning that it was part of a "war budget that cannot be balanced."

WASHINGTON, April 3--With much of what Bernard M. Baruch said and urged in his speech of March 31 to the Naval. War College at Newport, R.I., many officials here are in informal agreement. And they were impressed with his statement that he considers "extravagant" some current reports of the military strength of Soviet Russia.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 2.5 per cent in March, compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The stock market snapped back yesterday with considerable force. Led by the motors, with some assistance from the oils, steels and rails, it registered the best advance in almost three weeks.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range throughout yesterday's session, and final prices were 4 points higher to 4 points lower.

CHICAGO, April 3--Miss. Katherine Woodruff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Woodruff of Joliet, has completed plans for her marriage to Marshall Field Jr., son of Mrs. Diego Suarez of the River House, New York, and Marshall Field of New York and Chicago. The ceremony will take place on May 12 in the Central Presbyterian Church, Joliet.
STORRS, Conn., April 3--Gov. Chester Bowles today proposed a new national farm income-support program that would be geared to the national industrial economy.

DALLAS, April 3 (AP)--Ralph S. Trigg, president of the Commodity Credit Corporation, today announced a six-point cottonseed support program for the 1950 crop.

Lubka Kolessa, Polish pianist, who made her debut here two years ago, gave her second New York recital at Carnegie Hall last night. She proved again that she is an intelligent and skillful pianist with a musical nature and a charming personality.

Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, who visited Israel recently, expressed confidence last night that the Arab neighbors of the new country had no intention of using arms shipments for renewed warfare. Differing with him, Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, asserted there was definite proof that Egypt and the other Arab countries were preparing for war.

The major passenger lines operating from New York are planning a strong protest against a proposed change in the Immigration Law that would require aliens in transit to other countries via the United States, or the companies transporting them to post a $500 bond to insure the departure of the aliens at the end of their designated stay, it became known yesterday.

GENEVA, April 3--The rumble of millions of potatoes overflowing their bins in the United States was heard distinctly in the Palais des Nations in Geneva today.

MANILA, Tuesday, April 4--The Communist-led Hukbalahap rebellion has receded into the scare and rumor stage, so far as Manila is concerned, with operational censorship surrounding the Philippine Army's field actions and new raids on undefended towns being confined to isolated places on Luzon with eight more reported deaths.

DILLON, Col., April 3 (AP)-- The Dartmouth Indians, easily standing off late challenges by Denver and Washington, captured the championship of the first national college ski meet yesterday with a grand total of 1,483.84 points.

ST. PETERSBURG; Fla., April 4 --It may be that it all will amount to nothing. But the unalterable fact remains that the world champion Yankees still are finishing on the wrong end of the daily scores.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 4 (AP)--A move to draft Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for a third-term nomination apparently picked up speed today among Republican leaders.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The Department of Agriculture today announced that with acceptance by New Jersey potato growers of a marketing order as to quality, the 1950 price support program goes into effect on New Jersey potatoes.

Competition for the Sunday night television audience will be heightened this week-end when the DuMont network, which locally is WABD, unveils a new two-hour show, to be called "Starlit Time." It will be an informal musical revue running from 6 to 8 P.M.
WASHINGTON, April 4--Dr. Carter Godwin Woodson, founder and director of the Association for Study of Negro Life and History, died at his home here yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 74 years old.

MONTREAL, April 4--Getting off an accurate shot from the right alley and cleanly sending the drive into the cage, Elmer Lach kept the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League's playoffs tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 11 to 0 today to restrict the House-approved PointFour program for elevating the economies and living standards in backward areas of the world. The committee voted to limit the plan to the provision of technical aid and skills.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 4--A farmer-labor committee named by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, State Democratic chairman, mapped plans here today to blanket the state with a series of meetings during the next three months to bring farmers and labor together to solve mutual problems through political action.
BERLIN, April 4--All but one of the twenty-eight members of the Mozart girls choir of Dresden appealed to Western and German authorities today for sanctuary as political refugees.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The Senate subcommittee investigating Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charges of Communist infiltration of the State Department called upon him today to hand over all his information, "documentary or otherwise."

WASHINGTON, Aprii 4--Seven local housing authorities awarded $4,291,000 in short term loan notes in competitive bidding today, the Public Housing Administration announced.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, attacked President Truman's National Labor Relations Board Reorganization Plan today as "political" and designed to "nullify" and repeal the Taft-Hartley Act by "indirection."
In a message dispatched to Congress from his vacation headquarters in Key West, President Truman urges that the nation's farm policy be overhauled.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 2--If the Soviet Union were to invade Iran it is axiomatic that the country could not be held. The best the Shah's army and tribal units could accomplish would be to carry out demolitions, especially along the lengthy and many-tunneled railway, and raid and sabotage the occupation forces by guerrilla tactics.

"Hot" colors ranging from orange to red, tropical accents of bamboo and reed and bright glints of metallic yarn and pigments in floor coverings, wall coverings and fabric's seem indicated for next year's homes.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 4-- Harry Renton Bridges was labeled a Communist today by a jury, of his peers.

Although there always have been channel bass around Oregon Inlet by All Fool's Day, as attested by the memory of the oldest inhabitant, this year saw the day come and go without a single fish being spotted by the seekers.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- Members of the Civil Aeronautics Board took exception today to a charge by Gov. Ernest Greening of Alaska that the board had "cracked down" on independent air operators in Alaska and "practically put them out of business."
Wanda Landowska gave a harpsichord recital last night in Town Hall which observed in an original and enriching way the 200th anniversary of the death of J.S. Bach.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to approve purchase by the railroad of $2,000,000 of Boston Providence 5 per cent debentures from the railroad's president and chairman of the board, Frederick C. Dumaine.

The Electric Boat Company in its fiftieth annual report to stockholders, released today, disclosed that the company is preparing for future developments in the field of nuclear ship propulsion and a series of lectures on atomic energy have been started at its Groton plant.

PARIS, April 4--In one of its least important meetings, the European Marshall Plan council chose Dr. Dirk U. Stikker, Foreign Minister of the Netherlands, today as its chairman for the coming year and merged its Steering with its Executive Committee.

Only 2 cents is spent on psychiatric research in this country for every $50 expended on industrial research and for every $100 (spent on all medical research, Dr. William C. Menninger, psychiatrist, reported yesterday.

Twenty men and women were paroled yesterday in Lower Manhattan Magistrates Court on charges of disorderly conduct as the result of a demonstration at the welfare center at 44 Stanton Street. They agreed to refrain from further demonstrations until their hearing Tuesday.

Detectives, after a three-week surveillance, yesterday rounded up ten men and two women as suspects ink recent robberies in the Bath Beach, Borough Park and Bay Ridge sections of Brooklyn, where jewelry, furs and household articles worth $50,000 had been stolen.

A pair of dessert mixes has been added to grocery shelves this week, one a brand-new product of the Lipton Tea Company and the other Bird's Dessert Powder, which the British have been using for more than a century.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 4--While most of their classmates are seeking fine arts degrees for careers in business or the professions, nine students at the New Jersey College for Women are pursuing studies that will enable them to become farmers or--more probably--competent wives of farming men.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, ordered the Joint Chiefs of Staff today to re-examine the Administration's $14,114,460,000 military budget to determine whether more funds should be requested for aircraft procurement.
LAKE SUCCESS, April 4--Several influential United Nations delegates have proposed the resumption here of atomic discussions by the other great powers in the absence of Nationalist China.

SAIGON, Indo-China, April 3-- Leaders who have associated themselves with the Viet Nam regime established under last year's French agreement with Bao Dai uniformly hope for eventual modification of the accord to give Viet Nam fuller sovereignty.

Although stores here were jammed by crowds yesterdwy on the warmest day of spring, few establishments gave figures that exceeded last year's by an appreciable maigin, a check of the metropolitan area disclosed.
In contrast to the disintegration of family life after World War I, the current era is seeing a steady shift toward greater family stability, Miss Ardis Whitman declared last night.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber yesterday reserved decision on a motion by Landers, Frary Clark, manufacturer of home appliances, to restrain twelve dealers from allegedly underselling fair-traded merchandise.

LONDON, April 4--Sir Stafford Cripps, dour preacher of austerity, appeared before the House of Commons today as the bearer of cheerful tidings. The British and the sterling area, he said, had "earned a net gold and dollar surplus" of $40,000,000 in the first quarter of this year.

In his recent testimony before the House Appropriations Committee, not published until lash Monday, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner in Germany, stated that in his judgment increased Soviet pressure does not proceed from fear of attack or a sense of inferiority on the part of the Russians, "but because they feel their strength and immediate hope of success."

The Chase National Bank's loans outstanding at the end of the first quarter showed an increase of about $29,000,000 over the total at the close of 1949, according to the bank's statement of condition as of March 31, published today.
Prices of rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange advanced sharply in active trading yesterday.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 4--President Truman said today he knew nothing about the flying saucer, while other White House comment relegated this reputed wanderer of the air to the realm of myths.

"Cry of the Peacock," tomorrow night's scheduled premiere at the Mansfield, has been set back to next Tuesday evening. A spokesman for the management ascribed the delay to the illness of Raymond Lovell, one of the featured players.
NORFOLK, Va., April 4--Spreading accusations in the grounding of the Missouri appeared today to have enmeshed the battleship's executive officer, Comdr. George E. Peckham.

After a trial lasting almost five months, Harry Bridges, who must be the most investigated man in the United States, has been found guilty in Federal Court of having committed perjury at his naturalization hearing in September, 1945, when he said he was not then and had never been a member of the Communist party.
CHICAGO, April 4 (AP)--Athletic policy makers of American colleges met today amid growing indications something would be done to change the "Sanity Code" that has caused so much campus commotion.
Directors of the Duplan Corporation declared yesterday a 2 per cent stock dividend, payable April 28, and the regular semi-annual cash dividend of 25 cents for payment Aug. 1. Last year the com
Madeline Fried has purchased the five-story thirty-six-family apartment house at 2323 Creston Avenue, the Bronx, from Dorben Properties, Inc., of which Israel Pine is president.

HOUSTON, April 4--In nearwinter weather, the Dodgers drew 11,404 cash customers tonight and defeated Houston of the Texas League, 8--2. Some 60 per cent of the fans were Negroes who rooted for the Brooks.
DAYTON, Ohio, April 4 (UP)-- Ira B. Wilson, composer and music publisher, died yesterday in Los Angeles, relatives here have been informed.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The W.T. Grant Company of New York City, filed today a request with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the registration of 118,935 shares of its, $5 par common stock.

The annual report of Allen B. DuMont Laboratories issued to the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday disclosed an increase in net income for 1949 to $3,269,880 from the $2,701,767 realized the year before.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 4--Large scale shifts of white collar workers to basic industries began April 1 under the Government's program of increasing the nation's productive labor force.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- Appointment of seven new mem hers to the Loyalty Review Board was announced today by the Civil Service Commission.

LONDON, April 4--The controversy over the suitability of John Strachey as British Secretary for War and his sharing of North Atlantic pact defense secrets raises the larger issue of security within the North Atlantic Treaty organization as a whole.

With the Kentucky Derby a month away, the first of the local tests for Churchill Downs elegibles will be contested today at Jamaica in the eleventh running of the $20,000 added Experimental Free Handicap No. 1.
Having announced a few days ago a budget surplus of $173,000,000, Sir Stafford Cripps is now in a position to report a decided improvement in the British balance of payments.
Contract laborers from the British West Indies will be kept off New York farms this spring and summer by the United States Department of Labor, it was learned yesterday.

FOR more years than anyone can remember every fashion stylist has annually decreed that male garb is too drab and somber. Even nature art anges things better, they claim, because the male peacock is flashier and more appealing to the eye than the female of the species. The lion has a massive, regal mane.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Secretary of State Dean Acheson called upon the member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty today to work even more closely together if they would assure the peace of the world and gain "a higher state of well-being."

SAN ANTONIO, April 4--Dave Koslo narrowly missed the distinction of becoming the first pitcher on the club to go nine innings today even though the Giants suffered their fifth straight defeat, 7--6, when the Indians scored a run in the ninth inning.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 4-- Having failed to persuade exiled King Leopold III to abdicate, Albert Deveze, Liberal leader, formally surrendered today to the Regent, Prince Charles, his mandate to form a new Belgian Government.

PARIS, April 4--In a move to outlaw the French Communist party, an attempt unprecedented since creation of the Fourth Republic, twenty-seven Deputies-- many of them followers of Gen. Charles de Gaulle--today submitted a draft resolution inviting the Government to take "all legitimate measures of active defense" against a "foreign party called Communist."

Industrial possibilities in Greece have been greatly strengthened by plans for developing the "tremen dous potential" of hydroelectric power in the country, Carl C. Compton, dean and acting president of Anatolia College, Thessa loniki, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 4--In a memorandum to the British Government, the United States has protested the curb on dollar oil imports as "discriminatory" and insisted on the right of United States overseas oil companies to compete anywhere in the sterling area for the market for refined products covered by the British "subscription" program.

Some surprisingly young students are attending Wadleigh High School this term. Every morning along with the teen-age girls who troop into the venerable old building on 114th Street, west of Seventh avenue, come sixteen boys and girls, aged 3 to 4 . They are pupils in the school's new demonstration nursery, the first such project in academic high school in this city.

The Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company yesterday announced that it has concluded a contract to sell 1,300 new freight cars to the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, which in turn will rent them to the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad under a plan recently brought out by that insurance company.

BOISE, Idaho, April 4 (AP)--A nine-point summary of the Union Pacific Railroad's position has been submitted in the Interstate Commerce Commission hearing on the requested opening of the Ogden (Utah) gateway by the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad.
Of the accessories that play their part in the completion of the Easter ensemble, one of the most important is the handbag.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday an appropriation of $270,600 for the construction of three new parking fields near the boardwalk in Rockaway Beach, Queens. Intended primarily to relieve the parking problem during the summer months, the fields will provide space for 715 cars.

At a miltant meeting last night, 500 teachers in the city's public high schools voted to stop all voluntary extracurricular activities, beginning April 17, unless each received an annual cost-of-living adjustment of at least $600. Only six teachers voted in opposition.

In the redemption last week of $5,905,000 of bonds floated here twenty years ago to finance a water and sewerage improvement many thousands of miles away, an ironic commentary was written on the gulf that meantime has tended to alienate the needs of dollarpinched undeveloped lands of the far Pacific from the glut of private dollar investment money here.

GENEVA, April 4--The contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade ended a six-week session here today that, in the opinion of trade officials of the twenty participating countries, has strengthened the multilateral system of settling trade policy disputes.
Walter E. Poor, chairman of the board of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., 500 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 64.

Hanson W. Baldwin, military editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told an audience of teachers at Times Hall; 240 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday that the success of the European arms-aid program depended in large measure on France.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4-- After nearly ten years during which the project was revived several times and dropped, Warner Brothers today announced that its would bring to the screen next year the life story of Will Rogers.

Alfred Bleyer, president Of Alfred Bleyer Co., paper firm of Maspeth, Queens, who had been in the business for fifty-eight years, died yesterday in his home, 285 Central Park West, after a brief illness.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- The United States Treasury plans a study to determine the reason for a sharp drop in income taxes paid by professional men, farmers and higher-salaried individuals.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Proponents of broad liberalization of the Displaced Persons Act of 1948, confident but wary on the eve of,the showdown vote in the Senate, stood ready tonight to cope with a "filibuster by amendment," should one develop tomorrow.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 4 (AP)-- The executive committee of the Professional Golfers Association will meet here Monday with the dissident "eleven player board of governors" to attempt again to bring peace to professional golf.

The average national output over the next five years must increase $25,000,000,000 over the current $250,000,000,000 level or unemployment will increase to 10,000,000 to 12,000,000, Leon H. Keyserling, acting chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, warned last night.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Senate and House conferees agreed informally today to throw strong security safeguards around the proposed National Science Foundation, but not to go as far as the House Prescribed when it passed the bill.

WASHINGTON, April 4-- Thomas Knight Finletter, named by President Truman to become Secretary of the Air Force, is a New York lawyer and student of politics and foreign affairs who has served the Government in many capacities.
Leaders of labor, past and present Government officials and private citizens will pay tribute tomorrow to the late Leon Blum, former Premier of France, in a memorial ceremony at Manhattan Center.
Human and animal artists will come out from behind the adjective camouflage tonight and open the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus season at Madison Square Garden.

Taking the position that it was not desirable for women to be employed behind the bar, bartender union officials said yesterday they would seek introduction of a local law in the City Council to prohibit the employment of barmaids.

A system for measuring effectiveness of trade and business shows, said to be comparable to the Audit Bureau of Circulations' system for publications, will be made known soon by the Exhibitoys Advisory Council, it was learned yesterday.
New York had a one-day summer-in-spring yesterday. It was staged by a group of hot-headed zephyrs from down Gulf of Mexico way.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 4--The Bruederschaft, the organization of former German officers that plays a covert but important role in the politics of Western Germany, his moving toward the advocacy of German neutrality in the "cold war" between the East and the West.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Progressive party said today that proposed anti-Communist laws were unnecessary and a threat to everybody's rights.
WASHINGTON, April 4--Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, proposed today a program of unity for labor's organized millions.

"The Member of the Wedding," "The Cocktail Party" and "The Consul" were chosen yesterday by the New York Drama Critics Circle as the best stage productions of their kind on Broadway during the 1949-50 season.
KEY WEST, Fla., April 4-- Thomas Knight Finletter of New York, one of the early proponents of a seventy-group Air Force, was nominated by President Truman today as Secretary of the Air Force.

Rosemary, at this point, belongs and talkative. She is a little mimic, to no one. Her mother died recently and her father has deserted her. Rosemary is unable to put her feelings of loneliness into words, for she is only a year and half old.

In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Countess Elizabeth Maria Andrassy, daughter of Count and Countess Imre Andrassy of 17 East Sixty-seventh Street and Buenos Aires, was married to Aladar Olgyay, son of Mrs. Victor Olgyay of Budapest, Hungary, and the late Professor Olgyay.

"Mad About Opera," an Italianmade romance with music, with opera stars Beniamino Gigli, Maria Caniglia, Tito Gobbi and Tito Schipa and Lollo Brigida, Constance Dowling and Carlo Campanini heading the cast, is the film new comer arriving today at the Little CineMet. Mario Costa directed the importation, which is released here by Motion Picture Sales Corporation.

ALBANY, April 4--Governor Dewey was urged today by the committee on state legislation of the State Bar Association to veto a bill now before him that would outlaw picketing within 1,000 feet of a court house if the purpose of the picketing was to influence any trial or hearing.

The first "hall of fame" award of the Radio Pioneers, an organization of persons who have been employed in radio more than twenty years, was made in memory of Thomas A. Edison last night at the Pioneers' annual dinner at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
Thirteen persons live in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty on Bedloes Island, a brisk young census-taker discovered yesterday.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 4--Village government was at a standstill here today as each of two men insisted he was the head of the board of trustees and the board itself was divided into factions that demanded separate recognition from a thoroughly perplexed police department.

The White House has pledged the fullest cooperation to the new Federal Maritime Board in furthering a powerful privately owned merchant marine and has guaranteed the new agency virtual autonomy within the Department of Commerce, it became known yesterday.
A new transit crisis developed yesterday as Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., threatened a shutdown of the city's subway system.
A vacant tract of land, about 338 by 1,352 feet, on the west side of Fifth Avenue, south of Spence Street, in Bay Shore, L.I., has been purchased by Mutual Estates, Inc., from Adolph Gilbert.

Six men were indicted by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of seeking to flood the Eastern United States with Irish Sweepstakes tickets that had a sale value of $2,000,000. They were arrested last October by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who had been watching transatlantic passenger planes for eighteen months.

A post-season week of performances began at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with Puccini's "Tosca," which had a cast headed by Ljuba Welitch, Paul Schoeffler and Ferruccio Tagliavini. Since the evening's profit of $5,000 went to the Edward Johnson Testimonial Fund, that fund reached a total of more than $51, 000.

LONDON, April 4 (AP)--Two Conservative members of the House of Commons demanded today that Prime Minister Attlee "intensify the purge of Communists" and sympathizers from the Government and teaching profession.

TOKYO, March 31--Japanese war prisoners still held in Communist China fear that they will be pressed into service to assist in prospective attacks on the Nationalist strongholds in Hainan Island and Formosa, it has become known here.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Formation of a nonpartisan commission to makes "a completely impartial" study of the whole problem of Federal spending was urged here tonight by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, at a dinner in connection with the annual meeting of the American Retail Federation.
GENEVA, April 4--The United Nations Trusteeship Council gave final approval to a statute for an internationalized Jerusalem today and ended its sixth session immediately thereafter.

NEW DELHI, India, April 4-- The key problem of how to establish an efficient machinery to imelement the agreements on fair treatment of minorities occupied the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan today in their conference on issues between the two countries.

ROME, April 4--Deputy Premier Mehmet Shehu of Albania was reported today by Albanian exiles here to have shot and killed during a meeting a state official who had charged that Russia was abandoning Albania.

TOKYO, April 4--The post-war governments of Southeast Asia have a "very good chance" of checking the spread of communism in that area with small assistance from the United States and a "little more realistic attitude" on their own part; Vice Admiral Russell Berkey, commander of the United States Seventh Fleet, said today.

Principal leaders of the Democratic party in the state, in control of a majority of the delegations scheduled to be sent to the party's convention this fall, appeared yesterday to be in agreement that the state ticket must present candidates of the New Deal, Fair Deal stripe.
Timed for the holiday season, an exhibition entitled "Out of the East," showing the riches in ritual art wrought through the ages, will open today at the Brooklyn Museum.
HONOLULU, April 4--Hawaii opened its "forty-ninth state" constitutional convention here today with the flowers and music attendant on politics in these islands.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 4--Final facts and figures compiled by the United Nations on manufacturing and mining production throughout the world during 1949 showed today that global output was 4 per cent higher than the previous year and 40 per cent above the pivotal pre-war year of 1937.

Once again reports are coming out of Albania of purges, plots, assassination and discontent. This is Soviet Russia's only remaining foothold in the Mediterranean and it means much to keep her as a satellite.

A police plane is scheduled to take off from Floyd Bennett Field at 6 o'clock this morning on the second attempt of city experts to produce rain over the Catskill watersheds by seeding clouds with dry ice.

The forward movement on the stock market ran into some opposition yesterday, but only after prices almost had matched the year's highs.

WASHINGTON, April 4-The United States is reducing its diplomatic staffs in all Eastern European countries and otherwise reviewing all personnel policies in that part of the world. A drastic cut has been wordered by the State Department in Hungary and Rumania and lesser but still severe reductions in Poland and Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- Judge Edward A. Tamm refused in United States District Court today to prevent Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods from allowing a new rent control law in New York State to supersede Federal control.

National Girl Scout headquarters at 155 East Forty-fourth Street took on an international flavor yesterday as the office staff played host to Mrs. Mollie Home of London, director of the World Bureau of the World Association of Girl Guides and Girl Scouts, and Mme. Carmen Durocher, head of the Girl Guides in Haiti.

A paint contracting company, its president and a painters' union official were found guilty last night of defrauding the city of $150,000 in the redecoration of city-owned buildings.
"A large segment" of the lumber industry, which is now enjoying a booming business, "will again find itself wondering whether it is making a profit or not" in sixty to ninety days.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 4-- Edward Christiansen knows the face of death too well. Twice in the last two years he has seen it staring through the window of his diver's helmet as he lay helplessly trapped in darkness beneath the surface.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5-- Attorneys for Harry R. Bridges, fighting a criminal conviction, laid plans today to make a long argument for a new trial on Monday when the longshore leader faces Federal Judge George B. Harris for sentencing.

John Foster Dulles, a trustee of the Rockefeller Foundation since 1935, was elected chairman of the board yesterday, succeeding Walter W. Stewart, chairman since 1943, who will continue as a trustee until the end of the year.

Education's most urgent mission is to provide an intellectual bulwark against the spread of communism, Governor Dewey declared here yesterday at a ceremony marking the incorporation of the Long Island College of Medicine with the State University of New York.

The stock market made another attempt yesterday to reach the 1950 high marks and came within 0.30 point of this objective. The high selectivity of trading and narrow movements in the steels were blamed for the list's inability to go through the figure set last month.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation had a consolidated net income last year of $54,073,338 after deducting $5,000,000 for non-recurring writeoffs and possible losses in foreign exploratory operations, according to the annual report for 1949, issued today.
A study of water conservation through land management in the watersheds was begun yesterday by Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, and some of his engineering aides.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP)--The National Collegiate Athletic Association decided today to double the size of its post-season basketball tournament, the final round of which will probably be played elsewhere than Madison Square Garden.

While most railroads interested in the purchase of freight cars are considering the plan of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, the consensus seems to be that the plan mast be revamped considerably before it will be a popular medium for the purchase of new equipment.

Anybody who is handy with scissors and pastepot can turn plain furniture into things of beauty and make pictures and decorative accessories to dress up the home. The trick is in applying the art of decoupage, or paper cut-outs.

The special checking account with the flat rate charge of 10 cents a check has now been totally eliminated by the larger New York banks. Yesterday it was learned that Bankers Trust Company, last of the big banks to operate such accounts without an extra "maintenance" charge, has informed its customers that beginning on May 1 an additional fee of 25 cents a month will be imposed.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The highest official in the loyalty program swore today that 10,000 full field investigations in three years of screening had produced "not one single case" of espionage anywhere in the Federal Government's ranks.

The season's second performance of Wagner's "Parsifal" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, presented Charles Kullman in the title role and Rose Bampton as Kundry as the only changes from the previous cast.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., April 5 (AP)--The Cubs defeated the Browns today, 22 to 12, in a freehitting game sprinkled with nine home runs.
Loft and office buildings in downtown Manhattan passed to new control in deals reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5-- Motion-picture producers who directly supervise the making of films are organizing a guild of their own. Thirty-five of them met in Beverly Hills last night and took the first step in this direction.

Taking note of many warnings that growing Soviet pressure threatens to precipitate a new crisis in Europe which can be met successfully only by the earliest possible unification of Western Europe, with Germany as a partner, Secretary Acheson declared yesterday that the United States favors immediate steps toward that end.

Two designers and an architect, au identified with modern designs for the home, surprisingly undertook yesterday to resolve the question, "What Is Wrong With Modern?" The discussions took place at the closing session of the annual conference of the American Institute of Decorators at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BONN, Germany, April 5--Because he could not establish residence in Washington and assume a practical position as a sort of ambassador, Dr. Hana SchlangeSchoeningen will not go to the United States but to London as Germany's first foreign representative abroad, reliable sources said tonight.

That terror-inspiring figure revealed by the rear-vision mirror, the rapidly approaching motorcycle "cop," has become the subject of unusual study by the boss of the mobile police in New York, Deputy Inspector Francis X. Murphy.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 2 points lower to 7 points higher than on Tuesday. Fluctuations were within a 10point range for the active months.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5--Although several P.G.A. policies may be formulated here within the next few days, the chief concern of the golfing clan gathered tonight is: "Who will win the Masters?"
For most people, 1947 may not have been a particularly significant year, but one group--connoisseurs of white wine--describe it with reverence as "very great."

Barnard College's board of trustees voted last night to raise the yearly tuition $100, from the present $700, beginning next semester. Dean Millicent C. McIntosh had suggested the increase to help balance the budget.

James Marshall, senior member of the Board of Education, charged yesterday that the recent appointment of Morris Warschauer as secretary of the board was a "political deal," involving Mayor O'Dwyer and two Democratic county leaders. He identified the two as Edward J. Flynn of the Bronx and James A. Roe of Queens.

Two television networks will cover a Washington hearing this morning when Prof. Owen Lattimore, consultant on Far Eastern affairs, testifies before a Senate subcommittee on the accusation of being "the top Soviet agent" in the United States, a charge made by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, House minority leader, presented what he called "a nonpartisan prosperity program" during debate today one the $29,000,000,000 omnibus appropriations bill.

TRENTON, April 5--Spencer Miller Jr., New Jersey Highway Commissioner since 1942 and recognized as a leader in engineering and education, announced today his acceptance of the presidency of the American International College at Springfield, Mass.

Contestants already have been entered but spectators will be welcome at the annual egg-rolling contest scheduled for 2 P.M. on Saturday at the Great Lawn in Central Park. With the aid of spoons, boys and girls will guide their brightly colored eggs down courses ranging from 20 to 40 yards.

The big show, respendent with young men and women in spangled costume on swinging trapeze and high wire, dancing elephants, clowns, aerial ballets, prancing horses in shiny coats, came back to Madison Square Garden last night.
Psychoanalysis can help human beings to find solutions toward world order and peace, Dr. Harold Kelman, president of the American Institute for Psychoanalysis, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The Senate subcommittee on labormanagement relations today adopted rules of fair practices for its hearings. They provide a measure of protection for persons whose reputations may be injured by testimony.

For the first time since before World War II, prices of rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange advanced yesterday the daily permissible limit of 200 points, or 2 cents a pound. A tight supply situation, attributed to increased consumption and decreased production of the commodity, is responsible for the upturn, according to trade reports.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 5-- President Truman was pondering tonight whether to veto or approve the controversial natural gas bill after receiving a strong telegram urging him to kill it from the Mayors of eighteen major cities.

Spanish and Portuguese wine production centers are now in a position to meek all requirements of the American market and are fully recovered from war shortages, Major Patrick W. Sandeman, head of the company which produces Sandeman ports and sherries, disclosed yesterday.

Samuel J. Decker of National Laundry Company, Washington, D.C., and Harry Lupka, attorney, were elected directors of Consolidated Laundries Corporation at the annual meeting here yesterday. They succeed Louis Gordon and Charles Maslow, who declined renomination.

A two-alarm fire last night burned out most of the interior of Charles Butler Hall, a two-story physics laboratory on the campus of New York University at 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx.
The municipal transit lines incurred an operating loss of $2,065,623 for the eight months ended Feb. 28, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.
SAIGON, Indo-China, April 5-- Analysts of the Indo-China situation see the next year as crucial in determining the ultimate fate of the new French-sponsored state of Viet Nam.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Secretary of State Dean Acheson reported today a considerable improvement in United States-Argentine relations as officials of both Governments pressed for a solution of mutual trade and economic problems.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Senate and House manages, after nearly twelve hours of almost continuous contest, agreed tonight on all provisions of the already compromised Administration program for providing housing for families of low and moderate incomes.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 29:

PARIS, April 5--Dr. Frederic Joliot-Curie, French High Commissioner for Atomic Energy, told the national congress of the Communiat party in suburban Gennevilliera today that "a true progressive scientist" would never give a scrap of his knowledge for war against the Soviet Union.
ELMIRA, N.Y., April 5 (AP)--Alexander D. Falck, former president of the Corning Glass Works, died last night. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The Federal Trade Commission today criticized advertising claims of major cigarette companies and issued "cease and desist" orders against the makers of Camels and of Old Golds for alleged "false and misleading" advertising. In preparation were similar orders against the makers of Lucky Strike cigarettes and of Philip Morris brands.

PEACE DALE, R.I., April 5-- Wallace Campbell, long active in tho Solvay Process Company and closely identified with other chemical firms, died yesterday aboard the Ile de France at Le Havre. Members of his family here have been notified. His age was 71.
Manhattan apartment landlords rejected completely yesterday a program of wage, hour and working condition demands made by Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, A.F. of L.

HOUSTON, April 5--With a rookie, Catcher Sam Calderone, supplying the offensive power, Larry Jansen entertained 9,673 fans--largest crowd to see the Giants in action this spring--with a nine-inning, four-hit pitching performance that downed the Indians, 8--2.
DETROIT, April. 5--The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., today virtually accepted the Chrysler Corporation's offer of last week to set up a fund to assure $100 monthly pensions.
NEW DELHI, India, April 5--Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, and Liaquat Ali Khan, Prime Minister of Pakistan, came to an agreement today on what an informed ...

Shipments of cold-rolled steel sheets, used mainly in automobiles, refrigerators and other consumer goods, wet a larger in 1949 than the tonnage of any other single product of the steel industry the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ALBANY, April 5--Strong protests have been filed with Governor Dewey by New York, Buffalo and other cities against two bills concerning assessments left with him by the Legislature. The objettors assert that the measures were apparently designed to encourage taxpayers to contest real estate assessments in the courts.

World-wide knowledge of the atomic bomb has made possible the elimination of aggressive war "in our generation," it was declared yesterday by Dr. Robert A. Millikan, dean of American physicists. The peace-loving nations, he said, can achieve this age-old goal through collective security in spite of Russian opposition.

A second financial settlement was completed yesterday in the case of Evelyn Frehe of 2555 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, who became a cripple after a traffic accident Sept. 14, 1934, when she was 18 months old.
A contract between Roosevelt Hospital and the State Department of Mental Health was signed yesterday, marking the start of a pilot program for treating psychiatric patients at the hospital.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 5--Nine of the ten high-ranking members of Roman Catholic orders today were found guilty of attempting to overthrow Czechoslovakia's "people's democratic" re gime and drew sentences varying from nine years to life imprisonment.

LAKE SUCCESS, April 4--With new medical skills learned from United Nations field workers, a 57-year-old Chinese woman is trying to introduce sterile and safe obstetrical methods in a remote village, in Communist-controlled China.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 5 --Gustave E. Walter of 50 Lake Road, Rye, retired New York designer and manufacturer of ornamental sculpture for large public buildings, hotels and homes, died here today in United Hospital at the age of 89.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Management groups today urged rejection of President Truman's plan to abolish the independent office of General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board. The proposal would transfer the General Counsel's functions to the board.

NEW ORLEANS, April 5 (UP)-- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, held out hopes today that his organization might merge with this country's other major labor organization, the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A 50 per cent share of television and radio receipts for mainevent fighters was demanded unanimously by the members of the Boxing Managers Guild of New York yesterday at a meeting at the guild's headquarters.

TAIPEI, Formosa, April 5--The Nationalists today asserted Russia was pouring planes and pilots into Communist China and ordered the charges laid before the United Nations. The Nationalists will renew a request that the United Nations send observers to China.
HONOLULU, April (UP)--The Navy's giant seaplane Marshall Mars, the largest flying boat in the world, crash-landed at sea off Oahu Island today, then exploded and burned.

The 46 West Ninety-fifth Street Corporation, Joshuah Sidney Shultz, president, sold the nine-story apartment house for thirty-eight families at that address to an investing client of Norman Kemper, attorney, for cash over mortgages amounting to $155,000. Harold M. Silverman and the Rowley Realty Management Corporation were the brokers in the sale of the property, which is 55 by 100 feet and is assessed at $235,000.

Fashions by a creative designer usually disclose the signature of the maker in the line and silhouette of each costume. The clothes seen yesterday on the runway of the Sert Room in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel illustrated this point. They were distinctly by Claire McCardell.

PARIS, April 5--Communist-led demongtraters numbering about 1,500 clashed with helmeted police early this evening up and down the broad Avenue des ChampsElysees and its side streets in the center of Paris.

Eggs come to Easter breakfast hidden within hot, delicious, brioche-like rolls and if children are present, in hard-cooked form in the traditional tints. Something to interest old and young and to fortify both against the exertions of the Easter Parade.
The casualty rate among the city's 7,000 census-takers has been surprisingly small, it was reported yesterday.

Moscow, April 5--Soviet cartoonists are rapidly making the bristling mustache and eyebrows of United States Secretary Of State Dean Acheson one of best known subjects of caricature in their repertoire.

MOSCOW, April 5--The Soviet foreign affairs journal New Times declared today that settlement of the Soviet-American problem was a "cardinal problem from the point of view of securing a stable peace" and said that a number of American business men realized that national American interests "require peaceful collaboration with the Soviet Union."

DETROIT, April 5 (AP)--The increasingly confident Detroit Red Wings called up three players from their Omaha farm club today as they got set to renew their Stanley Cup semi-final series with the Toronto Maple Leafs here tomorrow night.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 5-- Twenty-two puppy bird dogs displayed hunting style despite intermittent showers and brisk winds today at the opening of the English Setter Club of America's forty-eighth annual spring field trials over the club's course. Pointers took the first three in the open puppy stage, first of four on the five-day program.

A major long-term uptrend of metalworking in New York is receiving a boost by the establishment of a record-size tool manufacturing plant here, it was revealed yesterday by Clarence Avildsen, chairman of the board of Avildsen Tools and Machines, Inc.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1949 net consolidated earnings of $100,877,041 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $8.89 each on the 11,345,250 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $153,539,299, or $13.53 a share, in 1948. Revenues from sales of products and other operations amounted to $969,502,768, against $1,068,876,539.

CHICAGO, April 5--Continued dry weather in the Southwestern winter wheat belt had little lasting effect as a price-making influence on the Board of Trade, the new crop deliveries reacting after an early upturn and closing 1/8 to cent lower. May, however, acted tight and gained 5/8 cent.

In a quick turnover of a Bronx property, David S. Meister, operator, yesterday resold the twostory business building on plot 44 by 100 feet at 471-75 East Tremont Avenue, northeast corner of Washington Avenue, to a syndicate of investors. Assessed at $110,000, the building contains seven stores and offices and rents for about $15,000 a year.

THE game of golf undoubtedly was invented by Satan because it is the most tantalizing and frustrating sport of them all. With rare exceptions, a fellow never gets to learn all its intricacies and mysteries until he is so old that he has lost the youthful resiliency he needs to exploit them.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The policies of the Arab League are bound to cause disastrous results to peace and stability in the Middle East, Eliahu Elath, Ambassador from Israel, told Secretary of State Dean Acheson today.
DALLAS, April 5--Big Don Newcombe had another outing today, pitching seven innings. While he was hit hard in one frame, he emerged the victor, 10--6, because the Dodgers outhit the Dallas Eagles.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Kirkland Weeks of 1088 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Sewall Boardman, to John Cullen Weadock, son of Mrs. Bernard Weadock of Greenwich, Conn., and New York, and the late Mr. Weadock. Miss Weeks attended the Spence School, was graduated in June, 1949, from the Oldfields School, Glencoe, Md., and is attending the Barmore School.

WASHINGTON, April 5--A funeral service was held today fox Dr. Charles Richard Drew, Negro scientist, one of the developers of blood plasma, who headed the wartime blood plasma program for British and United States armed forces.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, April 5 (AP)-- Robert E. Bednasek was acquitted today of the charge he murdered Margaret Anne Jackson, 20 years old, because she did not love him any more.

New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will receive bids April 12 on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $21,370,000 for the financing of two state-aid projects, the Bronx River Houses, the Bronx, and the Albany Houses, Brooklyn, the notes will be dated May 10 and will come due Nov. 10.

"There's the Derby winner!" That's what many of the 19,834 customers at chilly, rainy Jamaica were saying yesterday after Christopher T. Chenery's Virginia-bred Hill Prince had made up a dozen lengths on the turn and through the stretch to score a smashing, going-away victory in the $21,400 Experimental Free Handicap No. 1 for 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, April 5--An open hearing on the school construction bill today was enlivened by a woman witness taking issue with both the subcommittee chairman and the chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee who came in as a visitor.

The Argentine State Line may soon make a bid for the New YorkBuenos Aires passenger traffic that has been served almost exclusively since the war by the MooreMcCormack Lines Good Neighbor fleet, it was learned here yesterday.
The International Paper Company last year achieved the second largest sales and the third largest earnings in its fifty-twoyear history, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Factory sales or Philco Corporation's room air conditioners last week were four times those of the corresponding week of last year, John Otter, general sales manager, reported yesterday. He said the increase is the largest for any week so far this year. Dealers report they are placing heavier orders than last year.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Eastern Utilities Associates Boston holding company, was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission "to terminate its existence and distribute its assets to its security holders pursuant to a fair and equitable plan to be filed with and approved by the commission." The decision was made under the Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Trus tees of the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund announced today they had taken action that "paves the way for the reactivation" of pensions and other benefits suspended last September.

Action to lift a ban that had threatened to put scores of blind and other handicapped newsdealers out of business was forecast yesterday by City Councilman Charles E. Keegan, Democrat of the Bronx. Negotiations between dock loaders and the Motor Carrier Association of New York covering rates and services to truckmen on the city's piers, which had all but leached an impasse, will be renewed Tuesday as the result of an agreement announced yesterday between the association and the International Longshoremen's Union, A.F.L.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The Guatemalan Government has asked for the recall of United States Ambassador Richard C. Patterson Jr., informed quarters said today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 5-- Harold Williams Sanford, editor of The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle since 1937, died early today in his home here. He was 60 years old.

MANILA, April 5--The United States Air Forces base at Clark Field in Pampanga province in Huk territory reported today that security measures had been taken against Huk raids but would neither confirm nor deny that raids had been attempted to obtain ammunition.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)-- Marshall Plan countries bought 5,700,000 bales of American cotton--about a quarter of the nation's output--during the first two years of the European Recovery Program, the Economic Cooperation Administration reported today.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 5 --The Navy is building an experimental ship that may revolutionize warship propulsion overnight, Rear Admiral David H. Clark, chief of the Bureau of Ships, asserted today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 5--United States Ambassador George V. Allen is planning to fly to Rome on Monday to discuss with Ambassador James C. Dunn these the crisis in YugoslavItalian relations that has been developing over the question of Trieste.

The newly-formed Tea council, representing the American tea trade and producers in sterlingarea countries, will begin an advertising campaign on May 29 with a budget of more than $1,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

The Waterman Line freighter Hurricane remained aground off Fire Island last night. High winds and heavy seas hampered efforts to place heavy salvage rigging aboard preparatory to pulling the vessel off a sand bar.

Manufacturers of desirable bedroom furniture yesterday reported an upsurge in retail orders in the last few days which may bear out earlier predictions of a record first half.
Further barriers to free, objective news coverage were erected in many countries in the last year, The Associated Press management said yesterday.

DETROIT, April 7--It was learned authoritatively tonight that Chrysler Corporation had made a new offer to settle its pension dispute with the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., and that the offer was being discussed in a bargaining session.

A total of 250 non-medical per sonnel employed in three Veterans Administration offices here serving 2,500,000 veterans in the state were dismissed yesterday in accordance with the economy order issued from Washington by Carl R. Gray Jr., Veterans Administrator.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 7 (AP)--Ricardo Balbiers, champion of Chile, today upset fourth-seeded Seymour Greenberg of Chicago to move into the semi-finals of the second Good Neighbor tennis championships.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 7 (AP)-- The Mexican Baseball League won, lost and broke even today in rulings on its protests that U.S. minor loops were raiding south of the border rosters.

Every New York angler worthy of the name is stamping his feet on the bank of a lake or shivering with cold in a stream this morning, so we can forget all about local fishing and move to areas where the anglers are still impatiently waiting.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 7 --Imprints from the primordial world of molecules, where all life begins beyond the ken of man, glowed for an instant on the cold and unblinking eye of an electronic tube in the physics laboratory of Pennsylvania State College here tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 7--Mrs. Perle Mesta, United States Minister to Luxembourg, declined today to forecast a lifetime of diplomacy for herself but did say she looked forward to returning to her post in the little European duchy.

The top leadership of the Textile Workers Union, C.I.O., has been rent by a critical split that is causing serious concern to officials of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, it was learned yesterday.

Flowers in pots, boxes and crates have been converging all week on the wholesale floral market in this city. The final count will be the largest so far this year. New shipments will be received until late today to supply the lastminute demand for Easter cut flowers and corsages.
ATLANTA, April 8--Greatly increased demands for Easter apparel and accessories sent department store trade in the Southwest last week to the year's highest levels.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 8-- Huntington's Union School District No. 3, which includes the Senior and Junior High Schools and five elementary schools, will have a new elementary school building to cost not more than $1,100,000 provided the taxpayers approve the proposition at a special meeting on May 18.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., April 8--The engagement of Miss Nancy Lathrop Stephens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Stephens, to Wallace Hunter Kirkpatrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Kirkpatrick of Pittsburgh, has been announced by her parents. The wedding has been planned for June.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 8 --Pointers gained all three places today in the open derby--third of the four stakes on the program-- as the forty-eighth annual field trials of the English Setter Club of America neared conclusion.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8--Retail business activity in the Twelfth District showed slight to moderate increases during the week. Portland was the only area reporting a loss, while Salt Lake City held even with a year ago.

Beginning on April 18 and running through May, beginners' classes in Hebrew will be held in the Jewish Community House of Bensonhurst, 7802 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, under its adult Jewish cultural program, it was announced yesterday.
RICHMOND, April 8--Shoppers in the Fifth District were out in mass this week and improvement in Easter apparel sales was marked.
CLEVELAND, April 8--A seasonal drop was noted in business activity here last week. However, most indicators continued to show gains well above year-ago figures.

A one-story factory building in Ardsley, N.Y., was bought by the Alexander Smith Carpet Company of Yonkers from the Indiana Steel Company. The property was held at $250,000. Chauncey B. Griffen of White Plains and Brett, Wyckoff, Potter Hamilton, Inc., were co-brokers in the sale.
CAIRO, April 8 (Reuters)--The Arab League Council decided tonight to ban supplies for ships going to Israel, as part of a reinforcement of its economic blockade of the new state.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 8-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bruce Carr Jr. of the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Chandler, to Richard Doane Grinnell of Larchmont, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Grinnell of Charlottesville, Va. The wedding will take place in the summer.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 8--Western German acceptance of the invitation, to join the Council of Europe is regarded here as a prerequisite to progress on the solution of some of this country's problems when the Big Three Western Foreign Ministers meet in London next month.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 8--Lewis A. Jarvis of 155 East Seventy-second Street, New York, and Grand Rapids, announced the engagement of his daughter, Ruth Ann, to James Stuart Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard E. Smith of 270 Park Avenue, New York, last night at a dinner dance in the Blythefield Country Club here.

Wednesday's "crack-down" by the Federal Trade Commission against cigarette advertising that it first had declared false and misleading more than seven years ago inspired pungent comment in the advertising community.

Pre-Easter accessory volume made a better showing percentagewise than did the apparel departments and last-minute rush orders were plentiful, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buying office.

KANSAS CITY, April 8--Civic leaders today started a drive to force an all-out Federal investigation of the Binaggio killings as a national scandal, in spite of the political effects it might have on the Truman Administration.

NEW ORLEANS, April 8--Still rankled over the surprising upset they suffered at the hands of the Birmingham Barons yesterday, the Yankees served notice on the minor league universe today that the world champions are not having any more of it.

Arturo Toscanini's performance of the last three scenes of Verdi's "Falstaff," with the N.B.C. Orchestra, the Robert Shaw Chorale and ten distinguished soloists, was the glorious conclusion of his season's series for the radio audience of the nation.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- The Economic Cooperation Administration said today that it would stop paying shipping costs on American gift packages to Britain, Germany, the Netherlands and France after July 1.

A neighborhood X-ray survey and blood test program will be head by the Chelsea-Clinton Health Council, in cooperation with the Health Department, on Thursday and Friday from 3 to 8 P.M. at Hartley House, 413 West Fortysixth Street, it was announced yesterday.

Behind the three-hit pitching of veteran Bob Mueller, Queens College opened its season yesterday with a 6-3 triumph over St. Francis. Jim Odrich paced the winners with a triple in the first inning that drove in a pair of tallies and then batted in another in the fifth.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (U.P.)-- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, said today the committee will open hearings May 15 on a bill to license motion pictures.

Plans to develop an unofficial center for world amity in the projected headquarters building of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace came to light yesterday in connection with release of details of the proposed improvement of its plot on First Avenue facing the United Nations site.

THE day when airline passengers will be whisked from airports to downtown areas of cities by helicopters may not be as far away as is generally believed. Already helicopter designers, builders and operators are working on the problems of handling passengers.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP)--Oats spurted into new high ground while the rest of the market jogged along at an easy pace on the Board of Trade today. All oats deliveries established peaks since trading in the various contracts started.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 8 (AP)--Johnny Longden, American jockey taking his first whirl on Australian tracks, rode four mounts today and finished out of the money on three. He was a second on Derrymore, a 6 to 1 choice in the last race.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- Former Senator Dulles has held his first foreign policy huddle with the State Department on the tough problem of whether to press for an early Japanese peace treaty.

A survey among brokers in suburban areas around New York by Previews, Inc., indicated that sales of larger residential properties this spring probably will top last year's sales by a considerable margin, according to R.M. Stearns, president of the Previews concern.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 8 (AP)--Yugoslavia criticized the recent Bulgarian spy trial of six Yugoslavs and twenty Bulgarian tonight as a "stage-managed affair." A statement issued by the Foreign Affairs Ministry and handed to Bulgarian diplomats here said the trial had been "hostile and harmful to the peace-loving intentions of Yugoslavia."
LONDON, April 8 (Reuters)-- Sunderland displaced Liverpool as the leader in the English football league's championship division today.

A sustained interest in all types of realty in northern New Jersey is noted by J.I. Kislak, Inc., which reported 222 transactions involving residential, investment, mercantile and industrial properties in every community in Hudson County, fifteen towns in Bergen and Passaic Counties and several in Essex and Union Counties.

RANGOON, Burma, April 8 (AP) --The Burmese Army reported intense fighting between Government troops and Karen rebels yesterday in two small towns in the eastern Karen state adjoining Thailand. The report said that the Karens were retreating southward into the coastal area of Tenasserim, killing villagers and looting and burning monasteries.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Wil helm Munthe de Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Ambassador, said today that his Government's signing of the North Atlantic Pact had brought a new feeling of security to the people of the country, despite some initial opposition to participation--especially on the part of Communists.

The Norwegian Hospital Fair will be held Saturday to April 22, at the Kings County Lighting Company, Sixty-seventh Street and Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday. Proceeds will be turned in to the $750,000 building fund of Norwegian Hospital.

HONOLULU, April 8--The extent of communism in Hawaii, long a hotly debated issue in the Territory, will be the subject of an onthe-spot investigation by the UnAmerican Activities Committee of the United States House of Representatives at public hearings opening here Monday at Iolani Palace.

The Western Union Telegraph Company has sold its large warehouse at 5927-45 Southwestern Avenue in Chicago, to Charles B. Benenson, New York realty man, and has taken back a long lease on the property for forty years at a reported aggregate net rental of about $1,500,000.
DETROIT, April 8--John R. Robinson of Chicago, soldier, editor, paper distributing executive and publicist, died yesterday while here on a business trip. His age was 67.

WESTFIELD, N.J., April 8-- Easter services tomorrow in the First Congregational Church here will be the last in the sixty-eightyear-old structure, which is to be replaced by a new edifice, the Rev. J.L. McCorison, the pastor, announced today.

RED BANK, N.J., April 8--A new building with eight modern stores will open this week at 2935 Monmouth Street, Red Bank, on the site of the old Empire Theatre, for many years a downtown Red Bank landmark.
Myron C. Simon and Arthur I. Kraft have sold their six-store taxpayer building at 32-15 Steinway Street, in Astoria, Queens, to Jacob Barasch.
DETROIT, April 8 (AP)--The nation's auto industry is making a concerted drive for the elimination or reduction of Federal excise taxes. Joining in the effort are both manufacturers and retailers.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 8-- It took four ballots to convict Harry R. Bridges of lying to conceal Communist party membership, a jury member disclosed today.

Five years after the end of the war in Europe there are still some 390,000 displaced persons in the camps of the International Refugee Organization or otherwise under its care. There were 1,100,000 when the I.R.O. began operating in 1947, and others have come into the camps since then.

Rushing in where more experienced actors might fear to tread, an extremely ambitious band of budding players at the Master Institute Theatre stubbornly threaded their way last evening, through the maze of plot intricacies and the mass of similitudes that constitute William Congreve's "The Way of the World."

America's "house of labor" has been a house divided since 1936, when John L. Lewis led a secession from the A.F.L. to form the C.I.O. Since then there have been occasional efforts to achieve labor unity. The efforts have failed because of deep-seated rivalries between the two labor bodies.

Nearly 1,200 reservations have been made for the eighth anniversary dinner and dance of the Long Island Home Builders Institute to be held on Saturday at Hotel Statler. James Graham is chairman of the dinner committee. The guests will include Thomas P. Coogan, president of the National Association of Home Builders.

HILLSIDE, N.J., April 8--Plans for the erection of a $300,000 parochial school to accommodate 500 pupils, 200 more than in the present building, were announced today by the Rev. John J. Finnerty, pastor of St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church here.
LONDON, April 8--Vaslav Nijinsky, world famous Russian dancer, died here today at the age of 60, after a brief illness caused by nephritis.

With George Lehman going the distance, Hofstra College annexed its second Metropolitan Conference victory yesterday by routing Brooklyn College, 15--4, at the Flatbush field. The Dutchmen pounded three Kingsmen hurlers for 16 hits with Shortstop Carl Paladino contributing four safeties and batting in four runs.

Construction has been started on a new showroom on Route 4 in Fort Lee, N.J., for Wilson's Marine, distributor in northern New Jersey of Chris-Craft motorboats.

College students learn more about grammar and diction from public speaking than they do from elementary freshman English courses, according to a study conducted by Prof. Louis Hall Swain of North Carolina State College.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 8-- Thailand may be the focus of a future realignment of international relationships on the Southeast Asian peninsula as a consequence of recent and prospective developments in Indo-China.
In a loosely played game that lasted three hours, Fordham lost to Manhattan by 11--5 yesterday at Fordham Field in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference.

AUBURN, Mass., April 8 (AP)-- Three residents of Newark, N.J., were injured, two of them seriously, in a two-car collision here today. Mrs. Lillian Kelly, 45, of 74 South Street, Newark, was taken to Worcester City Hospital with a crushed chest and Eugene Fuer, 59, of 73 South Street, Newark, was taken there with internal injuries. John Fuer, 15, Mr. Fuer's son, received minor injuries.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 8--In an effort to ease parking problems in front of the Elizabeth Postoffice, metered parking will be instituted here, the Board of Public Works announced today. Special meters, restricted to twelve minutes of parking time, will be installed in the vicinity of the Postoffice in the business area of North Broad Street.

MOSCOW, April 8 (AP)--Two strong earthquakes were reported today by the Soviet press to have been registered during the past four days in or near Russian territory. Soviet seismological stations reported one of the quakes was centered in Mongolia and the other quake was centered in the south Asian province of Ashkhabad.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 8 (AP)--The yacht races between the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich, Conn., and the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club were called off today.

The St. John's College Alumni Association will hold its annual reunion and dinner April 19 in DeGray Hall, 75 Lewis Avenue, Brooklyn. The Most Rev. James H. Griffiths, Auxiliary to Cardinal Spellman as Military Vicar of the United States Armed Forces, will speak.

Some rather extraordinarily fluent playing was heard yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, where Iren Marik, a Hungarian pianist, made her local debut. Obviously an experienced recitalist, and undaunted by anything on her program, she took care of the music with complete efficiency and insight.
The transfer of four Liberty-type American tankers to the flag of Mexico has been approved by the Maritime Commission on the application of Gordon Duke, oil operator.

The seventh annual Squadron A Horse Show will be held on Friday and Saturday in the squadron's armory at Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street. In addition to the annual ball held in conjunction with the event, there will be a cocktail party given at the armory by Lieut. Col. Robert Ranlet, president of the Squadron A Association, and a fashion show.
The Long Island University baseball team gained its second victory of the season by defeating Pratt Institute, 9--3, on the Adelphi Academy field yesterday. It was the second loss for Pratt.

With a reception committee of one on hand--a black talking crow named Deacon that mumbled alternately "hello" and "good-by" --the Children's Zoo in the Bronx Zoo was opened officially yesterday for its tenth season.

New ways for applying knowledge about human development to practical situations in education, social group work, parent education and community recreation will be discussed at a workshop in human development and education conducted by the University of Chicago, June 26 to Aug. 4.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8--Touring golf stars won their fight with the P.G.A. tonight for more sayso in operating tournaments. They will remain in the P. G. A.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 8 (Reuters)--Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, upset her teammate, Miss Doris Hart, today in the all-American final of the South African women's singles tennis championship. Miss Fry won, 4--6, 7--5, 6--3.

The Belgian plebiscite on the question of King Leopold's return took place four weeks ago today and resulted in a 57.68 majority for the King. But the royal question is still unresolved and Belgium is still without a government.

MACASSAR, Indonesia, April 8 (AP)--Capt. Andi Abdul Aziz, whose rebel soldiers seized Macassar Tuesday, agreed today to supply food and water to federal troops on ships off the coast.

A youth caravan of thirty students affiliated with the United World Federalists, Inc., joined yesterday the week-long prayer vigil at the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street. Protesting the making of the hydrogen bomb, the vigil will end at 9 A.M. today.
WASHINGTON--About 100,000 foreigners who annually travel through the United States to points beyond will be required to post $500 bonds if a proposed change in immigration rules goes into effect.

In 1934 Johnny Lazia, then the underworld "czar" of Kansas City, Mo., was cut down by gangster bullets. His pallbearers were carefully chosen for their stature in the world of gangdom. One was Charles Gargotta, well-known hoodlum. Another, less notable at the time, was Charles Binaggio.

Three men alleged to be key figures in a large-scale policy bank in Brooklyn were arraigned early today as material witnesses in District Attorney Miles F. McDonald's inquiry into organized gambling in that borough. Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz held them in $25,000 bail each after a midnight hearing in Kings County Court.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Harvey W. Lowen of Jackson Heights, Queens, on Wednesday in the Doctors Hospital here. Mrs. Lowen is the former Miss Janice Feitelberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Feitelberg of Washington. The child will be named Renee Susan.

First prize in a poster contest sponsored by the New York Cancer Committee was won yesterday for the second consecutive year by Nick Amplo of 2958 West First Street, Brooklyn, an 18-year-old senior at Lincoln High School.

Mills Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mills of Williston Park, L.I., in the Garden City Community Church. The Rev. James N. Gettemy performed the ceremony.
