General agreement that the supply of mortgage money has virtually dried up so far as Harlem is concerned, and pleas for new financing policies there on the part of banks and other lending institutions were expressed by brokers and planners yesterday.

HONG KONG, April 8 (U.P.)-- The Peking radio said today that the Chinese Communist Cabinet has ordered all Government agencies and the army to deposit their funds in the central "peoples bank" in a move to fight inflation.

MILWAUKEE, April 8 (AP)-- John J. Ryan, former head football coach at the University of Wisconsin and Marquette University, died last night in St. Mary's Hospital, after an illness of seven months. His age was 62. He had been a member of the Milwaukee board of school directors since 1940, and had been in the insurance business.
PHILADELPHIA, April 8 (AP)-- A Philadelphia lawyer stated today that the Soviet Union had refused an American priest permission to celebrate Easter Sunday mass in Moscow tomorrow.

One fireman was hospitalized and nine others were treated at the scene of a smoky, stubborn fire that was discovered at 10:04 A.M. yesterday at 121 Manhattan Avenue, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Ehrlich of 41 West Seventy-second Street on Wednesday in the LeRoy Sanitarium. Mrs. Ehrlich is the former Miss Phyllis Dettelbach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Dettelbach of Belleville, N.J. The child will be named David Jay.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 8--Dr. and Mrs. Julius Burstein have made known the engagement of their daughter, Harriet, to Theodore R. Jackson, son of the late Dr. Victor J. Jackson.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 8-- Tax rates for eleven Union County municipalities are lower this year, the County Board of Taxation revealed today in its final computation. Realty rates increase in nine Communities of the county.
TEN months of work in drafting revisions of the Building Code's provisions on theatre building came to an end last week and as a result New York may have some new playhouses in a couple of years.
The Jewish Memorial-Hospital, Broadway and 196th Street, had operating costs of more than $1,000,000 in 1949, according to the annual report yesterday.

The "McCarthy inquiry" has been going on for a month before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee composed of three Democrats and two Republicans. The subcommittee has met nine times for a total of thirty hours. It has heard eleven witnesses; it has accumulated 1,030 pages of testimony.
TOKYO, April 8 (AP)--Twelve Japanese newspaper men returned today from a visit to the United States with praise for the "cooperation between the American public and its press."

BERLIN. THE ice on the lakes has gone, the new grass sprouts in the rubble, the sun filters through the shattered buildings onto the long avenues. Spring has come to Berlin and with it, crisis, the inevitable companion.

KANSAS CITY, April 8--A Puerto Rican mechanic who bilked a Wichita, Kan., fight crowd by using the name of topflight boxer Tuzo (Kid) Portuguez of Costa Rica, asserted today he had told "the promoters" all about it before the fight.

ALBANY--The growing popularity of the canoe tour through the Fulton chain of lakes from Old Forge to Tupper or Saranac Lake has induced the State Conservation Department to buy a 4.3-acre island in the middle of Fourth Lake for additional overnight camping facilities.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 8-- Unexplained "trivial difficulties" prevented Premier-designate Paul van Zeeland from annoucing today the composition of the new Belgian Government, which, he said last night, was "in my pocket."

Alexander C. Geddes, managing director of Associated British Oil Engines, Ltd., London, will deliver the keynote address at the first convention of the company's American distributors and dealers, it was announced yesterday.

Chedzoy, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Chedzoy of Scunthorpe, Lincolnshire, England. The child will be named Christopher Charles.

MARTINEZ, Calif., April 8 (U.P.) --Reports that 9-year-old William Thornton White 3d would inherit a $9,000,000 estate from his grandmother were described today by the boy's father as "a lot of baloney." He estimated that his son would receive only about $40,000 from the estate of Mrs. Katherine Brown Irvine, widow of James Irvine, California and Montana landowner.

Merchandising methods used in marketing "off-the-shelf" items are now being adapted to mass produced steel swimming pools for the first time, it was disclosed yesterday by Andrew Jensen Jr., general manager of Koven Steel Swimming Pool, Inc., Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, April 8--In as unusual case, the National Labor Relations Board today ordered a company to restore the forty-fivehour week it had cut to forty hours and to pay its employes the overtime they lost.
Eight members of the Polish Political Council now residing in the United States have formed a working committee with headquarters in New York, it was announced yesterday.

Profiting by past experience of builders who failed to plan adequately for steady expansion of patronage and population around business areas, the sponsors of new shopping centers now going up in many parts of the New York district are planning adequate parking and other facilities.

TORRINGTON, Conn., April 8 (AP)--John F. Williams, football coach at Torrington High School shortly before and during the first World War, died in a hospital here today while a funeral service was being held for his wife, Frances, who died on Thursday.

Colonel Robert R. Raymond Jr. has purchased from Charles R. Comben a new six-room house with five acres and a swimming pool in Washington, Conn., through James E. Curry, broker, who also reported the sale to Mr. Comben of the Burton B. Kinney homestead in New Milford, consisting of ten acres with a century-old saltbox type home.

WASHINGTON, April 8--A fourrun outburst in the sixth inning today enabled the Georgetown baseball team to defeat Princeton, 6--2. Right-hander Frank Mattingly went the route for the Hoyas, limiting the Tigers to seven safeties.

IT used to be that scientists stayed pretty close to their laboratories. Politics in particular they regarded as not within their province. But nowadays hardly a week goes by in which some individual scientist, or a group of scientists, fails to issue a statement on some important question of domestic or foreign policy.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8-- Jimmy Demaret's taste has run to pinks during the Masters golf tournament, but what he will wear tomorrow in the Easter parade final is something only known to Jimmy.

A campaign to raise $10,000,000 to establish the Japan International Christian University begins today and will run through May 28, it was announced yesterday. The movement to set up a Christian university in Japan was begun more than fifty years ago, but the first concrete steps were taken last year.

WASHINGTON, April 8--Mrs. Edward Chambers Betts has announced the engagement of her daughter, Matilda, to William Franklin Radcliff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Radcliff of Fredericksburg, Ind. The wedding will take place in the summer.

Natural gas, found largely in the Southwest, is mined either alone or as a by-product of petroleum. Oil miners used to burn the gas off when they found any because they had no way to transport it. But as pipelines were built, the use of natural gas in industry and homes increased sharply.

The mystery of the "flying saucers" was accorded renewed attention last week, this time even by President Truman himself. The President said he was just as puzzled as the next fellow by the latest flurry of reports about weird and wonderful sights in the sky.

Prices of stocks rose selectively during yesterday's short session on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at new high levels for the current movement. Motor, chemical and television issues paced the advance in the heaviest two-hour-session since mid-January.

As the Easter week-end began last Friday, Capitol Hill was crowded-- but not with Congressmen. Tourists and youngsters on vacation toured the halls of Congress while Representatives and Senators went off on their own Easter holiday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)--A Congressional study of a universal, pay-as-you-go pension system was advocated today by Senator Robert A. Taft.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- Harold Christoffel, former Milwaukee labor leader, was released from jail on $10,000 bond today pending his appeal on a perjury conviction. The Civil Rights Congress of New York posted $10,000 in Treasury bonds for his release.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8-- The conviction of Harry R. Bridges at the end of his four-and-onehalf-month trial for perjury and conspiracy posed questions this week for the leadership and the rank and file of his 65,000-member union.

CRANFORD, N.J., April 8-- The engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William C. McPherson of their daughter, Jean, to Robert E. Sollmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl P. Sollmann of Cedar Ridge Farm, Far Hills, formerly of Montclair.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP)--Hugh C. Willett, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, came out today in favor of "flexible" changes in the "sanity" code --a document which if sternly enforced could split American college ranks.

BOSTON, April 8 (AP)--Telephone girls who served in World War I are lining up to support four Congressional bills that would give them Army discharges and military status similar to World War II Wacs.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 8 (AP)-- Jack E. Harper of Australia won the singles title in Israel's International Open Tennis tournament today by defeating H. Weiss of Argentina, 6--3, 6--1, 8--6. Maria Weiss of Argentina took the women's singles crown, beating Gertrude Kornfeld of Israel, 6--2, 6--3.

MANCHESTER, N.H., April 8 (U.P.)--The three-man board of censors of the Hillsborough County Medical Society met secretly today to consider the case of Dr. HerMann N. Sander, who was acquitted last month of a murder charge in the death of a woman cancer patient.

Kleid. David P. Applebaum was the broker. Milton Landis represented the sellers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Unhappiness in children is a momentary thing, usually brought about from sources outside the child, it was agreed yesterday by a panel of six junior high school students and an audience of their classmates.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 8-- Army outlasted Wesleyan, 14 to 9, in a loosely played baseball game on Doubleday Field today.

CHICAGO, April 8--Easter trade activity increased substantially toward the end of the week, but merchants basing their opinions on estimates of total volume were uncertain about the ability of trade to offset the decline from a year ago, registered early in the period.

FROM England comes a book which sturdily refuses to be typed. It is prose and poetry, non-fiction and fiction of the most beguiling sort. It is not, as the title might mislead one to suppose, a handy guide for camp counselors on rainy days, though if they used it they might find it indispensable.

A major research project designed to help create a better economic understanding between American industry, its employes and plant communities, has been started at Boston University, it was announced yesterday by Daniel L. Marsh, president of the university.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 8-- President Truman accepted today the resignation of the Under Secretary of Agriculture, Albert J. Loveland, and thus the die was cast for the Administration's drive to defeat Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, in his campaign for re-election this year.

IN the summer of 1941, Dr. (now Sir) Howard Florey, an Australian-born pathologist, visited the United States from his laboratory at Oxford. In the previous year he and his colleagues had found that extracts obtain from a fungus and called penicillin had the power to cure certain otherwise fatal infections both in laboratory animals and humans.

The ratio of United States paper production to mill capacity was 104.1 per cent in the week ended on April 1, compared with 103.5 per cent (revised) in the preceding week and 87.2 per cent in the comparable week of last year, the American Paper and Pulp Association reported yesterday.

Birge, retired vice president of the General Electric Company who had supervised operations of affiliated manufacturing companies, died here in his home today, after a brief illness, at the age of 72. He retired in 1944 after more than forty-four years with General Electric.

THIS is nesting--or migrating--time for the great host of North America's wild birds. Most of the approximately 768 species continue to thrive, but a few have become so rare that ornithologists count them every year virtually as individuals, and note their hatchings as carefully as so many royal births. CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 8 (AP)--Bob Huff stole home in the eleventh inning today to give Virginia a thrilling 1-0 victory over Rensselaer Poly. With one down, Huff doubled, went to third on an infield out, and then streaked for home. He was safe on an extremely close call at the plate.

LILIES and orange blossoms form part of the annual Easter display at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park this week. However, a Chinese shrub (Pittosporum tobira) steals the show with its clusters of white, fragrant blossoms that almost hide the dark, glossy leaves.

Farrahy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Farrahy of Yonkers, N.Y. The wedding will take place at the Post Chapel here in the summer.

IN his brief foreword Julian Green tells how he recently met Francois Mauriac, the Roman Catholic novelist, in Paris and told him that he was finishing a translation of Peguy into English. "What a pity someone doesn't try to translate him into French," Mauriac exclaimed. Though he declares it is unfair, Mr. Green says every reader of Peguy will understand why Mauriac made the remark.

CATANIA, Sicily, April 8 (AP)-- A sharp earth shock damaged many buildings in the Catania area today. Only one person was reported injured, but at least twenty families were left homeless. Streets and highways were cracked.

Immediately after India was partitioned on Aug. 15, 1947, there took place the greatest mass migration in history. The rains of April have a different feel from the rains of March. They are not warm rains, really, but they are no longer the icy rains that threaten momentarily to turn to snow or sleet. The rains of April soak the hillsides and swell the streams, but most of all they strengthen the root and encourage the bud. The high-hung bud in particular.

High Moor, dean of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Cathedral, and Mrs. Moor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Ann, to Robert Howard Bidwell, son of Mrs. Howard F. Bidwell of New York and the late Mr. Bidwell. Plans have been made for a summer wedding.

PARIS, April 8--Baron Philippe de Rothschild, owner of the wellknown Bordeaux vineyards of Mouton Rothschild, sailed yesterday on the Ile de France for New York. He will make what he called "a gastronomical tour" of the United States on behalf of the Bordeaux wine industry. He will visit New York, Boston, Washington, New Orleans, Dallas and Los Angeles in addition to the California vineyards.

ALBANY, April 8 (AP)--Governor Dewey today proclaimed April 8-15 "Pan American Week" in New York State. The Pan American Union also has set the week "for a public demonstration of the solidarity of the free republics of the Americas," Governor Dewey noted.

A new safety record was established by Westinghouse Electric Corporation's employes in 1949, it was reported yesterday in Pittsburgh. Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that spokesmen for political parties would be allowed to present their views on the proposed 195051 expense budget of $1,243,451,794 at the three-day hearings that will begin before the Board of Estimate tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)-- The Supreme Court ruled twice today that states and Federal Courts had no power to make primary findings in disputes involvine railroad unions.

TULSA, Okla., April 10--The Giants were riding against a wind and dust storm today, but they broke through to conquer the Cleveland Indians, 15 to 8, in a game limited to eight innings because of transportation requirements.

DUBLIN, April 10--About noon on Easter Monday thirty-four years ago a party of armed men walked down O'Connell Street in Dublin and occupied the General Post Office opposite the Nelson Pillar. That was the beginning of the Easter Week rebellion, the seventh in a series of hopeless uprisings against British rule in Ireland.

WASHINGTON, April 10-- President Truman returned from Key West this afternoon in a gay mood and rested and tanned. He went to his desk and resumed his Washington routine, scheduling his meeting with Congressional leaders for tomorrow and his Cabinet meeting for Friday, the regular day.

WASHINGTON, April 10--The investigation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's charges of Communist infiltration in the State Department is attracting national attention to a New Yorker, chiefly known up to now for a stormy career in and out of Democratic and Christian Front politics in New York.

MADRID, April 10--In a setting of a royal wedding, although without any public display, Generalissimo Francisco Franco's only child, Carmen, was married at midday today in a ninety-minute ceremony in the chapel of El Pardo Palace just outside Madrid to the Marques de Villaverde, a physician.
LONDON, April 10--Some noticeable weaknesses in the present structure of the North Atlantic Treaty organization are beginning to come to light here as the twelvepower alliance enters its second year.

William J. Brede will speak on the human side of real estate at the monthly forum meeting of the Realty Luncheon Club tomorrow noon in the Metropolitan Room of the Brass Rail Restaurant, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street.

Banks throughout the state are responding to the recent request of the Economic Cooperation Administration for volunteers in assisting small business concerns to sell and export under the Marshall's Plan, the New York State Bankers Association reported yesterday.

The parishioners of the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn rallied to the support of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish at their annual meeting last night by electing a warden and three vestrymen favorable to the cause of the ousted rector.

WASHINGTON, April 10--William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today referred a labor unity plan of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to the federation's fifteenmember executive council. It is the governing body between conventions.
The Boston Edison Company borrowed yesterday $18,000,000 on thirty-year first mortgage bonds at an interest cost of about 2.65 per cent.

Alfred D. Brown Associates, an American importing concern, has just established, in conjunction with Indian interests, one of the first scientific quality control projects for manganese in India at Bombay. This was disclosed yesterday by Alfred D. Brown, head of the American organization, who said the company which is administering the project is Indo-American Enterprises, Ltd.
Firemen had considerable difficulty putting out a spectacular fire that enveloped Public School 26 Annex, 1005 Gates Avenue, in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn at 3 A.M. yesterday.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad announced yesterday that it had placed orders for 1,650 new freight cars, costing an estimated $8,500,000. The company said it had not been determined how the equipment would be financed.

Commodore K.F. Adams, commander of the three Canadian warships visiting here, and Kenneth A. Greene, Canadian Consul General, called at City Hall yesterday morning to thank Mayor O'Dwyer for the hospitality shown to the 1,200 officers and sailors of the ships by the city.

Veterans of Columbia College's Colloquium on Important Books-- a discussion course in the "great" classics of the Western world-- joined last night in a plea for increasingly broader, liberalized education in American colleges.
HONOLULU, April 10--Richard Kageyama, Democratic member of the Honolulu Board of Supervisors, and a delegate to Hawaii's State Constitutional Convention, today took the stand as a surprise
Plans were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings for the eleven-story store and office building to be erected by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., at 26

The self-elimination of Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, and a strengthened boom for W. Averell Harriman, Ambassador of the Economic Cooperation Administration, were the principal developments in state politics yesterday.
A series of motion pictures which will use marionette figures to depict Bible stories is being produced by the Protestant Radio Commission, it was disclosed yesterday.
WQXR and WQXR,-FM, the radio stations of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will move into new studios on the ninth and tenth floors of the Times Building at 229 West Forty-third Street next Sunday.
Imports of Czechoslovak shoes have been held up by the Commissioner of Customs in Washington until certain regulations of the Tariff Act of 1930 are complied with according to word received...

The Governments of India and Pakistan solemnly agree each shall insure to the minorities throughout its territory complete equality of citizenship, irrespective at religion, a full sense of security in respect of life, culture, property and personal honor, freedom of movement within each country, freedom of occupation, speech and worship, subject to law and morality.

WASHINGTON, April 10--Tentative plans for a Point Four technical assistance program in health were revealed today at the Public Health Service. They would put about 300 experts in the field, chiefly in tropical countries.

DARIEN, Conn., April 10--Construction of a bypass here that could serve as a link of the proposed New England. Thruway in Fairfield County will be started within ninety days. The route, which will ease congestion on the overloaded Boston Post Road, is to be in operation by the summer of 1951.

Now that the opening-day hysteria is past trout fishermen can be more selective as to the time and place for their fishing. Having worked off some of their enthusiasm during the past few days they will wait for better fishing conditions before planning another trip.

GUATEMALA, April 10--Foreign Minister Ismael Gonzalez Arevalo confirmed today that the Guatemalan Government, through its Ambassador in Washington, Antonio Goubaud Carrera, had requested the recall of United States Ambassador Richard J. Patterson Jr. on the ground of interference in the internal affairs of Guatemala.

A Federal three-judge statutory court reserved decision yesterday on an application for an interlocutory judgment that would restrain the State of New York from enforcing its rent control law scheduled to replace the Federal rent law May 1.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 10 --Stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., today gave overwhelming approval to a new company-financed pension plan.
WASHINGTON, April 10--Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia, introduced a bill today to set up a Bituminous Coal Commission to establish minimum prices for coal at the mines.

Despite a one-cent fare increase on March 25, the Bee Line Bus Company, serving 36,000 passengers daily in Queens and Nassau, will lose $69,000 in 1950, Arthur Gross, the company's accountant, testified yesterday at a Public Service Commission hearing.

ALBANY, April 10--Governor Dewey vetoed as unnecessary and dangerous today a bill that would have prohibited the picketing of any courthouse to influence a trial. The measure had been opposed by the committee on state legislation of the State Bar Association.

The price of some of the leading advertised brands of coffee declined two cents a pound on the wholesale market yesterday. Retailers indicated the full cut would be passed along to consumers, beginning today. That would make the retail price of advertised brands generally 76 to 85 cents a pound.

I. Jerome Riker has taken title to the fourteen-story Aeolian Hall Building at 27-29 West Fifty-seventh Street. Contract for the purchase of the property from the Archbishopric of New York was entered into early this year.
Maintaining its recent pattern, the money market continued tight yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 1 1/16 per cent, unchanged from Friday's levels.
WASHINGTON, April 10--Seven members of the Supreme Court (Justice Douglas took no part in the finding) saw little merit in a striking dissent by Justice Reed today.
Vandalism of the hoodlum gang type has been found in two West Side private schools attended by boys from wealthy families.

LOS ANGELES, April 10--The self-styled "Hollywood ten," the conviction of two of whom for contempt of Congress was upheld by the Federal Supreme Court in a test case today, announced the intention of asking the court for a rehearing. They denounced the tribunal's order as an encroachment on civil rights which the American public should oppose.

WASHINGTON, April 10--Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, told the Senate today he "fully supported" Secretary of State Dean Acheson's note calling upon the Korean people to do all they could to solve their serious inflation problems.

As city water supplies gained 1,234,000,000 gallons yesterday, raising the level of reservoirs to 75.6 per cent of capacity, Water Commissioner Stephen J. Carney cautioned the public that "the closer we get to June 1, the smaller that 75 per cent grows."
Commercial old age for women is 35 years, Miss Ollie A. Randall of the Community Service Society reported yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Women's City Club in the New Weston Hotel.

BERLIN, April 10--Holiday visitors from the Soviet zone of Germany reported today that the food situation there was steadily worsening, except for persons who enjoyed special privileges as members of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 10--The Federal Government is preparing a law that would give workers in plants throughout Western Germany the right to "codetermine" with management not only the policies of welfare but business practices as well.

William H. Byrne was sword in July 6,1949, as acting director of the city's Bureau of Smoke Control. He was to serve as consultant on a temporary basis at $1,000 a month for not longer than six months.

The fact that it is possible for modern ceramic lamps to take on a dignified formality that makes them adaptable to rooms of a more traditional nature is indicated by a new collection of pottery bases designed by Sara Jane Aleshire.

New York "is a very light, trifling city great watchfulness is necessary to steer a middle course," according to an anonymous English visitor here in 1797. This verdict, together with scores of others, appears in a collection of prints, drawings, paintings, posters and manuscripts, linked by diary quotations, to be placed on public view in the Museum of the City of New York tomorrow.

QUINCY, Ill., April 10--Ill fortune cracked down on the Yankees today, on two fronts, and while the situation may prove nothing serious, Manager Casey Stengel, still mindful of the seventy-two injuries that beset his Bombers last year, is beginning to wear a harried look.

In an effort to do something about reducing the nation's wheat surplus, the Department of Agriculture called upon the farmers in the winter wheat belt last fall to agree to reduce plantings by about 15 per cent.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday had the highest closing prices of the season, or 7 to 16 points net higher.

KANSAS CITY, April 10--At the funeral today of Charles Binaggio, gangster, the Rev. Raymond E. Jackson, vice chancellor of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Kansas City, denounced political leaders who allied themselves with gangsters.

WASHINGTON, April 10--Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, pointedly disassociated himself today from Senator Millard E. Tydings statement that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's summary of its file put Prof. Owen Lattimore completely in the clear "up to this moment."
Wallpapers today serve a dual purpose. Many of them, in addition to bringing a pleasant touch of color and design to a room, have definite qualities of depth and texture.

Confronted with an airtight pitching performance by Bob Mastruzzi, a left hander, and some lusty hitting by Nick Marino and Ray Clayton, Columbia's nine launched its 1950 campaign in discouraging fashion yesterday as it went down to an 8-to-0 setback at the hands of New York University at Baker Field.

LONDON, April 10 (Reuters)-- Manchester United, drawing its second Easter holiday game--this time a scoreless tussle with Birmingham City--today regained the leadership in the championship division of English soccer, displacing Sunderland, which briefly held the top spot.

WASHINGTON, April 10--The Inter-American Economic and Social Council, which convened here in special session March 20, ended its deliberations today by giving unanimous approval to the recommendations of four committees named to study phases of economic problems confronting the twentyone American republics.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 --Warner Brothers confirmed today the signing of Marlon Brando to repeat his stage role in the screen version of "A Streetcar Named Desire." His salary, it is understood, will be $75,000.

WASHINGTON, April 10--The United States Government is disturbed by reports that Yugoslavia is designing new moves toward the incorporation of part of the city of Trieste, but this country is not planning any diplomatic moves to induce Yugoslavia to give up her zone of Trieste.

Ralph Kirkpatrick gave a recital in Town Hall last night which reacquainted present-day listeners with an instrument of rare expressive qualities. His renditions of Bach and Scarlatti on the harpsichord, which have built him an enviable reputation over the years, were a joy to hear. But his playing of Mozart, on a special pianoforte such as the composer himself used, was completely entrancing.

The Metropolitan Opera Association's deficit for the 1948-49 season was $172,353.08, which was $61,003.67 less than that of the previous season, when the $233,357.08 loss put the future of the opera in jeopardy.

ALBANY, April 10--The state is going "all-out" in its program for the mid-century White House Conference on Children and Youth, and the results will have a far-reaching and continuing effect on the citi zens of New York, Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, asserted today.
A "substantial rise" in narcotics addiction since the end of World War II was reported yesterday by Garland H. Williams, district supervisor of the Federal Narcotics Bureau.

WASHINGTON, April 10--Senafor Scott W. Lucas, Democrat of Illinois, Democratic Floor Leader, moved today to consolidate various proposals for inquiries into crime, gambling and kindred subjects in a single investigation by a special committee appointed for the purpose.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 10-- Unless international aid is swiftly provided for Pakistan's more than 8,000,000 refugees--the largest dispossessed population in the world--a terrible human disaster may be shaping up.

Youngsters of 5 and 6 years with access to television sets are watching video programs for an average of four hours a day, which is appreciably more time than older children devote to TV attractions, preliminary findings in a survey of the United Parents Associations showed yesterday.
The formal agreement just reached by Prime Ministers Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Liaquat Ali Khan of Pakistan may prove to be a turning point in Asia. Pandit Nehru was hopeful.

CHICAGO, April 10--Confirmation of reports of serious damage to the winter wheat crop by the Government resulted in a bullish construction being placed on farm reserves of leading grains as of April 1, especially on soybeans.

Eddie Arcaro, the old maestro, rode his sixth, seventh and eighth winners of the Jamaica meeting in successive races yesterday. ROME, Wednesday, April 12--The Exilona, carrying the first shipment of United States arms to Italy under the North Atlantic Defense Treaty, steamed into the heavily guarded port of Naples at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon and started to unload half an hour later.
To leave the Federal Reserve Bank Building, at 33 Liberty Street, yesterday afternoon about 3:15 was impossible and any attempt to do so would have been highly perilous.

Miles F. McDonald, District Attorney of Kinga County, took an unprecedented step in his gambling inquiry yesterday when he asked for a blue-ribbon jury in County Court to try three men indicted for taking bets.

Edwin H. Warms, special partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Jacques Coe Co., 39 Broadway, died of a heart attack yesterday afternoon in his office.

BERLIN, April 11 (UP)--Dr. Erwin Mueller, 39-year-old physicist at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Physical Chemistry, said today he had developed a microscope that permits man to see a single molecule.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission was criticized by a New York grand jury yesterday as three men were indicted on charges that one defendant had impersonated the others in an examination for a city job.

WASHINGTON, April 11--With President Truman's approval, the Senate Democratic Policy Committee agreed today to a further postponement of floor tests on the Administration's civil rights program. It decided to give priority to consideration of foreign economic and arms assistance.

The Royal Canadian Navy Squadron visiting New York likes the city so well that its stay has been extended until this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11--The synthesis of more than a hundred new chemicals, a number of which match the potency of streptomycin in checking tuberculosis in animals, was reported here today at the meeting of the American Chemical Society.

BOSTON, April 19--This is Patriots' Day in the land of the bean and the cod. Since it is the anniversary of Paul Revere's ride, the trend hereabouts has been toward distance. There is the Boston Marathon, for instance. And there also is the baseball marathon, a round-theclock affair which doesn't go 26 miles 385 yards but just seems that long.

Myles J. Lane, former all-American football star, varsity coach and professional hockey player, was appointed yeaterday by United States Attorney Irving H. Saypol as his chief assistant. Mr Lane has been an assistant United States Attorney since 1937.

LONDON, April 19--About 1,800 dock workers in the port of London quit work today in an unofficial strike. Their action was taken ostensibly in protest against the expulsion of three members of the Transport and General Workers Union for participating in the Communist-inspired strike of last July.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, April 19--In the process of lighting the Communist insurgents of Malaya, the Federation authorities this year will uproot and resettle tens of thousands of humble rural dwellers who today are being used by the Communists as a source of food, manpower and aid in concealing their terrorist activities.

PARIS, April 19--Jacques Fath handles simplicity with a dramatic touch in a midsummer collection of wearable elegance. His two silhouettes are equally significant, the slim and vertical or the more fluid lines of pleated chiffon or organza.
WEIRTON, W. Va., April 19 (AP) --Weirton Steel Company today took the wraps off its new electrolytic tin-plating line--the fastest and largest of its type anywhere.

Miss Muriel Starr, a character actress, who was once a star of the Australian stage, died of a heart attack yesterday, back-stage in the John Golden Theatre, 252 West Forty-fifth Street, as a matinee performance of "The Velvet Glove," in which she had a part, was playing out front. She was 62 years old.
WASHINGTON, April--19-Resolutions reaffirming the members' belief in "free capitalism" and opposition to socialism were adopted unanimously today by the Daughters of the American Revolution.

WASHINGTON, April 19--In the most intently awaited Senate hearing of recent years, Louis F. Budenz goes tomorrow before an investigating committee in Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's "case" against Owen Lattimore.

A 65-year-old Long Island man who two months ago was pronounced dead on a hospital operating table twice within four hours will be discharged from the institution tomorrow as a recovered patient, it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. George Gilbert Timpson of Oakleigh Park, Whetstone, England, has announced here and in England the engagement of her daughter, Joan Helen, to Rodman Drake de Kay Jr., son of Captain and Mrs. de Kay of Port Washington. L.I.

ST. LOUIS, April 19 (AP).--The Pirates took advantage of a pair of fifth-inning errors by Eddie Kazak to hand the Cardinals a 4-to-3 defeat tonight. Cliff Chambers limited St. Louis to six hits. Pittsburgh, in turn, had just five safeties against Red Munger and Ken Johnson.

HOLLYWOOD, April 19 (UP)-- Ingrid Bergman and Dr. Peter Lindstrom ended their dispute over custody of their 12-year-old daughter, Pia, today by agreeing to joint legal custody.

Two of the scheduled flights to the Never-Never Land may not come off next week when "Peter Pan," James M. Barrie's children's classic, opens at the Imperial Theatre. Oddly enough, weather conditions are not expected to play a part in the reasons for the possible flight cancellations.

After early firmness, prices of rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange turned easy in late dealings yesterday and closed 5 to 50 points under Tuesday's final quotations. Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would recommend to the Board of Estimate salary increases of $250 a year for high school teachers and $150 for elementary school teachers. Nearly 40,000 teachers would benefit by the increase, which totals $7,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 19--President Truman proposed today a national register of men and women from which he could select candidates of particular qualifications for appointment to top Government positions, including even Cabinet members.

The City of Philadelphia, Pa., yesterday designated May 11 as the date for receiving bids on issues of bonds totaling $57,775,000. The offering will include $24,675,000 of general purpose bonds maturing over fifty years, and $18,000,000 of sewer bonds maturing over forty years.

Tom Casagrande, Fordham's sophomore southpaw, hurled the Rams to their sixth triumph of the season and proved a heavy hitter as well in the 13-to-4 victory registered over Columbia at the Rose Hill field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19--The Central Vermont Public Service Corporation has offered to acquire the assets of the Green Mountain Power Corporation in exchange for common stock of the former, it was learned here today.

Matinee offerings for young dance enthusiasts: "Around the World With Dance and Song" at 3:30 P.M. today includes dances of ancient India performed by Wasantha Singh, Lakshimi and Company at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street. Admissions 60 to 90 cents.
Details of an intensive promotion were announced yesterday by the Tide Water Associated Oil Company.

It takes little more than one twist of the wrist to shape cloverleaf or butterfly rolls with the newly devised Kesco roll cutter. Made of red plastic, it consists of a flat circular piece with four parallel blades on one side for fashioning the butterflies, and three blades forming the triangular sections of clover leaves on the other.
LONDON, Thursday, April 20 (UP)--Information from Moscow suggested today that a reorganization of Russian agricultural administration was in progress.

WASHINGTON, April 19--All the officials most concerned with the possible consequences of the note of protest which Ambassador Kirk last night in Moscow handed to Deputy Foreign Minister Gromyko were fully consulted before the note was sent.
A Department of Parks recreation director was found guilty yesterday in Mid-Manhattgn Magistrate's Court of using slugs in Times Square drug store's postage stamp vending machine.
CHICAGO, April 19--The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen today called a strike against four big railroads, for 6 A.M. next Wednesday.

ALBANY, April 19--Governor Dewey signed a series of bills today making school boards in all cities except New York, Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Albany and Yonkers financially independent of the municipal government in their respective cities.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19--The "pennant" that some of the local citizens figured the Phils won by beating the Dodgers in the opener yesterday was snatched away today when the Brooks won, 7--5, thanks to the excellent pitching of Clarence (Bud) Podbielan and lusty clouting by Gil Hodges, Carl Furillo, Jackie Robinson and Bobby Morgan.

The stock market halted yesterday just short of the year's high in a session during which the television section staged another sharp rise. Since the TV issues apparently are operating independent from the rest of the list,...

The Norwegian cargo-passenger vessel Havfalk will depart from Pier 7, Bush Terminal, Brooklyn, late today or early tomorrow on her maiden eastbound voyage to Antwerp and other Northern European ports.

Jonathan Penrose, London's 16year-old champion, made a bold bid for victory in the international tournament of the Southern Counties Cheas Union at Southsea yesterday, when he defeated Dr. S.T. Tartakower of Paris, according to a report from England.

Together with the first dividend payment mailed to stockholders yesterday by United Paramount Theatres, Inc., Leonard Goldenson, president, sent a report for the first quarter showing consolidated earnings of $3,193,000 and undistributed earnings of partly owned non-consolidated companies of $670,000, making the total $3,863,000.
CONCORD, Mass., April 19 (AP) --The United States, Britain and Canada--"politically joined"--will be strong enough to save democracy for the Western World, Gen. Omar N. Bradley said today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19--Efforts of Government authorities to "dump dry skim milk in Europe at ludicrous prices when it is needed in our own bread" were denounced today by Dr. Clive M. McCay, Professor of Nutrition at Cornell University.
WASHINGTON, April 19--The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered submission to stockholders of the Boston and Maine Railroad of a plan for reshaping its capital-stock structure, which...

Perhaps Kafka's day is just dawning. John F. Matthews' "The Scapegoat," which was put on at the President last evening, is derived from Franz Kafka's novel, "The Trial," which was written some time after the first World War and seemed like a macabre fantasy at the time. Mr. Matthews,...

SHUSHAN, N.Y., April 19-- Any water flowing out of the Green Mountains in April should be cold, and although the Battenkill warmed up a bit after it passed the Vermont border it was still too cold for good trout fishing when it rushed into the Hudson.

Two anonymous telephone calls received by the Brooklyn police prior to the raid by the District Attorney's anti-gambling squad on an alleged policy bank were not recorded at the division office until seven hours later, District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County charged yesterday.

State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi offered yesterday a program for easing the job problem of Puerto Ricans here through specific measures to be taken by the municipal, state and Federal administrations and the Puerto Rican Department of Labor.

The Majestic Realty Corporation, represented by Emanuel Goldberg, attorney, bought for investment from the Arod Realty Corporation the nine-story apartment house for seventy-eight families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 139 to 147 West Seventy-first Street in a deal negotiated by Irving Kornfeld, broker.

Fat, four-figure pay-offs glowed on the tote board in the win and place spots after the running of the $29,300 Firenze Handicap, a mile-and-a-sixteenth race for fillies and mares, at Jamaica yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 19 (AP)--Rebel soldiers in Macassar surrendered unconditionally and were imprisoned today as Federal troops swarmed ashore on Celebes beaches south of that city, the Indonesian Government announced. No bloodshed was reported.

Postal officials in this city went into hurried conferences yesterday to study means of carrying out the drastic economy order of Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson, which may cost the jobs of 10 per cent or more of the 44,200 post office workers in the city.

Secretary Acheson yesterday urged early action by Congress approving American participation in the International Trade Organization (I.T.O.), whose charter was agreed upon by the representatives of fifty-four nations at Havana in March, 1948.

BERLIN, April 18--Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn Government, said here today that he was surprised at the furor caused by the singing of part of the old German anthem "Deutschland Ueber Alles" at two meetings held in his honor yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (AP) --The Peiping radio said today the Chinese Communists had given the United States written permission to evacuate Americans from Shanghai two days before Secretary of State Dean Acheson had announced abandonment of plans.
The midnight flight of Cinderella had nothing on the Fridaynight sprints that are required of Long Island commuters, according to stories presented yesterday to the public Service Commission.

LONDON, April 19--The Cunard steam Ship Company, Ltd., parent concern of Cunard White Star, Ltd., announced tonight a net profit for the year 1949 of 2,094,299 [$5,864,037.20]. The dividend is being maintained at 10 per cent, the same as last year.

BOSTON, April 19--Three durable young runners from far-off Korea romped to an unprecedented sweep of top honors in the fiftyfourth annual Boston Athletic Association marathon today, as an estimated 500,000 spectators turned out in agreeable weather for the colorful Patriots' Day spectacle so dear to the heart of the Hub.
Disapproval of a Greyhound Bus System proposal to enlarge its terminal on Thirty-fourth Street, east of Eighth Avenue, was recommended yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

The Communist Government of Czechoslovakia has now closed down the United States Information Service in that country and expelled the press attache of the American Embassy in Prague. It attempts to justify this action with the same brazen, trumpedup charges of espionage which the American Government has repudiated...
EARLE, N.J., April 19--In a sylvan setting here lies a huge storehouse for destruction.

A general strike of all American Federation of Labor maritime workers on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts is now threatened for midnight Saturday as the result of a protracted deadlock in negotiations between steamship operators and the Masters, Mates and Pilots, it was learned yesterday.
More than 100 of the 950 stockholders who attended the six-hourand-fifty-minute session yesterday of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, participated in heated exchanges of opinion.

BOSTON, April 19--For a few pleasant hours today, Hub fandom had every reason to believe that the Red Sox' antics in yesterday's bizarre opening game were nothing more than the figments of an unpleasant dream, never to be seen again.

Mrs. William O'Dwyer made her debut yesterday in her official role as the Mayor's wife. In what she called her first public appearance, Mrs. O'Dwyer officiated at the preview of an exhibition of needlework for the benefit of the Friendship Fund of the New York Asso-- ciation for the Blind.
WASHINGTON, April 19--President Truman approved with "gratification" today a bill authorizing an economic rehabilitation program for the Navajo and Hopi Indian tribes that will run a tenyear course.

WASHINGTON, April 19--Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, declared today that United States participation in the International Trade Organization would support the objectives of the European Recovery and Point Four Programs for a prosperous, peaceful world.
VIENNA, April 20--Creation of an East-bloc customs union whose finances will be based on the Russian ruble is foreshadowed by reports from a reliable Hungarian source.

Highest American Communists "officially informed" Louis F. Budenz in years past Prof. Owen Lattimore belonged to a Communist cell and was a "hidden" party member, the former editor of The Daily Worker testified before a Senate subcommittee yesterday.

General-obligation bonds totaling $16,323,000 will be sold by the city of Detroit, Mich., in June, it was learned yesterday. No details of the offering were available last night other than the information that June 6 had been set as the tentative date of sale.

Richard A. Brennan, president of Brevoort Savings Bank, and A. Charles Schwartz, a partner in Bache Co., were elected directors of Childs Company, to replace Everett Frank and William P. Palmer, resigned, it was announced yesterday by N. C. Earl Jr., president. The annual stockholders' meeting will be held here today.

Leaders of the Liberal party expect no rift with the Democratic party in selecting a candidate for Governor on which both parties can agree and have no intention of attempting to dictate the choice of the candidate.
PARIS, April 20--Mature reflection has led high officials in Europe to attach great importance to the conception that gave rise to the proposal Sunday by Premier Georges Bidault.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP)-- Senator Harry P. Cain, Republican of Wisconsin, called on the State Department today to come forward with more "concrete" proof that Russian fighters had shot down an unarmed United States Navy plane over the Baltic Sea.

Bond men were occupied yesterday in watching prices for Government bonds continue their downward drift to new lows for the present movement. Twenty-seven of the thirty-one issues of Treasury bonds which figure in current trading were fractionally lower for ...
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 20--The Netherlanders have a strong suspicion that German manufacturers are dumping industrial products in the export markets.

Recent institutional fires that have taken a large toll of lives in other states are spurring New York State authorities to greater safety precautions. They want to make sure that such tragedies will not happen here.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 20-- Mrs. Charles O'Neill, formerly of New Rochelle, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Suzanne, to Gilbert L. Desvernine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raoul E. Desvernine of 111 East Fifty-sixth Street, New York. The wedding will take place in June.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP)-- Representative Vito Marcantonio, American Labor of New York, forced the House today to drop a proposed renewal of the State Department's power to fire "securityrisk" employes without explanation.
In an editorial on Wednesday we took note of the fact that any changes made in Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed $1,243,451,794 budget for 1950-51 are likely to be in the direction of enlargement.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 20--Disclosure today that fourteen of the thirty-one senior members of the Western German Federal Republic's embryo foreign service are former Nazis has complicated the already involved political situation that has arisen in Western Germany in the wake of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Berlin speeches.

WASHINGTON, April 20--The engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Susan Carroll Oulahan to Joseph Warren Bishop Jr., son of Mrs. Bishop and the late Mr. Bishop, formerly managing editor of Nation's Business, was announced today by her mother, Mrs. Richard V. Oulahan.

WASHINGTON, April 20--The House Ways and Means Committee, casting aside President Truman's tax recommendations in a series of tentative votes, agreed today on the repeal of about $75,000,000 of manufacturers' excise taxes.

WASHINGTON, April 20--Chairman Tom Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee opened the Senate's debate on the $3,372,450,000 foreign-aid authorization bill today with an appeal for nonpartisan support of the nation's foreign policy so as to raise the cause of world peace "above the mists and fogs of party politics."

LONDON, Friday, April 21--Russia has demanded withdrawal of occupation troops from strategic Trieste and elimination of what Moscow called an "illegal Anglo-American naval base" there, the Moscow radio said today.

WASHINGTON, April 20--A witness' charge that a House subcommittee was unfair and lacking in objectivity in its inquiry into monopolistic trends in the steel industry brought a sharp rebuke from a surprised subcommittee chairman here today.
Major league baseball is forming a rules interpretation committee so that all of baseball, including the fan, will know just what is going on, Commissioner A. B. Chandler announced yesterday.

Kaleidoscoping fashions from the period of 2000 B. C. down to the present day, the Cavalcade of Greek Fashions was unfolded yesterday in a brilliant performance at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. It was presented under the patronage of Mme. Vassili Dendramis, wife of the Greek Ambassador to ...

A "veteran, big league burglar" was singled out yesterday in a Supreme Court hearing on a writ of habeas corpus as the "finger man in the unsolved slaying of Albert E. Langford, textile manufacturer, who was shot almost five years ago in the doorway of his apartment in the Marguery Hotel 270 Park Avenue.
For the sixteenth consecutive month, the relief rolls in New York have increased because of unemployment, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard reported yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20-- The more the Christian Church learns about the daily problems confronting its members, the organizations to which they belong, and the "system which encompasses them," the more effective will its ministry become.

ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP)--The Pirates were as hot as the weather was chilly today when they scored an 8-to-4 victory over the seemingly benumbed Cardinals in the only contest played in the National League.

WASHINGTON, April 20--Alabama Dixiecrats are waging a fear campaign to keep control of the State Democratic party machinery with a warning to white voters that if forces loyal to the Administration win the May 2 primary Alabama's electors in 1952 might be pledged to vote for a Negro running for Vice President with President Truman.

The stock market drew yesterday a highly confused pattern. As measured by the averages, prices suffered the second widest break of the year and losses clearly predominated. Yet many of the heaviest-traded stocks enjoyed modest gains, despite outstanding weakness in some of the key industrial spots.

The National Transportation Company yesterday purchased a large plot of land on West Seventeenth Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, possibly for improvement with a garage building. Containing 25,000 square feet, the ...

The Quarter Century Club of The National City Bank of New York and City Bank Farmers Trust Company held its fourteenth annual dinner last night at the Astor Hotel. The membership, it was announced, includes one of every eight persons now employed by the two banks.
Trading in nonferrous metals futures on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday was active, and prices advanced moderately.

Eleven thousand New Jersey telephone operators received yesterday a $2.50 weekly wage rise under an arbitration award and the Bell Telephone Company immediately asked the state for substantial rate increases.

Representatives of 18,000 unionized elevator operators, janitors and other service employes in 2,000 Manhattan apartment buildings promised last night to withhold a threatened strike until Monday to give Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Mediation Board, additional opportunity to settle their contract dispute with the employers.
Stony Wold Sanatorium will be the beneficiary of a card party to be held this afternoon in the Wedgwood Room of the WaldorfAstoria.
A tract of land 210 by 1,201 feet in Patchogue, L. I., has been purchased by the Medford Development Corporation, of which Ludwig Brall is president, from the Med-Clark Operating Corporation ...

The American Cyanamid Company reported yesterday a sharp rise in earnings for the first quarter of the year and at the same time informed stockholders of a contemplated plan of financing to obtain additional working capital through the issuance of rights to ...

ATLANTIC CITY, April 20-- Nutritional experiments on animals at the University of Chicago, showing that animals receiving a rich diet are less fertile than those on a poor diet or a diet containing fewer calories, were described here ...

The National Dairy Products Corporation in the first quarter had larger sales tonnage and earnings than in the corresponding period a year ago, L.A. Van Bomel, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday.
Mr. Chairman, distinguished guests, members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors:

BERLIN, April 20--The West Berlin City Government has asked the commandants of the four occupation powers to approve a citywide election for a single city government conducted under the electoral order of 1946.
Michel Fokine's "Les Elfes" was revived last night by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House after an absence of some seven years from the repertoire.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 20--Deputy Foreign Minister Leo Mates issued a statement today to foreign correspondents in Belgrade saying Yugoslavia would never yield to the present Italian effort to force her to surrender Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste.
BERLIN, April 20--The Allied High Commission, meeting here today, turned down a Bonn law decreasing personal and corporation tax rates.
